description: Adobe InDesign Creative Cloud is used for laying out printed materials such as brochures, ads, business cards or newsletters. Elements that are created in Illustrator and Photoshop are combined to create blocks of texts, photos or other artwork and put together in InDesign to create single or multi-page layouts. This course covers exam objectives for the Adobe Certified Associate (ACA) certification.
name: InDesign CC
subtitle: Desktop Publishing Application

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Erica discuss what a viewer needs to know when getting started inside of Adobe InDesign. They talk about launching InDesign, opening existing document and creating new documents. They examine the some of the tools that will be used in later episodes.
episodes.title: Getting Started
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.081 --> 00:00:10.081
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:11.798 --> 00:00:14.597
Welcome back to another exciting
episode here at ITProTV.

3
00:00:14.597 --> 00:00:18.942
I'm your host, Wes Bryan, and in today's
episode we're continuing through our

4
00:00:18.942 --> 00:00:21.684
series in
the Adobe Creative Cloud Suite 2015.

5
00:00:21.684 --> 00:00:24.440
More specifically we're
focusing on InDesign.

6
00:00:24.440 --> 00:00:26.630
Joining me in the studios
today is Erica Gamet.

7
00:00:26.630 --> 00:00:27.560
Erica, how you doing?

8
00:00:27.560 --> 00:00:28.208
>> I'm doing pretty good, Wes.

9
00:00:28.208 --> 00:00:29.235
Thanks.
>> Hey, very good.

10
00:00:29.235 --> 00:00:31.039
So what are we gonna be
diving into first today?

11
00:00:31.039 --> 00:00:33.520
>> Today,
we're gonna start at the very beginning.

12
00:00:33.520 --> 00:00:36.210
We're going to start
where you would start.

13
00:00:36.210 --> 00:00:38.830
When you first sit down
to work in InDesign

14
00:00:38.830 --> 00:00:41.810
with a black screen staring
you back in the face.

15
00:00:41.810 --> 00:00:42.870
So we're gonna start there.

16
00:00:42.870 --> 00:00:44.750
I'm gonna go ahead, and jump in, and

17
00:00:44.750 --> 00:00:48.150
show you a couple of different
ways to get into InDesign.

18
00:00:48.150 --> 00:00:51.220
The first one is that you would
launch the application, however,

19
00:00:51.220 --> 00:00:52.680
you launch applications.

20
00:00:52.680 --> 00:00:55.040
That could be down on your dock so

21
00:00:55.040 --> 00:00:56.620
it might be sitting on your
dock if you have a Mac.

22
00:00:56.620 --> 00:01:00.710
If you're on a PC you might
have it in your Start menu.

23
00:01:00.710 --> 00:01:03.580
And however, you would launch it we
can just click on it and launch it.

24
00:01:03.580 --> 00:01:05.370
I already had it running so
it's pretty quick,

25
00:01:05.370 --> 00:01:09.220
otherwise you get the start up screen
which may or may not take awhile.

26
00:01:09.220 --> 00:01:12.950
Sometimes the first time you launch it,
don't be afraid, it might take awhile.

27
00:01:12.950 --> 00:01:15.220
Also when you do an update,
it tends to take longer.

28
00:01:15.220 --> 00:01:17.240
That freaks people out sometimes.

29
00:01:17.240 --> 00:01:19.080
Just keep calm, it's all right.

30
00:01:19.080 --> 00:01:20.027
I'm gonna actually hide that.

31
00:01:20.027 --> 00:01:25.228
I'm gonna use a command that I use on the
Mac which is Cmd+H, a Ctrl+H on the PC.

32
00:01:25.228 --> 00:01:27.603
And I just wanna show you
this before we get in to it,

33
00:01:27.603 --> 00:01:31.141
that when I'm hitting my modifier keys,
down at the bottom I have the little

34
00:01:31.141 --> 00:01:33.657
symbols that show me what
modifier key I'm hitting.

35
00:01:33.657 --> 00:01:36.946
So you're gonna see that throughout
every episode that I work on, so

36
00:01:36.946 --> 00:01:38.886
just you can see what it is I'm hitting.

37
00:01:38.886 --> 00:01:41.960
Now I'm hitting the Cmd key or
the swirly propeller key or

38
00:01:41.960 --> 00:01:45.174
wherever we wanna call it
sometimes known as the Apple key.

39
00:01:45.174 --> 00:01:50.504
And I'm in the Apple of course, and on
the PC that's going to be the Ctrl key so

40
00:01:50.504 --> 00:01:55.096
if you see this symbol that's Cmd or
Ctrl, you'll here me say both

41
00:01:55.096 --> 00:01:59.880
commands what I speak about what key
I'm hitting so I say Cmd or Ctrl.

42
00:01:59.880 --> 00:02:01.420
Mac vs PC second.

43
00:02:01.420 --> 00:02:02.760
The other one is option.

44
00:02:02.760 --> 00:02:04.780
That's what that little crazy icon means.

45
00:02:04.780 --> 00:02:05.450
That's option.

46
00:02:05.450 --> 00:02:11.280
And I have a control key on the Mac
that is right click on a PC,

47
00:02:11.280 --> 00:02:14.030
or if you have a multi
button mouse on a Mac also.

48
00:02:14.030 --> 00:02:17.300
And again, I will say right-click or
Ctrl+click.

49
00:02:17.300 --> 00:02:19.140
And that is what the Shift key looks like.

50
00:02:19.140 --> 00:02:20.936
So you see these little symbols up here?

51
00:02:20.936 --> 00:02:23.660
It's only going to be when I'm doing
something with a modifier key,

52
00:02:23.660 --> 00:02:25.210
so don't be nervous with that.

53
00:02:25.210 --> 00:02:28.300
So I'm gonna do Cmd or
Ctrl+H to hide that cuz I wanna

54
00:02:28.300 --> 00:02:30.630
show you a couple different
ways to get in there as well.

55
00:02:30.630 --> 00:02:35.450
The other thing that we can do is we can
launch from an actual InDesign document.

56
00:02:35.450 --> 00:02:37.610
So I'm gonna open up a file here.

57
00:02:37.610 --> 00:02:38.795
I've just got some blank layouts.

58
00:02:38.795 --> 00:02:41.690
We're gonna talk about the different
layouts in just a minute.

59
00:02:41.690 --> 00:02:46.172
And I just want to zoom in a little and
show you what the icon looks like.

60
00:02:46.172 --> 00:02:50.280
So in depending on your version and
we are talking about CC 2015 but

61
00:02:50.280 --> 00:02:53.200
you might be on an older version and
most of what I cover,

62
00:02:53.200 --> 00:02:58.010
will actually apply to older versions,
probably going back as far as CS6 so,

63
00:02:58.010 --> 00:03:01.990
don't be worried if you are not
on the newest newest version.

64
00:03:01.990 --> 00:03:05.660
And I will try to point out if
that's a brand new feature as well.

65
00:03:05.660 --> 00:03:09.920
Sometimes trying to remember which version
of 2015 that new feature came out in

66
00:03:09.920 --> 00:03:14.220
is tricky, because with the Cloud
the updates are coming a lot faster.

67
00:03:14.220 --> 00:03:16.040
When they get a new feature
they just throw it in.

68
00:03:16.040 --> 00:03:20.900
For instance, just recently there was one,
and it just made a few minor tweaks, so

69
00:03:20.900 --> 00:03:23.570
yours might like look again slightly
different if you haven't done

70
00:03:23.570 --> 00:03:24.750
the latest update.

71
00:03:24.750 --> 00:03:30.390
But going back to the file,
the file here, the file format is .indd.

72
00:03:30.390 --> 00:03:31.558
That's the file extension.

73
00:03:31.558 --> 00:03:35.880
That's an InDesign document, and
as we go throughout the different episodes

74
00:03:35.880 --> 00:03:40.520
in the course we're going to actually, see
that there are some other extensions and

75
00:03:40.520 --> 00:03:44.460
I'll point those out as we go along,
but indd means an InDesign

76
00:03:44.460 --> 00:03:48.370
document it's something that we've
layed out in InDesign ready to go.

77
00:03:48.370 --> 00:03:51.280
So one of the things that we can
do is also just double-click,

78
00:03:51.280 --> 00:03:54.290
I'm one of those obviously and
it brings up an existing file.

79
00:03:54.290 --> 00:03:57.920
I'm gonna close that,
Cmd or Ctrl+W to do that.

80
00:03:57.920 --> 00:04:01.130
Or we can always go to the File menu and
choose Close.

81
00:04:01.130 --> 00:04:03.650
All right, so
I'm gonna hide out of that as well.

82
00:04:05.050 --> 00:04:08.750
And the other thing we can do is we can
switch if you have a switcher on a Mac.

83
00:04:08.750 --> 00:04:13.010
We can just do the Cmd+Tab to
switch between open applications.

84
00:04:13.010 --> 00:04:14.200
So I'm gonna do that.

85
00:04:14.200 --> 00:04:16.660
And this is sort of how I start.

86
00:04:16.660 --> 00:04:18.550
I tend to launch the program and

87
00:04:18.550 --> 00:04:22.710
then I create a new document if I
don't have one already existing.

88
00:04:22.710 --> 00:04:26.580
So to create a new document
we have to really think about

89
00:04:26.580 --> 00:04:30.902
where this document is headed,
not just let's just dive right in.

90
00:04:30.902 --> 00:04:33.240
Even though I said we're gonna
just dive right in which we are.

91
00:04:33.240 --> 00:04:36.420
But we're gonna dive in, we're gonna
think about this ahead of time.

92
00:04:36.420 --> 00:04:40.162
What is happening to
this file down the road.

93
00:04:40.162 --> 00:04:43.730
So at something I can't stress enough,
we don't live in a vacuum.

94
00:04:43.730 --> 00:04:47.310
Even if it's just me doing all
the production, I'm gonna start here and

95
00:04:47.310 --> 00:04:50.980
I'm gonna make a printed version and
I'm gonna do a digital version.

96
00:04:50.980 --> 00:04:55.150
But I still need to know what
happens to that down the road.

97
00:04:55.150 --> 00:04:56.840
And as we go through the episodes,

98
00:04:56.840 --> 00:04:59.990
we will see all the considerations
that we need to make.

99
00:04:59.990 --> 00:05:03.070
So right now,
this might not make much sense to you.

100
00:05:03.070 --> 00:05:04.650
I'm telling you to think ahead.

101
00:05:04.650 --> 00:05:09.420
But maybe this is all very new to you,
and you're not even sure what is ahead.

102
00:05:09.420 --> 00:05:12.450
So we will learn that as we go through.

103
00:05:12.450 --> 00:05:14.747
So we're going to start
with a new document.

104
00:05:14.747 --> 00:05:19.111
And I'll discuss the considerations we
need to make but don't stress out too

105
00:05:19.111 --> 00:05:23.610
much if you don't understand that it will
all become clear but I want you to think

106
00:05:23.610 --> 00:05:27.390
about what the information is that
we're putting in each of this.

107
00:05:27.390 --> 00:05:31.740
So if you think I don't understand what
she meant by is a digital or print.

108
00:05:31.740 --> 00:05:34.870
That's something you can notate
to yourself, I need to look at,

109
00:05:34.870 --> 00:05:36.590
am I doing this print or digital?

110
00:05:37.640 --> 00:05:40.710
So I'm gonna open up the new
document dialog box.

111
00:05:40.710 --> 00:05:44.180
So I can do Cmd or Ctrl+N to do that.

112
00:05:44.180 --> 00:05:47.930
Or, I'm gonna cancel out of that
just I can show you the menu option,

113
00:05:47.930 --> 00:05:51.880
File > New and then we scroll
over here to the new document.

114
00:05:51.880 --> 00:05:55.390
And you can see I've got the little
keyboard shortcut for me right here and

115
00:05:55.390 --> 00:05:57.510
depending if you're on the PC it
will look a little different but

116
00:05:57.510 --> 00:05:59.942
you'll see your shortcut indicated for
you.

117
00:05:59.942 --> 00:06:03.176
We're gonna talk about shortcuts
in an upcoming episode as well.

118
00:06:03.176 --> 00:06:07.357
So now we're gonna use the one
that's there, new document, and

119
00:06:07.357 --> 00:06:08.980
I can turn on Preview.

120
00:06:08.980 --> 00:06:10.590
I don't remember what
version this came in.

121
00:06:10.590 --> 00:06:12.898
Somewhere in the cloud, probably 2014.

122
00:06:12.898 --> 00:06:16.400
Where I can actually see the page,
before we used to have to enter it.

123
00:06:16.400 --> 00:06:18.550
So you might not have that Preview button.

124
00:06:18.550 --> 00:06:22.460
And you enter the information and
hit OK and it's not what you look like.

125
00:06:22.460 --> 00:06:26.280
So they added this Preview button which
is great which means I can watch things

126
00:06:26.280 --> 00:06:28.990
being formed as I make changes to them.

127
00:06:28.990 --> 00:06:30.930
I can see that that is not what I want.

128
00:06:30.930 --> 00:06:34.020
I can also see that at the top
here it says Document Preset,

129
00:06:34.020 --> 00:06:35.802
it is something called postcards.

130
00:06:35.802 --> 00:06:40.335
Well, that's not what I want we're gonna
start with just a letter size page and

131
00:06:40.335 --> 00:06:44.208
we're going to work with single pages for
quite a while.

132
00:06:44.208 --> 00:06:46.940
We're not gonna get into it until we
learn a few more of the basics and

133
00:06:46.940 --> 00:06:49.180
start building on it,
then we can start adding pages.

134
00:06:49.180 --> 00:06:52.250
But for now we're gonna work for
the single page, letter size.

135
00:06:52.250 --> 00:06:56.460
It's a US letter so if you're not in the
US, of course, just adjust it accordingly.

136
00:06:56.460 --> 00:06:59.920
I am gonna work in inches as well so
adjust that accordingly.

137
00:06:59.920 --> 00:07:04.850
I'm gonna show you how to change that in
just a minute as well because InDesign

138
00:07:04.850 --> 00:07:09.560
does not ship with inches as
its default measurement, nor

139
00:07:09.560 --> 00:07:11.340
does it ship with anything metric.

140
00:07:11.340 --> 00:07:13.910
It ships with printing terms,
picas and points.

141
00:07:15.210 --> 00:07:17.210
So let's start putting in our information.

142
00:07:17.210 --> 00:07:19.440
So we see that
the Document Preset is postcards.

143
00:07:19.440 --> 00:07:23.060
It will probably show default
the first time you open that,

144
00:07:23.060 --> 00:07:24.510
which is actually a letter.

145
00:07:24.510 --> 00:07:26.290
But we're not gonna worry
about that to start with,

146
00:07:26.290 --> 00:07:29.500
because what we're going to
do is we're going to enter in

147
00:07:29.500 --> 00:07:34.242
all the information in this dialog box,
and then we're gonna save that preset.

148
00:07:34.242 --> 00:07:36.630
We're gonna tell it what
that preset is called so

149
00:07:36.630 --> 00:07:39.260
we don't have to enter
all this stuff again.

150
00:07:39.260 --> 00:07:40.632
That's what we're trying to do.

151
00:07:40.632 --> 00:07:44.675
You're gonna see that I'm really about
automation and not doing the same thing

152
00:07:44.675 --> 00:07:47.568
over and over again, not just so
that I get done sooner but

153
00:07:47.568 --> 00:07:51.150
because I know it will be consistent
if I set this up ahead of time.

154
00:07:51.150 --> 00:07:54.000
So always be thinking am I
going to use this again?

155
00:07:54.000 --> 00:07:57.097
Maybe I need to name it in such
a way that I can find it again.

156
00:07:57.097 --> 00:07:59.448
So let's start first here with Intent.

157
00:07:59.448 --> 00:08:03.293
So it's going to ask you what are you
doing with this file, this goes back to,

158
00:08:03.293 --> 00:08:04.962
what are we doing with this file?

159
00:08:04.962 --> 00:08:07.092
And InDesign right there in your face and
it says,

160
00:08:07.092 --> 00:08:08.900
what are you doing with this file?

161
00:08:08.900 --> 00:08:10.201
So you have a couple different options.

162
00:08:10.201 --> 00:08:13.020
You have Print, Web, and Mobile.

163
00:08:13.020 --> 00:08:17.760
Now, Web and Mobile, there's some overlap
to that but Print, I'm gonna start with.

164
00:08:17.760 --> 00:08:20.466
And for me,
if I know that it's going to print and

165
00:08:20.466 --> 00:08:22.522
it's going to some digital format.

166
00:08:22.522 --> 00:08:25.551
Whether it's something I'm
setting up say for a web page or

167
00:08:25.551 --> 00:08:28.774
a web layout, which I generally
don't do a lot of in InDesign.

168
00:08:28.774 --> 00:08:31.350
But sometimes I might do a layout and
I know I'm going to send it.

169
00:08:31.350 --> 00:08:35.770
It's maybe just going to be a background,
and I didn't do it say, in Photoshop.

170
00:08:35.770 --> 00:08:37.293
I use InDesign a lot for things,

171
00:08:37.293 --> 00:08:41.426
because there's a lot of crossover between
Illustrator and Photoshop and InDesign.

172
00:08:41.426 --> 00:08:44.398
I even find that for
me InDesign makes more sense.

173
00:08:44.398 --> 00:08:47.490
I can always save it in a format
later that I would send to Photoshop.

174
00:08:47.490 --> 00:08:53.340
So I might say, I need a background for
a web page and I would set it up web.

175
00:08:53.340 --> 00:08:55.390
But let's say,
I'm going to go to print first, and

176
00:08:55.390 --> 00:08:57.980
we're gonna print
a version of this document.

177
00:08:57.980 --> 00:09:00.859
Let's just say, we're gonna work with
a one page ad, something very simple.

178
00:09:00.859 --> 00:09:04.255
And we're gonna print it, but
we're also going to make a PDF of it,

179
00:09:04.255 --> 00:09:05.710
which is digital.

180
00:09:05.710 --> 00:09:07.670
So Web or Mobile?

181
00:09:07.670 --> 00:09:10.030
So again, is it Web or is it Mobile?

182
00:09:10.030 --> 00:09:11.972
Well it's a PDFm, it's digital.

183
00:09:11.972 --> 00:09:13.160
Digital isn't an option.

184
00:09:13.160 --> 00:09:16.890
So we're gonna look at that,
but Print is more restrictive.

185
00:09:16.890 --> 00:09:21.294
So when we start looking at things
like resolution and colors, there's

186
00:09:21.294 --> 00:09:26.058
a more narrow space because when we go
to Print, we're actually putting ink or

187
00:09:26.058 --> 00:09:29.185
toner on paper or
other things that we can print on.

188
00:09:29.185 --> 00:09:32.310
But we're kinda working on
this more restrictive space so

189
00:09:32.310 --> 00:09:35.700
if we're going to print on something else,
start with Print.

190
00:09:35.700 --> 00:09:38.420
It's a little more narrow,
we can always work out from there.

191
00:09:38.420 --> 00:09:39.600
We start with the web,

192
00:09:39.600 --> 00:09:42.910
it assumes that it's already kind of
this loosey-goosey kind of thing.

193
00:09:42.910 --> 00:09:48.770
And then when we wanna go to print, it
says you can't, you set it up too broad.

194
00:09:48.770 --> 00:09:50.440
So hopefully that makes sense.

195
00:09:50.440 --> 00:09:51.696
So I'm gonna choose print to start with.

196
00:09:51.696 --> 00:09:56.240
And when I do that,
my page sizes down here are print related.

197
00:09:56.240 --> 00:09:58.670
So the ones at the top
are ones that I've added,

198
00:09:58.670 --> 00:10:00.790
because we can add custom
ones along the way.

199
00:10:00.790 --> 00:10:03.040
But the ones you'll probably
see are Letter, Legal, Tabloid,

200
00:10:03.040 --> 00:10:06.510
Letter half, which is eight and a half
by five and a half, and a legal half.

201
00:10:06.510 --> 00:10:08.378
We've got some European sizes as well.

202
00:10:08.378 --> 00:10:10.699
And a couple of really useless
ones down here at the bottom.

203
00:10:10.699 --> 00:10:12.070
I never use these, compact disc.

204
00:10:12.070 --> 00:10:16.085
That's basically the size of
the insert that goes in a compact disc.

205
00:10:16.085 --> 00:10:17.178
What's a compact disc?

206
00:10:17.178 --> 00:10:18.581
Nobody uses those anymore.

207
00:10:18.581 --> 00:10:20.927
So I don't even use those at all.

208
00:10:20.927 --> 00:10:23.844
I'm gonna start with letter,
pretty basic, as I said.

209
00:10:23.844 --> 00:10:27.030
And I'm going to tell how many pages.

210
00:10:27.030 --> 00:10:29.730
I generally start with 1 page, unless for

211
00:10:29.730 --> 00:10:32.655
a fact you're doing
a 12 page doc document.

212
00:10:32.655 --> 00:10:35.305
Maybe they so,
we need a 12 page newsletter.

213
00:10:35.305 --> 00:10:36.595
I tend not to put that in there,

214
00:10:36.595 --> 00:10:40.585
I just leave it at 1 because you can
add pages super easy on the fly.

215
00:10:40.585 --> 00:10:42.785
Unless you absolutely know how many pages.

216
00:10:42.785 --> 00:10:45.760
Start page,
I'm gonna leave that as page number 1.

217
00:10:45.760 --> 00:10:48.816
When we get into a later episode,
we'll talk about sections and numbers and

218
00:10:48.816 --> 00:10:50.020
we can change all that again.

219
00:10:50.020 --> 00:10:52.069
We don't need to worry about that.

220
00:10:52.069 --> 00:10:54.270
Over here is Facing Pages.

221

00:31:47.419 --> 00:31:54.438

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Erica demonstrate the Adobe Workspace. They examine panels including topics like application frames, the control panel, panel menus, customizing keyboard shortcuts and saving your documents versus a template.
episodes.title: The Adobe Workspace
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:11.917 --> 00:00:12.417
Welcome back to another exciting
episode here at ItProTV.

3
00:00:15.040 --> 00:00:19.953
I'm your host Wes Bryan and in today's
episode we are continuing through our

4
00:00:19.953 --> 00:00:22.910
series in the Adobe Creative Cloud 2015.

5
00:00:22.910 --> 00:00:25.482
Specifically we're focusing on InDesign.

6
00:00:25.482 --> 00:00:27.837
Joining me in the studios
today is Erica Camden.

7
00:00:27.837 --> 00:00:28.462
How you doing, Erika?

8
00:00:28.462 --> 00:00:29.809
>> Pretty good, Wes, thanks.

9
00:00:29.809 --> 00:00:32.608
>> Looking good, so what are we
looking at in this episode today?

10
00:00:32.608 --> 00:00:36.180
>> This episode we're gonna start
looking at the Adobe workspace.

11
00:00:36.180 --> 00:00:40.448
So basically the environment that we
live when we're working in InDesign.

12
00:00:40.448 --> 00:00:41.690
So we're gonna get comfortable with

13
00:00:41.690 --> 00:00:43.940
some of the things we saw
in a previous episode.

14
00:00:43.940 --> 00:00:47.706
We looked at all these panels so
we're gonna start making sense of those.

15
00:00:47.706 --> 00:00:52.270
I'm gonna ahead and
jump back into InDesign and

16
00:00:52.270 --> 00:00:57.260
when we launched InDesign or
when we launched in actual document.

17
00:00:57.260 --> 00:00:59.430
Now, double click on document to open it.

18
00:00:59.430 --> 00:01:01.310
If the document is there
we would see that but

19
00:01:01.310 --> 00:01:03.950
right now,
let's just say we just launched InDesign.

20
00:01:03.950 --> 00:01:07.540
We're gonna have this thing staring us in
the face, what is this, a big gray square,

21
00:01:07.540 --> 00:01:09.530
that's what that is with stuff, right?

22
00:01:09.530 --> 00:01:11.550
So, let's start making
sense to some of the stuff.

23
00:01:11.550 --> 00:01:15.670
So, the first thing I wanna do is I wanna
change things and make it work for me.

24
00:01:15.670 --> 00:01:18.110
So, there's got to be a lot
of preferences in this.

25
00:01:18.110 --> 00:01:22.080
So don't copy what it is
that I do necessarily,

26
00:01:22.080 --> 00:01:26.560
kinda look at what it is I'm achieving and
then make your own choices from there.

27
00:01:26.560 --> 00:01:30.600
Because, like I said, it's preferences and
that is so that it works for you.

28
00:01:30.600 --> 00:01:33.630
That is the whole point of all this
customization of the workspace and

29
00:01:33.630 --> 00:01:34.190
preferences.

30
00:01:34.190 --> 00:01:38.683
So that it works f or you, so by default,
it's hard to say by default because these

31
00:01:38.683 --> 00:01:43.263
new versions come out so fast and furious
and the defaults change from time to time.

32
00:01:43.263 --> 00:01:46.429
In fact I'd like to play a little
game what defaults have changed and

33
00:01:46.429 --> 00:01:48.820
also where the Adobe has hidden my panels.

34
00:01:48.820 --> 00:01:49.840
Because in the menus,

35
00:01:49.840 --> 00:01:52.640
they move the panels around and regroup
them in sub groups as we get more and

36
00:01:52.640 --> 00:01:55.740
more panels to choose from, they have
to start putting them in sub menus.

37
00:01:55.740 --> 00:01:58.690
And sometimes trying to find where
those are is a bit of a challenge.

38
00:01:58.690 --> 00:02:01.800
So don't freak out if your version
doesn't look exactly like mine,

39
00:02:01.800 --> 00:02:04.410
because I'm gonna set it up
to my preferences anyway.

40
00:02:04.410 --> 00:02:06.780
So in a few minutes mine isn't
gonna look like any of yours.

41
00:02:06.780 --> 00:02:09.310
Is because I'm gonna set its
up exactly how I want to.

42
00:02:09.310 --> 00:02:14.300
But when we first launch it what we
probably see is a workspace up here called

43
00:02:14.300 --> 00:02:17.000
Essentials, that may or
may not be the one that you see, but

44
00:02:17.000 --> 00:02:20.880
you'll have a name up there and we'll
talk about workspaces in just a minute.

45
00:02:20.880 --> 00:02:23.950
And like I said we have this big
grey space, this is sort of the,

46
00:02:23.950 --> 00:02:26.370
I don't even know if there's
an actual name for it, but

47
00:02:26.370 --> 00:02:30.890
I just call it the Adobe workspace,
this is where I start putting in InDesign.

48
00:02:30.890 --> 00:02:32.660
Over on the left side
we have a tool panel,

49
00:02:32.660 --> 00:02:35.208
and we have some panels on
the right side as well.

50
00:02:35.208 --> 00:02:38.130
And we're gonna talk about all the panels
and how to arrange those in just a second.

51
00:02:38.130 --> 00:02:40.040
We're gonna start with the tool panel,

52
00:02:40.040 --> 00:02:43.120
up in the upper left there's this double
arrow, and I'm gonna click on that, and

53
00:02:43.120 --> 00:02:46.040
that will put it so
that it's in two columns.

54
00:02:46.040 --> 00:02:47.500
You can also click it again and

55
00:02:47.500 --> 00:02:51.600
you can actually get the single
one that way as well.

56
00:02:51.600 --> 00:02:53.720
So however it is you'd
like to see your tools,

57
00:02:53.720 --> 00:02:56.740
I just find that that makes
the icons too small for me.

58
00:02:56.740 --> 00:02:58.610
And I've had it that way for
many, many years and

59
00:02:58.610 --> 00:03:00.640
so I just like to put
it back the way it is.

60
00:03:00.640 --> 00:03:02.400
So I can see all my tools there.

61
00:03:02.400 --> 00:03:04.100
So that's my Tools panel.

62
00:03:04.100 --> 00:03:08.959
If I want to pull that off, I can, I can
actually grab this grey bar at the top.

63
00:03:08.959 --> 00:03:12.690
Anywhere in the grey bar and just pull it,
and it automatically comes off.

64
00:03:12.690 --> 00:03:17.210
And when I do that, you see on the left
side, my space, my workspace or

65
00:03:17.210 --> 00:03:21.250
what's called the application frame,
we're gonna look at in a second, expanded.

66
00:03:21.250 --> 00:03:24.810
So it says, you need more room to work so
moving the panels off and

67
00:03:24.810 --> 00:03:29.200
around actually expands your work space
as well, so just keep that in mind.

68
00:03:29.200 --> 00:03:31.170
I'm gonna grab this and
bring it right back.

69
00:03:31.170 --> 00:03:34.100
If it ever disappears,
I'm gonna click on this little x and

70
00:03:34.100 --> 00:03:35.780
that will make it disappear.

71
00:03:35.780 --> 00:03:39.410
If it's ever just gone for some reason,
you can always bring it back.

72
00:03:39.410 --> 00:03:43.020
Almost all of your panels
live under the Window menu.

73
00:03:43.020 --> 00:03:44.290
So up here at the top your Window menu,

74
00:03:44.290 --> 00:03:46.930
you're not going to have these
two extra menus that are here.

75
00:03:46.930 --> 00:03:48.930
These are some extra
items that I've added.

76
00:03:48.930 --> 00:03:51.700
So just keep that in mind that your Menus

77
00:03:51.700 --> 00:03:55.000
may look though may be fewer of
yours than there are of mine.

78
00:03:55.000 --> 00:03:57.900
As you add specialized tools,
little helpers,

79
00:03:57.900 --> 00:04:00.160
I'm always talking about how to
get your work done quicker and

80
00:04:00.160 --> 00:04:03.470
more efficiently, you might find
that you end up with extra menus.

81
00:04:03.470 --> 00:04:05.770
But the window menu will always be there.

82
00:04:05.770 --> 00:04:08.530
Up under the Window menu,
this is where most of your panels live so

83
00:04:08.530 --> 00:04:11.020
I wanna bring back my Tool
panel that disappeared.

84
00:04:11.020 --> 00:04:14.080
So I'm just gonna come down to
the tools menu, and choose that.

85
00:04:14.080 --> 00:04:17.130
And it's gonna put it back where I had it,
but I want to dock it back, so

86
00:04:17.130 --> 00:04:18.230
that's docking a panel.

87
00:04:18.230 --> 00:04:22.180
I want to grab it by the bar, and just
move it over to the side, and hopefully

88
00:04:22.180 --> 00:04:25.490
you can see that there's a little bit
of a blue bar that appears over there.

89
00:04:25.490 --> 00:04:27.370
That just means,
is that where you wanna dock it?

90
00:04:27.370 --> 00:04:29.410
Yes it is, I wanna put that there.

91
00:04:29.410 --> 00:04:30.650
And this one at the top,

92
00:04:30.650 --> 00:04:34.110
there's a lot of stuff at the top, that's
actually an individual panel as well.

93
00:04:34.110 --> 00:04:35.750
That's called the control panel.

94
00:04:35.750 --> 00:04:40.070
And what the control panel does
is it duplicates other panels.

95
00:04:40.070 --> 00:04:44.650
Sounds like it's not very helpful but
it actually is, it's a contextual panel.

96
00:04:44.650 --> 00:04:47.470
So that means if I select
something like the Type tool,

97
00:04:47.470 --> 00:04:51.980
when I select it, the top control
panel changes to all the text items.

98
00:04:51.980 --> 00:04:56.220
In fact, it basically combines your
character panel and your paragraph panel.

99
00:04:56.220 --> 00:04:57.860
Now, I will look at those
panels individually and

100
00:04:57.860 --> 00:05:01.970
what they do in the future episode but
it puts everything up at the top.

101
00:05:01.970 --> 00:05:05.090
So, I don't have to go and
fetch all this panels every time.

102
00:05:05.090 --> 00:05:09.150
I can but I don't need to,
if I change it to the direction,

103
00:05:09.150 --> 00:05:11.530
I'm sorry the selection tool,
the direction tool.

104
00:05:11.530 --> 00:05:13.610
Selection tool and
the direct selection tool.

105
00:05:13.610 --> 00:05:18.240
When I change it to those it contextualize
to the top it changes as well.

106
00:05:18.240 --> 00:05:19.580
So, again, as I change and

107
00:05:19.580 --> 00:05:22.880
select different tools,
that control panel changes.

108
00:05:22.880 --> 00:05:25.560
I can turn that on and
off as well, that's on by default.

109
00:05:25.560 --> 00:05:26.700
So the control panel is there.

110
00:05:26.700 --> 00:05:29.310
I can also dock that control
panel somewhere else.

111
00:05:29.310 --> 00:05:33.080
Instead of at the top, I can grab this
little gray handle that's over here.

112
00:05:33.080 --> 00:05:34.888
Some of these little things,
they don't make any sense.

113
00:05:34.888 --> 00:05:37.860
I like just to click on things and
drag and mess things up and

114
00:05:37.860 --> 00:05:39.570
see where they are, what they do.

115
00:05:39.570 --> 00:05:42.770
Because sometimes the little icons
don't make a whole lot of sense.

116
00:05:42.770 --> 00:05:45.120
But I can grab that and I can float that.

117
00:05:45.120 --> 00:05:46.580
So now I have this floating panel,

118
00:05:46.580 --> 00:05:48.920
notice I've got a little bit
more space at the top as well.

119
00:05:48.920 --> 00:05:52.450
So it's always making sure I'm
using my entire screen real estate.

120
00:05:52.450 --> 00:05:54.010
I can also bring this down to the bottom.

121
00:05:54.010 --> 00:05:57.040
Now, as a Mac user I don't want
to dock that at the bottom,

122
00:05:57.040 --> 00:05:59.760
because if I try to get to it I'm
going to run into my Mac dock, so

123
00:05:59.760 --> 00:06:01.580
that doesn't work very well for me at all.

124
00:06:01.580 --> 00:06:03.270
So I'm gonna grab that, pull it off and

125
00:06:03.270 --> 00:06:06.980
drag it back up to the top till I get
that little blue line at the top and

126
00:06:06.980 --> 00:06:09.330
that shows me it's gonna dock it in there,
kind of wedge it in there.

127
00:06:10.370 --> 00:06:12.370
So that's the control panel.

128
00:06:12.370 --> 00:06:13.200
The other thing,

129
00:06:13.200 --> 00:06:16.696
if we go up under the window menu down
at the bottom I have these two options.

130
00:06:16.696 --> 00:06:19.217
One's greyed out,
the application frame, so

131
00:06:19.217 --> 00:06:23.567
this is something that was introduced
several versions ago, and what it does is,

132
00:06:23.567 --> 00:06:26.360
just gives us that,
I think of it almost as a tray.

133
00:06:26.360 --> 00:06:30.490
So I can always work in,
put my items on top of that tray, and

134
00:06:30.490 --> 00:06:34.580
whether it's my panels, when I move a
panel out, and it expanded it, it's kinda

135
00:06:34.580 --> 00:06:38.840
like now I have more room in that tray
to work, so, by default, that's on.

136
00:06:38.840 --> 00:06:42.590
If I turn that off, now I can see
right through it to my desktop.

137
00:06:42.590 --> 00:06:44.310
Now if you've been on the Mac for
years and

138
00:06:44.310 --> 00:06:47.460
years, this is what you're used to
your applications looking like.

139
00:06:47.460 --> 00:06:50.030
When you open it up,
you could always see what was behind it.

140
00:06:50.030 --> 00:06:54.136
If you've been working on a PC forever,
you're actually used to it the other way.

141
00:06:54.136 --> 00:06:57.307
And I can tell you when they first put
that into InDesign It freaked me out,

142
00:06:57.307 --> 00:07:00.140
where's my desktop,
why can't I just see what's behind.

143
00:07:00.140 --> 00:07:02.410
I like to grab things from the desktop and
bring them into InDesign,

144
00:07:02.410 --> 00:07:03.600
why can't I do that?

145
00:07:03.600 --> 00:07:05.840
Well you can, it just takes an extra step.

146
00:07:05.840 --> 00:07:10.300
But as we've seen as I move a panel in or
out and it changes for

147
00:07:10.300 --> 00:07:13.620
me, that to me makes it totally worth it.

148
00:07:13.620 --> 00:07:16.630
The other thing that I have underneath
here is the application bar.

149
00:07:16.630 --> 00:07:20.490
Now, I can only turn it on or off when I'm
not working with an application frame.

150
00:07:20.490 --> 00:07:23.210
So now the application
bar option is available.

151
00:07:23.210 --> 00:07:26.050
When I turn that off it basically
just turned off that top row.

152
00:07:26.050 --> 00:07:27.870
And what that top row is,

153
00:07:27.870 --> 00:07:31.610
is it just has things where I can jump
out to my other applications like Bridge.

154
00:07:31.610 --> 00:07:34.290
I can go to Bridge Right away.

155
00:07:34.290 --> 00:07:36.740
I can play with the documents if
I have multiple documents open,

156
00:07:36.740 --> 00:07:38.830
I can rearrange them or
tile them on there.

157
00:07:38.830 --> 00:07:42.380
So there's just some extra
options that I get for InDesign.

158
00:07:42.380 --> 00:07:45.630
And I also have my workspace as well,
available to me right here,

159
00:07:45.630 --> 00:07:47.350
instead of having to go through a menu.

160
00:07:47.350 --> 00:07:51.420
I generally leave that on, I generally
leave the application frame on as well.

161
00:07:51.420 --> 00:07:54.230
So again, I have everything
in this neat little package.

162
00:07:54.230 --> 00:07:59.156
Now, other things that are on this tray,
if you will, are these Panels.

163
00:07:59.156 --> 00:08:02.946
Now the workspace is called essentials and
we're gonna look that there are several to

164
00:08:02.946 --> 00:08:06.360
choose from and we're gonna create
our own in just a second as well.

165
00:08:06.360 --> 00:08:11.280
Again it's all about being proficient
in your workflow, how you wanna work.

166
00:08:11.280 --> 00:08:14.200
Don't worry about what I have or what the
person sitting next to you if you're in

167
00:08:14.200 --> 00:08:17.770
a group environment what they have,
work so that it makes sense to you.

168
00:08:17.770 --> 00:08:20.190
When you go over to the panels
are the ones you need

169
00:08:20.190 --> 00:08:23.260
with the other ones that you need, are
they grouped together in a logical manner.

170
00:08:23.260 --> 00:08:25.560
Do you have a ton of
them that you never use?

171
00:08:25.560 --> 00:08:26.160
Why are they there?

172
00:08:26.160 --> 00:08:27.680
Take them out of your way,
you can always get to them,

173
00:08:27.680 --> 00:08:29.150
you can always add them later.

174
00:08:29.150 --> 00:08:30.390
But if they're in your way and

175
00:08:30.390 --> 00:08:34.030
you're constantly trying to look through
the panels because you can't remember what

176
00:08:34.030 --> 00:08:38.020
the panel is or
where it lives then get rid of it.

177
00:08:38.020 --> 00:08:41.770
So by default you can see the icons and
the names and

178
00:08:41.770 --> 00:08:44.900
in the most, most recent version,
depending on when you're looking at it but

179
00:08:44.900 --> 00:08:48.870
when I just updated to the version, one of
the things they did is they made the type

180
00:08:48.870 --> 00:08:51.840
bigger on the panels because it's
been getting smaller and smaller.

181
00:08:51.840 --> 00:08:55.220
Now I realize my eyes are getting
worse and worse, but it's not just me.

182
00:08:55.220 --> 00:08:57.790
The panel's type has been
getting smaller and smaller and

183
00:08:57.790 --> 00:08:59.400
they just made it bigger and
a little clearer.

184
00:08:59.400 --> 00:09:02.000
They changed the font which
sounds like a little thing but

185
00:09:02.000 --> 00:09:04.480
when you're looking at all these
panels it really makes a difference,

186
00:09:04.480 --> 00:09:06.920
especially when you're looking at them
in a list like they are right now.

187
00:09:06.920 --> 00:09:10.320
I can grab right here, if I roll over,
hopefully you can see that.

188
00:09:10.320 --> 00:09:12.620
I'll turn on the zoom, although it
never changes the size of that,

189
00:09:12.620 --> 00:09:16.190
let's actually zoom in this way,
we can actually see the arrow changes.

190
00:09:16.190 --> 00:09:18.920
So it changes to that double arrow,
I'm gonna zoom back in.

191
00:09:18.920 --> 00:09:20.840
I always like to tell you when
I'm zooming in and out so

192
00:09:20.840 --> 00:09:23.630
we don't get seasick,
look away if you need to.

193
00:09:23.630 --> 00:09:27.410
But I get that double arrow and then I can
basically change the size of the panel.

194
00:09:27.410 --> 00:09:30.680
Like I can slide them in and
out like that.

195
00:09:30.680 --> 00:09:32.940
So I can push it all
the way down to just icon.

196
00:09:32.940 --> 00:09:36.960
So again I have more room but for me,
I don't know what half those icons mean.

197
00:09:36.960 --> 00:09:39.240
And I've been staring at them for
15 years, right?

198
00:09:39.240 --> 00:09:42.020
But for whatever reason,
some of them don't make sense to me.

199
00:09:42.020 --> 00:09:47.080
So even if I want to conserve space,
maybe I'm working on a lower resolution on

200
00:09:47.080 --> 00:09:50.260
my screen, and I need to be able
to see as much as possible.

201
00:09:50.260 --> 00:09:53.220
I might move this over just a little bit,
so I've just enough so

202
00:09:53.220 --> 00:09:54.580
I can kind of see what they are.

203
00:09:54.580 --> 00:09:57.750
So again, that's a preference,
do what you need to do and

204
00:09:57.750 --> 00:10:00.400
these are actual panel groups.

205
00:10:00.400 --> 00:10:03.680
Now right now I'm seeing them in sort of
these buttons, so they almost look like

206
00:10:03.680 --> 00:10:08.120
buttons as I roll over one, and click on
it the panel bursts out from the side.

207
00:10:08.120 --> 00:10:12.110
Now it's not just that one panel,
you notice color and stroke both came with

208
00:10:12.110 --> 00:10:16.060
it and that's because it's in the panel
group, so those are nested together.

209
00:10:16.060 --> 00:10:18.380
I'm gonna show you how to do
that in just a minute as well.

210
00:10:18.380 --> 00:10:22.270
I can also view those as
tabbed panels as well.

211
00:10:22.270 --> 00:10:25.140
So instead of these buttons, the buttons
are nice and clean, just so you know,

212
00:10:25.140 --> 00:10:26.970
I like that, but you might not want that.

213
00:10:26.970 --> 00:10:30.690
I can come again to that double headed
arrow that's there and click on that.

214
00:10:30.690 --> 00:10:35.300
And now I have all my tabs so
I've still got my nested groups, but

215
00:10:35.300 --> 00:10:37.140
it's a little harder, I think, to see.

216
00:10:37.140 --> 00:10:38.470
But again this might be what you want.

217
00:10:38.470 --> 00:10:41.650
And the nice thing about this is that as

So that's wrapping it all up.

We got it.

It wasn't very exciting what we saved,
but it's there, we've got a file saved.

664

We can move on from there.

665
00:30:54.490 --> 00:30:58.160
>> You know what I think is amazing is
how much you showed us how much you can

666
00:30:58.160 --> 00:30:59.300
>> Can customize it to suit

667
00:30:59.300 --> 00:30:59.960
your own needs.

668

And like you said, the way you customize
it might not be the way I customize it.

669

And I like the other too, Ctrl+S is
your friend, or Cmd+S is your friend.

670
00:31:07.790 --> 00:31:10.050
Now it does like we're coming
to the end of another episode.

671
00:31:10.050 --> 00:31:11.610
But before we sign off,

>> Just remember that everything

And customize it, it makes you work

675

That's the goal, at least for me, is to
work efficiently and know that everything

676
00:31:24.850 --> 00:31:27.660

so I can just get my work done.

677
00:31:27.660 --> 00:31:28.210
>> Very good.

678
00:31:28.210 --> 00:31:31.240
Well, we appreciate you joining us in
the studios, and we appreciate you,

679
00:31:31.240 --> 00:31:32.400
the viewer, watching.

680
00:31:32.400 --> 00:31:34.029
Signing off for ITProTV.

681
00:31:34.029 --> 00:31:35.513
I Have been your host Wes Bryan.

682
00:31:35.513 --> 00:31:36.499
>> And I'm Erica Gammet.

683
00:31:36.499 --> 00:31:38.491
>> And we'll see you next time.

684
00:31:38.491 --> 00:31:46.870
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Erica demonstrate working with design elements and guides. They look at text frames and placeholders. They explain how to use graphics frames, unassigned frames and modifying polygons. They also explore placing, moving and deleting guides. They dive into smart guides including smart spacing, smart cursors and smart dimensions.
episodes.title: Elements and Guides

So, when I want to put text in a text

In the previous movie we set up

00:07:47.575 --> 00:07:50.841
I'm actually gonna used the menu item so

00:07:50.841 --> 00:07:54.537
Under the type menu, down at the bottom,
Fill with Placeholder Text and

00:07:54.537 --> 00:07:57.890
it's gonna go ahead and

175
00:07:57.890 --> 00:08:01.921
So now your text isn't going to look like
this, your text is going to be called,

176
00:08:01.921 --> 00:08:03.977

It's not even lorem ipsum, it's fakey

00:08:08.691 --> 00:08:11.852
the point of place holder text,
one of the points, is so

00:08:11.852 --> 00:08:16.026

when we start making adjustments and

180
00:08:16.026 --> 00:08:18.040

00:08:18.040 --> 00:08:20.750
So we get an idea of how things

Well if it's in a fakey-fake language,

00:08:26.606 --> 00:08:28.427

00:08:32.507 --> 00:08:34.928
The time machine page by HG Wells.

00:08:34.928 --> 00:08:37.320
I just changed out everyone well,

can set up and that's a polygon frame.
