00:19:43.710 --> 00:19:44.928
I'm gonna click and hold and

423
00:19:44.928 --> 00:19:47.684
again, you can use this tool, or
you can use the tool next to it.

424
00:19:47.684 --> 00:19:51.283
Like I said, they do the same thing,
they're just expecting different content.

425
00:19:51.283 --> 00:19:53.118
I'm gonna come right to the polygon tool.

426
00:19:53.118 --> 00:19:55.733
And when I click and
drag with that polygon,

427
00:19:55.733 --> 00:19:58.820
it automatically uses
the last shape that I did.

428
00:19:58.820 --> 00:20:03.050
So the number of sides that I had and
what's called a star inset or a pinch and

429
00:20:03.050 --> 00:20:05.962
in this case it pinched down and
gave me a five sided star.

430
00:20:05.962 --> 00:20:07.430
So I'll show you that in just a second,

431
00:20:07.430 --> 00:20:10.150
we're just going to use
the last thing that we created.

432
00:20:10.150 --> 00:20:12.150
Now the great thing about polygons,
I can do the same thing,

433
00:20:12.150 --> 00:20:15.460
I can hold down the shift key
to get a nice proportional item.

434
00:20:15.460 --> 00:20:18.120
I can hold down the option or
alt key to draw from the center outwards.

435
00:20:19.140 --> 00:20:22.670
I can also change on
the fly how many sides and

436
00:20:22.670 --> 00:20:25.610
what the pinches to
that particular object.

437
00:20:25.610 --> 00:20:28.730
To do that, it's a two step process
unless you're on a very old version,

438
00:20:28.730 --> 00:20:32.690
I think probably pre CS6 version,
you do not need to do this first step.

439
00:20:32.690 --> 00:20:35.820
So if you're CS6 or
afterwards you have to do this first step.

440
00:20:35.820 --> 00:20:40.310
Hit the space bar once, and it turns off
this other feature that was introduced,

441
00:20:40.310 --> 00:20:42.180
which we'll cover later.

442
00:20:42.180 --> 00:20:46.970
And now I can use my up arrow keys,
or my down arrow keys to add and

443
00:20:46.970 --> 00:20:50.220
subtract sides to that particular object.

444
00:20:50.220 --> 00:20:53.550
I can use the right and
left arrow keys, so

445
00:20:53.550 --> 00:20:57.200
just on the keyboard just the arrow keys
that are there, to change that star inset.

446
00:20:57.200 --> 00:20:58.690
So if I move all the way out, and

447
00:20:58.690 --> 00:21:02.030
Apple changes used to be able to
hold it down and it would change.

448
00:21:02.030 --> 00:21:05.510
Now Apple needs you to hit every
time you want something to change.

449
00:21:05.510 --> 00:21:08.890
So I'm gonna do that, just keep hitting
it, up and down, change to the size.

450
00:21:08.890 --> 00:21:10.740
And then I can still, at the last moment,

451
00:21:10.740 --> 00:21:13.880
I'm still holding down the mouse key
the whole time I'm doing this, by the way.

452
00:21:13.880 --> 00:21:16.980
I can then hold down the shift key to
constrain it or I can even do the option

453
00:21:16.980 --> 00:21:20.350
or alt to draw from that center outwards,
once I got the perfect starburst.

454
00:21:20.350 --> 00:21:24.450
Lets add a bunch of sides and
lets pinch this down and make a nice

455
00:21:24.450 --> 00:21:28.760
shiny starburst there and then I let
go and there's my shape, ready to go.

456
00:21:28.760 --> 00:21:33.200
Now if I don't want to do it that way,
I can double click on the polygon tool,

457
00:21:33.200 --> 00:21:36.270
again different from the other tools,
we click on the tool once,

458
00:21:36.270 --> 00:21:39.090
click on the page once,
polygon tool we double click on the tool.

459
00:21:39.090 --> 00:21:39.890
How many sides?

460
00:21:39.890 --> 00:21:43.883
That's exactly what I had last
time was 21 sides and a 55% pinch.

461
00:21:43.883 --> 00:21:48.150
Now I don't know how much the percentage
is the pinch, that's why I do it visually.

462
00:21:48.150 --> 00:21:49.500
But I can choose it that way, and

463
00:21:49.500 --> 00:21:52.730
it will automatically draw
the last thing that I created.

464
00:21:53.750 --> 00:21:54.710
So that's polygons.

465
00:21:55.970 --> 00:22:00.730
All right, now we're gonna start
putting some guides on the page.

466
00:22:00.730 --> 00:22:04.543
So now we're gonna actually tell
it where those sit on the page.

467
00:22:04.543 --> 00:22:07.650
I'm actually gonna jump to the next page.

468
00:22:07.650 --> 00:22:11.230
Actually, nope,
we'll stay on this page here.

469
00:22:11.230 --> 00:22:13.670
I'm gonna do some stacking
order stuff in just a second.

470
00:22:13.670 --> 00:22:20.040
So guides is just basically where I lay
out so I know where my stuff needs to go

471
00:22:20.040 --> 00:22:24.020
whether it's text frames or shape frames
or whatever, sometimes we need guides.

472
00:22:24.020 --> 00:22:26.135
Now, we already have some
guide set on this page.

473
00:22:26.135 --> 00:22:30.260
When we set up this document,
we ended up with margins and

474
00:22:30.260 --> 00:22:33.305
bleeds, those are guides they're
the specialized guides, but

475
00:22:33.305 --> 00:22:36.315
we can put all the guides we
want on the page as well.

476
00:22:36.315 --> 00:22:40.135
So to do that I'm going to come over here
and I want to make sure my rulers are on,

477
00:22:40.135 --> 00:22:42.565
right now I have the rulers on,
they should be on by default.

478
00:22:42.565 --> 00:22:46.360
If they are not command or
control R will turn those on and off.

479
00:22:46.360 --> 00:22:47.280
Here's another great thing, and

480
00:22:47.280 --> 00:22:49.990
we're gonna do this with
guides in just a second,

481
00:22:49.990 --> 00:22:53.950
I see that it's inches across the top,
that's what I set up as my preferences.

482
00:22:53.950 --> 00:22:56.970
I can always right click or
control click on a ruler and

483
00:22:56.970 --> 00:22:59.910
change the measurements
on the ruler right here.

484
00:22:59.910 --> 00:23:03.660
Maybe, for whatever reason, I need to
work in centimeters at this point.

485
00:23:03.660 --> 00:23:06.270
I showed you in a previous movie how you
can actually put in a different value

486
00:23:06.270 --> 00:23:09.880
amount and put in cm if you want to switch
to centimeters even though you're working

487
00:23:09.880 --> 00:23:10.840
in inches.

488
00:23:10.840 --> 00:23:14.330
I use that if I'm doing say a drop
shadow and I need a tiny amount,

489
00:23:14.330 --> 00:23:17.830
I don't know tiny amounts of inches,
right decimal parts of inches but

490
00:23:17.830 --> 00:23:21.190
I do know what two millimeters looks like,
so I might change it to that.

491
00:23:21.190 --> 00:23:23.420
So I can change the rulers
at anytime as well.

492
00:23:23.420 --> 00:23:27.640
Right click or control click on a ruler
and they each work individually.

493
00:23:27.640 --> 00:23:29.400
So let's put some guides on the page.

494
00:23:29.400 --> 00:23:33.240
So I can drag out a guide by clicking
on a ruler and dragging down.

495
00:23:33.240 --> 00:23:35.110
So I'm doing a horizontal ruler.

496
00:23:35.110 --> 00:23:37.190
So I go to the, I'm sorry,
horizontal guide,

497
00:23:37.190 --> 00:23:39.531
I pull it out of the horizontal ruler and
drag it down.

498
00:23:39.531 --> 00:23:42.472
If I drag off to the side you
notice my guides are infinite,

499
00:23:42.472 --> 00:23:44.103
they go across the paste board.

500
00:23:44.103 --> 00:23:45.186
This may or may not be helpful.

501
00:23:45.186 --> 00:23:48.009
You might want your guides kind
of all contained on that page.

502
00:23:48.009 --> 00:23:49.261
Again it's up to you.

503
00:23:49.261 --> 00:23:50.524
I'll just drag it to where I want.

504
00:23:50.524 --> 00:23:52.746
And if you look in
the upper left hand corner,

505
00:23:52.746 --> 00:23:56.724
which I can't point to cuz I'm holding
down my mouse key, but the upper left hand

506
00:23:56.724 --> 00:24:00.920
corner of my control panel, you notice
that the amount is changing the Y axis.

507
00:24:00.920 --> 00:24:03.860
There's no X axis because
rulers are infinite so

508
00:24:03.860 --> 00:24:05.620
they only work in one direction.

509
00:24:05.620 --> 00:24:08.596
So, it's telling me exactly where it is so
I can go, okay, let's try and

510
00:24:08.596 --> 00:24:11.620
get this at 2 and three-quarters and
I can let go and get it exactly there.

511
00:24:11.620 --> 00:24:13.860
Now the great thing is if
I'm not that accurate?

512
00:24:13.860 --> 00:24:16.702
I'm gonna undo that, Cmd or Ctrl+Z,
and I dropped it on the page and

513
00:24:16.702 --> 00:24:19.510
realize I want that to be at 2 and
three-quarters.

514
00:24:19.510 --> 00:24:21.283
I can make sure it's selected and

515
00:24:21.283 --> 00:24:24.333
I know it's selected because
my ruler is this dark blue.

516
00:24:24.333 --> 00:24:26.217
If I click off of it, it's the cyan.

517
00:24:26.217 --> 00:24:29.792
And that's because each layer,
we're gonna look at layers later on,

518
00:24:29.792 --> 00:24:32.175
but each layer has a different
color code to it so

519
00:24:32.175 --> 00:24:35.468
I can see that I'm on this base layer and
that's that light blue.

520
00:24:35.468 --> 00:24:38.207
So, I can put that there and say,
okay, I really want to select that.

521
00:24:38.207 --> 00:24:40.400
Well, I can either just roll over it,
and again,

522
00:24:40.400 --> 00:24:42.800
I get that mouse with a little
plus that's on there.

523
00:24:42.800 --> 00:24:44.420
Let's zoom in so we can see that.

524
00:24:44.420 --> 00:24:49.240
So, as I roll over an item, it turns on,
it shows me something is selected.

525
00:24:49.240 --> 00:24:52.400
All right, so I can select that,
or I can just drag across it.

526
00:24:52.400 --> 00:24:54.430
So, I drag across it,
have that guide selected.

527
00:24:54.430 --> 00:24:56.797
Now I can come up here and say,
I actually want it to be 2 and

528
00:24:56.797 --> 00:25:01.460
three-quarters, I can actually put the
exact amount there, 2 and three-quarters.

529
00:25:01.460 --> 00:25:04.620
Now I can do pretty much anything to
a guide that I do with other objects.

530
00:25:04.620 --> 00:25:07.380
I can step and repeat that if I
want it to be every quarter inch or

531
00:25:07.380 --> 00:25:08.510
something like that.

532
00:25:08.510 --> 00:25:10.410
I can move it if I decide
I don't like where it is.

533
00:25:10.410 --> 00:25:12.860
I can change the value here,
I can move it around.

534
00:25:12.860 --> 00:25:15.650
What I need to do when I want to get
rid of it though, is select it and

535
00:25:15.650 --> 00:25:17.480
I can just hit Delete.

536
00:25:17.480 --> 00:25:19.380
There is three or
four other ways to get rid of guides,

537
00:25:19.380 --> 00:25:21.010
that's the simplest way, I think.

538
00:25:21.010 --> 00:25:23.060
Now if I have objects on the page.

539
00:25:23.060 --> 00:25:25.030
Let's come back to this
page with some objects.

540
00:25:25.030 --> 00:25:29.120
And I put a couple rulers and
I'm gonna drag a ruler out here.

541
00:25:31.350 --> 00:25:32.480
Let me actually drag a ruler.

542
00:25:32.480 --> 00:25:34.740
Why is it not letting
me drag a ruler here?

543
00:25:35.780 --> 00:25:36.950
That's interesting.

544
00:25:36.950 --> 00:25:39.242
All right, let's try it over here.

545
00:25:39.242 --> 00:25:41.406
I have no idea why it's
not letting me drag.

546
00:25:41.406 --> 00:25:42.500
There we go.

547
00:25:42.500 --> 00:25:43.272
It was just tired.

548
00:25:43.272 --> 00:25:48.150
All right, so there it is, I drag a couple
of ruler guides that are out there and

549
00:25:48.150 --> 00:25:49.670
I want to select those guides.

550
00:25:49.670 --> 00:25:53.370
Well if I select over here,
I can select those guides individually.

551
00:25:53.370 --> 00:25:58.010
If I drag across the guides and
an object, only my object got selected.

552
00:25:58.010 --> 00:26:00.054
And that's because it
favors objects over guides,

553
00:26:00.054 --> 00:26:02.492
because you wouldn't want to
move everything together.

554
00:26:02.492 --> 00:26:03.490
That kinda defeats the whole

555
00:26:03.490 --> 00:26:05.410
purpose of putting guides on
your page in the first place.

556
00:26:05.410 --> 00:26:07.733
So, just know that if that you're
trying to select guides and

557
00:26:07.733 --> 00:26:11.210
you've got objects there, you're gonna
need to probably individually select them.

558
00:26:11.210 --> 00:26:15.160
So, like with any other item, and
this works across the Adobe spectrum.

559
00:26:15.160 --> 00:26:17.450
So that's why I haven't mentioned it,
but I will now.

560
00:26:17.450 --> 00:26:21.580
If I select something and hit Shift and
Select, I can select multiple items.

561
00:26:21.580 --> 00:26:25.220
So I can either drag across multiple
items or Shift+Select each of those.

562
00:26:25.220 --> 00:26:26.350
So I selected the guides.

563
00:26:26.350 --> 00:26:29.020
I delete those, but
my objects are still there left behind.

564
00:26:30.130 --> 00:26:31.028
So those are guides.

565
00:26:31.028 --> 00:26:33.970
I call these dumb guides now though
because a few versions back,

566
00:26:33.970 --> 00:26:36.220
they introduced what's
called Smart Guides.

567
00:26:36.220 --> 00:26:39.800
And Smart Guides are cool because they
work contextually and on the fly.

568
00:26:39.800 --> 00:26:43.740
As I'm creating items,
it shows me how things line up.

569
00:26:43.740 --> 00:26:47.040
So, it's kind of good and it's kind of
bad, because I've always been the stickler

570
00:26:47.040 --> 00:26:50.460
for everything lining up perfectly, and
having everything laid out beautifully.

571
00:26:50.460 --> 00:26:52.430
And, designers, I do a lot of work for

572
00:26:52.430 --> 00:26:55.210
designers, I do their production work for
them.

573
00:26:55.210 --> 00:26:57.320
And, they like to just
throw things on the page.

574
00:26:57.320 --> 00:26:59.970
This kind of gives you a happy medium,
it lets you throw things on the page but

575
00:26:59.970 --> 00:27:03.170
you also know when those
things are lined up.

576
00:27:03.170 --> 00:27:06.490
So I'm gonna go ahead and create an item.

577
00:27:06.490 --> 00:27:07.670
Grab the rectangle here.

578
00:27:07.670 --> 00:27:10.140
And I'm just gonna draw out the size.

579
00:27:10.140 --> 00:27:11.740
And them I'm gonna use the selection tool.

580
00:27:11.740 --> 00:27:14.080
So, I actually grab this item.

581
00:27:14.080 --> 00:27:16.180
And I wanna see where that sits.

582
00:27:16.180 --> 00:27:18.420
And I want to put another
item on the page, and

583
00:27:18.420 --> 00:27:21.290
I want it to be the same height,
or the same width, or whatever.

584
00:27:21.290 --> 00:27:23.437
So I'm gonna grab another item.

585
00:27:23.437 --> 00:27:25.099
And I'm just gonna start drawing.

586
00:27:25.099 --> 00:27:26.050
And hopefully you'll be able to see it.

587
00:27:26.050 --> 00:27:27.005
If not, I might have to zoom in.

588
00:27:27.005 --> 00:27:31.159
But when I get to the same height,
I get these little green arrows.

589
00:27:31.159 --> 00:27:33.278
So, actually,
I'm gonna zoom in really quick.

590
00:27:33.278 --> 00:27:34.160
I'm gonna undo that.

591
00:27:34.160 --> 00:27:36.197
Then I'm gonna zoom in so
we can see that for sure.

592
00:27:36.197 --> 00:27:40.130
I'm showing this cuz I feel like I'm
gonna get sea sick if I move too much.

593
00:27:40.130 --> 00:27:40.980
So, let's do that.

594
00:27:40.980 --> 00:27:44.060
You can see where it shows you where it's
lined up with the bottom of that object.

595
00:27:44.060 --> 00:27:45.070
Then I get this pink one.

596
00:27:45.070 --> 00:27:48.580
That shows me that's the center
of the page as well.

597
00:27:48.580 --> 00:27:50.405
And then, when I get to the same height,

598
00:27:50.405 --> 00:27:52.358
you can see that green
arrow that shows up.

599
00:27:52.358 --> 00:27:55.472
So it's telling me that it's the same
exact height as the object that's nearby.

600
00:27:55.472 --> 00:27:58.033
And then I can do the same thing
when it hits the width as well.

601
00:27:58.033 --> 00:27:59.934
If you have not had much
caffeine you can do this.

602
00:27:59.934 --> 00:28:00.724
There we go.

603
00:28:00.724 --> 00:28:02.622
It's the same width and the same height.

604
00:28:02.622 --> 00:28:03.947
We're gonna zoom back out now.

605
00:28:03.947 --> 00:28:07.110
And I could have copied and
pasted that one.

606
00:28:07.110 --> 00:28:09.420
But where that comes in handy is
if I want them to look different.

607
00:28:09.420 --> 00:28:12.150
I just wanna make sure that they're
the same height and same width.

608
00:28:12.150 --> 00:28:15.470
So I'm actually going to cheat now and
copy and paste that second item.

609
00:28:15.470 --> 00:28:17.900
So I'm gonna throw this guy off here,
and this guy here.

610
00:28:17.900 --> 00:28:18.870
I'm gonna do copy and paste.

611
00:28:18.870 --> 00:28:20.730
Cmd+ or Ctrl+C to copy.

612
00:28:20.730 --> 00:28:23.000
Cmd+ or Ctrl+V to paste.

613
00:28:23.000 --> 00:28:25.170
And what I wanna do is I wanna
make sure that this item,

614
00:28:25.170 --> 00:28:28.010
even though this is not
the same stair step value,

615
00:28:28.010 --> 00:28:30.950
I want to know that the width,
the separation is the same.

616
00:28:30.950 --> 00:28:34.020
So when I do that, I get these little
guides along the bottom that shows me that

617
00:28:34.020 --> 00:28:38.020
the gap between those
items is exactly the same.

618
00:28:38.020 --> 00:28:41.310
So that's Smart Guides, it shows me
all the time as I'm laying things out.

619
00:28:41.310 --> 00:28:44.765
I can say, okay, I want this
item to be centered on the page.

620
00:28:44.765 --> 00:28:47.560
It's centered left to right, and
now it's centered top to bottom.

621
00:28:47.560 --> 00:28:50.350
So now I know it's sitting
exactly in the center of the page

622
00:28:50.350 --> 00:28:52.120
because I'm using those Smart Guides.

623
00:28:52.120 --> 00:28:54.670
The other things that we can see
when we're doing that is we can see

624
00:28:54.670 --> 00:28:55.770
values turned on.

625
00:28:55.770 --> 00:28:57.760
Although it's not,
that might be off by default now.

626
00:28:57.760 --> 00:29:00.710
I'm gonna go into my preferences and
show you how to turn on and

627
00:29:00.710 --> 00:29:04.460
off the different Smart Guides, and
Smart Guides are on by default.

628
00:29:04.460 --> 00:29:07.160
You can turn them off entirely
if you don't want to see all

629
00:29:07.160 --> 00:29:08.600
those lines flashing on and off.

630
00:29:08.600 --> 00:29:11.380
That can be kind of confusing
when you have a lot of objects.

631
00:29:11.380 --> 00:29:14.923
Because if you have ten objects on there,
every time it gets to the size of one of

632
00:29:14.923 --> 00:29:17.841
the other objects,
you're gonna get that flash of that guide.

633
00:29:17.841 --> 00:29:22.566
So, I'm gonna go into my preferences,
InDesign > Preferences on a Mac,

634
00:29:22.566 --> 00:29:24.368
Edit > Preferences on a PC.

635
00:29:24.368 --> 00:29:27.697
And I am gonna come down to Guides and
Pasteboard.

636
00:29:27.697 --> 00:29:29.940
And down at the bottom here,
Smart Guide Options.

637
00:29:29.940 --> 00:29:32.720
So align to object center and edges,
that's what we were just doing was

638
00:29:32.720 --> 00:29:34.760
the center,
showed us when it was lined up to that,

639
00:29:34.760 --> 00:29:37.840
when it was lined up to
the other object's edges.

640
00:29:37.840 --> 00:29:39.650
Smart dimensions is turned on,

641
00:29:39.650 --> 00:29:43.220
it was not displaying so that might
be something with this new version.

642
00:29:43.220 --> 00:29:44.100
It might be a bug.

643
00:29:44.100 --> 00:29:47.870
You'll find this, what it should show you
is a little box that shows you how wide

644
00:29:47.870 --> 00:29:49.240
and how tall that object is.

645
00:29:49.240 --> 00:29:52.160
Or if you're rotating an object,
what the rotation value is.

646
00:29:52.160 --> 00:29:52.960
Should be a little gray box.

647
00:29:52.960 --> 00:29:56.148
I tend to have that turned off because
that's just too much information for me.

648
00:29:56.148 --> 00:29:59.672
And also smart spacing, that's where
we set up those three items and

649
00:29:59.672 --> 00:30:01.550
how much gap was between each.

650
00:30:01.550 --> 00:30:03.914
You can decide which
things you want to show.

651
00:30:03.914 --> 00:30:08.539
But we can also turn on and off Smart
Guides altogether if you right-click or

652
00:30:08.539 --> 00:30:10.570
or Ctrl+click on the artboard.

653
00:30:10.570 --> 00:30:13.667
Don't have anything selected
when you do this, right-click or

654
00:30:13.667 --> 00:30:18.010
Ctrl+click come down to Grids & Guides and
you can turn on or off Smart Guides here.

655
00:30:18.010 --> 00:30:20.190
So, if you want them off altogether,
just turn them off.

656
00:30:20.190 --> 00:30:23.010
So, the nice thing is I leave all the
options selected, I can turn it off when

657
00:30:23.010 --> 00:30:26.550
I don't want it, turn it right back on but
all my options are still there exactly.

658
00:30:26.550 --> 00:30:31.490
And again, that smart dimensions should be
showing a little gray box as we drag and

659
00:30:31.490 --> 00:30:33.100
it's not for whatever reason.

660
00:30:33.100 --> 00:30:35.091
So we're gonna call that a bug,
not a feature.

661
00:30:35.091 --> 00:30:37.406
And yeah, so that's Smart Guide.

662
00:30:37.406 --> 00:30:40.516
So I can actually work really quickly,
start pasting things together and

663
00:30:40.516 --> 00:30:42.420
know that things are lined up well.

664
00:30:42.420 --> 00:30:46.000
But I can do it sort of haphazardly but
not exactly.

665
00:30:46.000 --> 00:30:48.080
That's kind of putting
some elements on the page.

666
00:30:48.080 --> 00:30:50.580
We got our guides to figure out
where elements need to go and

667
00:30:50.580 --> 00:30:52.790
we know how to draw some simple elements.

668
00:30:52.790 --> 00:30:56.380
So we'll start making some changes to
those simple elements in a future episode.

669
00:30:56.380 --> 00:30:58.990
>> I can see where those smart guides
would definitely assist you in

670
00:30:58.990 --> 00:31:00.680
making things look a little
bit more symmetric.

671
00:31:00.680 --> 00:31:03.450
Now it does look like we are coming
to the end of another episode.

672
00:31:03.450 --> 00:31:07.180
But Erica, before we sign out, do you have
any additional words you'd like to say?

673
00:31:07.180 --> 00:31:09.860
>> No, I think we've pretty much said
everything we need to about elements.

674
00:31:09.860 --> 00:31:12.870
So we're just ready to put some more
stuff into those elements soon.

675
00:31:12.870 --> 00:31:14.720
>> Well, that's great and
I look forward to seeing you.

676
00:31:14.720 --> 00:31:16.231
Thank you for joining us in the studio and

677
00:31:16.231 --> 00:31:18.020
thank you to the viewer out there for
watching.

678
00:31:18.020 --> 00:31:20.949
Signing out at ITPro.tv,
I've been your host, Wes Bryan.

679
00:31:20.949 --> 00:31:22.193
>> And I'm Erica Gamet.

680
00:31:22.193 --> 00:31:23.601
>> And we'll see you next time.

681
00:31:23.601 --> 00:31:32.360
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Erica explore frames and paths within InDesign. They explain selecting, moving, copying, duplicating and resizing frames. They look at path concepts like points, segments, control handles and corner points. They demonstrate how to close a path, modifying paths through the Convert Direction Tool as well as moving and modifying points.
episodes.title: Frames and Paths
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:11.884 --> 00:00:14.702
Welcome back to another great
episode here at IT Pro TV.

3
00:00:14.702 --> 00:00:16.260
I'm your host, Wes Bryan.

4
00:00:16.260 --> 00:00:18.740
And in today's episode we're
continuing through our series in

5
00:00:18.740 --> 00:00:20.490
the Adobe Creative Cloud 2015.

6
00:00:20.490 --> 00:00:23.310
More specifically,
we're diving into InDesign.

7
00:00:23.310 --> 00:00:26.220
And joining me in the studios for
this endeavor is Erica Gamet.

8
00:00:26.220 --> 00:00:27.100
Erica, how you doing?

9
00:00:27.100 --> 00:00:28.090
>> Good, Wes.
How are you?

10
00:00:28.090 --> 00:00:29.215
>> All right.
Great today.

11
00:00:29.215 --> 00:00:31.765
And so, what is the next topic that
we're gonna be looking at today?

12
00:00:31.765 --> 00:00:34.075
>> We're gonna start in
with some frames and paths.

13
00:00:34.075 --> 00:00:36.395
So we're gonna take some of
the elements that we've created and

14
00:00:36.395 --> 00:00:38.725
we're gonna start doing stuff to them.

15
00:00:38.725 --> 00:00:41.740
Transforming them,
moving them around on a page.

16
00:00:41.740 --> 00:00:43.940
And then we're also going
to work with paths as well,

17
00:00:43.940 --> 00:00:45.500
which is kind of what
our frames are made of.

18
00:00:45.500 --> 00:00:47.252
So we're gonna go ahead and jump in.

19
00:00:47.252 --> 00:00:51.240
I'm gonna jump into a file that
I've used recently called elements.

20
00:00:51.240 --> 00:00:53.730
We've got some elements on the page, and

21
00:00:53.730 --> 00:00:58.520
I'm gonna jump to a page here, this page,
unassigned frames and polygons.

22
00:00:58.520 --> 00:01:00.520
I talked about the different
types of frames.

23
00:01:00.520 --> 00:01:02.930
We have graphics frames,
and just playing frames,

24
00:01:02.930 --> 00:01:05.130
or unassigned frames is
what they call them.

25
00:01:05.130 --> 00:01:07.790
We can just call them shapes,
that's what I usually call them.

26
00:01:07.790 --> 00:01:09.690
And we're gonna make changes to them, and

27
00:01:09.690 --> 00:01:13.500
it doesn't matter if they're graphics
frames or if there shapes frames.

28
00:01:13.500 --> 00:01:16.660
This is just how we adjust
elements that are on the page.

29
00:01:16.660 --> 00:01:18.820
So we do things like resize them,
move them, and

30
00:01:18.820 --> 00:01:21.710
then we're gonna start
putting stuff into them soon.

31
00:01:21.710 --> 00:01:23.945
All right, so
let's just take a look at some of those.

32
00:01:23.945 --> 00:01:26.730
I'm using a keyboard shortcut you can see,
hopefully.

33
00:01:26.730 --> 00:01:31.580
Its Cmd+Space, or Ctrl+Space on a PC, and
it just brings up the marquee zoom, so

34
00:01:31.580 --> 00:01:34.600
when I slide across it I can
actually zoom in on that item.

35
00:01:34.600 --> 00:01:36.810
You will notice, though,
I get the spotlight search that comes up.

36
00:01:36.810 --> 00:01:39.420
That's a Mac thing,
it uses the same keyboard shortcut,

37
00:01:39.420 --> 00:01:42.350
which is a little annoying, I know,
but just pretend that the spotlight

38
00:01:42.350 --> 00:01:45.900
one doesn't come up there because I do
have to have both of those on there.

39
00:01:45.900 --> 00:01:46.940
All right, so let's modify them.

40
00:01:46.940 --> 00:01:48.480
I've got a frame, like I said.

41
00:01:48.480 --> 00:01:50.648
I created that using the frame tool.

42
00:01:50.648 --> 00:01:53.575
So we come over here to the frame tool,
I've got the shape tool and

43
00:01:53.575 --> 00:01:57.415
the graphics shaper, the graphics frame
tool, or each one is individually named,

44
00:01:57.415 --> 00:01:59.605
the rectangle, the ellipse, the polygon.

45
00:01:59.605 --> 00:02:02.075
So, you can basically call it
graphics frame, and just a frame.

46
00:02:02.075 --> 00:02:04.950
That's, I tend to put it that way.

47
00:02:04.950 --> 00:02:07.640
So, to select either one,
we drew a frame by clicking,

48
00:02:07.640 --> 00:02:09.710
dragging and drawing out that shape.

49
00:02:09.710 --> 00:02:12.580
I'm gonna delete that cuz I
already have one here, and

50
00:02:12.580 --> 00:02:13.850
I'm gonna use the Selection tool.

51
00:02:14.870 --> 00:02:18.660
I mentioned in a very, very early episode,
that we have two Selection tools.

52
00:02:18.660 --> 00:02:20.910
We have a Selection tool and
a Direct Selection tool.

53
00:02:20.910 --> 00:02:23.830
And the Selection tool,
or the solid arrow or

54
00:02:23.830 --> 00:02:27.680
the black arrow, is used for
grabbing or selecting or

55
00:02:27.680 --> 00:02:32.870
modifying a container, a frame, as
opposed to the content within that frame.

56
00:02:32.870 --> 00:02:34.520
So, for this demonstration,

57
00:02:34.520 --> 00:02:38.260
we're just going to go ahead and
select the frame itself and work with it.

58
00:02:38.260 --> 00:02:40.190
So when I use the Selection tool,

59
00:02:40.190 --> 00:02:43.580
I'm gonna just click on
anywhere on that graphic.

60
00:02:43.580 --> 00:02:45.110
Now, I can click in the middle.

61
00:02:45.110 --> 00:02:46.510
And you notice, it didn't get selected.

62
00:02:46.510 --> 00:02:49.140
Hopefully, you can see that, that it
didn't, as opposed to when I select here.

63
00:02:49.140 --> 00:02:51.960
I get my handles that show up,
and it's selected.

64
00:02:51.960 --> 00:02:54.030
When I click in the middle, it did not.

65
00:02:54.030 --> 00:02:59.690
And that's because I have this frame, and
if I click on it, I can look down here,

66
00:02:59.690 --> 00:03:03.010
and we're gonna go into color and
fills and strokes in a future episode.

67
00:03:03.010 --> 00:03:06.590
But I can see just by looking at that,
that I have no fill, and

68
00:03:06.590 --> 00:03:09.670
I have a stroke,
which means I have the line around it.

69
00:03:09.670 --> 00:03:13.270
And because I have nothing in the middle,
when I click in the middle,

70
00:03:13.270 --> 00:03:16.720
if I just click in the middle,
it's like nothing's there.

71
00:03:16.720 --> 00:03:18.770
It's just basically this big,
empty frame, so

72
00:03:18.770 --> 00:03:21.520
when I'm clicking,
I'm clicking the page back behind it.

73
00:03:21.520 --> 00:03:24.040
So I need to be aware of that,
that to select an item,

74
00:03:24.040 --> 00:03:29.300
I either need to click on the frame edges
or I can click and drag across items.

75
00:03:29.300 --> 00:03:32.320
I can click and
drag across multiple items that way.

76
00:03:32.320 --> 00:03:34.815
So, if I wanted to drag across everything,
I could do that.

77
00:03:34.815 --> 00:03:38.440
So, to select just one item,
though, I'm just gonna click on it.

78
00:03:38.440 --> 00:03:41.220
And again, when I do that,
I'm gonna zoom in so you can see that,

79
00:03:41.220 --> 00:03:44.250
when I roll over an item, and
I have something that can be selected,

80
00:03:44.250 --> 00:03:47.170
I get that little square at
the bottom that tells me something

81
00:03:47.170 --> 00:03:49.690
is underneath my cursor and
ready to be clicked on.

82
00:03:49.690 --> 00:03:51.780
So when I click on it,
now that's selected.

83
00:03:51.780 --> 00:03:52.480
Gonna zoom back out.

84
00:03:53.520 --> 00:03:57.260
So I have that Item selected,
I now have the grab handles, and

85
00:03:57.260 --> 00:03:58.460
there's nine grab handles.

86
00:03:58.460 --> 00:04:00.620
There's three across the top,
three across the bottom.

87
00:04:00.620 --> 00:04:03.210
And the sides, and
I also have this one here.

88
00:04:03.210 --> 00:04:04.780
So just the one in the middle.

89
00:04:04.780 --> 00:04:07.940
So, even though I don' have anything
technically to grab in the middle,

90
00:04:07.940 --> 00:04:13.120
I can when I select that, I can grab
it by that center and move it as well.

91
00:04:13.120 --> 00:04:14.730
But I can't just grab anywhere.

92
00:04:14.730 --> 00:04:17.430
If I grab here, again,
I'm just clicking through that.

93
00:04:17.430 --> 00:04:21.930
So I'm gonna click and drag, and I'm
gonna grab one of these corner handles.

94
00:04:21.930 --> 00:04:24.830
I'm gong to ignore this blue one and
this yellow one.

95
00:04:24.830 --> 00:04:25.520
Thos are special.

96
00:04:25.520 --> 00:04:26.870
And they keep adding them.

97
00:04:26.870 --> 00:04:30.740
I keep joking that by CC22 or whatever,

98
00:04:30.740 --> 00:04:33.962
we're going to have Christmas lights all
the way around the whole outside of that.

99
00:04:33.962 --> 00:04:36.740
Because there's always something new
that they're adding to the outside.

100
00:04:36.740 --> 00:04:40.080
The ones we're going to work with,
are these hollow ones on the corner and

101
00:04:40.080 --> 00:04:41.750
in the center of each line.

102
00:04:41.750 --> 00:04:44.370
So, basically, to size an object,
it's pretty easy.

103
00:04:44.370 --> 00:04:47.960
I can grab it by the corner, and
I get that double headed arrow.

104
00:04:47.960 --> 00:04:50.040
Zoom in so you can see that as well.

105
00:04:50.040 --> 00:04:52.590
So I get that double headed arrow
when I get close to a corner.

106
00:04:52.590 --> 00:04:56.840
And InDesign's smart enough, it says,
you're near a corner, let's change it.

107
00:04:56.840 --> 00:04:58.224
But it changes to something else here, and

108
00:04:58.224 --> 00:04:59.750
we're gonna look at that
in a minute as well.

109
00:04:59.750 --> 00:05:02.850
So, depending on how close we are to what,
it changes.

110
00:05:02.850 --> 00:05:06.820
So, I don't have to change between tools,
I'm just still using the Selection tool.

111
00:05:06.820 --> 00:05:09.330
All right, so I'm gonna zoom back out.

112
00:05:09.330 --> 00:05:11.850
I can grab that, and I can drag in.

113
00:05:11.850 --> 00:05:14.870
Now, I can either drag really quickly, and

114
00:05:14.870 --> 00:05:18.550
depending on the preferences that I have
set up and how quick your system is,

115
00:05:18.550 --> 00:05:22.610
you may or may not actually see
it being drawn as you drag.

116
00:05:22.610 --> 00:05:26.780
So, if I click and drag, you might
not see anything until you let go.

117
00:05:26.780 --> 00:05:29.140
If that's the case,
if you click and hold for

118
00:05:29.140 --> 00:05:33.900
a split second, then start dragging,
you will actually see the outline of that.

119
00:05:33.900 --> 00:05:37.430
So again, it's all set on preferences and
your processor speed.

120
00:05:37.430 --> 00:05:41.320
But if you're not seeing what you need,
a lot of times just stop and hold it for

121
00:05:41.320 --> 00:05:44.470
a second, and
then you'll get this live preview.

122
00:05:44.470 --> 00:05:45.550
So we can size it that way.

123
00:05:45.550 --> 00:05:48.610
I can obviously just size
it by one side or another.

124
00:05:48.610 --> 00:05:51.190
So if I use the side handles
as opposed to the corner,

125
00:05:51.190 --> 00:05:53.850
I'm only moving it in one direction.

126
00:05:53.850 --> 00:05:55.200
So I can move that.

127
00:05:55.200 --> 00:05:58.590
I can also hold down
the Option on the Alt key and

128
00:05:58.590 --> 00:06:02.197
have it just like when we drew it from
the center outwards using the Option or

129
00:06:02.197 --> 00:06:06.100
Alt key, I can also resize
it from the center inwards.

130
00:06:06.100 --> 00:06:09.250
So if I'm grabbing a corner handle and
holding the Option key, or

131
00:06:09.250 --> 00:06:13.190
Alt key on the PC, I can come in here,
and when I drag in,

132
00:06:13.190 --> 00:06:17.740
it's now sizing down from all sides
because I'm choosing the corner.

133
00:06:17.740 --> 00:06:20.920
So, it's coming on all sides,
it's being drawn in.

134
00:06:20.920 --> 00:06:23.070
But it's doing it from the center inward.

135
00:06:23.070 --> 00:06:27.920
If I hold on a Shift key at the same time,
it's drawing it proportionally.

136
00:06:27.920 --> 00:06:30.650
So, it works exactly the opposite
as we created the item.

137
00:06:30.650 --> 00:06:35.900
Now, I can resize it using the same Option
or Alt key and the Shift key as well.

138
00:06:35.900 --> 00:06:38.920
If I drag from the side and
hold on the Option key,

139
00:06:38.920 --> 00:06:43.090
it's only going to bring in the two sides,
but again, from the center outwards.

140
00:06:43.090 --> 00:06:44.690
That's the Option or the Alt key on a PC.

141
00:06:44.690 --> 00:06:48.515
And so
that's pretty much how we resize items.

142
00:06:48.515 --> 00:06:50.765
Do the same thing here if I select this.

143
00:06:50.765 --> 00:06:55.815
Now, you notice this one, I selected a
circle but I still have a rectangular box.

144
00:06:55.815 --> 00:06:59.345
So I said before that everything
in InDesign lives in a frame.

145
00:06:59.345 --> 00:07:03.860
Well, those frames are all technically
rectangular, even circles.

146
00:07:03.860 --> 00:07:05.040
Even stars.

147
00:07:05.040 --> 00:07:06.480
It's called a bounding box.

148
00:07:06.480 --> 00:07:09.870
So everything lives inside this bounding
box, and it has to be rectangular.

149
00:07:09.870 --> 00:07:13.710
So when I size this down, I'm still
gonna grab these corner handles, even

150
00:07:13.710 --> 00:07:18.420
though I'm really changing the size of the
circle, without manipulating the shape.

151
00:07:18.420 --> 00:07:19.810
It's still circular.

152
00:07:19.810 --> 00:07:22.690
Same thing, hold down the Shift key and
it's proportional.

153
00:07:22.690 --> 00:07:26.140
If I hold a second,
I can actually see as I drag it.

154
00:07:26.140 --> 00:07:29.850
Hold on the Option or the ALT key, and
it drags it, draws it from the center.

155
00:07:31.190 --> 00:07:33.720
Go to the Option key,
keep the Shift key selected,

156
00:07:33.720 --> 00:07:36.270
I get a proportion,
same thing with the polygon.

157
00:07:36.270 --> 00:07:39.373
One of the other things we can do
with a polygon, oris we can also, or

158
00:07:39.373 --> 00:07:42.220
any shape,
we can change it to another shape.

159
00:07:42.220 --> 00:07:45.510
So if I go up into the object menu and
come down to convert shape,

160
00:07:45.510 --> 00:07:48.110
I can now convert this
star to something else.

161
00:07:48.110 --> 00:07:49.800
I can convert it to an ellipse.

162
00:07:49.800 --> 00:07:52.950
So it's suddenly a circle, and
it's always gonna fill the bounding box.

163
00:07:52.950 --> 00:07:54.530
So that might not look great.

164
00:07:54.530 --> 00:07:55.268
If I undo that,

165
00:07:55.268 --> 00:07:59.130
Cmd- or Ctrl-Z to go backwards, that looks
like a pretty proportional star to me.

166
00:07:59.130 --> 00:08:00.620
It looks like pretty good, right?

167
00:08:00.620 --> 00:08:02.226
It's exactly the same on all sides.

168
00:08:02.226 --> 00:08:06.011
But when I converted that to a circle, you
could see that it was slightly flattened.

169
00:08:06.011 --> 00:08:07.678
It wasn't quite a perfect circle.

170
00:08:07.678 --> 00:08:10.691
So whenever I made that I obviously
didn't hold down my Shift key, but

171
00:08:10.691 --> 00:08:12.185
converting shape is pretty easy.

172
00:08:12.185 --> 00:08:15.521
I can choose to have it convert to
a polygon, and when I do that you think,

173
00:08:15.521 --> 00:08:17.110
well it was a polygon.

174
00:08:17.110 --> 00:08:21.040
It automatically uses the last
input that we did when we created.

175
00:08:21.040 --> 00:08:23.930
The last time I created a polygon
we made a starburst, and so

176
00:08:23.930 --> 00:08:26.120
that's what worked its
way into that as well.

177
00:08:26.120 --> 00:08:27.330
So I can always change that.

178
00:08:27.330 --> 00:08:32.170
I can also change it if I wanna change
to the polygon-shaped tool here.

179
00:08:32.170 --> 00:08:35.310
I can double click on that and
I can change the size.

180
00:08:35.310 --> 00:08:40.100
Let's do that, and we'll say 20, change
that I can change that after the fact if I

181
00:08:40.100 --> 00:08:42.990
didnt like how many sides there were.

182
00:08:42.990 --> 00:08:46.770
Because when I drew that I was able to use
my up and down arrow keys to add sides and

183
00:08:46.770 --> 00:08:48.560
that star pinch that was there.

184
00:08:48.560 --> 00:08:52.510

00:16:05.550 --> 00:16:09.420
So stacking order is basically how
things have been put on a page.

344
00:16:09.420 --> 00:16:13.707
So when I put an item on a page,
and I put another item on a page,

345
00:16:13.707 --> 00:16:16.690
it knows that that second
item is on top of.

346
00:16:16.690 --> 00:16:19.170
So it's be kind of like if you started
on putting things on the table.

347
00:16:19.170 --> 00:16:22.580
You have your little cutout of a rectangle
and you put it on a table, and

348
00:16:22.580 --> 00:16:26.170
you take the green circle and you put
that on top of it, and it's on top of it.

349
00:16:26.170 --> 00:16:31.560
Even if it's not technically touching it,
it keeps track of what order it went in.

350
00:16:31.560 --> 00:16:33.500
There's a lot of reasons
why that's important.

351
00:16:33.500 --> 00:16:36.100
One is, when I stack them
all up on top of each other,

352
00:16:36.100 --> 00:16:38.885
one of them obviously blocks
out the one that's behind.

353
00:16:38.885 --> 00:16:42.529
When you get into things like doing
automation, doing automatic captions,

354
00:16:42.529 --> 00:16:45.179
and things like that,
it knows what order you put it in.

355
00:16:45.179 --> 00:16:47.387
And then that's how it's going
to automatically number it.

356
00:16:47.387 --> 00:16:48.620
It's the only way it knows.

357
00:16:48.620 --> 00:16:50.350
It doesn't know what you're thinking,
so it says, hey,

358
00:16:50.350 --> 00:16:53.310
this is the order she put them in,
this must be the order that they go in.

359
00:16:53.310 --> 00:16:56.120
So always be aware of that,
but you can change it.

00:19:02.040 --> 00:19:02.580
I can click.

00:19:02.580 --> 00:19:05.170
And I can still grab that star.

00:19:05.170 --> 00:19:07.930
Let's move it so we can't, let's go

00:19:10.010 --> 00:19:13.090
And we'll close that up so we don't see

00:19:13.090 --> 00:19:16.500
If I click on this item all I keep
clicking on is that rectangle.

411
00:19:16.500 --> 00:19:20.210
But I can drill down through the stacking
order by hitting the command key or

412
00:19:20.210 --> 00:19:22.970
the control key on a PC and
when I do that, and actually,

00:19:22.970 --> 00:19:24.110
let's put this guy up front too.

00:19:24.110 --> 00:19:25.890
I want to put them all here,

00:19:25.890 --> 00:19:28.140
because now I have to drill

416
00:19:28.140 --> 00:19:32.229
So I'm gonna select first that first item,
that green circle.

417
00:19:32.229 --> 00:19:33.411
I clicked on it, that's what happened.

418
00:19:33.411 --> 00:19:36.970
If I keep clicking, that's all it does

00:19:36.970 --> 00:19:39.010
I want to click the rectangle behind it.

00:19:39.010 --> 00:19:41.000
Now granted in this case I

00:19:41.000 --> 00:19:44.060
But let's for clarity sake we're

422
00:19:44.060 --> 00:19:47.510
I'm gonna hold down the command key or
the control key and click again.

423
00:19:47.510 --> 00:19:51.200
Now it grabs the next thing down In the
stacking order, which is that rectangle.

424
00:19:51.200 --> 00:19:56.240
In a command or control click one more
time, and now I've got a square selected.

425
00:19:56.240 --> 00:19:57.280

00:19:57.280 --> 00:20:00.370

00:20:01.110 --> 00:20:03.850

00:20:03.850 --> 00:20:04.960
So I can drill down.

00:20:04.960 --> 00:20:08.350
Now I can do stuff like I knew it was

00:20:08.350 --> 00:20:09.029

00:20:09.029 --> 00:20:11.370

00:20:11.370 --> 00:20:13.680

00:20:16.770 --> 00:20:19.590
But, you would have to be careful,

00:20:19.590 --> 00:20:22.560

00:20:22.560 --> 00:20:26.930
What I tend to do is hold on to that or,

00:20:28.070 --> 00:20:31.660

00:20:31.660 --> 00:20:33.560

00:20:33.560 --> 00:20:35.800

00:20:35.800 --> 00:20:38.710
That's what we always used to have to do,

00:20:38.710 --> 00:20:40.990

00:20:40.990 --> 00:20:42.740

00:20:42.740 --> 00:20:44.770
we can drill down through

00:20:44.770 --> 00:20:48.310
So just keep in mind as you put things

00:20:49.630 --> 00:20:51.930
>> Erica,
it looks like if you're new to this, and

00:20:56.200 --> 00:20:59.000
what object you're selecting,

00:20:59.000 --> 00:21:02.390
So would you say definitely pay
attention to the cursor and

00:21:02.390 --> 00:21:04.790
definitely pay attention
to what you're selecting?

00:21:04.790 --> 00:21:07.260
Absolutely, and that's kind of
why I like to use the arrow key,

00:21:07.260 --> 00:21:10.590
because once I select it
>> If I grab it and move it, and

00:21:10.590 --> 00:21:12.510
I just move that,
say that rectangle like I did and

00:21:12.510 --> 00:21:14.790
it was exactly where I needed it,
and maybe I didn't have guides or

00:21:14.790 --> 00:21:17.070
I didn't have it locked down,

00:21:17.070 --> 00:21:18.780
I mean I probably could do undo, but

00:21:18.780 --> 00:21:21.660
sometimes you forget where you

00:21:21.660 --> 00:21:25.530
So yea so I always pay attention to that

00:21:25.530 --> 00:21:28.260
I try to keep an eye on that as

00:21:28.260 --> 00:21:29.130
that's not going to help you.

00:21:29.130 --> 00:21:32.170
But yeah, once I select something I

00:21:32.170 --> 00:21:35.290

00:21:43.965 --> 00:21:45.505

00:21:45.505 --> 00:21:48.835
But definitely you have to keep

469
00:21:48.835 --> 00:21:51.505
So that's pretty much how we

00:21:51.505 --> 00:21:52.525

00:21:52.525 --> 00:21:56.460
And like I said, keep in mind that there's

00:21:56.460 --> 00:22:00.190

00:22:00.190 --> 00:22:02.380
So we kind of see how everything

00:22:02.380 --> 00:22:03.770
We've got the stacking order, and

475
00:22:03.770 --> 00:22:06.279
then after that we also have layers
stacked on top of each other.

476
00:22:06.279 --> 00:22:08.892
So again we sort of keeping track at
least with layers we have a little bit of

00:22:08.892 --> 00:22:09.407

00:22:09.407 --> 00:22:13.380
With a stacking order all you have is

My other option that I can do,

00:25:24.780 --> 00:25:27.580

624
00:29:08.040 --> 00:29:12.120
you wanna make sure that they're hollow
and so it's really an awkward thing.

625
00:29:12.120 --> 00:29:14.670
Sometimes change to
the Direct Selection tool,

626
00:29:14.670 --> 00:29:17.860
click off of it,
now just click right on that point.

627
00:29:17.860 --> 00:29:20.470
For whatever reason, sometimes it just
wants to grab it and move it, but

628
00:29:20.470 --> 00:29:23.420
what I really wanted was to be
able to grab just that segment.

629
00:29:23.420 --> 00:29:26.060
It's a tricky thing and sometimes
you find yourself clicking off and

630
00:29:26.060 --> 00:29:27.780
clicking off just to get to what you need.

631
00:29:27.780 --> 00:29:29.570
But I can change that,

632
00:29:29.570 --> 00:29:32.530
I'm just gonna drag this out here and
make something crazy like that.

633
00:29:32.530 --> 00:29:34.350
Now I've got a little rocket ship going,
right.

634
00:29:34.350 --> 00:29:39.410
So I can change the actual points and
segments that

635
00:29:39.410 --> 00:29:43.240
make up this path that we created with the
tools, just that tool made it easy to do.

636
00:29:44.250 --> 00:29:48.340
Couple of the other items that are under
the Pen tool when we're manipulating,

637
00:29:48.340 --> 00:29:51.210
is the Add Anchor Point and
Delete Anchor Point tool.

638
00:29:51.210 --> 00:29:54.940
So if I decide I needed some more
anchor points, I could do that as well.

639
00:29:54.940 --> 00:29:58.420
So by doing the plus, when I get close
I can see the little plus that shows up

640
00:29:58.420 --> 00:30:01.970
on my cursor and
I can add extra points along the way.

641
00:30:01.970 --> 00:30:06.010
So if I click on, let's actually select
this with the Direct Selection tool,

642
00:30:06.010 --> 00:30:07.200
here's one of those tricky things.

643
00:30:07.200 --> 00:30:10.680
I've got it selected,
go back to the Add Anchor Point tool and

644
00:30:10.680 --> 00:30:12.840
click on a line, there we go.

645
00:30:12.840 --> 00:30:16.190
And I've just added some points to that.

646
00:30:16.190 --> 00:30:18.805
So now I have even more points
I can grab and pull and

647
00:30:18.805 --> 00:30:21.936
put little spikeys on the star or
whatever it is I need to do.

648
00:30:21.936 --> 00:30:24.825
I can also delete points
if there are too many.

649
00:30:24.825 --> 00:30:27.480
Maybe I don't like this one here,
I can just delete that and

650
00:30:27.480 --> 00:30:30.480
it automatically gets rid
of that line that's there.

651
00:30:30.480 --> 00:30:33.880
Now InDesign's smart enough,
if I have just the Pen tool,

652
00:30:33.880 --> 00:30:37.756
it knows that if I'm near a point,
as I roll over an existing point,

653
00:30:37.756 --> 00:30:40.488
it will say do you wanna
delete that point?

654
00:30:40.488 --> 00:30:41.645
Yes I do.

655
00:30:41.645 --> 00:30:45.690
If I roll over a segment it
says do you wanna add a point?

656
00:30:45.690 --> 00:30:47.770
So I don't even need to
switch to that Add and

657
00:30:47.770 --> 00:30:50.760
Delete Anchor Point tool,
it's smart enough to know that.

658
00:30:50.760 --> 00:30:53.980
However, if you've got lots of points
together and you're trying to delete some

659
00:30:53.980 --> 00:30:57.290
and add some, it can get confused
if you're not super accurate so

660
00:30:57.290 --> 00:30:59.510
I tend to switch back and forth.

661
00:30:59.510 --> 00:31:03.240
And the last tool that's on here is
the Convert Direction Point tool.

662
00:31:03.240 --> 00:31:05.840
And this basically says,
you have a hard corner point and

663
00:31:05.840 --> 00:31:07.775
you want it to be a smooth curve?

664
00:31:07.775 --> 00:31:08.853
You can do that.

665
00:31:08.853 --> 00:31:10.155
Or if you've got a smooth curve,

666
00:31:10.155 --> 00:31:13.105
we'll have to go back to the page that
has some smooth curves, here we go.

667
00:31:13.105 --> 00:31:15.935
I'm gonna select this one with
the Direct Selection tool,

668
00:31:15.935 --> 00:31:18.765
go back to the Convert Anchor Point.

669
00:31:18.765 --> 00:31:20.860
and this convert,
with this nice smooth curve that's here,

670
00:31:20.860 --> 00:31:24.430
I'm gonna click on it once and
it makes that hard corner point.

671
00:31:24.430 --> 00:31:25.550
Or I can take a hard corner point,

672
00:31:25.550 --> 00:31:28.700
which we just created,
and click and drag it out.

673
00:31:28.700 --> 00:31:31.300
Sometimes you drag it the wrong way and
you'll get this nice twist in your line.

674
00:31:31.300 --> 00:31:32.710
Make sure you drag the right way.

675
00:31:32.710 --> 00:31:36.350
But again, I can select that and
now I can grab these handles as well

676
00:31:36.350 --> 00:31:40.570
with the Drect Selection tool and
I can change those individually.

677
00:31:40.570 --> 00:31:44.848
I can also hold down the Option or the Alt
key and just grab one of the handles.

678
00:31:44.848 --> 00:31:48.414
Right, so I can change it that way,
get it back to that corner point and

679
00:31:48.414 --> 00:31:50.390
just manipulate it that way.

680
00:31:50.390 --> 00:31:53.560
There's some websites on line about, there
used to be one called Zen of the Pen and

681
00:31:53.560 --> 00:31:55.220
I think he'since changed.

682
00:31:55.220 --> 00:31:57.575
But if you do a Google search
on Zen of the Pen you'll find,

683
00:31:57.575 --> 00:31:59.278
I think it's switched over to a blog now.

684
00:31:59.278 --> 00:32:01.525
But he has got some great tips for
drawing and

685
00:32:01.525 --> 00:32:03.602
a lot of time he shows it in Illustrator.

686
00:32:03.602 --> 00:32:07.111
But if it's just pen stuff,
it works just as well in InDesign.

687
00:32:07.111 --> 00:32:10.575
So it's the same sort of stuff, it still
understands, it's still just vector,

688
00:32:10.575 --> 00:32:13.461
it's still math, it's still figuring
out how it needs to draw it.

689
00:32:13.461 --> 00:32:15.472
It's just that you don't have
as many tools to work with, but

690
00:32:15.472 --> 00:32:16.487
you've got some great tools.

691
00:32:16.487 --> 00:32:20.661
For instance, if I were wanting to make
a frame, maybe to put some text in or

692
00:32:20.661 --> 00:32:22.120
whatever.

693
00:32:22.120 --> 00:32:26.340
I might just come in here and say,
I just want this frame right here and

694
00:32:26.340 --> 00:32:27.670
that's my frame.

695
00:32:27.670 --> 00:32:31.160
I don't want it to be a closed box, even
though it is and it sees it as that, but

696
00:32:31.160 --> 00:32:33.320
it only drew the frame on the outside.

697
00:32:33.320 --> 00:32:35.280
Now I can either fill that with color or
text or

698
00:32:35.280 --> 00:32:37.560
whatever, we'll add to
that as we go along.

699
00:32:37.560 --> 00:32:41.801
But I can make easy paths that way and
I can do things like I just want a nice

700
00:32:41.801 --> 00:32:45.225
little squiggle,
I'm going to hold down the Shift key.

701
00:32:45.225 --> 00:32:47.950
And hold down the Shift key and
here's where guides might come in handy.

702
00:32:47.950 --> 00:32:50.561
Put a guide across there so you know
you're always clicking in the same spot.

703
00:32:50.561 --> 00:32:52.710
But I can come in here and
make some waves.

704
00:32:52.710 --> 00:32:55.590
And i would make sure that each
one is exactly the same height.

705
00:32:55.590 --> 00:32:58.460
Smart guides help a little bit but
the spacing isn't great.

706
00:32:58.460 --> 00:33:02.060
But I can come in here and make that nice
little squiggle that's there as well.

707
00:33:02.060 --> 00:33:04.360
So sometimes you just
need a little element and

708
00:33:04.360 --> 00:33:07.060
you don't wanna go out to something
like Illustrator to get that done.

709
00:33:07.060 --> 00:33:09.450
Use the Pen tool inside InDesign.

710
00:33:09.450 --> 00:33:12.942
>> That's very great, in fact there's been
times when I have to draw an analogue wave

711
00:33:12.942 --> 00:33:14.950
and I can't tell you how many
times I've had to erase it.

712
00:33:14.950 --> 00:33:16.984
Cuz I can't draw a squiggly line,
let alone a straight line.

713
00:33:16.984 --> 00:33:17.987
>> Exactly.
[LAUGH]

714
00:33:17.987 --> 00:33:19.356
>> [LAUGH] All great information there,

715
00:33:19.356 --> 00:33:22.191
Erica, it does look like we're coming
to the end of another great episode.

716
00:33:22.191 --> 00:33:22.929
But before we do,

717
00:33:22.929 --> 00:33:25.782
do you have any additional words
you'd like to throw into this one?

718
00:33:25.782 --> 00:33:28.400
>> Nope, just know that you've got
the tools that you need to InDesign for

719
00:33:28.400 --> 00:33:30.062
a lot of this stuff that you need to do.

720
00:33:30.062 --> 00:33:32.076
>> Well, very good and thank you for
joining us in the studios and

721
00:33:32.076 --> 00:33:33.640
thank you to the viewer for
watching out there.

722
00:33:33.640 --> 00:33:36.526
Signing out for the ITProTV,
I've been your host Wes Bryan.

723
00:33:36.526 --> 00:33:37.438
>> And I'm Erica Gamet.

724
00:33:37.438 --> 00:33:39.453
>> And we'll see you next time.

725
00:33:39.453 --> 00:33:48.120
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Erica discuss placing assets within InDesign. They look at the import options, replace options and proportional frames. They talk about placing graphics in frames, native .psd and .ai files as well as placing multiple files.
episodes.title: Placing Assets
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:11.795 --> 00:00:14.540
Welcome back to another exiting
episode here at ITProTv,

3
00:00:14.540 --> 00:00:18.291
I'm your host West Brian and in today's
episode we're continuing through our

4
00:00:18.291 --> 00:00:20.481
Series in the Abode Creative Cloud 2015.

5
00:00:20.481 --> 00:00:24.270
More specifically,
we're focusing more on end design and

6
00:00:24.270 --> 00:00:26.630
joining me back in the studios
today is Erica Gambit.

7
00:00:26.630 --> 00:00:27.520
Erica how you doing?

8
00:00:27.520 --> 00:00:29.530
>> I'm doing great
>> All right, very good.

9
00:00:29.530 --> 00:00:31.810
So, we been talking about
many different topics now,

10
00:00:31.810 --> 00:00:33.620
whats the next thing we
are going to be learning about?

11
00:00:33.620 --> 00:00:36.130
>> We're going to start
placing stuff into InDesign.

12
00:00:36.130 --> 00:00:39.880
So up until this point we've been creating
things using the tools that are built in,

13
00:00:39.880 --> 00:00:43.910
we've been looking at the environment,
starting to put a little structure to it,

14
00:00:43.910 --> 00:00:45.792
and then we started to
build some simple shapes.

15
00:00:45.792 --> 00:00:49.990
We're gonna actually bring in stuff from
other places, because that's what InDesign

16
00:00:49.990 --> 00:00:53.650
is for, really, it's for
taking all these assets From everywhere,

17
00:00:53.650 --> 00:00:58.100
whether it's a type that we're putting in
InDesign, bringing photos from Photoshop,

18
00:00:58.100 --> 00:01:00.680
we're bringing in vector
graphics from Illustrator and

19
00:01:00.680 --> 00:01:02.940
we're gonna put them all
together in one place.

20
00:01:02.940 --> 00:01:04.370
It's kinda like the aggregator.

21
00:01:04.370 --> 00:01:06.500
It's where we put everything together for
output.

22
00:01:06.500 --> 00:01:09.150
Whether that's a PDF or print or whatever.

23
00:01:09.150 --> 00:01:10.640
But we need to start putting
some stuff in here, and

24
00:01:10.640 --> 00:01:12.120
we need to bring those
in from other places.

25
00:01:12.120 --> 00:01:15.370
So, we're gonna place some assets and
I'm gonna call the assets because it

26
00:01:15.370 --> 00:01:18.390
could be graphics, it could be PDFs,
it could be all sorts of things.

27
00:01:18.390 --> 00:01:19.860
So, we'll call that assets.

28
00:01:19.860 --> 00:01:23.540
So, I'm gonna go ahead and jump into
InDesign and I'm gonna double click on

29
00:01:23.540 --> 00:01:26.800
this file that I have here called placing
and it's a big blank file because that's

30
00:01:26.800 --> 00:01:29.220
exactly what you're gonna be staring
at when you start working, right?

31
00:01:29.220 --> 00:01:32.880
We're gonna put some things like some
guides, I'm gonna hit my W key and bring

32
00:01:32.880 --> 00:01:36.120
in those guides and I actually have some
files here, I'm sorry, some elements here,

33
00:01:36.120 --> 00:01:39.840
I've got some frames that are graphics
frames, I know they're graphics frames

34
00:01:39.840 --> 00:01:44.040
because they have xs in the middle of them
and I'm gonna place some file in there.

35
00:01:44.040 --> 00:01:46.370
I am gonna add an extra page
that is completely blank,

36
00:01:46.370 --> 00:01:48.350
we're gonna come back to this page.

37
00:01:48.350 --> 00:01:52.140
So I'm just gonna do Command+Shift+P or
Ctrl+Shift+P on a PC.

38
00:01:52.140 --> 00:01:53.400
To add a new page.

39
00:01:53.400 --> 00:01:55.460
So we're gonna add a new blank page.

40
00:01:55.460 --> 00:01:56.780
The only thing it has on it are guides.

41
00:01:56.780 --> 00:01:58.550
But I'm gonna place some objects.

42
00:01:58.550 --> 00:02:04.500
So when you place something in InDesign,
whether it's a PDF or an Illustrator

43
00:02:04.500 --> 00:02:09.690
file or a Photoshop file or a tif or
an eps or jpg or whatever we have,

44
00:02:09.690 --> 00:02:13.500
we can put that in using the same exact
command, and that is the place command.

45
00:02:13.500 --> 00:02:17.540
It's Cmd or Ctrl+D or,
I'm gonna go back and

46
00:02:17.540 --> 00:02:19.030
show you what the met word is in the menu.

47
00:02:19.030 --> 00:02:21.250
It's file and then place.

48
00:02:21.250 --> 00:02:22.300
So, Cmd or Ctrl+D.

49
00:02:22.300 --> 00:02:25.550
So, no matter what it is we're placing,
we don't have to worry about

50
00:02:25.550 --> 00:02:27.640
remembering what is it we're placing and
choosing from a menu.

51
00:02:27.640 --> 00:02:28.360
We're just gonna place it.

52
00:02:28.360 --> 00:02:31.820
And design's smart enough, it says,
hey I need to place something.

53
00:02:31.820 --> 00:02:36.470
And I mentioned in earlier episode that
when we place stuff or create stuff,

54
00:02:36.470 --> 00:02:39.900
InDesign's smart enough to create a frame
because everything lives in a frame.

55
00:02:39.900 --> 00:02:43.430
And if you haven't created a frame,
then it creates one for you on the fly.

56
00:02:43.430 --> 00:02:45.710
So in this case I don't have
a frame on this page at all,

57
00:02:45.710 --> 00:02:49.060
we're gonna go back to that first page
that had all those graphics frames there

58
00:02:49.060 --> 00:02:51.080
and we'll put things into those frames.

59
00:02:51.080 --> 00:02:54.040
But in this case maybe I don't even know,
I don't know what size frame I need, or

60
00:02:54.040 --> 00:02:57.000
what shape frame or
what proportion anyway, obviously

61
00:02:57.000 --> 00:03:01.070
it's going to be rectangular to start
with, but I don't know what size I need.

62
00:03:01.070 --> 00:03:03.750
I'm going to do that based on
the image that I end up with.

63
00:03:03.750 --> 00:03:05.770
So I'm just going to go out and
it's going to say place and

64
00:03:05.770 --> 00:03:09.220
here I see everything
that's on my computer.

65
00:03:09.220 --> 00:03:11.810
So I have things over on the side bar,
I've got everything here.

66
00:03:11.810 --> 00:03:14.290
Let's go out to the desktop,
I'm going to do command or control D,

67
00:03:14.290 --> 00:03:17.410
I know that's just place and in design,
but when you are in this dialog box,

68
00:03:17.410 --> 00:03:20.390
now it's go to Desktop, and
that's a system based thing.

69
00:03:20.390 --> 00:03:25.270
So, we go on here, and I'm just gonna in
to where I have a bunch of images here.

70
00:03:25.270 --> 00:03:30.240
I have a folder called graphics and
photos, and in there I've got some AI

71
00:03:30.240 --> 00:03:35.720
files, I've got some layer coms, so
just sort of a nice collection of photos.

72
00:03:35.720 --> 00:03:39.260
And graphics that I have
that are out of Illustrator.

73
00:03:39.260 --> 00:03:42.470
Let's place something, so I'm gonna drill
down until I get to something interesting.

74
00:03:42.470 --> 00:03:44.010
Let's come here.

75
00:03:44.010 --> 00:03:46.480
Italy's always interesting let's
grab some pictures from Italy.

76
00:03:46.480 --> 00:03:49.190
And so I'm just gonna grab
one picture to start with.

77
00:03:49.190 --> 00:03:51.250
We're gonna look at putting
multiple one's at a time.

78
00:03:51.250 --> 00:03:53.040
But right now I'm just
gonna find one that I want,

79
00:03:53.040 --> 00:03:55.390
I get a nice Preview of it over here.

80
00:03:55.390 --> 00:03:56.430
It's a JPEG file.

81
00:03:56.430 --> 00:04:00.200
And I mentioned that you could
bring in JPEGs, EPS, TIFF.

82
00:04:00.200 --> 00:04:04.760
You can do PSDs, PNGs,
Illustrator files, PDFs.

83
00:04:04.760 --> 00:04:06.030
I think I mentioned PDFs.

84
00:04:06.030 --> 00:04:10.530
You can place all of those in there, and
it knows what to do with most of those.

85
00:04:10.530 --> 00:04:12.910
I'm gonna talk about some best
practices in just a few minutes.

86
00:04:12.910 --> 00:04:14.720
For right now, let's take this JPEG.

87
00:04:14.720 --> 00:04:18.950
This is something I took on probably
my cell phone, I don't remember, or

88
00:04:18.950 --> 00:04:20.090
maybe my digital camera.

89
00:04:20.090 --> 00:04:21.200
But it's digital.

90
00:04:21.200 --> 00:04:22.360
And it's JPEG.

91
00:04:22.360 --> 00:04:24.940
So down here I've got
a couple different options.

92
00:04:24.940 --> 00:04:27.280
I can show my import options.

93
00:04:27.280 --> 00:04:28.960
I can replace the selected item.

94
00:04:28.960 --> 00:04:29.740
And we can do captions.

95
00:04:29.740 --> 00:04:32.510
We're not going to worry about
captions at all right now.

96
00:04:32.510 --> 00:04:35.120
But replace selected item,
that means if I have a frame.

97
00:04:35.120 --> 00:04:37.720
already selected on my page.

98
00:04:37.720 --> 00:04:40.410
And I say replace selected item,
this image is going to

99
00:04:40.410 --> 00:04:44.640
wedge its way into that frame, and
whatever was in that frame before is gone.

100
00:04:44.640 --> 00:04:47.620
I almost always have that deselected.

101
00:04:47.620 --> 00:04:49.250
I believe it is on by default.

102
00:04:49.250 --> 00:04:52.720
But I'm one of those people that may
have something selected on page 13,

103
00:04:52.720 --> 00:04:56.710
I'm back on page two working and
I forgot that that frame was selected and

104
00:04:56.710 --> 00:04:59.040
I'm ready to place it and
I wonder where it is?

105
00:04:59.040 --> 00:04:59.910
Where did it go?

106
00:04:59.910 --> 00:05:02.550
That's cuz I just kicked out whatever
was in that frame on page 13.

107
00:05:02.550 --> 00:05:04.710
So I tend to turn that off.

108
00:05:04.710 --> 00:05:08.300
And, Show Import Options,
this is important many times.

109
00:05:08.300 --> 00:05:10.770
When I place an image though,
probably not important.

110
00:05:10.770 --> 00:05:12.930
What that does,
it brings up a second dialogue box.

111
00:05:12.930 --> 00:05:14.920
And says,
here's some options that you have.

112
00:05:14.920 --> 00:05:18.030
Depending on the file type,
your options will be different.

113
00:05:18.030 --> 00:05:19.540
I'm also gonna turn that off right now.

114
00:05:19.540 --> 00:05:21.470
We're gonna look at it in a few
minutes when we do need it.

115
00:05:21.470 --> 00:05:23.750
Right now I have those both turned off.

116
00:05:23.750 --> 00:05:26.050
And I'm just gonna select the one
that I need and say open.

117
00:05:26.050 --> 00:05:30.850
And when I do that, I now have
what's called a loaded place cursor.

118
00:05:30.850 --> 00:05:34.530
So it's or a place gun is what they call
it sometimes, which sounds like I should

119
00:05:34.530 --> 00:05:36.830

That happens to me all the time,

00:12:16.410 --> 00:12:20.190
So right now what the cursor looks like

00:12:20.190 --> 00:12:21.540
hopefully you can see it.

00:12:21.540 --> 00:12:25.030
On the upper left edge of the corner

when I do that, I roll over and

298
00:13:24.930 --> 00:13:29.170
So we have options how to get
things into our InDesign page.

299
00:13:30.828 --> 00:13:35.360
We want to make sure when we place
graphics that we place native files.

300
00:13:35.360 --> 00:13:39.910
So what that means is if I'm placing, if
Im working with the object in Photoshop,

301
00:13:39.910 --> 00:13:42.780
it's a photo or
what we call raster images.

302
00:13:42.780 --> 00:13:45.780
So hopefully you'll know the difference
between raster and vector.

303
00:13:45.780 --> 00:13:49.630
Raster is pixel based or
we got dots when we go to print it,

304
00:13:49.630 --> 00:13:55.730
that's pixel based on screen and
where in the It's photographic usually not

305
00:13:55.730 --> 00:14:00.000
necessarily, but anything is in Photoshop
is considered a rasterized graphic,

306
00:14:00.000 --> 00:14:02.890
if I'm working in Illustrator,
that's vector graphics.

307
00:14:02.890 --> 00:14:05.660
Now, each program can handle the other,
but

308
00:14:05.660 --> 00:14:11.530
basically Illustrator is a vector drawing
program and Photoshop raster program.

309
00:14:11.530 --> 00:14:14.600
So when I bring files in,
if I done them in Photoshop,

310
00:14:14.600 --> 00:14:18.330
or I want to bring them in,
in those native formats.

311
00:14:18.330 --> 00:14:23.060
So I want to bring in a Photoshop file,
if I can, or an Illustrator file.

312
00:14:23.060 --> 00:14:26.820
So that means a PSD file or an AI file.

313
00:14:26.820 --> 00:14:30.980
Back in the old days, when I started,
well, even after I started, but

314
00:14:30.980 --> 00:14:35.880
when I finally got into computers, you had
to save out as a TIFF file or an APS file.

315
00:14:35.880 --> 00:14:38.500
And that's because the page
layout programs at the time,

316
00:14:38.500 --> 00:14:41.690
couldn't handle all those file formats,
couldn't handle all the cool stuff that

317
00:14:41.690 --> 00:14:45.630
you can have in a Photoshop file
like transparency and layers.

318
00:14:45.630 --> 00:14:50.110
So, if you have a Photoshop file that
has 18 layers or hundred layers,

319
00:14:50.110 --> 00:14:53.550
I probably wouldn't push it to a hundred
layers but you know whatever you have.

320
00:14:53.550 --> 00:14:57.370
If you have a layer file,
you wanna bring in that layered PSD file.

321
00:14:57.370 --> 00:15:02.140
And there's still people that adhere to
that old work flow, where if you had that

322
00:15:02.140 --> 00:15:05.320
layered file, we have to flatten
all the layers in Photoshop and

323
00:15:05.320 --> 00:15:07.460
save it out as a .tif or an .eps.

324
00:15:07.460 --> 00:15:08.450
We don't do that anymore.

325
00:15:08.450 --> 00:15:09.460
We don't want to do that.

326
00:15:09.460 --> 00:15:14.260
Because they all share, all the Adobe Apps
share the same engines underneath.

327
00:15:14.260 --> 00:15:18.440
So if I bring in this layered
Photoshop file into InDesign,

328
00:15:18.440 --> 00:15:22.750
InDesign has access to all that
information that Photoshop put in there.

329
00:15:22.750 --> 00:15:25.370
When I flatten it and do things in
Photoshop, and if you're not working in

330
00:15:25.370 --> 00:15:28.150
Photoshop, this might be over your
head and don't worry about it, but

331
00:15:28.150 --> 00:15:32.710
the bottom line is if you have
access to the PSD file, use that.

332
00:15:32.710 --> 00:15:37.270
If someone gives you something that's got
PSD and an APS and a tif, use the PSD file

333
00:15:37.270 --> 00:15:41.340
because when we go to export it, whether
it's for print or exporting it to pdf,

334
00:15:41.340 --> 00:15:45.180
it can access all that cool information
that Photoshop put in there.

335
00:15:45.180 --> 00:15:47.998
Yes, it makes it slightly bigger.

336
00:15:47.998 --> 00:15:50.688
But the great thing is,
when we're working in InDesign, and

337
00:15:50.688 --> 00:15:53.690
we'll see this in a later episode
when we start talking about links,

338
00:15:53.690 --> 00:15:56.452
it actually isn't putting
the entire Photoshop file in here.

339
00:15:56.452 --> 00:15:58.054
It's just referencing it.

340
00:15:58.054 --> 00:16:00.179
Your Photoshop file is
still your Photoshop file.

I'm going to say transparent and

563
00:26:18.630 --> 00:26:21.630
then every place where I had
none assigned an illustrator.

564
00:26:21.630 --> 00:26:24.640
You can see through in InDesign as well.

565
00:26:24.640 --> 00:26:27.580
So that's one of the reasons you might
want to turn on the Show Preview.

566
00:26:27.580 --> 00:26:29.650
And that's placing that logo.

567
00:26:29.650 --> 00:26:32.640
So actually, let's place it, and then
I'm gonna drop it on top of this image.

568
00:26:32.640 --> 00:26:36.150
So you can see that that
transparency actually shows through.

569
00:26:37.410 --> 00:26:41.100
I'm gonna go out to Illustrator
where that logo is sitting.

570
00:26:41.100 --> 00:26:45.650
And am gonna do something else, instead
of placing it, so if i place it InDesign.

571
00:26:45.650 --> 00:26:46.860
Go back to InDesign I place that.

572
00:26:48.760 --> 00:26:53.160
And I wanna move it or resize it,
obviously I can do that as a group, but

573
00:26:53.160 --> 00:26:56.540
I wanna get into the different
elements of that file,

574
00:26:56.540 --> 00:26:57.880
like maybe I don't like that green.

575
00:26:57.880 --> 00:27:00.210
And I decide in this brochure
I don't want it to be green,

576
00:27:00.210 --> 00:27:01.670
even though my logo is normally green.

577
00:27:01.670 --> 00:27:03.410
I want to change that to orange.

578
00:27:03.410 --> 00:27:06.130
So I'm going to jump out to Illustrator.

579
00:27:06.130 --> 00:27:09.710
And I could change it here and make

00:27:09.710 --> 00:27:13.620

why not work with the elements.

581
00:27:13.620 --> 00:27:16.430
So I can select everything that's here,
just do the command or

00:27:16.430 --> 00:27:18.220
control A to select all.

583
00:27:18.220 --> 00:27:20.700
And then command or
control C to copy that.

584
00:27:20.700 --> 00:27:22.510
And I'm gonna jump out to InDesign.

585
00:27:22.510 --> 00:27:24.840
And I'm going to delete
the one that's there.

586
00:27:24.840 --> 00:27:25.770
And I'm gonna hit paste.

587
00:27:25.770 --> 00:27:27.980
So I'm gonna paste it inside here.

588
00:27:27.980 --> 00:27:31.230
So when I do that,
I get this dotted line around it.

589
00:27:31.230 --> 00:27:35.170
And that just shows me that it's a grouped
bunch of elements that are here.

590
00:27:35.170 --> 00:27:36.600
Zoom back out.

591
00:27:36.600 --> 00:27:41.290
And if I want to size that, I can,
I can play around with that and size it.

592
00:27:41.290 --> 00:27:42.980
But I just scrunched it up, right?

593
00:27:42.980 --> 00:27:45.350
So I'm gonna talk about sizing

594
00:27:45.350 --> 00:27:48.380
But when I did that, you notice I've got
some weird things with the font here,

00:27:48.380 --> 00:27:50.840
that's just how the font
traveled sometimes.

596
00:27:50.840 --> 00:27:53.620
When they come over from Illustrator,

597
00:27:53.620 --> 00:27:56.640
But the cool thing is I can use
my Direct Selection Tool and

598
00:27:56.640 --> 00:27:59.330
select the individual items that are here.

599
00:27:59.330 --> 00:28:02.020
For whatever reason,
that split a part, and,

600
00:28:02.020 --> 00:28:04.260
again, sometimes it's just
the way it translates.

601
00:28:04.260 --> 00:28:06.640
If I select this,
I can now see that that's green.

602
00:28:06.640 --> 00:28:07.920
I can go and change the colors.

603
00:28:07.920 --> 00:28:09.040
We haven't done colors yet.

604
00:28:09.040 --> 00:28:10.700
We're gonna do that in a future episode.

605
00:28:10.700 --> 00:28:13.720
But, I can go ahead and
make changes to the individual elements.

606
00:28:13.720 --> 00:28:17.850
Each thing I select is its own thing,
instead of one particular image.

607
00:28:17.850 --> 00:28:21.310
And that's because I copied
the vectors out of Illustrator and

608
00:28:21.310 --> 00:28:23.740
I pasted those into InDesign.

609
00:28:23.740 --> 00:28:26.300
So I'm able to actually manipulate

610
00:28:26.300 --> 00:28:30.810
Now where that doesn't work is that if
I decide to change the name from wild.

611
00:28:30.810 --> 00:28:32.620
I drop the E off of it.

612
00:28:32.620 --> 00:28:34.870
This one is,
it's kind of own standalone thing.

613
00:28:34.870 --> 00:28:39.030
If I change the logo in Illustrator it
will update wherever it lives in other

614
00:28:39.030 --> 00:28:42.320
InDesign files, except this one
because I didn't really place it.

615
00:28:42.320 --> 00:28:43.880
There's no link back to the original.

616
00:28:43.880 --> 00:28:47.530
I copied it and
then I just pasted it inside there.

617
00:28:47.530 --> 00:28:51.070
So we wanna keep that in mind as well.

618
00:28:51.070 --> 00:28:53.088
>> Erica, one of the things that
you showed us earlier that I

619
00:28:53.088 --> 00:28:53.900
thought was great.

620
00:28:53.900 --> 00:28:58.080
Any time you can do something once and it
will happen multiple times, that's great.

621
00:28:58.080 --> 00:29:00.430
It's when you imported multiple files,
>> Yes.

622
00:29:00.430 --> 00:29:02.300
>> You uncheck that option and
you could just sit there and

place them as you needed, didn't have
to go through many parts of the Wizard.

624
00:29:05.343 --> 00:29:06.256
Now judging by the time,

625
00:29:06.256 --> 00:29:09.520
it does look like we're coming to the end
of another episode, but before we do,

626
00:29:09.520 --> 00:29:12.610
do you got any additional words that
you'd like to throw into this one?

627
00:29:12.610 --> 00:29:15.290
>> No, just get ready cuz we're gonna
start manipulating these images

628
00:29:15.290 --> 00:29:16.660
even more in the next episode.

629
00:29:16.660 --> 00:29:18.270
>> All right,
I look forward to seeing you in that, and

630
00:29:18.270 --> 00:29:19.670
we look forward to seeing you as well.

631
00:29:19.670 --> 00:29:22.270
Signing out for ITProTV,
I've been your host, Wes Bryan.

632
00:29:22.270 --> 00:29:23.470
>> And I'm Erica Gamet.

633
00:29:23.470 --> 00:29:25.364
>> And we'll see ya next time.

634
00:29:25.364 --> 00:29:31.029
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Erica demonstrate how to manipulate images and frames within InDesign. They explain working with layers and the options associated with layers. They explore frame fitting, the options and frame auto-fitting. They talk about working with high-quality images and the considerations when using them.
episodes.title: Manipulating Images and Frames
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

[MUSIC]

in today's episode we're continuing

Erica, how are you doing?

8

9

Great.

13

S,o we're gonna go ahead and take some

one of the issues that we had

00:01:08.470 --> 00:01:11.170
So if I don't know what layers,

in my Photoshop file that I want to
turn on or off, I wanna bring those in.

24
00:01:15.020 --> 00:01:17.890
And actually I'm gonna go ahead and

25
00:01:17.890 --> 00:01:21.170
as well, it just dawned on me, we're going
to actually see what those look like.

26
00:01:21.170 --> 00:01:24.880
So I am going to go ahead and go to my
applications, that's where all of my Adobe

applications live, and I'm going to find

00:01:28.740 --> 00:01:31.150
I have a million different versions,

that will launch in the background

00:01:33.240 --> 00:01:37.410
I'm going to go back to InDesign, and
o I have these layered Photoshop files but

I can choose in InDesign Which

So that means that if I have something and

00:01:48.550 --> 00:01:50.580

00:01:50.580 --> 00:01:53.650

00:01:55.570 --> 00:01:57.220
So let's go ahead and

Ctrl + D to bring up my place command.

00:01:59.740 --> 00:02:01.440

00:02:04.310 --> 00:02:06.760
I just happen to know it has layers,

00:02:06.760 --> 00:02:07.620

And I wanna say show import options,

this is the only way we can choose

We'll see in a minute,
we can actually go back later and

So it automatically jumps

But I can turn on and

I'm not affecting my

It's just how it's displayed, snd again,

00:04:06.530 --> 00:04:08.500
But I tend to keep the layer

87
00:04:08.500 --> 00:04:10.730
So I'm gonna say OK and
then I place it and

00:04:35.070 --> 00:04:37.450

That's a great way to get

And a little trick, if you hold down

00:05:18.380 --> 00:05:19.710

115
00:05:19.710 --> 00:05:22.060

00:05:22.060 --> 00:05:26.070

117
00:05:26.070 --> 00:05:27.430
Maybe I want black and white.

00:05:27.430 --> 00:05:28.760

00:06:06.980 --> 00:06:09.730
Let's come here to graphics and

00:06:12.870 --> 00:06:14.080

00:06:53.470 --> 00:06:55.070
So again I just turned layers on and
off and

00:27:05.456 --> 00:27:09.080
However you did it, you can copy and paste
it, and use smart guides to line them up

603
00:27:09.080 --> 00:27:13.180
whatever, but I can take all of these and
you notice they have little each one have

00:27:13.180 --> 00:27:17.400
as x that means I can bring in multiple
files and I can place them in here, right.

605
00:27:17.400 --> 00:27:21.315
So I can drop those in and
actually let me back up really quick cuz I

00:27:21.315 --> 00:27:24.560
realized I did not cover multiple
files of different types.

607
00:27:24.560 --> 00:27:26.790
We brought in multiple images.

608
00:27:26.790 --> 00:27:30.830
Let me just add that really quick cuz it
actually feeds in nicely to this piece.

609
00:27:30.830 --> 00:27:32.530
I just added a new page.

610
00:27:32.530 --> 00:27:37.150
I'm gonna do Cmd or Ctrl+D to place and
I'm gonna back up here to I

00:27:37.150 --> 00:27:42.025
believe, Let's come in here too.

612
00:27:43.738 --> 00:27:48.470
Placing assets, which is out here and
I have this place multiple files, so

I can place files that are Illustrator,
PDFs, JPEGs.

614
00:27:52.730 --> 00:27:55.350
I have some rich text,
I have a text file here.
