00:27:55.350 --> 00:27:57.300
And I can bring those all in at once.

00:27:57.300 --> 00:27:58.320
So let's go ahead and do that.

617
00:27:58.320 --> 00:27:59.260
So that's from the desktop.

00:27:59.260 --> 00:28:02.980
I'm gonna grab,

00:28:02.980 --> 00:28:06.050
I'm gonna grab everything,

00:28:06.050 --> 00:28:07.640
And I'm not gonna say show import options,

00:28:07.640 --> 00:28:10.590
that will take me forever to

00:28:10.590 --> 00:28:13.540
And now when I place that,
here's my PDF file.

623
00:28:13.540 --> 00:28:14.280
Right?
So, I got to place

00:28:14.280 --> 00:28:15.740
all the images to the PDF.

00:28:15.740 --> 00:28:19.212
Look there's a text file,
here's an image Image file, that's a JPEG,

626
00:28:19.212 --> 00:28:22.190
here's an Illustrator file,
and that's all I had was that.

00:28:22.190 --> 00:28:24.650
So I have all those multiple ones,
so just keep in mind,

00:28:24.650 --> 00:28:26.640
you don't have to place

You can grab everything you need for that

I just side stepped there a little bit,

00:28:37.100 --> 00:28:39.910
And I'm gonna go back to these frames and

00:28:39.910 --> 00:28:44.016

00:28:44.016 --> 00:28:47.720

00:28:47.720 --> 00:28:51.600
But what I really want,
is I want this to be one Graphics frame

00:28:51.600 --> 00:28:54.740
where it kinda looks like a window pane,
is what it's gonna end up looking like.

00:28:54.740 --> 00:28:58.790
I have all these individual grids, and
I wanna place it, one image in there and

00:28:58.790 --> 00:29:02.360

00:29:02.360 --> 00:29:04.250
So to do that,

640
00:29:04.250 --> 00:29:06.320
So I'm gonna select all of these,

641
00:29:06.320 --> 00:29:08.820
I'm just gonna drag across all

I'm going to go up under the Object menu,

I'm gonna choose Paths, and I'm gonna

644
00:29:17.532 --> 00:29:21.380
So I'm gonna do that, and notice instead

00:29:21.380 --> 00:29:25.230
individual graphics frames, it's going
to give me one big X that's gonna say

00:29:25.230 --> 00:29:28.120
this is actually one, big compound frame.

647
00:29:28.120 --> 00:29:29.070
Make compound path.

648
00:29:29.070 --> 00:29:30.640
Now I've got one big X.

649
00:29:30.640 --> 00:29:34.870
Now when I bring in an item, and I have
it selected, so I'll leave it selected.

650
00:29:34.870 --> 00:29:37.930
So, even though there's still individual
items and I can still sort of manipulate

them individually, takes a little bit
of extra effort, I tend not to make

00:29:41.188 --> 00:29:43.890
a compound path until I'm pretty sure

653
00:29:43.890 --> 00:29:46.870
Only cuz you have to step

654
00:29:46.870 --> 00:29:50.100
But I'm gonna do command or control D,
or I can go up to the file menu and

655
00:29:50.100 --> 00:29:51.540
choose place.

656
00:29:51.540 --> 00:29:52.470
And replace that item.

657
00:29:52.470 --> 00:29:53.420
And I'm just gonna go ahead and

00:29:53.420 --> 00:29:56.520
we'll just grab, let's grab that one,

659
00:29:56.520 --> 00:29:58.780
And I'm gonna say replace selected item.

660
00:29:58.780 --> 00:30:01.330
So it's gonna automatically

661
00:30:01.330 --> 00:30:02.960
Now it drops it in there and

662
00:30:02.960 --> 00:30:05.120
It's individual, it's one frame,

00:30:05.120 --> 00:30:07.760

00:30:07.760 --> 00:30:10.290
When I roll over it,

00:30:10.290 --> 00:30:13.240
So that content grabber that's

00:30:13.240 --> 00:30:16.290
whatever reason when I make compound
frames it throws it wherever.

667
00:30:16.290 --> 00:30:17.020
It's sort of random.

668
00:30:17.020 --> 00:30:17.850
But the nice thing is,

669
00:30:17.850 --> 00:30:21.000
if you have that content grabber turned
on, you roll over it, it shows up.

670
00:30:21.000 --> 00:30:22.200
Just grab it there.

671
00:30:22.200 --> 00:30:24.570
I'm gonna click and hold,
if you notice it's a little short, right?

672
00:30:24.570 --> 00:30:27.240
So I don't quite have it

673
00:30:27.240 --> 00:30:31.020
So the first thing I'm gonna do is

674
00:30:31.020 --> 00:30:32.490
I'm gonna hold down my shift key and

00:30:32.490 --> 00:30:35.820
just make sure that it actually

676
00:30:35.820 --> 00:30:38.150
Now I can move that wherever I need,

677
00:30:38.150 --> 00:30:40.920
until I decide it looks good

678
00:30:40.920 --> 00:30:45.760
And again, those are all individual items
that I had created into one compound path.

679
00:30:46.780 --> 00:30:49.200
And the last compound path
that I wanna show you,

is that you can actually take text and

681
00:30:51.780 --> 00:30:55.470
So I'm gonna make a text frame and

00:30:55.470 --> 00:30:58.130
we're gonna be getting

683
00:30:58.130 --> 00:31:00.730
We like to start with the pretty pictures

684
00:31:00.730 --> 00:31:01.862
Then we'll put text in there, right?

685
00:31:01.862 --> 00:31:04.230
And we don't know what we need to say
until we know what the images are.

686
00:31:04.230 --> 00:31:06.270
I'm just gonna put some text in there.

687
00:31:06.270 --> 00:31:08.310
Don't worry so
much about what I'm doing with that but

00:31:08.310 --> 00:31:09.370
I'm just gonna draw some text.

00:31:09.370 --> 00:31:10.540
You might already have this in there.

00:31:10.540 --> 00:31:12.990
You might have already worked with text.

00:31:12.990 --> 00:31:15.598
But I've got some, an image there.

00:31:15.598 --> 00:31:19.200
And I'm gonna go ahead and tell it,

693
00:31:19.200 --> 00:31:21.418
In fact,

00:31:21.418 --> 00:31:24.890
Well I'm gonna go up and choose

And when I do that,

00:31:45.270 --> 00:31:47.930
In fact if I go down

00:31:47.930 --> 00:31:50.770

00:31:50.770 --> 00:31:52.100
So it already made one for me.

I want to keep it.

So now I can actually put

Command or Control D, let's grab a picture

When I do that there's

Anyway, I can put that around

Maybe I just wanted

But I can use text as a frame.

So by converting outlines,

We always like when that happens too.

00:32:46.500 --> 00:32:50.300

>> Nope.

00:32:58.330 --> 00:32:59.380

00:32:59.380 --> 00:33:01.390

00:33:01.942 --> 00:33:02.635

737
00:33:02.635 --> 00:33:09.690

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Erica demonstrate ways to manage assets within Adobe InDesign. They discuss concepts such as gridify, the gap tool, various options inside of the link panel as well as inline and anchored objects.
episodes.title: Managing Assets
episodes.transcript:

1

[MUSIC]

00:00:14.758 --> 00:00:16.095

So we're gonna work with links and we're

we also gonna do some staff in

So we're gonna go ahead and

00:00:49.510 --> 00:00:53.230
So I'm gonna put multiple items, we saw on

00:01:47.560 --> 00:01:52.356
Files and

And I'm gonna go ahead and

00:01:56.460 --> 00:01:59.090
Travel, I'm gonna just keep

00:02:08.157 --> 00:02:11.288
The only reason I wanna do that is I want

I'm gonna make sure
Show Import Options is not turned on,

00:02:16.518 --> 00:02:20.350

00:02:20.350 --> 00:02:24.260
Now, when I do that,

00:02:24.260 --> 00:02:27.210
I can see that I have six

00:02:27.210 --> 00:02:30.940
Now I can place them like I have been,

00:02:30.940 --> 00:02:34.810
I can place them as I have been by

00:02:34.810 --> 00:02:39.104

00:02:39.104 --> 00:02:43.000
So to do that, and

00:02:43.000 --> 00:02:46.800
I'm gonna actually change that to a wide

53
00:02:46.800 --> 00:02:49.620
because I'm working with

00:02:49.620 --> 00:02:51.830
Let's do that I'm just gonna
create a new one really quickly,

55
00:02:51.830 --> 00:02:53.280
and I'm gonna do the same thing.

56
00:02:53.280 --> 00:02:55.460
Load up those same images,
one through six.

57
00:02:55.460 --> 00:02:59.906
They're all wide images and

58
00:02:59.906 --> 00:03:03.969
Now what I can do is I can start

00:03:03.969 --> 00:03:07.829
it automatically says,

00:03:07.829 --> 00:03:11.079
We've done this before, a million

00:03:11.079 --> 00:03:13.029
I wanna place them all

So, I have to use the secret item, this

00:03:29.547 --> 00:03:31.670

Holding down the mouse key

But there it is holding it down.

And I want to cross my hands

All right, so on the laptop,

So what I'm gonna do is I'm gonna hit

75
00:03:44.720 --> 00:03:49.230
And when I do that, I now can see that

76
00:03:49.230 --> 00:03:50.570

77
00:03:50.570 --> 00:03:52.550
I'm gonna do that one more time.

00:03:52.550 --> 00:03:53.890
So now I have three rows.

79
00:03:53.890 --> 00:03:54.990
Now I know I have six images.

80
00:03:54.990 --> 00:03:59.440
So I'm gonna now do three rows and

81
00:03:59.440 --> 00:04:01.640
I have space for all six images.

82
00:04:01.640 --> 00:04:05.180
So, I'm gonna use the right arrow key,

83
00:04:05.180 --> 00:04:08.133
So as I use the right and

84
00:04:08.133 --> 00:04:11.550
down arrow keys I can add and

85
00:04:11.550 --> 00:04:14.830
Now I am still holding down the mouse key
and at this point I'll just drag it out

86
00:04:14.830 --> 00:04:19.650
to the size I want but I'm not gonna let

The Shift key only moves that.

00:25:08.790 --> 00:25:12.950
I'm gonna select the image in InDesign
in a right click or control click and

532
00:25:12.950 --> 00:25:14.610
come down to Edit With.

533
00:25:14.610 --> 00:25:16.100
And I can choose Edit Original, but

534
00:25:16.100 --> 00:25:19.430
if I do Edit Original, it automatically
opens up that file type in

535
00:25:19.430 --> 00:25:22.530
whatever you have your system set
up to open that file type in.

536
00:25:22.530 --> 00:25:25.255
So I have jpg JPEG's, it automatically
wants to open it in preview,

537
00:25:25.255 --> 00:25:25.935
which I don't want.

538
00:25:25.935 --> 00:25:27.005
I wanna open it in Photoshop.

539
00:25:27.005 --> 00:25:28.705
So, I'm gonna choose edit width.

540
00:25:28.705 --> 00:25:30.375
And then it says,
what do you wanna edit with?

541
00:25:30.375 --> 00:25:32.425
Choose the right version of Photoshop.

542
00:25:32.425 --> 00:25:35.640
And so, because I start in InDesign,
I'm gonna come in here.

543
00:25:35.640 --> 00:25:39.300
Squiggly line across there and
deface that, and I'm gonna hit save.

544
00:25:39.300 --> 00:25:41.030
I'm not gonna close it, but
I'm just gonna hit Save.

545
00:25:41.030 --> 00:25:46.070
I'm gonna jump back to InDesign and
automatically, there's my new image

546
00:25:46.070 --> 00:25:49.150
already updated with that image,
because I started it here and went out.

547
00:25:49.150 --> 00:25:51.300
So now I can keep doing that,
keep going around.

548
00:25:51.300 --> 00:25:55.670
And if I come back to Photoshop and
do Step Backwards, let's do that.

549
00:25:55.670 --> 00:25:56.530
Resave it,

550
00:25:56.530 --> 00:26:00.590
come back because I started in Photo Shop
it says hey you need to update that.

551
00:26:00.590 --> 00:26:03.040
So just double click on that,
and it updates it for you.

552
00:26:03.040 --> 00:26:05.940
So it's just a quick way to make sure
your links are always updated and

553
00:26:05.940 --> 00:26:09.880
changes are being reflected
in your in design document.

554
00:26:09.880 --> 00:26:11.680
All right.

555
00:26:11.680 --> 00:26:12.440
We've relinked.

556
00:26:12.440 --> 00:26:16.460
We've brought things in linked to the same
file when something needs to be changed,

557
00:26:16.460 --> 00:26:18.730
we've also relink to new files,
which is great like I said,

558
00:26:18.730 --> 00:26:20.300
we decide we hate this picture.

559
00:26:20.300 --> 00:26:24.930
You could relink to an entirely
new image that's in there.

560
00:26:24.930 --> 00:26:28.500
One last thing with images that I wanna
talk about in this episode is what's

561
00:26:28.500 --> 00:26:33.430
called in line and anchored objects, and
actually I have a document for that.

562
00:26:33.430 --> 00:26:37.140
So let's go out to the desktop, and
I want to choose this one here,

563
00:26:37.140 --> 00:26:40.580
Anchored Inline Objects, and
I'm missing some objects, so

564
00:26:40.580 --> 00:26:42.870
I do have to relink those,
let's do that as well.

565
00:26:42.870 --> 00:26:45.390
So I'm gonna go ahead and
select both those objects that are here,

566
00:26:45.390 --> 00:26:48.870
and I'm gonna say relink and
we moved out of Italy,

567
00:26:48.870 --> 00:26:50.310
we're now working with
Alice In Wonderland which.

568
00:26:50.310 --> 00:26:50.820
Which is great.

569
00:26:50.820 --> 00:26:51.610
I'm gonna come in here.

570
00:26:51.610 --> 00:26:55.050
And I'll re-link to the Drink Me one,
which is here.

571
00:26:55.050 --> 00:26:56.420
And I"lll say Open.

572
00:26:56.420 --> 00:26:58.430
And it automatically is going to say,

573
00:26:58.430 --> 00:27:00.210
there's also this other one
that you might want to do that.

574
00:27:00.210 --> 00:27:01.480
Let's do the White Rabbit one.

575
00:27:01.480 --> 00:27:03.720
We say okay, and everything is updated.

576
00:27:03.720 --> 00:27:08.540
So I have nothing missing, and I know
that my graphics are all set for me.

577
00:27:08.540 --> 00:27:12.120
So what I want to do,
I want to take this text and

578
00:27:12.120 --> 00:27:16.555
I want to place this image along with
the text, so that when the text changes or

579
00:27:16.555 --> 00:27:20.615
flows, moves up and down,
the image will move with it, and

580
00:27:20.615 --> 00:27:24.035
that's called an in-line graphic
if it's inside the frame.

581
00:27:24.035 --> 00:27:27.155
It's called an anchored graphic
if it's outside the frame.

582
00:27:27.155 --> 00:27:29.260
So let's look at that, how do we do that?

583
00:27:29.260 --> 00:27:33.090
Right now I have a frame over here,
and I have text over here.

584
00:27:33.090 --> 00:27:35.650
Now we haven't worked a lot with text,
but we did do a frame and

585
00:27:35.650 --> 00:27:38.230
we filled it with placeholder
text in earlier episode.

586
00:27:38.230 --> 00:27:39.370
So let's pretend that's what we did.

587
00:27:39.370 --> 00:27:43.090
Just happens to be that it actually
makes sense in this text here, but

588
00:27:43.090 --> 00:27:44.700
I want to put that image inside.

589
00:27:44.700 --> 00:27:48.200
So maybe I want it to appear
before this second paragraph.

590
00:27:48.200 --> 00:27:51.580
And, as the text changes or moves, I
change the size of the frame, or I add or

591
00:27:51.580 --> 00:27:54.340
subtract text,
I want that image to go with it.

592
00:27:54.340 --> 00:27:58.170
So, I create what's called an in-line,
I'm sorry, yes, an in-line graphic.

593
00:27:58.170 --> 00:28:01.340
So I'm gonna come in here, and
I'm going to just zoom in a little bit, so

594
00:28:01.340 --> 00:28:03.730
we can actually see a little bitter.

595
00:28:03.730 --> 00:28:06.830
And, I'm gonna use this little
blue square that's here, so

596
00:28:06.830 --> 00:28:09.950
I said there's this big thing that's been
sitting here, waiting for us to use this.

597
00:28:09.950 --> 00:28:12.790
So what I need to do for an inline one,

598
00:28:12.790 --> 00:28:17.930
inline like it sits inside the text frame,
I need to grab this item and

599
00:28:17.930 --> 00:28:21.340
I'm gonna drag it to where I need
to sit wherever my cursor is, and

600
00:28:21.340 --> 00:28:25.900
I'm gonna hold down the shift key, that's
going to force it inside the text frame.

601
00:28:25.900 --> 00:28:30.710
When I let go of that, that image is
now sitting inside the text frame.

602
00:28:30.710 --> 00:28:33.800
Now I have to hit an extra return here,
because there wasn't any space.

603
00:28:33.800 --> 00:28:36.900
I'm just gonna return, so there's a little
bit of breathing room between that.

604
00:28:36.900 --> 00:28:40.060
But what happens to that if I make
changes to this text, I'm just gonna

605
00:28:40.060 --> 00:28:44.790
add some returns the image moves with it,
so that's an inline graphic, and

606
00:28:44.790 --> 00:28:48.970
it moves and says, as the text changes,
that image travels with it.

607
00:28:48.970 --> 00:28:53.040
So you can be sure that it's always
sitting exactly where you want it to be.

608
00:28:53.040 --> 00:28:55.220
So I'm going to actually
jump to the next page.

609
00:28:55.220 --> 00:28:57.020
And show you an anchored one.

610
00:28:57.020 --> 00:29:00.150
Maybe I want it sitting
out here off to the side.

611
00:29:00.150 --> 00:29:03.480
But I want it sitting, so it's attached
to this second paragraph here,

612
00:29:03.480 --> 00:29:07.430
that starts with in another moment,
but I don't want it inside the frame.

613
00:29:07.430 --> 00:29:09.640
I like where it's sitting off to the side.

614
00:29:09.640 --> 00:29:13.210
But, if the text moves down or
jumps to a whole new page,

615
00:29:13.210 --> 00:29:17.220
I would like that image to travel
to that next page as well.

616
00:29:17.220 --> 00:29:18.850
So I'm gonna go ahead and

617
00:29:18.850 --> 00:29:22.580
do sort of the same thing only I'm not
gonna hold down the shift key this time.

618
00:29:22.580 --> 00:29:25.490
I'm gonna select the frame
that the selection tool,

619
00:29:25.490 --> 00:29:29.070
I'm gonna grab the little blue square,
and I'm just gonna drag it in.

620
00:29:29.070 --> 00:29:34.240
Now you notice as I roll over that little
square it tells me exactly what I need.

621
00:29:34.240 --> 00:29:38.580
It says drag into text anchor the object,
shift drag to make an in line.

622
00:29:38.580 --> 00:29:40.660
So just remember and
that line is inside the frame.

623
00:29:40.660 --> 00:29:43.200
But I'm gonna grab that and
just drag it without doing shift, and

624
00:29:43.200 --> 00:29:45.230
I'm gonna drop it right at the beginning.

625
00:29:45.230 --> 00:29:47.170
Now, nothing looks like it changed.

626
00:29:47.170 --> 00:29:49.120
So it really kinda didn't except that,

627
00:29:49.120 --> 00:29:51.510
that little blue dot
now is a little anchor.

628
00:29:51.510 --> 00:29:53.520
And that just tells me
it's an anchored object.

629
00:29:53.520 --> 00:29:54.770
That means it's anchored,

630
00:29:54.770 --> 00:29:59.170
now I have to set up the settings
otherwise it just uses the default.

631
00:29:59.170 --> 00:30:02.140
Right now it looks pretty good, but I'm
gonna make some changes to it, but if this

632
00:30:02.140 --> 00:30:07.210
text changes, and I hit return that tag or
that image travels with the text.

633
00:30:07.210 --> 00:30:09.270
So it's anchored to that spot.

634
00:30:09.270 --> 00:30:10.490
Now, where did it get anchored?

635
00:30:10.490 --> 00:30:12.730
Well, that's when we need to go
in the options and look at that.

636
00:30:12.730 --> 00:30:17.090
So I'm gonna use the Selection tool,
I'm gonna come over here to the frame, and

637
00:30:17.090 --> 00:30:20.150
I'm gonna Option or
Alt-click on the little anchor.

638
00:30:20.150 --> 00:30:24.730
And that brings up my options, so I have
custom, I have in line or above the line.

639
00:30:24.730 --> 00:30:27.790
And actually that's what I do when I
just shift dragged it in there, and

640
00:30:27.790 --> 00:30:28.480
it was an in line.

641
00:30:28.480 --> 00:30:30.270
It would have said in line
if I had gone in there.

642
00:30:30.270 --> 00:30:31.670
But we have fewer options to play with,

643
00:30:31.670 --> 00:30:35.410
I'm gonna choose custom which
is what it automatically did.

644
00:30:35.410 --> 00:30:40.840
And I need to tell it how it knows where
it's anchored, and what it's anchored too,

645
00:30:40.840 --> 00:30:44.180
by fault it automatically put it
on what's called the baseline.

646
00:30:44.180 --> 00:30:46.470
So when I dragged that in there,
it automatically took,

647
00:30:46.470 --> 00:30:49.160
and now I have to see
where it's anchored to.

648
00:30:49.160 --> 00:30:53.640
But it says take the bottom
right part of that image, and

649
00:30:53.640 --> 00:30:57.700
anchor it to the baseline on the X axis.

650
00:30:57.700 --> 00:30:59.830
On the y axis which is up and down, and

651
00:30:59.830 --> 00:31:03.090
we'll look at each of these in just
a second, but you think it didn't actually

652
00:31:03.090 --> 00:31:07.480
anchor the bottom right it
looks like it's the top right.

653
00:31:07.480 --> 00:31:13.440
Well I need to tell it how that
relates to that baseline that's there.

654
00:31:13.440 --> 00:31:14.330
So I'm going to come in here and

655
00:31:14.330 --> 00:31:19.360
say OK let's anchor the top right of
that image and let's turn on preview.

656
00:31:19.360 --> 00:31:21.240
The top right of that image.

657
00:31:21.240 --> 00:31:24.960
And I want it to be to the baseline
of where I dragged that into,

658
00:31:24.960 --> 00:31:27.100
which was right at this in another frame.

659
00:31:27.100 --> 00:31:28.110
Well, the thing is look at this.

660
00:31:28.110 --> 00:31:30.110
I have an offset of almost three inches.

661
00:31:30.110 --> 00:31:31.280
Well, I don't want that.

662
00:31:31.280 --> 00:31:31.960
Why is that there?

663
00:31:31.960 --> 00:31:34.470
That's just because I dragged it manually.

664
00:31:34.470 --> 00:31:36.480
So I'm gonna hit 0 and hit tab.

665
00:31:36.480 --> 00:31:37.860
So now it brings it up.

666
00:31:37.860 --> 00:31:39.660
And, I guess I did it to this one here,

667
00:31:39.660 --> 00:31:42.220
to the Rabbit Hole Dragged
it to the wrong place.

668
00:31:42.220 --> 00:31:45.230
But I can tell it how I want
it to sit in relation to that.

669
00:31:45.230 --> 00:31:50.330
So I've got on the x and y axis I've told
it I want it to be to the text frame.

670
00:31:50.330 --> 00:31:51.800
Right, so back and

671
00:31:51.800 --> 00:31:56.980
forth the right side is anchored to the
text frame with an offset of .32 inches.

672
00:31:56.980 --> 00:31:59.610
So if I move that I can see
how far off I want that, but

673
00:31:59.610 --> 00:32:00.630
maybe that's not where I want it.

674
00:32:00.630 --> 00:32:06.160
Maybe I want the Upper left hand
to be anchored to the page margin.

675
00:32:06.160 --> 00:32:08.730
So I can have that sitting over
there in the page margin and

676
00:32:08.730 --> 00:32:10.580
with no offset whatsoever.

677
00:32:10.580 --> 00:32:11.600
So I can tell it where it sits.

678
00:32:11.600 --> 00:32:14.440
I can do the page margin here as well.

679
00:32:14.440 --> 00:32:19.920
So when I do that, I have the upper
left corner anchored to the page margin.

680
00:32:19.920 --> 00:32:21.900
So I can tell it where
it sits on the page.

681
00:32:21.900 --> 00:32:24.772
One of the other options I
have is relative to spine, but

682
00:32:24.772 --> 00:32:28.360
I can't select that,
because it only knows it's the spine

683
00:32:28.360 --> 00:32:31.500
if it's facing pages because
of not working facing pages.

684
00:32:31.500 --> 00:32:33.020
I don't have that option, so

685
00:32:33.020 --> 00:32:37.070
whittled is anchored with facing pages,
and it is anchored in upper left.

686
00:32:37.070 --> 00:32:40.320
When I have facing pages
turned on relative to spine

687
00:32:40.320 --> 00:32:43.500
it will say anchored to the upper left
on the left hand side of the page and

688
00:32:43.500 --> 00:32:46.380
the upper right on a right hand side page.

689
00:32:46.380 --> 00:32:47.690
Hopefully that makes sense.

690
00:32:47.690 --> 00:32:49.870
The other two things I can say is,
prevent manual positioning,

691
00:32:49.870 --> 00:32:52.920
which means I can't accidentally drag it,
which is the whole point of anchoring it,

692
00:32:52.920 --> 00:32:53.690
so it doesn't do that.

693
00:32:53.690 --> 00:32:56.680
And then also keep within top and
bottom boundaries.

694
00:32:56.680 --> 00:33:01.585
It means it won't ever go higher or
lower than the text that it's anchored to.

695
00:33:01.585 --> 00:33:02.919
So there's a lot of options in there.

696
00:33:02.919 --> 00:33:05.795
But i just wanted to show you how
you could anchor that to that, so

697
00:33:05.795 --> 00:33:09.280
that as this text changes, that image
travels along with it by anchoring it.

698
00:33:09.280 --> 00:33:10.860
So you can put it on the page
where you want it, and

699
00:33:10.860 --> 00:33:13.470
say anchor and
it automatically does the magic for you.

700
00:33:13.470 --> 00:33:14.750
It's just automatically there.

701
00:33:14.750 --> 00:33:19.130
So it's a quick way to get anchored images
in line, they live inside the frame.

702
00:33:19.130 --> 00:33:22.080
>> Well, we've appreciated it Erica,
thank you for showing us that.

703
00:33:22.080 --> 00:33:24.510
And I tell you,
that Gridify that you mentioned, now we're

704
00:33:24.510 --> 00:33:28.170
seeing something under the hood that maybe
even the help topics don't have access to.

705
00:33:28.170 --> 00:33:31.060
It does look like we're coming to the end
of another episode, but before we do,

706
00:33:31.060 --> 00:33:32.920
do you have any additional words
you'd like to throw in here?

707
00:33:32.920 --> 00:33:34.730
>> No, I think we've covered it all.

708
00:33:34.730 --> 00:33:35.580
>> All right, very good.

709
00:33:35.580 --> 00:33:37.050
Thank you for
joining us in the studios, and

710
00:33:37.050 --> 00:33:38.690
we appreciate you, the viewer, watching.

711
00:33:38.690 --> 00:33:41.366
Signing out for ITProTV,
I've been your host Wes Bryan.

712
00:33:41.366 --> 00:33:42.253
>> And I'm Erica Gavin.

713
00:33:42.253 --> 00:33:44.091
>> And we'll see you next time.

714
00:33:44.091 --> 00:33:52.330
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Erica discuss the various options when using effects to modify images within Adobe InDesign. They explain the effects panel, clipping paths, transparencies, blending modes, drop shadows, bevels, glows and feathers.
episodes.title: Effects
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:11.876 --> 00:00:14.665
Welcome back to another exciting
episode here in ITPRO.TV.

3
00:00:14.665 --> 00:00:18.998
I'm your host Wes Bryan and in today's
episode we're continuing through

4
00:00:18.998 --> 00:00:21.910
our series in
the Adobe Creative Cloud 2015.

5
00:00:21.910 --> 00:00:24.040
And we're focusing in on End Design.

6
00:00:24.040 --> 00:00:27.460
And joining me back in the studios
today is none other than Erica Gamet.

7
00:00:27.460 --> 00:00:28.100
Erica, how you doing?

8
00:00:28.100 --> 00:00:29.310
>> I'm doing great, Wes, thanks.

9
00:00:29.310 --> 00:00:30.590
>> Great.
Welcome back in the studios.

10
00:00:30.590 --> 00:00:31.918
What are we going to be looking at today?

11
00:00:31.918 --> 00:00:34.240
>> Today we are going to
start out looking at effects.

12
00:00:34.240 --> 00:00:36.620
So we're just going to see some of
the cool effects that we can create

13
00:00:36.620 --> 00:00:38.680
in End Design and
add to things we put in there.

14
00:00:38.680 --> 00:00:43.440
So, the first thing that we're going to
look at is something called Clipping Path.

15
00:00:43.440 --> 00:00:47.020
Now, if you're working in Photoshop
you're used to probably creating paths.

16
00:00:47.020 --> 00:00:51.130
And we can actually use those in
InDesign to create a clipping.

17
00:00:51.130 --> 00:00:54.150
So I'm gonna go ahead and jump over and
show you what a clipping path is.

18
00:00:54.150 --> 00:00:56.180
It's easier to show you than to tell you.

19
00:00:56.180 --> 00:01:01.334
And basically, I'm going to place
an item inside photo, in this case.

20
00:01:01.334 --> 00:01:02.860
And we're going to create a clipping path.

21
00:01:02.860 --> 00:01:06.170
And a clipping path basically
makes a path around an object

22
00:01:06.170 --> 00:01:09.480
that you can now see what's
behind through that.

23
00:01:09.480 --> 00:01:12.370
So for instance, think of if
you've ever used PowerPoint and

24
00:01:12.370 --> 00:01:14.390
you take something that looks transparent.

25
00:01:14.390 --> 00:01:17.550
It's sitting on a white background,
you think that looks great and you

26
00:01:17.550 --> 00:01:21.440
put it on top of something else and you've
got that big white square back behind it.

27
00:01:21.440 --> 00:01:23.430
Well a clipping path gets rid of that.

28
00:01:23.430 --> 00:01:27.370
So if you've created a path in Photoshop,
InDesign can access that and

29
00:01:27.370 --> 00:01:30.200
say just take that bit of
the path that we drew and

30
00:01:30.200 --> 00:01:33.200
just that part of the image that's
inside that path will show.

31
00:01:33.200 --> 00:01:37.510
But InDesign also has a way to create
its own clipping path if there isn't one

32
00:01:37.510 --> 00:01:38.790
already available in there.

33
00:01:38.790 --> 00:01:42.080
So on certain Files, and
we'll see what that looks like.

34
00:01:42.080 --> 00:01:44.610
So the first thing I'm gonna do is,
I'm just gonna put a nice

35
00:01:44.610 --> 00:01:48.440
color square in the background here,
and I'm just gonna put color in it.

36
00:01:48.440 --> 00:01:52.240
We're gonna get to colors in
a later episode, very soon.

37
00:01:52.240 --> 00:01:53.518
And so we'll come in here and

38
00:01:53.518 --> 00:01:56.730
I'm just gonna give it a nice

whereas this is transparent.

258
00:12:21.210 --> 00:12:23.790
And, I know that because I put
the transparency in there.

259
00:12:23.790 --> 00:12:26.080
So, in Photoshop,
I have just the flower sitting there,

260
00:12:26.080 --> 00:12:28.650
and it's on a transparent background.

261
00:12:28.650 --> 00:12:30.550
InDesign understands transparency.

262
00:12:30.550 --> 00:12:32.664
So not only can it add transparency but

263
00:12:32.664 --> 00:12:35.844
if it comes in with the file

264
00:12:35.844 --> 00:12:38.252
So we're gonna bring that file in and
I'm just gonna drop this in.

265
00:12:38.252 --> 00:12:38.995
And you notice,

266
00:12:38.995 --> 00:12:42.400
I didn't have to do a clipping path
that's because there is no background.

267
00:12:42.400 --> 00:12:44.980
There is a transparent
background in Photoshop so

268
00:12:44.980 --> 00:12:47.270
InDesign honors that when I bring that in.

269
00:12:47.270 --> 00:12:51.590
So if I had this to work with I can go
from here and start doing the effects that

270
00:12:51.590 --> 00:12:55.340
we're gonna look at, or, in this case,
because I had a white background,

271
00:12:55.340 --> 00:12:59.460
I had to actually create the transparency
by putting the clipping path in.

272
00:12:59.460 --> 00:13:03.110
I didn't really create transparency,
I knocked out everything else so

273
00:13:03.110 --> 00:13:04.740
that everything else can show through.

274
00:13:04.740 --> 00:13:05.720
Hopefully that makes sense.

275
00:13:06.920 --> 00:13:09.599
So, yeah, so whether or
not you create it in InDesign or

276
00:13:09.599 --> 00:13:13.930
if you create it in Photoshop,
the transparency is there and usable.

277
00:13:13.930 --> 00:13:16.110
So, let's actually look
at what that means,

278
00:13:16.110 --> 00:13:18.420
I'm gonna look at this first one
which is called the drop shadow.

279
00:13:18.420 --> 00:13:20.520
Everybody kinda knows
about the drop shadow.

280
00:13:20.520 --> 00:13:25.399
When InDesign first, InDesign version
2 way back when, not CS2, before that,

281
00:13:25.399 --> 00:13:27.083
there is 1, 1.5 and 2.

282
00:13:27.083 --> 00:13:30.037
When 2 came out it handled transparency
and this was so amazing for

283
00:13:30.037 --> 00:13:33.362
anybody that had been working in page
layout because until that point if you

284
00:13:33.362 --> 00:13:36.422
wanted transparency on something you
had to go out to Photoshop to add

285
00:13:36.422 --> 00:13:39.459
the transparency and bring it in,
and then it was still flattened.

286
00:13:39.459 --> 00:13:42.312
You still couldn't put it on anything
because you still had that white

287
00:13:42.312 --> 00:13:44.246
background but
the the transparent object, or

288
00:13:44.246 --> 00:13:46.729
the drop shadow was still on
that object and it looked great.

289
00:13:46.729 --> 00:13:50.290
And so became this joke that everything
had to have drop shadows when we came in.

290
00:13:50.290 --> 00:13:52.850
So now I think people are trying
to get away from that but

291
00:13:52.850 --> 00:13:56.340
I still have the drop shadow, it still
gives it a little bit of pop off the page.

292
00:13:56.340 --> 00:13:57.200
So that's basically what it is.

293
00:13:57.200 --> 00:13:58.740
It's not an actual shadow.

294
00:13:58.740 --> 00:14:01.950
An actual shadow looks obviously slightly
different but a drop shadow just means

295
00:14:01.950 --> 00:14:05.700
it's the same object right back
behind it with a transparent.

296
00:14:05.700 --> 00:14:07.490
The fuzzy edges, you know,
that kind of look.

297
00:14:07.490 --> 00:14:09.130
So that's a drop shadow.

298
00:14:09.130 --> 00:14:11.810
So that's actually what we're gonna
do to these objects that are here.

299
00:14:11.810 --> 00:14:15.954
And whether or not we did one with
a clipping path, so in this case,

300
00:14:15.954 --> 00:14:18.400
this one is the transparent one right?

301
00:14:18.400 --> 00:14:20.743
And we've got the clipping
path on this one.

302
00:14:20.743 --> 00:14:25.140
But it doesn't matter which one we use,
I can go ahead and create a drop shadow.

303
00:14:25.140 --> 00:14:28.430
When you are creating a drop shadow for
an object, like a photo that's in a frame,

304
00:14:28.430 --> 00:14:31.580

the drop shadow to the right thing.

305
00:14:31.580 --> 00:14:35.474
If I use my selection tool, my solid
tool and I select on this frame and

306
00:14:35.474 --> 00:14:36.493
do a drop shadow.

307
00:14:36.493 --> 00:14:40.250
I'm gonna get a drop shadow on my frame,
that's not what we want, we want to make

308
00:14:40.250 --> 00:14:43.818
sure we are working with the image If I
want to drop shadow around that image.

309
00:14:43.818 --> 00:14:45.370
And that's why I did that clipping path.

310
00:14:45.370 --> 00:14:48.780
So now it's gonna put it on the flower
instead of around the white box that was

311
00:14:48.780 --> 00:14:50.180
back there before.

00:14:50.180 --> 00:14:53.410
So to get to the drop shadow, I'm gonna

00:14:53.410 --> 00:14:56.770

and then we'll put it on the flower.

00:14:56.770 --> 00:14:59.792
So to get to the drop shadow and all

There's this little menu

There's also an effects menu

00:15:05.350 --> 00:15:07.060
Menu, effects.

here it's spelled with an F.

So, it just depends on

00:15:14.020 --> 00:15:14.890
FX.

00:15:14.890 --> 00:15:18.010
So, I come in here and

if I want to say apply something else

I have to remember not

So I need to make sure I'm gonna turn

00:15:46.020 --> 00:15:49.150
So in the drop shadow, I'm going to

00:15:49.150 --> 00:15:52.920
So now it went ahead and added a drop

00:15:52.920 --> 00:15:54.720
Just the frame itself.

00:15:54.720 --> 00:15:58.422
So we're going to come in here, I'm going

00:15:58.422 --> 00:16:01.970
So by default it's set at black and

Swatches in a future episode, but right

ode to the different colors of

So actually, yeah,

00:16:40.041 --> 00:16:44.685
And the opacity is how dark that shadow

00:16:44.685 --> 00:16:46.845

00:16:46.845 --> 00:16:48.912
So I come in here just

00:16:50.561 --> 00:16:54.369
And the blending mode, if you're familiar

For drop shadows, we tend to do multiply.

Just a couple of them to

For the most part, it can be

00:17:48.689 --> 00:17:53.567
default, it's set over here we have 120,
135 I forgot what was that, but

I also tell use global light 120,
it's gonna put back to 120.

Every time I create a new effect,

So if you've set it as something else and

00:18:10.484 --> 00:18:14.660

00:18:14.660 --> 00:18:18.316

00:18:18.316 --> 00:18:22.330
I can also choose what size

00:18:22.330 --> 00:18:26.100
As I make it larger,

And basically, that's just saying,

00:18:40.570 --> 00:18:42.400

We can also choose Spread,

If I do back to 100,

It doesn't look like a drop shadow.

So play with that, and

Noise is the last thing

We can just put those

This kinda gives it
a kinda fun effect to it.

Again, it depends on what the effect

00:19:27.920 --> 00:19:29.880
So that's a drop shadow,

But that's not actually what we wanted,

So keep that in mind, if I'm going to

00:19:39.850 --> 00:19:45.590

So I wanna make sure

So now I've got that

00:20:18.580 --> 00:20:19.370

So, when it gets to that the edge

I could play with the path a little bit,

Obviously not important in this instance,

00:21:14.580 --> 00:21:17.380
So that's something you need to be aware

They pull your frame out far

it actually fades to transparent.

480
00:22:26.990 --> 00:22:30.920
So if I have an image back behind,
let's just copy this guy and

481
00:22:30.920 --> 00:22:34.430
I'm pasting him, and I paste him over
here and I'm gonna send him to the back.

482
00:22:34.430 --> 00:22:39.000
I'm gonna use our stacking order and do
Object Arrange and send that to the back.

483
00:22:39.000 --> 00:22:43.190
When I do that, I can see that that
yellow is fading out into the green.

484
00:22:43.190 --> 00:22:46.675
So if you had a photo and you had that
fade off, you could actually have it fade

485
00:22:46.675 --> 00:22:49.485
to nothing instead to white or
just feathering off to the side.

486
00:22:50.685 --> 00:22:51.235
So let's do that.

487
00:22:51.235 --> 00:22:53.665
Let's actually do some text drop shadow.

488
00:22:53.665 --> 00:22:56.725
And also we'll do an image
with that feather around it.

489
00:22:57.765 --> 00:22:58.565
So, let's do that first.

490
00:22:58.565 --> 00:23:02.195
I'm going to actually place,
let's grab this guy.

491
00:23:03.235 --> 00:23:04.313
Let's do something here.

492
00:23:04.313 --> 00:23:06.439
Let's do that image there.

493
00:23:06.439 --> 00:23:12.281
All right, so we've got here of
this cemetery near where I live.

494
00:23:12.281 --> 00:23:16.420
I live in the desert so we don't have
a lot of grass in our cemeteries.

495
00:23:16.420 --> 00:23:19.377
It's just one of those, not ancient,
just an old, old cemeteries,

496
00:23:19.377 --> 00:23:21.345
it's one of the original
cemeteries in town.

497
00:23:21.345 --> 00:23:23.409
So it's got some great, hard looks.

498
00:23:23.409 --> 00:23:25.556
So let's soften it up
a little bit with a vignette.

499
00:23:25.556 --> 00:23:28.403
And the next thing I actually wanna do,
I kind of wanted this in an oval.

500
00:23:28.403 --> 00:23:30.157
I think an oval would've
looked better than a square.

501
00:23:30.157 --> 00:23:34.005
But when I just do Place, it automatically
wants to place it into a rectangle.

502
00:23:34.005 --> 00:23:37.487
If I knew it was gonna go into an oval,
I could've drawn the oval first, and

503
00:23:37.487 --> 00:23:39.642
placed it inside, but
I'm gonna do this, and

504
00:23:39.642 --> 00:23:41.824
I can change the object
that it's sitting in.

505
00:23:41.824 --> 00:23:44.310
So under Object,
I'm gonna come down here and

506
00:23:44.310 --> 00:23:47.897
I'm gonna convert that shape to
to an ellipse, so we'll do that.

507
00:23:47.897 --> 00:23:50.322
And I'll just make it a little bit taller,
maybe.

508
00:23:50.322 --> 00:23:51.560
And that's looks good.

509
00:23:51.560 --> 00:23:54.465
So I'm gonna do that, but
I'm want to put a feathered edge on this.

510
00:23:54.465 --> 00:23:58.575
I go back up to the Effects panel and
choose basic feather, and

511
00:23:58.575 --> 00:24:01.725
come over here and I can see that it
gave it a little bit of a softer edge.

512
00:24:01.725 --> 00:24:04.102
I can play with the different
types of corners.

513
00:24:04.102 --> 00:24:07.986
So it's either sharp, round, again this is
one of the ones that you just sort of play

514
00:24:07.986 --> 00:24:09.201
with and see how it looks.

515
00:24:09.201 --> 00:24:10.822
And then we can also change the amount.

516
00:24:10.822 --> 00:24:13.094
Let's give it a softer edge there.

517
00:24:13.094 --> 00:24:16.918
I can add noise which is that speckle as
well if I wanted to, but that looks good,

518
00:24:16.918 --> 00:24:18.960
and so I think, okay, that looks great.

519
00:24:18.960 --> 00:24:22.040
But maybe I decide I don't like that
shape or I don't like the oval,

520
00:24:22.040 --> 00:24:23.290
I need to change it.

521
00:24:23.290 --> 00:24:25.380
All these effects are live effects, and

522
00:24:25.380 --> 00:24:29.180
that's where this really shined when it
first came out that you could do this.

523
00:24:29.180 --> 00:24:31.960
Because before, if I changed that,
I had to go back into Photoshop and

524
00:24:31.960 --> 00:24:34.190
change my mask and import it.

525
00:24:34.190 --> 00:24:36.780
This way, I can just be like, actually
yeah let's show a little bit more of this,

526
00:24:36.780 --> 00:24:38.700
and as I draw it,
I actually get the nice hardage,

527
00:24:38.700 --> 00:24:41.980
so I can see, and
then when I let go I can see that as well.

528
00:24:41.980 --> 00:24:44.760
Now you see, if we get too close to the
edge here sometimes like the edge of this

529
00:24:44.760 --> 00:24:47.350
picture you end up with that
really weird shape on the end.

530
00:24:47.350 --> 00:24:50.570
So you gotta make sure that you can
accommodate not only the shape but

531
00:24:50.570 --> 00:24:52.500
whatever diffusion you have pass it.

532
00:24:52.500 --> 00:24:54.260
So, you always want to leave a little
bit of breathing room there so

533
00:24:54.260 --> 00:24:56.450
you don't get weird hard edges to that.

534
00:24:56.450 --> 00:24:59.480
So, there we go, it's live effects,
I can change that on the fly that way.

535
00:25:01.040 --> 00:25:08.740
Let's do some text and we will put a drop
shadow on that so let's do, what's it?

536
00:25:08.740 --> 00:25:10.483
We had one that was called a cactus bloom,
right?

537
00:25:10.483 --> 00:25:12.270
So, Cactus bloom is what we'll say.

538
00:25:12.270 --> 00:25:16.340
And again, we're going to work with text
in just a little while, but we'll go

539
00:25:16.340 --> 00:25:21.670
ahead and put some text in here, and
I want to put a drop shadow on that text.

540
00:25:21.670 --> 00:25:26.070
Now, when I work with text, we normally
work with a text tool, but the drop shadow

541
00:25:26.070 --> 00:25:29.675
is an effect Effect for an object, they
don't have to do anything to this text.

542
00:25:29.675 --> 00:25:33.665
We don't have to convert it to a compound
shape or anything, it's just text.

543
00:25:33.665 --> 00:25:37.395
And it will continue to be text that we
can change on the drop shadow update.

544
00:25:37.395 --> 00:25:39.485
But we do work with the frame itself so

545
00:25:39.485 --> 00:25:42.990
as a little hard thing to get your head
around sometimes you're not working with

546
00:25:42.990 --> 00:25:46.550
the type tool, we're gonna work with the
Selection tool or the Solid Arrow tool.

547
00:25:46.550 --> 00:25:51.450
So I'm gonna select the frame,
go up under effects, choose Drop Shadow,

548
00:25:51.450 --> 00:25:54.480
just like we've been doing,
and there's my Drop Shadow.

549
00:25:54.480 --> 00:25:58.160
Now I can change that, I said you could
do a hard one instead of a nice soft one,

550
00:25:58.160 --> 00:26:03.300
let's do a hard shadow, we come over here,
and we'll just crank this down

551
00:26:03.300 --> 00:26:08.190
a hundred,
let's not do zero let's do zero there.

552
00:26:08.190 --> 00:26:15.690
And I can go ahead and I can even make
the opacity 100% so it's a solid color.

553
00:26:15.690 --> 00:26:20.650
So instead of having two text frames back
behind, it's actually a drop shadow.

554
00:26:20.650 --> 00:26:25.189
So if I need to change this and
say BLOOMS instead I can do that.

555
00:26:26.810 --> 00:26:29.720
Just drop to the next line there,
but it goes ahead and

556
00:26:29.720 --> 00:26:31.660
it updates that effect that there.

557
00:26:31.660 --> 00:26:33.300
So again it's a live effect.

558
00:26:33.300 --> 00:26:37.060
So you can make changes to it and the drop
shadow actually updates from there.

559
00:26:38.470 --> 00:26:39.970
So those are some of
the effects that you can do.

560
00:26:39.970 --> 00:26:43.450
Again, it's all transparency, and
one of the things that we need to

561
00:26:43.450 --> 00:26:46.680
watch out in transparencies is we
need to actually be able to view

562
00:26:46.680 --> 00:26:50.680
the transparency how it's going to look,
whether it's being printed or exported.

563
00:26:50.680 --> 00:26:55.180
And when we get to the export episode,
we're talking about how to

564
00:26:55.180 --> 00:26:58.740
Give the most optimized version of
everything when we're exporting or

565
00:26:58.740 --> 00:27:01.150
printing then we'll look at transparency.

566
00:27:01.150 --> 00:27:04.020
And transparency while fun is,

567
00:27:04.020 --> 00:27:07.610
you know, can have a little bit
of downsides to it as well.

568
00:27:07.610 --> 00:27:12.070
Because if things are going to trip up,
whether it's exporting to PDF or printing.

569
00:27:12.070 --> 00:27:14.830
You're going to have some
issues with transparency.

570
00:27:14.830 --> 00:27:18.490
So I wanna just look, one last thing we're
gonna look at the different blend modes,

571
00:27:18.490 --> 00:27:22.120
a couple of the blend modes, just to show
you what the different ones look like.

572
00:27:22.120 --> 00:27:25.860
So I'm basically gonna create two shapes
here, we're just gonna overlap them,

573
00:27:25.860 --> 00:27:31.010
and I'm gonna create one,
and we'll make it blue.

574
00:27:31.010 --> 00:27:33.170
Cuz all I can remember is blue and
yellow make green, so

575
00:27:33.170 --> 00:27:35.300
you see I gotta use
something I can remember.

576
00:27:35.300 --> 00:27:39.912
So I'm gonna choose a blue color and fill
that, and I'm gonna do a yellow color on

577
00:27:39.912 --> 00:27:45.520
this one, and let's actually make that
a little darker there, there we go.

578
00:27:45.520 --> 00:27:48.040
And then I'm gonna add
transparency to both of those.

579
00:27:48.040 --> 00:27:50.510
So I'm gonna go ahead and
select this item.

580
00:27:50.510 --> 00:27:53.300
And I'm gonna go up to the effects panel,
but I'm not doing a drop shadow or

581
00:27:53.300 --> 00:27:57.060
anything like that,
I'm just choosing transparency.

582
00:27:57.060 --> 00:28:00.250
Or, the other side of
that coin is opacity.

583
00:28:00.250 --> 00:28:03.190
So just keep that in mind,
that InDesign uses both

584
00:28:03.190 --> 00:28:06.640
of those sort of interchangeably, they're
sort of two sides of the same coin.

585
00:28:06.640 --> 00:28:11.280
So the opacity is how much color
our light is coming through,

586
00:28:11.280 --> 00:28:14.430
as opposed to how much this
solid item that we have.

587
00:28:14.430 --> 00:28:16.350
So in this case I'm just gonna
drop the opacity a little bit,

588
00:28:16.350 --> 00:28:18.880
cuz it's the background item,
I don't need it as much, and

589
00:28:18.880 --> 00:28:21.180
I'm gonna use the basic
binding mode to start with.

590
00:28:21.180 --> 00:28:24.670
We'll do the same thing with the yellow,
and come in to the transparency.

591
00:28:24.670 --> 00:28:28.740
And I'm gonna drop this down
to about fifty percent.

592
00:28:28.740 --> 00:28:32.710
And I have it set to normal, and now you
can kind of see that it's showing through

593
00:28:32.710 --> 00:28:34.640
the blue, but
it's not creating that green.

594
00:28:34.640 --> 00:28:36.680
And that's what I would
expect when I put yellow and

595
00:28:36.680 --> 00:28:38.380
blue together is to create green.

596
00:28:38.380 --> 00:28:40.730
With the normal blending mode does is,

597
00:28:40.730 --> 00:28:44.345
it sort of creates what i like to think of
like a frosted window or frosted glass.

598
00:28:44.345 --> 00:28:45.220
It's sort of like what it did.

599
00:28:45.220 --> 00:28:49.850
If I had a yellow piece of glass, on top
of that blue, it might just block it out.

600
00:28:49.850 --> 00:28:51.390
It's not really blending it together.

601
00:28:51.390 --> 00:28:56.670
Just sort of saying here's transparency
and it's like a frosted window in front of

602
00:28:56.670 --> 00:28:59.420
it, where you'll get that mixture
depending on the colors, and

603
00:28:59.420 --> 00:29:03.610
depending on the colors space that you're
using, you might get that mix of green.

604
00:29:03.610 --> 00:29:05.310
So let's choose Multiply.

605
00:29:05.310 --> 00:29:08.430
Now Multiply might be hard to see but
it is a little bit green

606
00:29:08.430 --> 00:29:11.710
depending on the amount of transparency,
but it has a greenish tint to it,

607
00:29:11.710 --> 00:29:14.920
because what Multiply does is
it blends the colors together.

608
00:29:14.920 --> 00:29:17.600
Now again depending on what
colors you're using you may or

609
00:29:17.600 --> 00:29:23.020
may not get the expected results with
that, because if you're printing it and

610
00:29:23.020 --> 00:29:27.000
you're using CMYK, and
you're using it for both of them, sort of

611
00:29:27.000 --> 00:29:31.280
the colors together if they have the same
value, will sort of cancel each other out.

612
00:29:31.280 --> 00:29:33.430
So that's something to keep in mind,
but for

613
00:29:33.430 --> 00:29:35.800
a lot of stuff on screen
we'll be able to see it.

614
00:29:35.800 --> 00:29:39.550
And the reason for that is that on screen,
and we're talking with opacity,

615
00:29:39.550 --> 00:29:40.760
which has to do with light.

616
00:29:40.760 --> 00:29:43.620
When we're viewing it on screen
we're working with the light, so

617
00:29:43.620 --> 00:29:45.410
what we see is what we get.

618
00:29:45.410 --> 00:29:49.380
It's when we try and put it on paper and
we're no longer working with the light, so

619
00:29:49.380 --> 00:29:52.660
we're trying to make it look opaque but
you can't really have opacity or

620
00:29:52.660 --> 00:29:55.700
transparency in ink,
if that makes any sense.

621
00:29:55.700 --> 00:30:01.640
So it sort of has to make it up, so that's
where your results may vary come in.

622
00:30:01.640 --> 00:30:04.190
So we can pull up
the different blend modes,

623
00:30:04.190 --> 00:30:05.430
again some of them don't make any sense.

624
00:30:05.430 --> 00:30:07.110
We have to come down
here to the bottom and

625
00:30:07.110 --> 00:30:10.690
half the time I'm like I don't see
anything, it just sort of knocked it out.

626
00:30:10.690 --> 00:30:13.850
So I basically play with the few that are
at the top screen and overlay usually, and

627
00:30:13.850 --> 00:30:15.000
normal and multiply.

628
00:30:15.000 --> 00:30:17.910
And multiply is that one where
you're going to get the actual,

629
00:30:17.910 --> 00:30:20.470
it looks like you actually blended
them together and that's the.

630
00:30:20.470 --> 00:30:23.770
It is the one that drop
shadow uses because it know

631
00:30:23.770 --> 00:30:26.290
that the drop shadow needs to show.

632
00:30:26.290 --> 00:30:29.830
But so does the object or object that's
underneath it needs to show through,

633
00:30:29.830 --> 00:30:32.660
and that's the whole point of
the transparent effects is that you can

634
00:30:32.660 --> 00:30:35.800
see everything below like
you would in real life.

635
00:30:35.800 --> 00:30:39.900
So that's the sort of the low down
on transparency without getting

636
00:30:39.900 --> 00:30:40.700
too much into it.

637
00:30:40.700 --> 00:30:42.370
We'll do a little bit more
when we get to output,

638
00:30:42.370 --> 00:30:45.790
because like I said, you come up with some
issues that you have to watch out for

639
00:30:45.790 --> 00:30:48.720
with that, but that's some neat
transparent effects that we can use.

640
00:30:48.720 --> 00:30:51.340
I love that they're live
transparency effects so

641
00:30:51.340 --> 00:30:53.320
that as you make changes it updates.

642
00:30:53.320 --> 00:30:55.250
You don't have to do round
tripping to Photoshop anymore

643
00:30:55.250 --> 00:30:56.510
like in the bad old days.

644
00:30:56.510 --> 00:30:59.190
I like how they're keeping your processor
in mind in the background, too.

645
00:30:59.190 --> 00:31:00.650
>> Yes.
>> Because as a tech person,

646
00:31:00.650 --> 00:31:01.810
that's all I think of,

647
00:31:01.810 --> 00:31:05.410
is how can I make this machine a little
bit faster to support the end-user?

648
00:31:05.410 --> 00:31:08.100
Well, it does look like we're coming to
the end of another episode, Erica, but

649
00:31:08.100 --> 00:31:10.270
before we sign out, do you have
any additional words on this one?

650
00:31:10.270 --> 00:31:13.100
>> Nope, just remember that the
transparency effects might not look how

651
00:31:13.100 --> 00:31:16.600
you want at the end, so always be thinking
of that, and test as you go along, and

652
00:31:16.600 --> 00:31:18.220
>> Instead of waiting til the last minute.

653
00:31:18.220 --> 00:31:20.050
>> All right, well results may vary.

654
00:31:20.050 --> 00:31:23.150
Thank you for being in the studios with us
and thank you, the viewer for watching.

655
00:31:23.150 --> 00:31:26.190
Signing off for ITProTV,
I've been your host Wes Bryan.

656
00:31:26.190 --> 00:31:26.883
>> And I'm Erica Gamet.

657
00:31:26.883 --> 00:31:31.219
>> And we'll see you next time.

658
00:31:31.219 --> 00:31:34.827
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Erica explain colors and swatches within Adobe InDesign. They explain some concepts on color like CMYK, RGB, styling, strokes and fills. They explore swatches including adding colors from the palette, defining and deleting unused colors. They also take a look at swatch libraries, gradient swatches, color stops, color ramps, linear vs. radial and applying color.
episodes.title: Color and Swatches
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:11.800 --> 00:00:14.524
Welcome back to another exciting
episode here at ITPRO.TV.

3
00:00:14.524 --> 00:00:15.858
I'm your host Wes Bryan.

4
00:00:15.858 --> 00:00:17.114
And in today's episode,

5
00:00:17.114 --> 00:00:20.777
we're coming back at you with more
of the Adobe Creative Cloud, 2015.

6
00:00:20.777 --> 00:00:23.900
And we're diving back into
none other than InDesign.

7
00:00:23.900 --> 00:00:26.780
And joining me back in
the studios again is Erica Gamet.

8
00:00:26.780 --> 00:00:27.377
Erica, how ya doing?

9
00:00:27.377 --> 00:00:28.560
>> I'm doing fantastic.

10
00:00:28.560 --> 00:00:29.605
>> All right.
And thank you for

11
00:00:29.605 --> 00:00:32.105
the journey you've taken us on,
what is the next stop?

12
00:00:32.105 --> 00:00:34.065
>> We're gonna do colors, finally.

13
00:00:34.065 --> 00:00:37.195
I've been tempting you with
colors forever and ever,

14
00:00:37.195 --> 00:00:38.695
we're actually gonna
start putting colors in.

15
00:00:38.695 --> 00:00:40.185
I know we've had some color in here but

16
00:00:40.185 --> 00:00:42.120
now we're gonna learn how
to put the color in there.

17
00:00:42.120 --> 00:00:46.190
So we're going to talk about two different
panels that deal with color in InDesign.

18
00:00:46.190 --> 00:00:48.959
We've got our color panel and
our swatches panel.

19
00:00:48.959 --> 00:00:52.061
I know that sounds kind of confusing but
it will make sense in just a minute, so

20
00:00:52.061 --> 00:00:55.130
lets go ahead and take a look at
both of those panels that are there.

21
00:00:55.130 --> 00:00:57.900
So i'm going to open up each of these and
what I'm going to do is click on them and

22
00:00:57.900 --> 00:00:59.310
I'm going to pull them off.

23
00:00:59.310 --> 00:01:03.520
Because, as we saw before, if you work
with the little buttons in the panels and

24
00:01:03.520 --> 00:01:05.240
you click one then the other ones go away.

25
00:01:05.240 --> 00:01:08.270
But in this case I want both of them
working at the same time so I'm going to,

26
00:01:08.270 --> 00:01:09.380
what I call, rip them off.

27
00:01:09.380 --> 00:01:10.890
We're just going to rip them and
float them around and

28
00:01:10.890 --> 00:01:13.280
we're going to start with
the color panel first.

29
00:01:13.280 --> 00:01:18.520
And the color panel is where we
start mixing or creating our colors.

30
00:01:18.520 --> 00:01:21.020
Now colors can come from other places and
we'll look at that as well.

31
00:01:21.020 --> 00:01:22.880
When we bring things in, in just a minute.

32
00:01:22.880 --> 00:01:26.770
But right now I want to work with
colors that I'm creating from scratch.

33
00:01:26.770 --> 00:01:28.970
But I do want to talk about
the different color modes.

34
00:01:28.970 --> 00:01:30.450
Theres are three in end design.

35
00:01:30.450 --> 00:01:34.880
Only two that you'll, probably, deal with,
and there's a lot of acronyms, and

36
00:01:34.880 --> 00:01:37.120
I'm gonna throw a lot of color
stuff at you, really quick.

37
00:01:37.120 --> 00:01:39.190
If you wanna learn more,
though, definitely go out and

38
00:01:39.190 --> 00:01:40.760
look into color theory.

39
00:01:40.760 --> 00:01:42.030
I'm really bad with color theory.

40
00:01:42.030 --> 00:01:44.020
I'll let you know that, right now.

41
00:01:44.020 --> 00:01:45.750
I just mix colors until they look pretty.

42
00:01:45.750 --> 00:01:49.400
But, what you need to know is,
you need to know how this is being,

43
00:01:49.400 --> 00:01:53.610
what the final destination
of your piece's journey is.

44
00:01:53.610 --> 00:01:54.430
Where is it going?

45
00:01:54.430 --> 00:01:56.450
Is it going to be viewed on screen solely?

46
00:01:56.450 --> 00:01:57.900
Is it going to be printed?

47
00:01:57.900 --> 00:01:59.621
Or is it going to be both?

48
00:01:59.621 --> 00:02:04.521
In the very, very, very early episodes we
decided when we created a new document,

49
00:02:04.521 --> 00:02:06.200
we said what is the intent?

50
00:02:06.200 --> 00:02:07.390
Where is this going?

51
00:02:07.390 --> 00:02:11.770
Well one of the things that it does when
you choose an intent, if you chose print,

52
00:02:11.770 --> 00:02:16.660
it automatically assumes it is in
the CMYK color space, and that is cyan,

53
00:02:16.660 --> 00:02:18.560
magenta, yellow, and black.

54
00:02:18.560 --> 00:02:21.040
K stands for black,
of course why wouldn't it.

55
00:02:21.040 --> 00:02:21.800
But what it is.

56
00:02:21.800 --> 00:02:25.002
That is the exact opposite of RGB.

57
00:02:25.002 --> 00:02:27.970
You've probably heard these acronyms and
didn't know what they were.

58
00:02:27.970 --> 00:02:29.930
RGB is red, green, and blue.

59
00:02:29.930 --> 00:02:33.458
So when we are working on screen,
whether it is on your laptop or

60
00:02:33.458 --> 00:02:36.985
you're reading a PDF, or
you're viewing it on a television or

61
00:02:36.985 --> 00:02:40.170
you are viewing it on
a screen in a presentation.

62
00:02:40.170 --> 00:02:42.830
You're working with light and
the color of light and

63
00:02:42.830 --> 00:02:46.230
those colors that we deal with are red,
green, and blue.

64
00:02:46.230 --> 00:02:51.300
The sort of opposite of those is cyan,
magenta and yellow.

65
00:02:51.300 --> 00:02:54.678
And that's the flip side when you're
printing whether it's toner or ink,

66
00:02:54.678 --> 00:02:56.860
you're actually printing
in something solid.

67
00:02:56.860 --> 00:03:02.069
You have to print in CMYK now I said
the opposite is CMY, the black we throw in

68
00:03:02.069 --> 00:03:07.360
because if you put C, M and Y together,
you get a really nice dark brown.

69
00:03:07.360 --> 00:03:09.050
Nobody likes that, we want it to be black.

70
00:03:09.050 --> 00:03:11.210
We want our shadows to be black, etc.

71
00:03:11.210 --> 00:03:13.775
So, in the printing world we
throw in black as well and

72
00:03:13.775 --> 00:03:15.373
that gives it that rich texture.

73
00:03:15.373 --> 00:03:20.980
So RGB if it's going to be viewed on
screen, CMYK If it's going to be printed.

74
00:03:20.980 --> 00:03:22.390
Now if you're doing both,

75
00:03:22.390 --> 00:03:27.590
I said start with your intent at printing
because it automatically assumes CMYK.

76
00:03:27.590 --> 00:03:29.960
And CMYK has a smaller color spectrum,

77
00:03:29.960 --> 00:03:32.430
meaning you have fewer
colors to choose from.

78
00:03:32.430 --> 00:03:36.380
So if I start out building RGB colors,
I get these great,

79
00:03:36.380 --> 00:03:39.690
sometimes bright ones because
we're working with light.

80
00:03:39.690 --> 00:03:41.380
I can get that bright color.

81
00:03:41.380 --> 00:03:43.810
When I go to print that,
I get that dull look.

82
00:03:43.810 --> 00:03:46.336
And you might have done that, where
you created a color or something, and

83
00:03:46.336 --> 00:03:48.658
no matter what you've been working in,
and then you print it out and

84
00:03:48.658 --> 00:03:49.584
it doesn't look so good.

85
00:03:49.584 --> 00:03:50.660
Looks really dull.

86
00:03:50.660 --> 00:03:54.075
Maybe your bright orange is now sort
of a dark brown or a light, brown.

87
00:03:54.075 --> 00:03:57.735
That's because it did a color shift
between those two color spectrums.

88
00:03:57.735 --> 00:03:58.855
So just keep that in mind.

89
00:03:58.855 --> 00:04:00.355
If you are working and

90
00:04:00.355 --> 00:04:03.845
you told it its print, it automatically
is assuming that you're going to print.

91
00:04:03.845 --> 00:04:07.630
So when we start putting colors that
are outside that CMYK color spectrum

92
00:04:07.630 --> 00:04:11.210
It's going to give us an alert, and

93
00:04:11.210 --> 00:04:14.090
You can certainly work

94
00:04:14.090 --> 00:04:18.070
But just know that if you do go to print,
you may or may not get colors shift.

95
00:04:18.070 --> 00:04:20.330
Especially the brighter colors.

00:04:20.330 --> 00:04:23.650
