created these colors and

702
00:33:56.310 --> 00:34:00.710
added them to the swatches and made
the color groups with no document open.

703
00:34:00.710 --> 00:34:01.520
So that now,

704
00:34:01.520 --> 00:34:05.440
every new document that I create has
that same exact set of swatches.

705
00:34:05.440 --> 00:34:09.000
So if you have Corporate colors or
as colors you like to use all the time.

706
00:34:09.000 --> 00:34:10.480
Clean it up,
make it how you wanna look and

707
00:34:10.480 --> 00:34:11.930
you always have those
colors available to you.

708
00:34:11.930 --> 00:34:14.430
And you don't have to build them
each time you create a new document.

709
00:34:15.720 --> 00:34:18.410
>> Very good, thank you for
that demonstration there, Erica.

710
00:34:18.410 --> 00:34:20.420
It does look like we're coming
to the end of another episode.

711
00:34:20.420 --> 00:34:21.150
But before we do,

712
00:34:21.150 --> 00:34:24.010
do you have any additional words you'd
like to throw in about applying color?

713
00:34:24.010 --> 00:34:26.200
>> Just know where it's gonna end up so

714
00:34:26.200 --> 00:34:28.340
you know what color space
you should be working in.

715
00:34:28.340 --> 00:34:30.560
>> Great advice, thank you for
being here in the studios with us.

716
00:34:30.560 --> 00:34:31.880
And thank you the viewer for watching.

717
00:34:31.880 --> 00:34:34.530
Signing off for ITPRO.TV,
I've been your host Wes Bryan.

718
00:34:34.530 --> 00:34:35.540
>> And I'm Erica Gavin.

719
00:34:35.540 --> 00:34:37.480
>> And we'll see you next time.

720
00:34:37.480 --> 00:34:46.130
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Erica demonstrate working with text within Adobe InDesign. They explain how to type, select, move and delete text inside a frame. They look at other concepts like dynamic spelling, spell check, auto correct, alignments, indents, as well as the character and paragraph panels.
episodes.title: Working with Text
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:11.798 --> 00:00:14.163
Welcome back to another exciting
episode here at ITProTV.

3
00:00:14.163 --> 00:00:16.779
I'm your host Wes Bryan,
and in today's episode,

4
00:00:16.779 --> 00:00:20.176
we're coming back at you with
more Adobe Creative Cloud 2015.

5
00:00:20.176 --> 00:00:22.119
That's right, more InDesign, and

6
00:00:22.119 --> 00:00:25.707
joining me back in the studios again
is none other than Erica Gamet.

7
00:00:25.707 --> 00:00:26.671
Erica, how are you doing?

8
00:00:26.671 --> 00:00:28.030
>> I'm doing great, thanks.

9
00:00:28.030 --> 00:00:31.284
>> Great, so we've been, again,
through this journey in InDesign,

10
00:00:31.284 --> 00:00:32.361
what is our next stop?

11
00:00:32.361 --> 00:00:35.230
>> Text at last,
we're finally going to get some text.

12
00:00:35.230 --> 00:00:38.988
We're gonna start putting text into our
document, and we can have words now with

13
00:00:38.988 --> 00:00:41.810
all the pictures and all the designs
that we've been putting in here.

14
00:00:41.810 --> 00:00:44.580
So let's go a head and
jump right in with some text.

15
00:00:44.580 --> 00:00:47.607
So the first thing I wanna do is trade
a text frame, and in the early episode,

16
00:00:47.607 --> 00:00:50.754
I showed you how to create a text frame,
and we put some placeholder text in it.

17
00:00:50.754 --> 00:00:54.090
But now we gonna actually bring some text
in and actually work with that text.

18
00:00:54.090 --> 00:00:55.745
So to start with, I'm gonna go ahead and

19
00:00:55.745 --> 00:01:00.150
just show you some of the text
options that you have inside InDesign.

20
00:01:00.150 --> 00:01:04.460
So I'm gonna choose the Type tool,
and I'm gonna drag out a text frame.

21
00:01:05.790 --> 00:01:08.621
And in this case, I'm just gonna go
ahead and fill with placeholder text.

22
00:01:08.621 --> 00:01:11.067
I'm gonna use a keyboard
shortcut that I setup, F2.

23
00:01:11.067 --> 00:01:14.265
If you don't have that, you can go up
under the Type menu, down to the bottom,

24
00:01:14.265 --> 00:01:15.486
Fill with Placeholder Text.

25
00:01:15.486 --> 00:01:19.850
And that just throws in that placeholder
text that you have in your document.

26
00:01:19.850 --> 00:01:20.897
It may not look like this.

27
00:01:20.897 --> 00:01:23.713
Again, I set up a custom
one in a previous episode,

28
00:01:23.713 --> 00:01:26.215
so I have some actual
English text to look at.

29
00:01:26.215 --> 00:01:29.113
So I'm just gonna go ahead and
see what that looks like.

30
00:01:29.113 --> 00:01:32.181
And I've got my type in a text frame.

31
00:01:32.181 --> 00:01:36.030
Again, text and type, one of those
things that's interchangeable InDesign,

32
00:01:36.030 --> 00:01:39.423
just keep that in mind, I may say
the wrong one, but it's type or text,

33
00:01:39.423 --> 00:01:41.840
whatever we're working with.

34
00:01:41.840 --> 00:01:44.660
So to type text,
if I wanna actually type something,

35
00:01:44.660 --> 00:01:48.880
I just double-click inside a text frame,
and I get my text cursor.

36
00:01:48.880 --> 00:01:51.250
And I'm just gonna put the cursor at
the very beginning of that paragraph, and

37
00:01:51.250 --> 00:01:55.150
I'm just gonna hit a couple returns just
to get a little bit of breathing room.

38
00:01:55.150 --> 00:01:57.870
I'm gonna tell you later in a later
episode why we don't actually wanna

39
00:01:57.870 --> 00:01:59.910
do those harder turns,
a bunch of those in order.

40
00:01:59.910 --> 00:02:02.358
But I am right now just to kind
of push the text out of the way.

41
00:02:02.358 --> 00:02:03.567
The other thing I can do,

42
00:02:03.567 --> 00:02:06.515
is I can just start obviously
typing inside of here, right.

43
00:02:06.515 --> 00:02:07.460
Here's the text.

44
00:02:08.860 --> 00:02:11.880
I'm not gonna worry about typos,
probably gonna have those.

45
00:02:11.880 --> 00:02:13.390
I type way too quickly sometimes.

46
00:02:13.390 --> 00:02:14.378
But I have the text, and

47
00:02:14.378 --> 00:02:17.403
I just wanna show you a little bit about
how to select it and how to move it.

48
00:02:17.403 --> 00:02:20.941
So it works a little differently than
something if you've been working with

49
00:02:20.941 --> 00:02:24.924
something like Word, where you can select
separate words, non-congruous words,

50
00:02:24.924 --> 00:02:28.262
non-contiguous words, that's the word,
non-contiguous words.

51
00:02:28.262 --> 00:02:29.964
And InDesign, you can't.

52
00:02:29.964 --> 00:02:32.848
I can't select the word Here and
the word text.

53
00:02:32.848 --> 00:02:34.510
I can select everything in between.

54
00:02:34.510 --> 00:02:36.040
So couple different things,

55
00:02:36.040 --> 00:02:38.960
I can double-click on a word
to select an entire word.

56
00:02:38.960 --> 00:02:41.740
By default, I can triple-click
to select an entire line.

57
00:02:41.740 --> 00:02:44.688
So if I'm down here, and
I just want that line, I can.

58
00:02:44.688 --> 00:02:48.050
And I can quadruple-click
to select a paragraph.

59
00:02:48.050 --> 00:02:49.111
That is a lot of clicking,

60
00:02:49.111 --> 00:02:51.733
you probably will end up with
some repetitive stress injuries.

61
00:02:51.733 --> 00:02:59.430
I actually have, at my working desk,
I have a mouse, it's a track ball.

62
00:02:59.430 --> 00:03:04.890
I can do a double-click with two fingers,
double-click, and that actually saves

63
00:03:04.890 --> 00:03:08.850
me a lot of time, because I am constantly
needing to select an entire paragraph.

64
00:03:08.850 --> 00:03:11.550
I'm gonna show you where you can
rid of that triple-click line.

65
00:03:11.550 --> 00:03:14.290
That will save you a little bit, so
you can triple-click for a paragraph.

66
00:03:14.290 --> 00:03:15.570
That's in your preferences, so

67
00:03:15.570 --> 00:03:17.620
I'm going to show you where to
change that really quickly.

68
00:03:17.620 --> 00:03:21.170
It's either under InDesign Menu
preferences if you're on a Mac.

69
00:03:21.170 --> 00:03:23.441
Or it's under Edit preferences
if you're on a PC.

70
00:03:23.441 --> 00:03:27.869
Now we'll go into here, and we'll go
into the, let's see, the Type menu.

71
00:03:27.869 --> 00:03:31.500
Sometimes I try to remember where it is,
and I did notice that they just changed

72
00:03:31.500 --> 00:03:33.822
a few things where they
sat in the newest version.

73
00:03:33.822 --> 00:03:37.027
Again, that's a game I like to play,
where did they move my preferences and

74
00:03:37.027 --> 00:03:38.343
where did they move my panels.

75
00:03:38.343 --> 00:03:40.770
Triple-click to Select
a Line is right here.

76
00:03:40.770 --> 00:03:43.830
So it's in the Type pane, and
it's Triple-click to Select a Line.

77
00:03:43.830 --> 00:03:47.040
I can turn that off, so
that the triple-click becomes paragraph.

78
00:03:47.040 --> 00:03:49.965
Because very rarely do I need
to select just one line,

79
00:03:49.965 --> 00:03:52.575
because I'm probably not
gonna select a line.

80
00:03:52.575 --> 00:03:55.000
Of course, now I can't do it,
because I turned that off.

81
00:03:55.000 --> 00:03:57.870
I'm not gonna select one line and
then make a change to just that line.

82
00:03:57.870 --> 00:04:01.060
I'm probably working with either a word or
an entire paragraph.

83
00:04:01.060 --> 00:04:04.260
The other thing that I can do is I can
double-click to select a word, and

84
00:04:04.260 --> 00:04:07.040
then I can either Shift+Select and

85
00:04:07.040 --> 00:04:10.893
click the end of my selection that I want,
and it selects everything in between.

86
00:04:10.893 --> 00:04:15.460
Or maybe if I wanna choose a group of
words, I can double-click on one word, and

87
00:04:15.460 --> 00:04:17.890
hold down the Shift key and
double-click on the next word, and

88
00:04:17.890 --> 00:04:20.260
it selects everything in between.

89
00:04:20.260 --> 00:04:24.451
So again, it has to be connected,
has to grab everything in between.

90
00:04:24.451 --> 00:04:28.832
The other thing that I can do is I
can send this to the end of a story,

91
00:04:28.832 --> 00:04:31.070
I can't see the end of my story.

92
00:04:31.070 --> 00:04:32.693
I have what's called overset text.

93
00:04:32.693 --> 00:04:33.979
I'm actually going to zoom in on that.

94
00:04:33.979 --> 00:04:36.593
And I have this little plus, and
that means there's more to that story.

95
00:04:36.593 --> 00:04:38.761
We're gonna discuss that
in a future episode.

96
00:04:38.761 --> 00:04:42.422
We're gonna talk about what happens
when it ends where there's too much text

97
00:04:42.422 --> 00:04:43.054
for a frame.

98
00:04:43.054 --> 00:04:44.014
We'll talk about that later.

99
00:04:44.014 --> 00:04:49.409
But if I wanna jump my cursor to
the end of that, I can do end.

100
00:04:49.409 --> 00:04:54.331
Now I can't do that on my laptop because
Apple got rid of the ten key from

101
00:04:54.331 --> 00:04:55.675
the MacBook Pros.

102
00:04:55.675 --> 00:04:58.939
So I have no way to use the keys
that I used to be able to use,

103
00:04:58.939 --> 00:05:01.532
which were my End keys and
my Beginning keys.

104
00:05:01.532 --> 00:05:06.926
So if you're on a regular keyboard and
you click End, it will automatically

105
00:05:06.926 --> 00:05:11.740
send the cursor to the end of
the story even if you can't see it.

106
00:05:11.740 --> 00:05:12.660
I can send it there.

107
00:05:12.660 --> 00:05:14.260
Then what I can do is say,
send it to the end.

108
00:05:14.260 --> 00:05:16.158
So let's pretend that it's
all the way at the end.

109
00:05:16.158 --> 00:05:17.946
But right now it's just at
the end of the visual story.

110
00:05:17.946 --> 00:05:22.389
Then you can hold down the Shift key and
click at the beginning of the first one,

111
00:05:22.389 --> 00:05:24.678
and it selects everything in the story,

112
00:05:24.678 --> 00:05:27.470
including all the stuff
that you can't see.

113
00:05:27.470 --> 00:05:28.940
So just keep that in mind.

114
00:05:28.940 --> 00:05:32.230
There's also something called the Story
Editor, which I won't go into a lot, but

115
00:05:32.230 --> 00:05:35.180
I will show you that if you do
have what's called overset text,

116
00:05:35.180 --> 00:05:38.650
text that's hanging outside that text
frame, you can actually get to it.

117
00:05:38.650 --> 00:05:41.908
So Cmd or
Ctrl+Y brings up the Story Editor.

118
00:05:41.908 --> 00:05:45.850
So it basically shows you the text in
just sort of plain text format, but

119
00:05:45.850 --> 00:05:48.590
the cool thing is,
I could see here, this is overset.

120
00:05:48.590 --> 00:05:51.750
So now I see everything, this are all
the words that I'm missing from here.

121
00:05:51.750 --> 00:05:56.679
So I could actually come in here and do a
Cmd or Ctrl+A and select everything here.

122
00:05:56.679 --> 00:05:59.186
And now when I jump back to
my regular story over here,

123
00:05:59.186 --> 00:06:01.432
I know that that's
actually selected as well.

124
00:06:01.432 --> 00:06:04.192
All right, so
I can make changes in the story.

125
00:06:04.192 --> 00:06:08.637
That's something to check out on your own,
definitely a cool thing we can see a lot

126
00:06:08.637 --> 00:06:11.872
of stuff that we can't see on the page or
the layout editor.

127
00:06:11.872 --> 00:06:16.900
All right, so some of the other things
that we can do is we can select and move.

128
00:06:16.900 --> 00:06:19.785
So if I select some text here and

129
00:06:19.785 --> 00:06:24.652
I wanna move it somewhere else,
by default, I have to copy that, so Cmd or

130
00:06:24.652 --> 00:06:29.920
Ctrl+C ,or I can do edit copy and then
scroll down wherever it is I wanna put it.

131
00:06:29.920 --> 00:06:34.204
Let's put it down here,
I'm just gonna pull a space and put paste,

132
00:06:34.204 --> 00:06:36.093
Cmd or Ctrl+V to paste that.

133
00:06:36.093 --> 00:06:39.400
Now you may be used to using what
is called drag and drop editing,

134
00:06:39.400 --> 00:06:42.110
where you grab a word and
you just drag it and move it.

135
00:06:42.110 --> 00:06:44.011
If you're coming from
the world of Word especially,

136
00:06:44.011 --> 00:06:46.125
this is something that you're used to.

137
00:06:46.125 --> 00:06:48.860
These are all preference that
we can turn on in InDesign.

138
00:06:48.860 --> 00:06:49.666
So I'm gonna do that.

139
00:06:49.666 --> 00:06:51.080
I'm gonna go into Preferences.

140
00:06:51.080 --> 00:06:55.143
And we're gonna look at a couple different
Preferences that work the way you were

141
00:06:55.143 --> 00:06:58.441
probably used to if you're coming
from a Word processing world.

142
00:06:58.441 --> 00:07:00.400
So let's go back to Preferences.

143
00:07:00.400 --> 00:07:03.790
And I'm gonna come down and choose on
here, it doesn't matter which one you

144
00:07:03.790 --> 00:07:07.190
choose from that pull-down menu, you get
all the access to all the panes here.

145
00:07:07.190 --> 00:07:11.090
And I'm gonna go ahead and
choose Type, and

146
00:07:11.090 --> 00:07:14.350
I'm going to choose Drag and
Drop Text Editing.

147
00:07:14.350 --> 00:07:16.781
Now, I can choose whether or not to
do it in Layout View or Story Editor.

148
00:07:16.781 --> 00:07:19.720
Story Editor is what I just showed you,
we're not gonna actually work with that.

149
00:07:19.720 --> 00:07:22.470
We'll just say Enable in Layout View.

150
00:07:22.470 --> 00:07:26.980
And what that does is that lets us grab
that if I decide I don't want this word

151
00:07:26.980 --> 00:07:30.140
here, and
I wanted to just grab it and drag it.

152
00:07:30.140 --> 00:07:33.234
I can select this text and now my cursor,
let's see if we can see that,

153
00:07:33.234 --> 00:07:34.505
let's zoom in a little bit.

154
00:07:34.505 --> 00:07:37.545
Hopefully, you can see that my
cursor now turned to this little t,

155
00:07:37.545 --> 00:07:38.807
this little arrow with a t.

156
00:07:38.807 --> 00:07:43.450
And that basically lets me know that
drag and drop text editing is on.

157
00:07:43.450 --> 00:07:46.724
What I can do with that is I
can drag this, just grab it and

158
00:07:46.724 --> 00:07:50.024
drag it down from wherever my
cursor is and drop it here.

159
00:07:50.024 --> 00:07:53.097
And it actually moved it from
that space to that space.

160
00:07:53.097 --> 00:07:57.561
I did a drag and drop text editing,
gonna undo that cuz what I might wanna go

161
00:07:57.561 --> 00:08:01.174
is actually Actually copy it,
but also with drag and drop.

162
00:08:01.174 --> 00:08:05.018
So what I need to do is start dragging it
first and then hold down the Option or

163
00:08:05.018 --> 00:08:06.130
the Alt key.

164
00:08:06.130 --> 00:08:09.040
When I do that,
my cursor changes to a double arrow.

165
00:08:09.040 --> 00:08:10.610
Hopefully you can see that as well.

166
00:08:10.610 --> 00:08:12.600
So I come in here, drag and drop.

167
00:08:12.600 --> 00:08:15.640
So now it moved it over,
it copied it over.

168
00:08:15.640 --> 00:08:17.160
But it also left it where it was.

169
00:08:17.160 --> 00:08:18.610
But again, that's drag and drop editing.

170
00:08:18.610 --> 00:08:20.410
You have to have that turned on.

171
00:08:20.410 --> 00:08:23.350
You may also want to drag and
drop to a new frame.

172
00:08:23.350 --> 00:08:24.290
I'm gonna do that.

173
00:08:24.290 --> 00:08:26.390
Just make this frame a little bit smaller.

174
00:08:26.390 --> 00:08:31.670
Again, I'm just grabbing the drag
handles to shrink up that text frame.

175
00:08:31.670 --> 00:08:35.450
I'm gonna select that same word and
I'm going to drag it and

176
00:08:35.450 --> 00:08:40.700
move it outside that frame, and
whoops come on let's just grab this.

177
00:08:40.700 --> 00:08:43.920
And I'm gonna Cmd and
click on that, so Cmd, so

178
00:08:43.920 --> 00:08:47.620
I get this new text frame, or
Ctrl on the PC, excuse me.

179
00:08:47.620 --> 00:08:50.830
If I hold down the Cmd key I can see that
it's going to draw a new frame out for me,

180
00:08:50.830 --> 00:08:54.240
and I'm just gonna let it go, basically
it's gonna drop to whatever size it

181
00:08:54.240 --> 00:08:56.960
wants to, it's always the square,
no matter how much text you have.

182
00:08:56.960 --> 00:08:58.170
I think that's a little annoying.

183
00:08:58.170 --> 00:09:01.620
But I was able to move that
to a new frame entirely.

184
00:09:01.620 --> 00:09:05.430
I'm gonna undo that, step back one and
now I'm gonna start dragging.

185
00:09:05.430 --> 00:09:06.320
Remember, you have to do,

186
00:09:06.320 --> 00:09:09.870
you have to start the dragging first
before you hit your modifier keys.

187
00:09:09.870 --> 00:09:12.230
Let me start dragging, and
we'll hold down the Cmd key so

188
00:09:12.230 --> 00:09:13.590
that I get a new text frame.

189
00:09:13.590 --> 00:09:16.340
But I'm also gonna hold
down the Option key, or

190
00:09:16.340 --> 00:09:20.630
the Alt key on a PC, to copy it to
a new frame, and then I'm gonna let go.

191
00:09:20.630 --> 00:09:22.680
All right, so
I can actually drag that out.

192
00:09:22.680 --> 00:09:25.280
So it's really nice if I've got
a sentence I wanna bring really quickly,

193
00:09:25.280 --> 00:09:27.280
I just come over here and
say, okay that looks great.

194
00:09:27.280 --> 00:09:30.000
Let's Cmd, Ctrl, Option, Alt.

195
00:09:30.000 --> 00:09:32.880
Click over here, and
there we have that frame ready to go.

196
00:09:32.880 --> 00:09:35.400
Now we can start styling it how I need to.

197
00:09:35.400 --> 00:09:37.300
That's drag and drop editing.

198
00:09:37.300 --> 00:09:41.260
I'm gonna turn that off because I
am the type who will accidentally

199
00:09:41.260 --> 00:09:44.310
grab something and drag it in my modifier
keys and then I'll have text and

200
00:09:44.310 --> 00:09:45.070
I don't know where it moved to.

00:19:50.570 --> 00:19:52.180
So I'm just gonna select some text.

424
00:19:52.180 --> 00:19:54.220
I'll just drag across section of text.

425
00:19:54.220 --> 00:19:58.210
So all that we'll be working with
is this particular amount of text.

426
00:19:58.210 --> 00:19:59.970
I'm going to open my character panel,
like I said,

427
00:19:59.970 --> 00:20:03.370
and the first thing I'm going
to choose is probably a font.

428
00:20:03.370 --> 00:20:06.890
If we don't have it set up so
that default font is the font we want,

429
00:20:06.890 --> 00:20:09.340
I'm going to choose a font from here.

430
00:20:09.340 --> 00:20:13.850
When I choose fonts, I can use the font
pull down menu that's here, or.

431
00:20:13.850 --> 00:20:17.080
I can use the one that's in the control
panel, and the nice thing is

432
00:20:17.080 --> 00:20:19.732
I don't have to open up this
paragraphing character panel every time.

433
00:20:19.732 --> 00:20:24.750
When I'm in the type tool, in my control
panel I have all my character settings

434
00:20:24.750 --> 00:20:27.080
by clicking this little
A that's over here.

435
00:20:27.080 --> 00:20:28.780
Or I can get to all
the paragraph settings.

436
00:20:28.780 --> 00:20:30.340
By clicking the little paragraph.

437
00:20:30.340 --> 00:20:33.780
That's called a pilcrow,
in case you needed that for trivia night.

438
00:20:33.780 --> 00:20:36.300
That's what the little
paragraph symbol is.

439
00:20:36.300 --> 00:20:37.500
I always do it the wrong way, though.

440
00:20:37.500 --> 00:20:39.890
So, I do a backwards pilcrow, apparently.

441
00:20:39.890 --> 00:20:41.870
So, I have this, for
the character panel, or

442
00:20:41.870 --> 00:20:43.540
I can come over to
the character panel itself.

443
00:20:43.540 --> 00:20:45.280
Again, it's the same exact thing.

444
00:20:45.280 --> 00:20:48.040
Now if I know the name of the font
I can just start typing it.

445
00:20:48.040 --> 00:20:52.250
Let's just change it to Palatino, and
it's Palatino Regular, let's say.

446
00:20:52.250 --> 00:20:55.570
Now once I choose a font I can
come down here to the face and

447
00:20:55.570 --> 00:20:58.800
I can choose a bold,
regular bold italic, or italic.

448
00:20:58.800 --> 00:21:01.850
Now you may be coming from something like
Word where you can just do a keyboard

449
00:21:01.850 --> 00:21:03.170
shortcut to make it bold.

450
00:21:03.170 --> 00:21:07.540
If you want something to be Paltino bold,
we can do that in InDesign as well.

451
00:21:07.540 --> 00:21:10.580
It's command or control shift b for bold.

452
00:21:10.580 --> 00:21:15.400
But InDesign is smart enough that if you
don't actually have Palatino Bold loaded,

453
00:21:15.400 --> 00:21:16.950
it does not fake bold it.

454
00:21:16.950 --> 00:21:19.640
And that's what other things
like Microsoft Word does.

455
00:21:19.640 --> 00:21:21.220
It says, you want to bold?

456
00:21:21.220 --> 00:21:24.480
I'll just make it a little bolder,
that's all actually,

457
00:21:24.480 --> 00:21:27.270
you need the font loaded for
it to work properly.

458
00:21:27.270 --> 00:21:30.240
A bold font is just not a fatter
version of the regular font.

459
00:21:30.240 --> 00:21:31.950
It's actually crafted differently.

460
00:21:31.950 --> 00:21:34.960
So, I mean, I'm not saying I
don't sometimes go ahead and

461
00:21:34.960 --> 00:21:38.740
just make a fake bold or fake italic
because sometimes you just need for

462
00:21:38.740 --> 00:21:40.030
that one little piece of text.

463
00:21:40.030 --> 00:21:41.930
But it's a really bad typography.

464
00:21:41.930 --> 00:21:45.380
But that's probably for a whole different
day altogether, the typography wars.

465
00:21:45.380 --> 00:21:49.860
So anyway, I can choose it if I have it,
if not, I don't want to use it.

466
00:21:49.860 --> 00:21:52.890
I'm in InDesign like I said, I can hit
that keyboard shortcut all I want,

467
00:21:52.890 --> 00:21:55.590
if I don't have bold loaded,
it's not going to bold it for me.

468
00:21:55.590 --> 00:21:58.340
I have to actually do a work
around to get that to happen.

469
00:21:58.340 --> 00:22:01.320
Let's work in this font file that we have,
lets actually come over.

470
00:22:01.320 --> 00:22:03.150
I am gonna use the control
panel over here,

471
00:22:03.150 --> 00:22:06.660
just because it's a little higher and
easier to see.

472
00:22:06.660 --> 00:22:08.670
Under the font, when I choose Palatino,

473
00:22:08.670 --> 00:22:12.540
the last ones I used are up here at
the top, I also have these little symbols.

474
00:22:12.540 --> 00:22:16.620
I have the star symbol, and
that's because I can put stars by clicking

475
00:22:16.620 --> 00:22:18.410
next to any of these fonts,
that's my favorite.

476
00:22:18.410 --> 00:22:21.010
So, then I can filter it
by just my favorites.

477
00:22:21.010 --> 00:22:24.080
So, if they're the same ten fonts used all
the time, and they're down at the bottom,

478
00:22:24.080 --> 00:22:26.480
and you don't want to scroll
through your thousands of fonts.

479
00:22:26.480 --> 00:22:27.780
Make it a favorite so
that it's at the top.

480
00:22:27.780 --> 00:22:29.560
You can always turn it back off later.

481
00:22:29.560 --> 00:22:32.360
The other thing that you can do is
hit this TK, and this is Typekit.

482
00:22:32.360 --> 00:22:34.540
Now I'm not gonna go into
that a whole lot, but

483
00:22:34.540 --> 00:22:38.030
Typekit is part of
the Creative Cloud subscription.

484
00:22:38.030 --> 00:22:39.420
So if you have Creative Cloud,

485
00:22:39.420 --> 00:22:43.552
you have a subscription to that,
you have a subscription to Typekit.

486
00:22:43.552 --> 00:22:47.010
And Typekit is thousands of fonts that
are available for you to download and

487
00:22:47.010 --> 00:22:47.760
use free.

488
00:22:47.760 --> 00:22:48.860
In all your projects.

489
00:22:48.860 --> 00:22:50.850
Because that's part of the subscription.

490
00:22:50.850 --> 00:22:53.420
So if you know you're using Typekit fonts,
and

491
00:22:53.420 --> 00:22:56.130
the good thing about Typekit fonts
is if I'm working on a project and

492
00:22:56.130 --> 00:22:59.660
I'm going to send it off to Wes,
who's also going to work on the project.

493
00:22:59.660 --> 00:23:03.260
I use a Typekit font because I know
that he also has the cloud, so

494
00:23:03.260 --> 00:23:07.140
I know any font I use he
also has available to him.

495
00:23:07.140 --> 00:23:09.310
So it's a nice way to sync your fonts.

496
00:23:09.310 --> 00:23:13.320
So that being said, the reason I mention
that here, is that I can say I can just

497
00:23:13.320 --> 00:23:17.390
click Typekit, and only my Typekit
fonts that I have loaded will show up.

498
00:23:17.390 --> 00:23:20.029
If there's ones I need,
I can click add fonts from Typekit.

499
00:23:20.029 --> 00:23:23.460
It will go out to Typekit Website and
I can say I like these, these and these,

500
00:23:23.460 --> 00:23:26.790
download them, it automatically syncs and
now it's available in InDesign.

501
00:23:26.790 --> 00:23:29.460
There's lots to read up on Adobe
site about Typekit as well.

502
00:23:29.460 --> 00:23:31.040
But just know that's there and

503
00:23:31.040 --> 00:23:34.520
it makes it really easy that I know
that everybody has that font available.

504
00:23:34.520 --> 00:23:36.640
Because as we'll see when
we get to exporting and

505
00:23:36.640 --> 00:23:39.270
packaging of files in a later episode.

506
00:23:39.270 --> 00:23:42.420
We get the notice from the font police
reminding you that you cannot actually

507
00:23:42.420 --> 00:23:43.630
distribute fonts to everybody.

508
00:23:43.630 --> 00:23:47.829
There's a whole copyright,
trademark issue in the font world.

509
00:23:47.829 --> 00:23:50.789
So the font police will come up and
say, you can't send that font to Wes.

510
00:23:50.789 --> 00:23:54.719
You better make sure Wes has that font and
if I'm using Typekit, I know he's got it.

511
00:23:54.719 --> 00:23:57.004
So I can turn on those filters or not.

512
00:23:57.004 --> 00:24:00.010
So anyway, I can just scroll through,
find a font that I want.

513
00:24:00.010 --> 00:24:02.750
When I find one that has one of those
arrows, I can drill down on that and

514
00:24:02.750 --> 00:24:05.640
actually see which particular
face that that is.

515
00:24:05.640 --> 00:24:08.640
Or I can choose it from the menu
in the character panel.

516
00:24:08.640 --> 00:24:11.700
Some of the other things that we can do in
the character panel are choose your font

517
00:24:11.700 --> 00:24:13.700
size and your leading.

518
00:24:13.700 --> 00:24:15.310
You may know this as line spacing,

519
00:24:15.310 --> 00:24:18.500
if you're coming from somewhere else,
we call it leading, not leading.

520
00:24:18.500 --> 00:24:20.180
It looks like leading, but it's leading.

521
00:24:20.180 --> 00:24:21.950
It's just an old, old printing term.

522
00:24:21.950 --> 00:24:25.110
And that is the amount
of space between lines.

523
00:24:25.110 --> 00:24:30.770
By default, it's set to auto, and auto is
set by default to 120% of your font size.

524
00:24:30.770 --> 00:24:33.160
Here's that math again, but
don't worry about it too much.

525
00:24:33.160 --> 00:24:38.670
But just know that if you have a 10 pt
font, you will have a 12 pt leading.

526
00:24:38.670 --> 00:24:40.550
So, that's 120% of that.

527
00:24:40.550 --> 00:24:43.605
You can change that default
value in your preferences, and

528
00:24:43.605 --> 00:24:46.242
you can also change it if you like,
this is 14 pt.

529
00:24:46.242 --> 00:24:48.120
I'm gonna just scroll up,
make it a little bit bigger.

530
00:24:48.120 --> 00:24:52.940
And then I can change it, instead of the
auto, which is 120%, I can say, actually,

531
00:24:52.940 --> 00:24:55.532
I want it to be really huge leading,
all right?

532
00:24:55.532 --> 00:24:58.020
And in this case,
leading is set per line, so

533
00:24:58.020 --> 00:25:00.390
I can change the text
that I have selected.

534
00:25:00.390 --> 00:25:04.300
This has different leading than
the leading in the same paragraph.

535
00:25:04.300 --> 00:25:07.870
You can also change that preference
if you want leading to be

536
00:25:07.870 --> 00:25:09.870
a paragraph wide setting as well.

537
00:25:09.870 --> 00:25:12.361
All right, so let's change the kerning.

538
00:25:12.361 --> 00:25:15.710
The kerning is the amount of
space between letter pairs.

539
00:25:15.710 --> 00:25:18.310
So I like this sample, it's a V and an A.

540
00:25:18.310 --> 00:25:21.816
And it says great, if you have a V and
A next to each other,

541
00:25:21.816 --> 00:25:26.713
if it's set up to metrics, which is what
the option is by default, is metrics,

542
00:25:26.713 --> 00:25:29.708
that basically says when
that font was created,

543
00:25:29.708 --> 00:25:33.756
it said the V takes up this space and
the A takes up this much space.

544
00:25:33.756 --> 00:25:37.108
But they kind of nest together well, so
lets actually squish them together and

545
00:25:37.108 --> 00:25:38.560
that's what kerning is.

546
00:25:38.560 --> 00:25:42.970
So you can change kerning on any text by
putting your cursor in between two letters

547
00:25:42.970 --> 00:25:45.600
and changing the amount of kerning here.

548
00:25:45.600 --> 00:25:50.260
Or what I had, is I have what's called
optical kerning on for all my text.

549
00:25:50.260 --> 00:25:53.225
If do metrics,
it just changes the spacing a little bit.

550
00:25:53.225 --> 00:25:56.744
And optical just looks at each letter
pair and says, how do these fit together?

551
00:25:56.744 --> 00:25:59.412
A little closer may be better,
maybe a little bit further apart, and

552
00:25:59.412 --> 00:26:00.240
it looks at each one.

553
00:26:00.240 --> 00:26:03.589
So when I move my cursor through,
each kerning value is different,

554
00:26:03.589 --> 00:26:06.700
because it looked at each letter pair and
did that.

555
00:26:06.700 --> 00:26:08.110
So just know that you can turn that on and

556
00:26:08.110 --> 00:26:10.300
off, to kind of get
a better flow to your text.

557
00:26:10.300 --> 00:26:14.960
I have it set to optical, in fact I set
it to optical with no document open.

558
00:26:14.960 --> 00:26:18.010
I went in, chose my type tool,
character panel and said optical.

559
00:26:18.010 --> 00:26:21.190
So now every new bit of text
I put in every new document,

560
00:26:21.190 --> 00:26:22.450
automatically has that applied.

561
00:26:22.450 --> 00:26:23.720
So I don't have to apply
that all the time.

562
00:26:24.780 --> 00:26:29.070
The tracking is the overall
spacing between the letters, so

563
00:26:29.070 --> 00:26:30.900
it's not individually.

564
00:26:30.900 --> 00:26:32.180
Set that back to 0.

565
00:26:32.180 --> 00:26:34.210
You also have horizontal and
vertical scaling.

566
00:26:34.210 --> 00:26:35.830
We're not gonna use that very often.

567
00:26:35.830 --> 00:26:38.000
Again, that's just messing
up the typography.

568
00:26:38.000 --> 00:26:40.300
So I can just change the horizontal and
vertical scaling.

569
00:26:40.300 --> 00:26:43.800
I might do that in an ad,
like a brand name or something.

570
00:26:43.800 --> 00:26:45.950
I might stretch it a little bit if
that's the effect I'm going for.

571
00:26:45.950 --> 00:26:48.220
I'm not gonna do that in prose like this.

572
00:26:48.220 --> 00:26:49.248
The baseline shift.

573
00:26:49.248 --> 00:26:52.700
I'm just gonna select this one word and
move off of the baseline shift.

574
00:26:52.700 --> 00:26:54.393
So the baseline is where your letters sit,

575
00:26:54.393 --> 00:26:57.460
I'm just moving it off the baseline
a little bit, you can also move it below.

576
00:26:57.460 --> 00:27:00.900
This is great if you
are doing chemical formulas,

577
00:27:00.900 --> 00:27:02.710
obviously you want to
move things down below.

578
00:27:02.710 --> 00:27:05.990
You can also tell it that you want it to
be superscript or subscript if you want.

579
00:27:05.990 --> 00:27:09.985
And there's a lot in the character panel,
we're not gonna go into everything.

580
00:27:09.985 --> 00:27:13.693
As you can see there's just tons of
options that are here, available to you,

581
00:27:13.693 --> 00:27:14.330
to the text.

582
00:27:14.330 --> 00:27:18.190
Text could be a whole two
day class altogether.

583
00:27:18.190 --> 00:27:21.160
So, but baseline shift, here's that
false italic I was telling you about.

584
00:27:21.160 --> 00:27:24.343
I can fake an italic by
putting in a value here and

585
00:27:24.343 --> 00:27:27.180
it just cranks everything to the side.

586
00:27:27.180 --> 00:27:30.440
Again, that's not actually italic,
it's called false italic.

587
00:27:30.440 --> 00:27:33.540
But the one thing you do wanna make sure
that you have is you wanna make sure

588
00:27:33.540 --> 00:27:38.670
that you have your language set to
the language that the type is in.

589
00:27:38.670 --> 00:27:41.500
So obviously, it assumes it's English USA
because that's what I've set up for

590
00:27:41.500 --> 00:27:42.420
my system.

591
00:27:42.420 --> 00:27:46.860
However, I could tell it that this
entire text is actually Spanish.

592
00:27:48.020 --> 00:27:49.800
Now, it's gonna magically translate it.

593
00:27:49.800 --> 00:27:51.060
No, not really.

594
00:27:51.060 --> 00:27:52.530
Was hoping, but it didn't.

595
00:27:52.530 --> 00:27:54.520
But what I've told it is it's Spanish.

596
00:27:54.520 --> 00:27:58.165
Now I wanna run spellcheck, it's gonna
say all these words are spelled wrong,

597
00:27:58.165 --> 00:27:58.880
most of them.

598
00:27:58.880 --> 00:28:00.340
Because they're not Spanish words.

599
00:28:00.340 --> 00:28:03.530
I'm just basically telling it what
language it is supposed to be in, so

600
00:28:03.530 --> 00:28:04.430
that it knows.

601
00:28:04.430 --> 00:28:09.345
And also things like different
punctuation, quotes and things like that,

602
00:28:09.345 --> 00:28:14.898
will be flagged as being wrong, because
it's not in English anymore, English USA.

603
00:28:14.898 --> 00:28:19.190
So again, so now it knows what dictionary
to use when we do spellcheck on that.

604
00:28:19.190 --> 00:28:22.508
So that's character settings, but
we also have paragraph settings.

605
00:28:22.508 --> 00:28:25.850
And I'm gonna do what I said not to do,
which is that extra return in between,

606
00:28:25.850 --> 00:28:28.500
because what I want to have is
this paragraph kind of by itself.

607
00:28:28.500 --> 00:28:31.026
Close the character panel and
zoom in a little bit.

608
00:28:31.026 --> 00:28:36.063
And I'm gonna zoom in a little bit more,
come on, there we go.

609
00:28:36.063 --> 00:28:39.360
And I'm gonna work with
the paragraph settings now.

610
00:28:39.360 --> 00:28:40.970
When I work with character settings,

611
00:28:40.970 --> 00:28:44.980
I select all the text that needs to be,
that I'm trying to affect.

612
00:28:44.980 --> 00:28:48.080
When I'm working with paragraph settings,
I only have to have my cursor

613
00:28:48.080 --> 00:28:50.390
in the paragraph, I don't need to
select the whole entire paragraph.

614
00:28:50.390 --> 00:28:53.490
So even though we set it up so
we don't have to triple-click to do it,

615
00:28:53.490 --> 00:28:55.240
I don't have to do it and
that's the good thing.

616
00:28:55.240 --> 00:28:57.000
So I'm gonna put my cursor
in the paragraph and

617
00:28:57.000 --> 00:29:00.730
now every paragraph setting I do
affects the whole entire paragraph.

618
00:29:00.730 --> 00:29:06.110
So along the top of the paragraph panel
are all these different alignment options.

619
00:29:07.200 --> 00:29:08.310
And I'm just gonna go through each one.

620
00:29:08.310 --> 00:29:13.310
There's left, so we just watch this
paragraph here, left, centered, right.

621
00:29:13.310 --> 00:29:14.776
And then these are all justified.

622
00:29:14.776 --> 00:29:17.124
So it's even on both sides
Instead of a ragged right,

623
00:29:17.124 --> 00:29:18.750
is what we call the other ones.

624
00:29:18.750 --> 00:29:21.976
It's even on both sides but
it's what happens to the last line.

625
00:29:21.976 --> 00:29:26.017
Center the last line to the right or
this one spaced everything out.

626
00:29:26.017 --> 00:29:28.880
If you notice,
it put in a lot of extra white space.

627
00:29:28.880 --> 00:29:32.637
Also, I have several spaces
after punctuation here.

628
00:29:32.637 --> 00:29:34.162
And this is driving me crazy,

629
00:29:34.162 --> 00:29:37.640
cuz we all know we only want
one space after punctuation.

630
00:29:37.640 --> 00:29:39.330
Also not gonna get into that conversation.

631
00:29:39.330 --> 00:29:40.980
Erika said so, that's how it is.

632
00:29:40.980 --> 00:29:44.410
But wherever I grabbed this from,
they had extra spaces.

633
00:29:44.410 --> 00:29:47.530
But you can see when I set it to the
center one, is not only were there already

634
00:29:47.530 --> 00:29:51.300
those spaces, but then because it wanted
to justify that last line as well,

635
00:29:51.300 --> 00:29:53.360
you get what we call rivers of white.

636
00:29:53.360 --> 00:29:56.300
You can just kind of see these white
rivers flowing through your text,

637
00:29:56.300 --> 00:29:56.880
and that's not good.

638
00:29:56.880 --> 00:30:00.370
So, we wanna play with things like
that to scrunch it up a little bit.

639
00:30:00.370 --> 00:30:04.340
The other things we can do is change
the left and right margins, so

640
00:30:04.340 --> 00:30:09.180
we can bring in these margins here,
so if I bring that in, bring that in.

641
00:30:09.180 --> 00:30:12.580
So I don't have to actually make a smaller
text frame to make something like, say,

642
00:30:12.580 --> 00:30:13.780
a pull-out quote.

643
00:30:13.780 --> 00:30:16.660
I can just move in the left and
right margins for that to work.

644
00:30:16.660 --> 00:30:20.480
The other thing that I can do
is I can do a first-line indent.

645
00:30:20.480 --> 00:30:24.190
So let's set these both back to 0,
let's do that to 0.

646
00:30:24.190 --> 00:30:25.850
And then I can do a first-line indent.

647
00:30:25.850 --> 00:30:28.080
I can say, okay I would like
the first line to indent.

648
00:30:28.080 --> 00:30:30.570
I have an extra space in here for
some reason, let's delete that.

649
00:30:30.570 --> 00:30:33.090
So I don't actually have a space,
I can see that there's no spacing here.

650
00:30:33.090 --> 00:30:34.930
It's just this first-line indent.

651
00:30:34.930 --> 00:30:38.752
So I can say that's how much I want that
first line of each new paragraph to indent

652
00:30:38.752 --> 00:30:40.534
if I wanted, as an indention there.

653
00:30:40.534 --> 00:30:44.987
The other thing that I can do is I can
move in, if I move in my left margin,

654
00:30:44.987 --> 00:30:48.553
I can move out my first-line
indent to a negative value,

655
00:30:48.553 --> 00:30:53.650
out to where it hits the edge of the frame
and it will tell me when I hit the edge.

656
00:30:53.650 --> 00:30:55.330
But I can do hanging punctuation as well.

657
00:30:55.330 --> 00:30:58.570
Maybe we want our bullets hanging
outside of the text there.

658
00:30:58.570 --> 00:31:00.240
But it doesn't have to actually
hang outside the frame,

659
00:31:00.240 --> 00:31:03.480
you just scrunch in the margins and
then do that first-line indent outwards.

660
00:31:04.810 --> 00:31:08.690
So, I've set all these back to 0 as well,
just so we're back to where we had it.

661
00:31:08.690 --> 00:31:11.490
And here's where I said don't do
these extra extra returns, right?

662
00:31:11.490 --> 00:31:13.560
We don't want these extra returns here.

663
00:31:13.560 --> 00:31:15.280
But I want some breathing room.

664
00:31:15.280 --> 00:31:18.290
The reason I don't want
that extra return is that

665
00:31:18.290 --> 00:31:21.130
if that extra return is actually there,
that hard return.

666
00:31:21.130 --> 00:31:24.922
And then this paragraph moves
to the top of a new frame,

667
00:31:24.922 --> 00:31:29.968
maybe on a new page or just a new frame,
that extra return will go with it.

668
00:31:29.968 --> 00:31:32.590
And sometimes you'll have that extra
return at the top of the frame.

669
00:31:32.590 --> 00:31:36.551
Well, if I manually delete it, that's
great until it maybe flows backwards if

670
00:31:36.551 --> 00:31:38.820
text changes, text flows backwards.

671
00:31:38.820 --> 00:31:41.312
Now I don't have that breathing
room in between the paragraph.

672
00:31:41.312 --> 00:31:44.792
So what we want to do is delete those
hard returns that are there and

673
00:31:44.792 --> 00:31:48.526
tell it in the paragraph, we wanna say,
put some extra space before or

674
00:31:48.526 --> 00:31:51.340
after the paragraph,
however you want to set it up.

675
00:31:51.340 --> 00:31:54.905
Keep in mind that if I have the one
before has space afterwards, and

676
00:31:54.905 --> 00:31:57.897
this one has space before,
those two values will add and

677
00:31:57.897 --> 00:32:00.842
there will be a bigger gap
than you might be expecting.

678
00:32:00.842 --> 00:32:03.982
But I add that there and then that way,
that's a It's a contextual space.

679
00:32:03.982 --> 00:32:07.660
If it needs to be there, if there's two
paragraphs near each other, it's there.

680
00:32:07.660 --> 00:32:10.060
If it moves to the next page,
it goes away.

681
00:32:10.060 --> 00:32:11.810
So it's smart, it knows that.

682
00:32:11.810 --> 00:32:14.200
So I'm clicking in this paragraph here and

683
00:32:14.200 --> 00:32:16.320
I'm gonna use the space before or
space after.

684
00:32:16.320 --> 00:32:18.300
In this case,
I'm gonna do space before and

685
00:32:18.300 --> 00:32:20.380
I'm just gonna add a little
bit of extra space.

686
00:32:20.380 --> 00:32:23.450
And as I do that,
it actually added that extra space.

687
00:32:23.450 --> 00:32:26.740
But if I select that text, I can see
there's not an actual space there.

688
00:32:26.740 --> 00:32:27.340
It's like I say,

689
00:32:27.340 --> 00:32:31.090
it's contextual, if that paragraph
goes away that space also goes away.

690
00:32:31.090 --> 00:32:36.530
And the great thing is, in a later
episode we're gonna look at text styles.

691
00:32:36.530 --> 00:32:39.600
And we're gonna build this in, so I don't
have to do this for every paragraph.

692
00:32:39.600 --> 00:32:43.300
I'm gonna build it once and I'm gonna
create a style that has that built in.

693
00:32:43.300 --> 00:32:45.890
All the stuff will be built in,
and so when I go to style it,

694
00:32:45.890 --> 00:32:48.670
I just click on Style and
all those magically happen.

695
00:32:48.670 --> 00:32:50.330
So that's what we're building to.

696
00:32:50.330 --> 00:32:52.960
So right now it seems like a lot
of work to do it, and it is, but

697
00:32:52.960 --> 00:32:56.730
once you set it up as a style then
it's automatic and it's just great.

698
00:32:56.730 --> 00:32:58.330
So I can do space before or after.

699
00:32:58.330 --> 00:33:01.550
One trick that you can do if I know that
this spacing, let's say this, I'm gonna go

700
00:33:01.550 --> 00:33:05.380
back to the character styling, and
let's look at the line spacing.

701
00:33:05.380 --> 00:33:08.420
I'm gonna make it 18 point just so
it's a nice even value.

702
00:33:08.420 --> 00:33:12.790
If I come back to the paragraph settings
here and I want my space after or

703
00:33:12.790 --> 00:33:17.950
space before to look like one full return,
I can come in here, instead

704
00:33:17.950 --> 00:33:24.020
of putting an inch value I can say, I want
it to be 18 pt, and that's 18 points.

705
00:33:24.020 --> 00:33:27.000
It will change it to inches for me,
which happens to be 1/4 of an inch.

706
00:33:27.000 --> 00:33:30.140
So I actually have what
looks like one hard return.

707
00:33:30.140 --> 00:33:31.850
I could do the same thing here.

708
00:33:31.850 --> 00:33:33.550
Let's actually do it to
this second paragraph, so

709
00:33:33.550 --> 00:33:36.040
this is a whole new paragraph,
cuz I did a hard return.

710
00:33:36.040 --> 00:33:38.440
And let's tell it that we want it
to be that quarter of an inch,

711
00:33:38.440 --> 00:33:38.960
which is 18 point.

712
00:33:38.960 --> 00:33:45.090
And now it looks like a hard return but
there isn't actually a hard return there.

713
00:33:45.090 --> 00:33:48.390
Last two things on paragraph
is I have drop caps,

714
00:33:48.390 --> 00:33:52.250
let's actually do this paragraph down here
so I have a nice drop cap to look at.

715
00:33:52.250 --> 00:33:56.680
So I can tell it that the drop cap over
here is how many lines, obviously,

716
00:33:56.680 --> 00:33:58.900
one line doesn't do anything,
because it's just a regular character.

717
00:33:58.900 --> 00:34:03.260
I'm gonna say two, and now I have
a two line drop cap, a three line and

718
00:34:03.260 --> 00:34:07.154
I could also choose how many characters
they needed to be the drop cap.

719
00:34:07.154 --> 00:34:09.625
Probably won't use that very often,
but we might.

720
00:34:09.625 --> 00:34:10.825
We might do each one separately and

721
00:34:10.825 --> 00:34:13.515
say we just want the first word to
always be in drop cap settings.

722
00:34:13.515 --> 00:34:14.295
I can do that as well.

723
00:34:15.565 --> 00:34:18.565
And then we can choose whether or
not to hyphenate that paragraph.

724
00:34:18.565 --> 00:34:21.255
So I can choose hyphenate,
I can turn that off which means there's

725
00:34:21.255 --> 00:34:24.980
absolutely no hyphenation which
on a ragged right isn't that bad.

726
00:34:24.980 --> 00:34:27.840
I'm actually going to
select these paragraphs.

727
00:34:27.840 --> 00:34:31.190
I said when I'm working on paragraphs,
I only need my cursor in the paragraph,

728
00:34:31.190 --> 00:34:33.810
well, if I wanna work with
two different paragraphs or

729
00:34:33.810 --> 00:34:37.210
multiple, I just need to have a little
bit of each of the paragraphs set.

730
00:34:37.210 --> 00:34:40.670
So I can do that and
I can turn on hyphenate, or off.

731
00:34:40.670 --> 00:34:43.940
I'm going to turn that off,
and when I justify that text.

732
00:34:43.940 --> 00:34:47.440
Turning off hyphenation really
gives me those rivers of white,

733
00:34:47.440 --> 00:34:51.010
because it absolutely has to fit on that
line, there's no way for it to hyphenate.

734
00:34:51.010 --> 00:34:52.990
So, I can turn off hyphenation,
turn that on or

735
00:34:52.990 --> 00:34:55.720
off, and I have a little bit
more control over hyphenation

736
00:34:55.720 --> 00:34:59.270
if I go to the paragraph panel menu and
I choose hyphenation.

737
00:35:00.690 --> 00:35:04.660
And I can really just get into how
much which hyphenation there is and

738
00:35:04.660 --> 00:35:05.930
where that happens.

739
00:35:05.930 --> 00:35:10.040
So that check box that I just
did only gives me on or off,

740
00:35:10.040 --> 00:35:11.485
this gives me a slider.

741
00:35:11.485 --> 00:35:14.310
And anybody that's old enough
to know what this means,

742
00:35:14.310 --> 00:35:15.760
this is called the Nygil slider,

743
00:35:15.760 --> 00:35:18.590
any guess why it's called the Nygil slider
>> Maybe the person

744
00:35:18.590 --> 00:35:19.820
that invented it names is Nygil?

745
00:35:19.820 --> 00:35:21.420
>> No, it goes to 11.

746
00:35:21.420 --> 00:35:23.450
There are 11 spots on this slider and

747
00:35:23.450 --> 00:35:26.260
if you understand that reference well,
welcome to my world.

748
00:35:26.260 --> 00:35:29.580
So the slider what it is,
in the middle right now,

749
00:35:29.580 --> 00:35:31.820
is kind of the best of both worlds.

750
00:35:31.820 --> 00:35:33.950
But I can either say I
want better spacing,

751
00:35:33.950 --> 00:35:38.199
if I turn on preview, better spacing, is
gonna give me more hyphens, most likely.

752
00:35:39.920 --> 00:35:43.860
Obviously, fewer hyphens, maybe down to
zero but my spacing's not as good, so you

753
00:35:43.860 --> 00:35:46.980
kind of want to find the happy medium and
the middle is the happy medium for that.

754
00:35:46.980 --> 00:35:49.530
I can tell it how many words there
has to be before there's a break.

755
00:35:49.530 --> 00:35:51.620
Like I said, there's a ton of
different options in here.

756
00:35:51.620 --> 00:35:53.020
I'm not gonna go over all of them but

757
00:35:53.020 --> 00:35:56.030
if you're really into hyphenation, this
is where the magic happens for that, and

758
00:35:56.030 --> 00:35:58.480
I can choose what does and
does not get hyphenated.

759
00:35:58.480 --> 00:36:00.800
So we can get into that even more in that.

760
00:36:00.800 --> 00:36:04.150
So that's kind of some of the things with
text, how to format what it looks like,

761
00:36:04.150 --> 00:36:09.000
how to format, remember with the Character
Panel or when you're character styling?

762
00:36:09.000 --> 00:36:11.560
You need to select the character,
it's the type itself.

763
00:36:11.560 --> 00:36:14.590
If you're working with paragraph
you only need to have your cursor

764
00:36:14.590 --> 00:36:18.250
in the paragraph because those
settings affect the entire paragraph.

765
00:36:18.250 --> 00:36:22.839
>> I like the dynamic three-o there,
the dynamic spelling,

766
00:36:22.839 --> 00:36:26.160
the auto-correct and the spell checker.

767
00:36:26.160 --> 00:36:28.760
I could see me using every one of
those when we're dealing with text.

768
00:36:28.760 --> 00:36:32.920
Now I know we got some future episodes
coming up where we're gonna go into text

769
00:36:32.920 --> 00:36:36.330
more, but does looks like we're coming to
the end of another episode, but before we

770
00:36:36.330 --> 00:36:38.710
sign out do you have any additional
words you'd like to say in this episode?

771
00:36:38.710 --> 00:36:40.052
>> Nope, just get ready cuz there's more.

772
00:36:40.052 --> 00:36:40.890
[LAUGH]
>> All right, well,

773
00:36:40.890 --> 00:36:42.750
we look forward to seeing
you in those episodes.

774
00:36:42.750 --> 00:36:43.960
We look forward to seeing you, too.

775
00:36:43.960 --> 00:36:46.990
Signing out for IT Pro TV,
I've been your host Wes Bryant.

776
00:36:46.990 --> 00:36:47.958
>> And I'm Erica Gamut.

777
00:36:47.958 --> 00:36:49.780
>> And we'll see you next time.

778
00:36:49.780 --> 00:36:57.077
[NOISE]

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Erica talk about special characters and text effects. They explain attributes of special characters such as hidden characters, glyphs and white spaces. They look at text effects like wrapping, text on a path, changing case, the tabs panel, repeating values and paragraph rules.
episodes.title: Special Characters and Text Effects
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:11.704 --> 00:00:14.453
Welcome back to another exciting
episode here at ITProTV.

3
00:00:14.453 --> 00:00:18.495
I'm your host, Wes Byran and in today's
episode we're continuing through our

4
00:00:18.495 --> 00:00:20.821
Series in the Adobe Creative Cloud 2015.

5
00:00:20.821 --> 00:00:24.140
That's right,
coming back at you with more InDesign.

6
00:00:24.140 --> 00:00:26.930
And joining me in the studios
today again is Erica Gamet.

7
00:00:26.930 --> 00:00:27.865
Erica, how you doing?

8
00:00:27.865 --> 00:00:28.830
>> I"m doing great, thanks.

9
00:00:28.830 --> 00:00:29.370
>> All right, great,

10
00:00:29.370 --> 00:00:32.530
well this journey that we've been on
before has taken us all over the place.

11
00:00:32.530 --> 00:00:33.690
Where are we going next?

12
00:00:33.690 --> 00:00:35.230
>> We are gonna work with more text.

13
00:00:35.230 --> 00:00:37.590
We're gonna start looking
at some special characters.

14
00:00:37.590 --> 00:00:39.410
And just see what those are, right?

15
00:00:39.410 --> 00:00:42.240
So special characters and
special helper characters.

16
00:00:42.240 --> 00:00:43.810
So I'm just gonna open
up a text file here.

17
00:00:45.390 --> 00:00:46.700
And let's look at some text.

18
00:00:46.700 --> 00:00:50.140
I don't know, I've just got house of
Usher, that's cheery, let's go with that.

19
00:00:50.140 --> 00:00:52.650
I've got Dracula if this
gets too depressing for us.

20
00:00:52.650 --> 00:00:55.120
All right, so I'm gonna come in here and
just look at some text.

21
00:00:55.120 --> 00:00:57.740
And we're gonna look at,
like I said, special characters.

22
00:00:57.740 --> 00:01:02.050
So there's just sort of a huge collection
of characters that either do something

23
00:01:02.050 --> 00:01:04.330
special or they're hidden,
we can't see them.

24
00:01:04.330 --> 00:01:06.010
So that's what we're gonna look at first,
actually.

25
00:01:06.010 --> 00:01:09.120
We're just gonna look at something
called hidden characters, or invisibles.

26
00:01:09.120 --> 00:01:10.280
And basically, that's just so

27
00:01:10.280 --> 00:01:13.300
that it tells us what it's
doing behind the scenes.

28
00:01:13.300 --> 00:01:16.930
So sometimes you might look at something
and think, why does it look like that?

29
00:01:16.930 --> 00:01:20.360
Or I mentioned in a previous episode
about not wanting to have these double

30
00:01:20.360 --> 00:01:22.870
spaces after punctuation.

31
00:01:22.870 --> 00:01:26.040
But I can look at that and say,
that looks like a lot of space.

32
00:01:26.040 --> 00:01:30.880
But I don't want to have to come in here
and go one, two, yes there are two spaces.

33
00:01:30.880 --> 00:01:34.720
I can actually turn on my invisible so
I can see that there are two spaces, and

34
00:01:34.720 --> 00:01:37.340
it just makes it visually easier for
me to see that.

35
00:01:37.340 --> 00:01:42.210
So I'm gonna go up under the Type menu and
come down to Show Hidden Characters, or

36
00:01:42.210 --> 00:01:43.720
use my keyboard shortcut for that.

37
00:01:43.720 --> 00:01:45.100
What I usually do.

38
00:01:45.100 --> 00:01:47.510
And I can look and
see that there are extra spaces.

39
00:01:47.510 --> 00:01:52.060
Now this is interesting because
this space character is just a dot.

40
00:01:52.060 --> 00:01:54.520
But I've got this dot with
this carrot thing over it.

41
00:01:54.520 --> 00:01:56.340
That means it's a special kind of space,
and

42
00:01:56.340 --> 00:01:58.820
we're gonna look at the different
white spaces in just a minute.

43
00:01:58.820 --> 00:02:02.460
So for whatever reason this has
a regular space and this does not.

44
00:02:02.460 --> 00:02:06.060
Again this text is just something
that I got off the Internet just some

45
00:02:06.060 --> 00:02:07.300
public domain text.

46
00:02:07.300 --> 00:02:10.160
And so for whatever reason
that's how it was formatted.

47
00:02:10.160 --> 00:02:12.240
So I can look at and
go okay, that's crazy.

48
00:02:12.240 --> 00:02:15.640
That's also gonna slow me down if
I were just doing say a find and

49
00:02:15.640 --> 00:02:17.460
I said find space, space.

50
00:02:17.460 --> 00:02:20.650
I'm looking for those double spaces
to get rid of them automatically it's

51
00:02:20.650 --> 00:02:23.790
not gonna find that because
that's a special kind of space.

52
00:02:23.790 --> 00:02:28.340
I also can look at the end of
a paragraph and I can see my paragraph,

53
00:02:28.340 --> 00:02:30.371
my turn character there as well.

54
00:02:30.371 --> 00:02:32.275
And it says okay that's an end character.

55
00:02:32.275 --> 00:02:34.330
I can see the extra returns here.

56
00:02:34.330 --> 00:02:37.590
If I had something like a tab which
I'm gonna cover in just a few minutes,

57
00:02:37.590 --> 00:02:40.820
I'm just gonna go ahead and
hit my Tab key and tab that in.

58
00:02:40.820 --> 00:02:44.450
That's what a tab looks like, so I could
see that's a tab, that's not space,

59
00:02:44.450 --> 00:02:46.300
that's why that doesn't work right.

60
00:02:46.300 --> 00:02:49.140
Or if you've gotten something
that you think is tabbed and

61
00:02:49.140 --> 00:02:52.290
you're like why do the tabbed columns
not line up very well, and you look and

62
00:02:52.290 --> 00:02:56.130
just the person who gave it to you
actually did spaces all the way across.

63
00:02:56.130 --> 00:02:59.520
That happens to me more times than I would
like to admit and so I look at that and

64
00:02:59.520 --> 00:03:03.040
go that's because there's no tabs,
now I know I can add a tab in there.

65
00:03:03.040 --> 00:03:06.430
So, those are my invisibles so
I can keep tabs, if you will,

66
00:03:06.430 --> 00:03:08.300
on everything that's in them, right?

67
00:03:08.300 --> 00:03:09.940
So, that's a special character.

68
00:03:09.940 --> 00:03:11.310
It's a hidden character.

69
00:03:11.310 --> 00:03:13.190
There's also something called glyphs.

70
00:03:13.190 --> 00:03:15.520
And I'm gonna open up a new page for this.

71
00:03:15.520 --> 00:03:16.760
Add a new text frame.

72
00:03:16.760 --> 00:03:21.310
So glyphs are actually any
character that is inside a font,

73
00:03:21.310 --> 00:03:24.320
whether that's letters or
numbers or special characters.

74
00:03:24.320 --> 00:03:27.390
You've got your currency symbols,
you've got mathematical symbols,

75
00:03:27.390 --> 00:03:28.770
you've got Greek symbols.

76
00:03:28.770 --> 00:03:31.530
If you've got dingbats,
they're just all the little pictures,

77
00:03:31.530 --> 00:03:33.750
you've got your planes, and your apples,
and everything that's in there,

78
00:03:33.750 --> 00:03:35.830
all the little emoji looking things.

79
00:03:35.830 --> 00:03:39.220
So those are called glyphs any
character is called a glyph.

80
00:03:39.220 --> 00:03:41.430
And sometimes you need a special glyph and

81
00:03:41.430 --> 00:03:43.550
you don't know where it
lives on the keyboard.

82
00:03:43.550 --> 00:03:45.100
You can use the glyphs panel for that.

83
00:03:45.100 --> 00:03:48.680
I'm going to actually turn off my
invisibles because I, right now,

84
00:03:48.680 --> 00:03:50.410
I see the hash sign that's there.

85
00:03:50.410 --> 00:03:52.270
That tells me that's the end of my story.

86
