00:24:14.347 --> 00:24:15.800
So you can put on whatever shape you want.

530
00:24:17.890 --> 00:24:18.440
All right.

531
00:24:18.440 --> 00:24:22.970
Let's talk about using the eye
dropper tool for text.

532
00:24:22.970 --> 00:24:24.770
So I am gonna just put some text in here.

533
00:24:24.770 --> 00:24:26.630
Fill it with placeholder text.

534
00:24:26.630 --> 00:24:28.880
And I am gonna make this bold and

535
00:24:28.880 --> 00:24:33.670
maybe italic and
maybe even lets make it a color as well.

536
00:24:33.670 --> 00:24:35.230
Get really wild and do that.

537
00:24:35.230 --> 00:24:39.800
And go ahead and tell I want
the Text Fill to be this green.

538
00:24:39.800 --> 00:24:43.335
All right, so I'm gonna do that,
then I'm gonna create another text frame,

539
00:24:43.335 --> 00:24:45.010
also filled with placeholder text.

540
00:24:46.200 --> 00:24:50.510
And I wanna pick up the attributes
of this text and apply it here.

541
00:24:50.510 --> 00:24:53.940
Now, as we'll see in a future movie,
this is great place for styles.

542
00:24:53.940 --> 00:24:54.550
So, I can say,

543
00:24:54.550 --> 00:24:57.980
whenever I want text to look like this
I'm gonna create a style and apply it.

544
00:24:57.980 --> 00:25:01.390
But sometimes you just need to do it
once or twice and making the style will

545
00:25:01.390 --> 00:25:04.520
actually take longer than just
copying the attributes and pasting it.

546
00:25:04.520 --> 00:25:07.530
Where style comes in handy is you
continually update the style and

547
00:25:07.530 --> 00:25:08.780
all the text updates.

548
00:25:08.780 --> 00:25:09.605
This you can't.

549
00:25:09.605 --> 00:25:11.950
But I'm gonna do it once and
I'm not gonna worry about it again.

550
00:25:11.950 --> 00:25:15.310
But I want this second paragraph
to look like the first one.

551
00:25:15.310 --> 00:25:18.540
So what I can do is I can use
my eye dropper tool for that.

552
00:25:19.880 --> 00:25:24.280
And so I'm come over here and I can just,
I have two different options.

553
00:25:24.280 --> 00:25:28.040
I can either select the text
first that I want to affect and

554
00:25:28.040 --> 00:25:31.630
then click on text with the eye
dropper tool, and have it change.

555
00:25:31.630 --> 00:25:36.320
Or I can pick up the attributes and
then apply it to text along the way.

556
00:25:36.320 --> 00:25:39.250
So this case I'm gonna select
the text that I want to effect,

557
00:25:39.250 --> 00:25:42.450
choose the eye dropper tool, and I'm gonna
click and make sure I click on the image.

558
00:25:42.450 --> 00:25:44.130
Or I mean on the text itself.

559
00:25:44.130 --> 00:25:48.328
And now the text that I selected now
has that attribute applied to it.

560
00:25:48.328 --> 00:25:50.282
And if I double click on
the eye dropper tool,

561
00:25:50.282 --> 00:25:52.460
this is where I choose what gets changed.

562
00:25:52.460 --> 00:25:54.430
So there is everything
that's selected by default.

563
00:25:54.430 --> 00:25:56.940
I can say I just want
the fill color to change.

564
00:25:56.940 --> 00:25:58.660
So I can be really picky on that.

565
00:25:58.660 --> 00:26:00.050
But, right now, it has everything set.

566
00:26:00.050 --> 00:26:02.990
The other thing that I can do, though,
like I said, is that I can pick up

567
00:26:02.990 --> 00:26:06.530
something and I can say let's pick up
this text, so I just picked it up.

568
00:26:06.530 --> 00:26:08.250
Now, I can come down here and

569
00:26:08.250 --> 00:26:12.245
my icon changes to a text with
the eyedropper tool, and now I can say,

570
00:26:12.245 --> 00:26:17.050
double-click on this word, Traveller,
and this word here, and this word here.

571
00:26:17.050 --> 00:26:20.050
So, I can just double-click on it and
it's applying what's in that eye-dropper.

572
00:26:20.050 --> 00:26:23.540
I can see that the eyedropper's full with
all those attributes that are on there.

573
00:26:23.540 --> 00:26:26.450
So there's two different ways to do that,
and again, whoops.

574
00:26:26.450 --> 00:26:29.260
Let's zoom back out of there, there we go.

575
00:26:29.260 --> 00:26:32.730
And it's just a quick way to pick up all
the attributes, but I haven't saved it.

576
00:26:32.730 --> 00:26:37.360
So if I decide to change this text to red,
all this will stay green and

577
00:26:37.360 --> 00:26:39.750
it won't update, and
that's where a style comes in handy.

578
00:26:39.750 --> 00:26:42.253
But it's a quick way to do it.

579
00:26:42.253 --> 00:26:45.870
All right, let's talk about
changing the case a little bit.

580
00:26:45.870 --> 00:26:50.340
So some of the other things in text is I
can change the case that something's in.

581
00:26:50.340 --> 00:26:56.264
Maybe I want this to all be in lowercase,
or I'm sorry in uppercase or small caps.

582
00:26:56.264 --> 00:26:57.800
So I'm coming over to the character panel.

583
00:26:59.680 --> 00:27:01.700
And I can choose the case.

584
00:27:01.700 --> 00:27:05.430
So I come in here, and I tell it that I
want it to be in all caps, or small caps,

585
00:27:05.430 --> 00:27:06.920
or superscript, or subscript.

586
00:27:06.920 --> 00:27:12.100
We talked about doing chemical formulas,
we would always tell the superscript H2O.

587
00:27:12.100 --> 00:27:14.796
We're going to select the two and
make that a subscript.

588
00:27:14.796 --> 00:27:17.200
So I come here and
say all caps or small caps.

589
00:27:17.200 --> 00:27:18.330
Let's just choose that.

590
00:27:18.330 --> 00:27:19.500
It changes the case for us.

591
00:27:19.500 --> 00:27:22.340
We didn't have to do a caplocks on
which is a good thing because if you

592
00:27:22.340 --> 00:27:24.850
have those cap locks on then
you're stuck with those caps.

593
00:27:24.850 --> 00:27:28.157
Where as this way I can turn it on and
off, and again all this stuff,

594
00:27:28.157 --> 00:27:31.543
I can build this into a style, so
I don't have to do this every time.

595
00:27:31.543 --> 00:27:35.913
I've already got it all set there, I've
got it so that it's bold, it's italic,

596
00:27:35.913 --> 00:27:39.845
it's green, and it's in caps, and
then I can just say apply that style and

597
00:27:39.845 --> 00:27:42.924
then all that text changes,
so it's super, super easy.

598
00:27:42.924 --> 00:27:44.910
We're gonna do paragraph rules,
this is fun.

599
00:27:46.060 --> 00:27:47.900
Let's actually create a new page for this.

600
00:27:48.910 --> 00:27:53.520
If you want your paragraph to
kinda be set off either by bars,

601
00:27:53.520 --> 00:27:57.100
lines, or whatever I can set that
into what's called a paragraph rule.

602
00:27:57.100 --> 00:28:01.000
This is not a rule like something that
must be done It is an actual rule or

603
00:28:01.000 --> 00:28:02.540
line that we are creating.

604
00:28:02.540 --> 00:28:04.470
So I'm gonna fill up the placeholder text.

605
00:28:04.470 --> 00:28:09.440
And I'm gonna call this,
I'm just gonna say, The Time Machine.

606
00:28:09.440 --> 00:28:11.294
And I want that to be my header.

607
00:28:11.294 --> 00:28:15.538
And I'm probably gonna do something like
give a little bit of space afterwards.

608
00:28:15.538 --> 00:28:17.250
Push a little bit of
space afterwards there.

609
00:28:17.250 --> 00:28:21.160
So again, I have that breathing room,
but I don't have any hard returns.

610
00:28:21.160 --> 00:28:24.028
And I'm gonna take this text, and
I'm probably gonna make it bold, and

611
00:28:24.028 --> 00:28:27.147
we'll make it a little bit bigger anyway,
so it looks a little bit different.

612
00:28:27.147 --> 00:28:28.410
But I also want to do something else.

613
00:28:28.410 --> 00:28:31.000
I want to put either an underline
under it, or a double set of bars.

614
00:28:31.000 --> 00:28:34.800
Or maybe I want a colored box
back behind this text as well.

615
00:28:34.800 --> 00:28:36.660
And I can do that with paragraph rules.

616
00:28:36.660 --> 00:28:39.390
So under the Paragraph Panel,
under the Paragraph Panel Menu,

617
00:28:39.390 --> 00:28:41.120
called Paragraph Rules.

618
00:28:43.330 --> 00:28:45.770
And turn on the previews
we can see it happening,

619
00:28:45.770 --> 00:28:47.850
I can choose if I want to rule above or
below.

620
00:28:47.850 --> 00:28:49.670
I might want both and that's okay.

621
00:28:49.670 --> 00:28:51.868
So I can say let's do a rule above.

622
00:28:51.868 --> 00:28:53.610
And I turn that on.

623
00:28:53.610 --> 00:28:56.050
And it's above but why is it so low.

624
00:28:56.050 --> 00:28:56.810
It should not be above.

625
00:28:58.740 --> 00:29:02.360
That's very strange,
the rule above is not above at all, is it?

626
00:29:03.420 --> 00:29:06.400
Let's do a rule of below and see what
we can get with that, the rule above,

627
00:29:06.400 --> 00:29:08.800
actually set it down below,
should have been up above.

628
00:29:08.800 --> 00:29:10.160
I thought may be there was an offset.

629
00:29:10.160 --> 00:29:12.040
You can tell either by
how much to offset that.

630
00:29:12.040 --> 00:29:15.145
So I can have this, have a little bit
more breathing room, if I want to.

631
00:29:15.145 --> 00:29:16.930
You want something like that.

632
00:29:16.930 --> 00:29:21.080
I can play with color, text color is nice
because as I change the text color of that

633
00:29:21.080 --> 00:29:23.630
headline, the line will change as well.

634
00:29:23.630 --> 00:29:25.880
But I can also just say no,
let's make it cinnamon,

635
00:29:25.880 --> 00:29:28.350
let's make it a little bit bolder.

636
00:29:28.350 --> 00:29:31.900
I can tell it whether it's the width of
the column, which is sitting right now,

637
00:29:31.900 --> 00:29:35.710
or the width of the text itself so
the line will grow with the text.

638
00:29:35.710 --> 00:29:38.790
Now if you like the text but you also want
it to maybe stick out a little bit on

639
00:29:38.790 --> 00:29:40.590
the right, I can do that as well.

640
00:29:40.590 --> 00:29:43.290
Come here and give it a negative value,
which I know sounds weird, but

641
00:29:43.290 --> 00:29:45.330
it's negative because
it's moving out of that.

642
00:29:45.330 --> 00:29:46.880
So I can say it always
sticks out a little bit.

643
00:29:46.880 --> 00:29:48.040
I can do it on the left side too, but

644
00:29:48.040 --> 00:29:51.000
it might look a little weird here
because it hangs outside the text frame.

645
00:29:51.000 --> 00:29:55.800
But I can do that, and I can also,
in this case using the rule above or

646
00:29:55.800 --> 00:29:59.920
below, whichever one you want I can
make a colored bar back behind it.

647
00:29:59.920 --> 00:30:00.767
So, let's do that.

648
00:30:00.767 --> 00:30:06.095
I'm going to go ahead and tell it it's,
let's make it 80% of the cinnamon.

649
00:30:06.095 --> 00:30:07.659
And I closed it, didn't want to do that.

650
00:30:07.659 --> 00:30:10.620
I wanted to hit tab and
I went ahead and closed that.

651
00:30:10.620 --> 00:30:13.740
So when I do that I can also, like I said,
I can change the type of line.

652
00:30:13.740 --> 00:30:15.760
Maybe I want a wavy line
instead of a sold line.

653
00:30:15.760 --> 00:30:19.030
But we're gonna go back to the solid line
right now and I'm gonna go ahead and

654
00:30:19.030 --> 00:30:20.710
make this just a really really thick one.

655
00:30:20.710 --> 00:30:27.610
Let's make this actually like 30 and then,
return again just out of habit there.

656
00:30:27.610 --> 00:30:28.630
Let's come back to this.

657
00:30:28.630 --> 00:30:30.160
And I want to offset it.

658
00:30:30.160 --> 00:30:34.410
I'm gonna move it up a bit, so
let's just move it way up like this and

659
00:30:34.410 --> 00:30:40.250
now I've got my bar, my color bar back
behind it But that will change as I add

660
00:30:40.250 --> 00:30:45.530
this, I said if I call this the cool
time machine it keeps growing with that.

661
00:30:45.530 --> 00:30:46.680
If I hit return,

662
00:30:46.680 --> 00:30:50.410
I actually hit a hard return,
now it continues that line that's there.

663
00:30:50.410 --> 00:30:53.480
Now you notice I can't keep them
together unless I make a really,

664
00:30:53.480 --> 00:30:56.640
really fat border that, or
a fat line that's there.

665
00:30:56.640 --> 00:30:57.570
I can fake it.

666
00:30:57.570 --> 00:31:00.020
But, generally speaking,
it's because it's each paragraph, so

667
00:31:00.020 --> 00:31:02.060
we don't want to break it.

668
00:31:02.060 --> 00:31:04.430
If I do break,
it breaks it into two lines.

669
00:31:04.430 --> 00:31:06.090
And if I hit Shift + Return,

670
00:31:06.090 --> 00:31:09.990
which is a soft carriage return,
which keeps it in the same paragraph.

671
00:31:09.990 --> 00:31:12.290
Well, the underline is
only from the bottom.

672
00:31:12.290 --> 00:31:14.118
Now if I always know
it's gonna be two lines,

673
00:31:14.118 --> 00:31:17.257
I can make another one that's thick
enough to accommodate both those lines.

674
00:31:17.257 --> 00:31:18.921
So there's a little bit of
work arounds that you can do.

675
00:31:18.921 --> 00:31:23.233
But you can also do something fun,
like take this paragraph rule,

676
00:31:23.233 --> 00:31:26.934
and instead of doing a solid line,
I can do a dotted line.

677
00:31:26.934 --> 00:31:29.603
Which is kind of fun,
just some dots back there, but

678
00:31:29.603 --> 00:31:33.900
what you do is you can also is change the
color of the gap in between those lines.

679
00:31:33.900 --> 00:31:38.276
So I could make this also cinnamon 80%.

680
00:31:38.276 --> 00:31:41.520
And now I have a nice rounded
bar that's back behind it.

681
00:31:41.520 --> 00:31:42.510
So that's actually kind of cool.

682
00:31:42.510 --> 00:31:45.490
And then what works really well with
that is that this moves with the text,

683
00:31:45.490 --> 00:31:46.330
obviously.

684
00:31:46.330 --> 00:31:50.850
So if I have some other text up above,
I'm just gonna grab some.

685
00:31:50.850 --> 00:31:54.144
And paste that and return that,
whoops, let's do that one.

686
00:31:54.144 --> 00:31:58.890
And so now I have that so as this changes,
it automatically moves with it.

687
00:31:58.890 --> 00:32:02.280
I don't have to maintain
a separate element back behind it,

688
00:32:02.280 --> 00:32:04.760
behind that text and
have that move with him.

689
00:32:04.760 --> 00:32:07.405
So it's just some fun things to do,
obviously though as an underline,

690
00:32:07.405 --> 00:32:08.915
if you did an underline above and below.

691
00:32:08.915 --> 00:32:11.870
It's a nice way to set up your header
to look a little different and

692
00:32:11.870 --> 00:32:13.773
have just a little bit of offset in there.

693
00:32:13.773 --> 00:32:17.791
And again, build that into a style so
you don't have to do that.

694
00:32:17.791 --> 00:32:18.687
Every time.

695
00:32:18.687 --> 00:32:22.337
Whether it's the bubble header, or
if it's the line header, or whatever,

696
00:32:22.337 --> 00:32:23.813
we can build that into a style.

697
00:32:23.813 --> 00:32:26.651
And the last thing I wanna show you with
the text right now, is something that is

698
00:32:26.651 --> 00:32:29.200
not very exciting, but there's two
things that I like that are in it.

699
00:32:29.200 --> 00:32:30.430
And this is Tabs.

700
00:32:30.430 --> 00:32:32.090
I mean, tab text is boring, right?

701
00:32:32.090 --> 00:32:33.720
Well, we have to work with tabs.

702
00:32:33.720 --> 00:32:37.050
And as we see when we get into a future
episode when we talk about tables,

703
00:32:37.050 --> 00:32:40.160
we're gonna see that tabs come in super,
super handy with that.

704
00:32:40.160 --> 00:32:42.591
So all I'm gonna do is I'm
gonna type some text, and

705
00:32:42.591 --> 00:32:44.597
I'm just gonna hit tab in-between each.

706
00:32:44.597 --> 00:32:47.164
So 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, I'm gonna hit Return.

707
00:32:47.164 --> 00:32:50.610
And do a, and b, and c, and d, and e.

708
00:32:50.610 --> 00:32:51.438
So I just hit tab in-between.

709
00:32:51.438 --> 00:32:53.430
I can turn on my invisibles to see that.

710
00:32:53.430 --> 00:32:54.379
Those are tabs.

711
00:32:55.540 --> 00:32:56.840
Turn those back off.

712
00:32:56.840 --> 00:32:59.362
So if you're used to working with tabs,
you know that you can say, okay,

713
00:32:59.362 --> 00:33:00.635
I don't like the way these tabs are.

714
00:33:00.635 --> 00:33:03.270
I need to space out the tabs a little bit.

715
00:33:03.270 --> 00:33:04.440
I'm gonna go up into the Type menu.

716
00:33:04.440 --> 00:33:06.587
This is one that does not
live in the Window menu.

717
00:33:06.587 --> 00:33:09.080
It's over here in the Type menu > Tabs.

718
00:33:09.080 --> 00:33:11.200
And I can move this elsewhere if I want.

719
00:33:11.200 --> 00:33:14.820
It's nice because it locks into it, and
I can see where the tabs are gonna be.

720
00:33:14.820 --> 00:33:18.223
But I also can see tabs over here
if I click and hold on a tab.

721
00:33:18.223 --> 00:33:19.607
I assume everybody knows how to work tabs.

722
00:33:19.607 --> 00:33:20.990
I'm just gonna assume that you do.

723
00:33:20.990 --> 00:33:23.020
Here's a left tab, and
if I click and hold,

724
00:33:23.020 --> 00:33:24.920
though, I can see where
that tab is gonna sit.

725
00:33:24.920 --> 00:33:27.512
So I get a nice visual even
if it's not connected to it.

726
00:33:27.512 --> 00:33:29.440
And I can say, okay,
I really like where that sits.

727
00:33:29.440 --> 00:33:31.100
I like that spacing.

728
00:33:31.100 --> 00:33:32.240
Well, how many of you've done this?

729
00:33:32.240 --> 00:33:34.836
When you've done like, let's say,
we like it at three quarters of an inch.

730
00:33:34.836 --> 00:33:38.849
And you say, okay, so I need the next
one at, [SOUND], one and a half inches.

731
00:33:38.849 --> 00:33:40.673
The next one at two and a quarter inches.

732
00:33:40.673 --> 00:33:41.397
The next one at three.

733
00:33:41.397 --> 00:33:44.677
You sit there, and you do the math,
and you do the whole thing.

734
00:33:44.677 --> 00:33:47.650
And then you still have more room and
you needed to space it out more.

735
00:33:47.650 --> 00:33:49.205
Then you go,
maybe I make it seven-eighths, and

736
00:33:49.205 --> 00:33:50.320
then I gotta do all that math again.

737
00:33:50.320 --> 00:33:52.130
I'm not in to math.

738
00:33:52.130 --> 00:33:53.249
Here's what InDesign does for you.

739
00:33:53.249 --> 00:33:54.400
I like this spacing.

740
00:33:54.400 --> 00:33:56.090
Let's make it something really weird.

741
00:33:56.090 --> 00:33:58.380
Beautiful, I love the space between 1 and
2.

742
00:33:58.380 --> 00:33:59.930
Make everything else the same.

743
00:33:59.930 --> 00:34:02.110
Come over to the Tabs panel menu, and

744
00:34:02.110 --> 00:34:05.840
say, Repeat Tab, and
it repeats it at that same amount.

745
00:34:05.840 --> 00:34:06.840
You don't like that amount?

746
00:34:06.840 --> 00:34:08.540
Let's shorten that up.
It took up too much space.

747
00:34:08.540 --> 00:34:12.600
Shorten that up, Repeat Tab, and
it shortens it all back up again.

748
00:34:12.600 --> 00:34:15.030
So that, to me, is really super cool.

749
00:34:15.030 --> 00:34:18.210
The other thing is that you can position
the panel against the text frame by

750
00:34:18.210 --> 00:34:19.247
hitting that little magnet.

751
00:34:19.247 --> 00:34:20.973
That's a real quick way to do that.

752
00:34:20.973 --> 00:34:25.969
And also, obviously,
you can set up alignments.

753
00:34:25.969 --> 00:34:30.737
If you've got an align on a decimal point,
well there's no actual decimal point, but

754
00:34:30.737 --> 00:34:34.284
I can come over here and, instead,
say align on any character.

755
00:34:34.284 --> 00:34:36.760
So it doesn't have to be just
align on a decimal point.

756
00:34:36.760 --> 00:34:39.200
Maybe I know that there's always
an X in my product number or

757
00:34:39.200 --> 00:34:41.420
something like that, and
I want to align on that.

758
00:34:41.420 --> 00:34:43.798
So I can align on any character and,
of course, if I do that,

759
00:34:43.798 --> 00:34:46.290
there isn't an X here and
it doesn't know what to do with that.

760
00:34:46.290 --> 00:34:48.658
But there are a couple of
really cool things in Tabs.

761
00:34:48.658 --> 00:34:53.941
And like I said, when we look at tables
we will see that we go from tabs, and

762
00:34:53.941 --> 00:34:59.500
I can change this tabbed text into
columns and tables as well, super easily.

763
00:34:59.500 --> 00:35:01.665
So sometimes you set up tabs
a little bit ahead of time and

764
00:35:01.665 --> 00:35:03.752
then you're gonna make
a table out of it afterwards.

765
00:35:03.752 --> 00:35:06.063
So knowing a little bit
about tabs is good.

766
00:35:06.063 --> 00:35:07.776
It's not very exciting, but there it is.

767
00:35:07.776 --> 00:35:09.860
It's something we need to know.

768
00:35:09.860 --> 00:35:10.590
>> All right, Erica.

769
00:35:10.590 --> 00:35:12.300
Thank you for
all that information on text.

770
00:35:12.300 --> 00:35:14.230
Does look like we're coming to
the end of another episode.

771
00:35:14.230 --> 00:35:16.880
But before we sign out, do you have any
additional words you'd like to throw in?

772
00:35:16.880 --> 00:35:17.760
>> No, I think we're good.

773
00:35:17.760 --> 00:35:18.440
>> All right, very good.

774
00:35:18.440 --> 00:35:20.190
I look forward to seeing you
in the next episode, and

775
00:35:20.190 --> 00:35:21.680
we look forward to seeing you the viewers.

776
00:35:21.680 --> 00:35:24.111
Signing out for ITProTV,
I've been your host, Wes Bryan.

777
00:35:24.111 --> 00:35:24.951
>> And I'm Erica Gannon.

778
00:35:24.951 --> 00:35:27.079
>> And we will see you next time.

779
00:35:27.079 --> 00:35:35.450
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Erica explore text layouts within InDesign. They discuss OpenType, fractions, kerning pairs, and ligatures. They talk about importing text into InDesign such as import options, flowing, linking text, overset text, threads and smart text reflow.
episodes.title: Text Layout
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.015 --> 00:00:14.850
Welcome back to another exciting episode,
here at ITProTV.

3
00:00:14.850 --> 00:00:16.220
I'm your host, Wes Bryan, and

4
00:00:16.220 --> 00:00:20.420
in today's episode we're coming back at
you with more Adobe Creative Cloud 2015.

5
00:00:20.420 --> 00:00:24.100
That's right,
another episode inside of InDesign.

6
00:00:24.100 --> 00:00:26.250
Joining me back in the studios
today is Erica Gamet.

7
00:00:26.250 --> 00:00:27.090
Erica, how are you doing?

8
00:00:27.090 --> 00:00:28.050
>> I'm doing great, thanks.

9
00:00:28.050 --> 00:00:30.750
>> Great.
And really enjoying the journey that we've

10
00:00:30.750 --> 00:00:32.920
been on with InDesign, and
where are we gonna go next?

11
00:00:32.920 --> 00:00:34.080
>> More type.

12
00:00:34.080 --> 00:00:34.890
>> All right.
Very good.

13
00:00:34.890 --> 00:00:36.625
>> We'll look into diving
into some more type.

14
00:00:36.625 --> 00:00:37.220
[COUGH] Excuse me.

15
00:00:37.220 --> 00:00:40.810
So the first thing we're gonna do is
we're gonna start talking about OpenType.

16
00:00:40.810 --> 00:00:43.660
So OpenType is a type of font format.

17
00:00:43.660 --> 00:00:45.780
So you might have heard
something called PostScript or

18
00:00:45.780 --> 00:00:47.860
TrueType, there's also OpenType.

19
00:00:47.860 --> 00:00:49.590
And OpenType just allows for

20
00:00:49.590 --> 00:00:53.634
more of those glyphs that we talked
about in the previous episode.

21
00:00:53.634 --> 00:00:57.280
The characters, how many characters
we can get into one font.

22
00:00:57.280 --> 00:01:00.910
When I say a font I'm talking about
the actual physical, well I guess it's not

23
00:01:00.910 --> 00:01:04.640
really physical, it's digital, but
the actual package of the software that

24
00:01:04.640 --> 00:01:08.450
is a font that makes up a font when
we load a font into our machine.

25
00:01:08.450 --> 00:01:11.985
So an OpenType font and that's what all
your type kit fonts will be if you have

26
00:01:11.985 --> 00:01:15.370
the Creative Cloud and you have access
to Typekit, those are OpenType.

27
00:01:15.370 --> 00:01:18.340
And I always tell people that if
you're buying fonts make sure that you

28
00:01:18.340 --> 00:01:19.790
buy OpenType if you can,

29
00:01:19.790 --> 00:01:23.840
if it's an available option, because it
does have a lot more available to you.

30
00:01:23.840 --> 00:01:26.630
So the old fonts, I don't remember
how many characters they had.

31
00:01:26.630 --> 00:01:27.240
They weren't many.

32
00:01:27.240 --> 00:01:30.980
Some of the old ones didn't have a lot of
characters that you could fit into a font.

33
00:01:30.980 --> 00:01:35.320
OpenType can have up to
65,000 glyphs in one font.

34
00:01:35.320 --> 00:01:36.350
What does that mean to us?

35
00:01:36.350 --> 00:01:39.530
It means we have some cool stuff to
look at and some cool things that may or

36
00:01:39.530 --> 00:01:42.200
may not be built into a specific font, and

37
00:01:42.200 --> 00:01:44.550
again, it depends on what
font you're looking at.

38
00:01:44.550 --> 00:01:48.190
So I'm gonna go ahead and grab some text,
and we'll just look at some text here,

39
00:01:48.190 --> 00:01:52.660
and I wanna look at some of the different
OpenType features that are available here.

40
00:01:52.660 --> 00:01:55.084
So, I'm just gonna actually
put a couple returns in there,

41
00:01:55.084 --> 00:01:58.600
we're gonna put some things, we're gonna
put some numbers in here, we're gonna make

42
00:01:58.600 --> 00:02:01.760
this into fractions, and we're also
gonna look at things called ligatures.

43
00:02:01.760 --> 00:02:05.398
So again, this is something that's
built into the font, I just wanna kind

44
00:02:05.398 --> 00:02:08.890
of show you where to access this, and
your font may or may not have that.

45
00:02:08.890 --> 00:02:12.480
What we wanna look for though,
is in fonts, when we're looking at those,

46
00:02:12.480 --> 00:02:15.800
I'm gonna, take off that filter, is I'm
gonna come over here to the fonts, and

47
00:02:15.800 --> 00:02:19.320
I can see that some of them
have this O next to them.

48
00:02:19.320 --> 00:02:22.600
And if it's in color,
cuz the font menus used to be in color and

49
00:02:22.600 --> 00:02:25.490
they're not anymore, they're green and
black, is what you might see, so green and

50
00:02:25.490 --> 00:02:27.750
black O, and that's just O for OpenType.

51
00:02:27.750 --> 00:02:28.910
And that means, that, like I said,

52
00:02:28.910 --> 00:02:31.440
you probably have a lot more
options to choose from.

53
00:02:31.440 --> 00:02:34.610
The other thing that you'll notice
when you have an OpenType font is that

54
00:02:34.610 --> 00:02:39.640
you may have a lot of different faces,
different typefaces available to you.

55
00:02:39.640 --> 00:02:42.740
So when I've got this one, I'm not even
gonna attempt to pronounce that font, but

56
00:02:42.740 --> 00:02:44.650
I've got Light, Book,
Demi, Medium and Bold.

57
00:02:44.650 --> 00:02:47.280
So that's what you're looking for
when you choose a font,

58
00:02:47.280 --> 00:02:49.370
especially if you're going
to be doing a lot of text.

59
00:02:49.370 --> 00:02:54.350
You're going to want one with a lot of
different faces to it, you want bold and

60
00:02:54.350 --> 00:02:56.780
italic and medium and
condensed and all that so

61
00:02:56.780 --> 00:02:58.870
that you're not putting
in different fonts.

62
00:02:58.870 --> 00:03:01.150
You're not using Palentino and
Times and whatever else.

63
00:03:01.150 --> 00:03:02.400
You're not mixing all of those.

64
00:03:02.400 --> 00:03:06.180
It's all in the same family but
just different fonts off of that.

65
00:03:06.180 --> 00:03:08.408
So just keep in mind that's OpenTpe and

66
00:03:08.408 --> 00:03:12.860
there's a special OpenType menu to
access special OpenType features.

67
00:03:12.860 --> 00:03:14.920
So I'm gonna go over to
the Character panel.

68
00:03:16.230 --> 00:03:18.650
I'm gonna pull that off and
pull that up and

69
00:03:18.650 --> 00:03:20.820
in that Character panel
when I have text selected.

70
00:03:20.820 --> 00:03:23.700
So I'm just gonna select one
word just to start with, and

71
00:03:23.700 --> 00:03:26.620
I wanna make sure that I have
assigned an OpenType font to that.

72
00:03:26.620 --> 00:03:29.060
So I'm gonna come down to something like,
let's do Minion Pro.

73
00:03:31.410 --> 00:03:33.320
So I'm gonna choose that.

74
00:03:33.320 --> 00:03:34.610
Let's do Myriad instead.

75
00:03:34.610 --> 00:03:35.820
I only have regular in there.

76
00:03:35.820 --> 00:03:37.220
I want something with a lot of choices.

77
00:03:37.220 --> 00:03:37.880
Look at Myriad.

78
00:03:37.880 --> 00:03:40.880
When I choose Myriad Pro,
look at all those choices I have,

79
00:03:40.880 --> 00:03:44.300
even when I choose Myriad Pro regular when
I pull down this menu I can see that I

80
00:03:44.300 --> 00:03:48.120
have all those different fonts
available within that Myriad family and

81
00:03:48.120 --> 00:03:49.310
that's just good to know.

82
00:03:49.310 --> 00:03:51.400
So I put that in there,
I just made that one word Myriad,

83
00:03:51.400 --> 00:03:52.800
let's make it a little bit bigger as well.

84
00:03:52.800 --> 00:03:58.398
And then I'm going to go over to the
character panel menu and choose OpenType.

85
00:03:58.398 --> 00:04:01.450
And from OpenType I get this huge
menu that pops up from there.

86
00:04:01.450 --> 00:04:05.340
And we're not gonna worry about a lot
of that, just look and see at the top

87
00:04:05.340 --> 00:04:09.810
section, there are certain things like
Fractions, Ordinals, which are the numbers

88
00:04:09.810 --> 00:04:13.610
like first, second, the st, and
the nd and all that, those are ordinals.

89
00:04:13.610 --> 00:04:15.790
And some items are in brackets.

90
00:04:15.790 --> 00:04:20.500
If they're in brackets it means that they
are not available in this particular font.

91
00:04:20.500 --> 00:04:24.290
And what the fractions mean, it's not
that I can't type one, slash, two.

92
00:04:24.290 --> 00:04:26.117
And as we saw in the glimpse panel,

93
00:04:26.117 --> 00:04:29.030
they might have some
standard fractions built in.

94
00:04:29.030 --> 00:04:31.198
Like half, or a quarter and
an eighth maybe.

95
00:04:31.198 --> 00:04:36.115
But what OpenType can do if
they have fractions available,

96
00:04:36.115 --> 00:04:40.125
and they're not in the brackets,
is it can take any number that it sees

97
00:04:40.125 --> 00:04:43.325
as a fraction, and
actually format it to be a fraction.

98
00:04:43.325 --> 00:04:46.205
So that's one of the great things
about OpenType is that you have

99
00:04:46.205 --> 00:04:49.305
access to this special
handling of characters.

100
00:04:49.305 --> 00:04:51.895
So other things I might have
are things like ligatures.

101
00:04:51.895 --> 00:04:53.665
Now, this one does not
have ligatures at all.

102
00:04:53.665 --> 00:04:56.720
I'll show one in a minute that does
have ligatures, and also swashes.

103
00:04:56.720 --> 00:05:00.210
So we'll go with fractions for
this one and I'm going to turn it on, and

104
00:05:00.210 --> 00:05:02.880
actually I need to select all
the text where I want that to be,

105
00:05:02.880 --> 00:05:07.570
and then I'm going to go ahead and make
that Myriad or go Myriad Pro regular, and

106
00:05:07.570 --> 00:05:11.380
I'm going to turn on Fractions
from the Panel Menu.

107
00:05:11.380 --> 00:05:15.860
Under the OpenType select Fractions,
and what that does for me,

108
00:05:15.860 --> 00:05:19.300
is that when when I type a number,
if I type 12 and

109
00:05:19.300 --> 00:05:24.780
I type slash I go ahead and I get that
fraction number that's there already.

110
00:05:24.780 --> 00:05:26.790
So then, I know that that number is, or

111
00:05:26.790 --> 00:05:30.500
that text can handle whatever
fractions I end up with.

112
00:05:30.500 --> 00:05:32.580
I shouldn't have done
that when I first did it.

113
00:05:32.580 --> 00:05:33.400
Let's turn this off.

114
00:05:33.400 --> 00:05:34.429
Let's turn fractions off.

115
00:05:35.590 --> 00:05:38.410
And that's what it looks like
when I first type it, right?

116
00:05:38.410 --> 00:05:41.950
12 over 13, just any weird amount
that I can do and put it over that.

117
00:05:41.950 --> 00:05:44.890
But I can tell, oops,
needs to be numbers to be a fraction.

118
00:05:44.890 --> 00:05:49.950
Let's select just that text, and then
I'm coming here to OpenType Fractions.

119
00:05:49.950 --> 00:05:52.810
And it goes ahead and
it formats that as a fraction for me.

120
00:05:52.810 --> 00:05:55.670
I didn't have to have this
glyph that actually had that

121
00:05:57.240 --> 00:05:59.360
specific fraction in there.

122
00:05:59.360 --> 00:06:01.050
It just is those numbers.

123
00:06:01.050 --> 00:06:02.160
It sees it, sees the slash.

124
00:06:02.160 --> 00:06:05.430
As soon as I put the slash in there
it knows, that must be a fraction.

125
00:06:05.430 --> 00:06:08.310
I'm gonna change it to a different
font that I know we have some.

126
00:06:08.310 --> 00:06:12.770
Some swashes in here, so
it's called Caflisch Script Pro.

127
00:06:12.770 --> 00:06:15.900
And I'm just gonna zoom in a little
bit more on the text here.

128
00:06:15.900 --> 00:06:21.710
And I'm gonna find a letter T or let's see
a letter A maybe, N might work as well.

129
00:06:21.710 --> 00:06:23.240
I'm gonna have this all selected.

130
00:06:23.240 --> 00:06:27.120
I'm gonna go up again to that OpenType
menus and I'm gonna come in here and

131
00:06:27.120 --> 00:06:28.390
say swash.

132
00:06:28.390 --> 00:06:31.460
Now watch the upper case N in
nevertheless over here and

133
00:06:31.460 --> 00:06:34.260
it should change, hopefully that
has a different character to it.

134
00:06:35.330 --> 00:06:36.570
So now it's got swash.

135
00:06:36.570 --> 00:06:39.230
You can see it's a little bit more fancy,
it's got those swirls on it.

136
00:06:39.230 --> 00:06:40.730
And that's what swashes are.

137
00:06:40.730 --> 00:06:43.880
So it means that there's this
alternate set of characters for

138
00:06:43.880 --> 00:06:46.890
any of the letters that
are in this font here.

139
00:06:46.890 --> 00:06:48.370
Those are swashes.

140
00:06:48.370 --> 00:06:52.408
So again anything that you think, any
special typography that you might need,

141
00:06:52.408 --> 00:06:54.840
look into OpenTpe.

142
00:06:54.840 --> 00:06:57.730
And again typography is
a subject all to itself.

143
00:06:57.730 --> 00:07:01.230
We could go on and on about it and I'm
probably not the person to talk about that

144
00:07:01.230 --> 00:07:03.830
because sometimes I don't know
the difference between fonts but

145
00:07:03.830 --> 00:07:06.950
I have friends who do typer files and
I'm an embarrassment to them I'm sure.

146
00:07:06.950 --> 00:07:10.860
But I do like that I can come in here and
say, I don't really like the sort of,

147
00:07:10.860 --> 00:07:13.810
it looked more like handwriting or
just printing, I guess.

148
00:07:13.810 --> 00:07:15.200
In this particular font.

149
00:07:15.200 --> 00:07:18.380
When I turn on the swashes, it gives
it that little bit of extra flair,

150
00:07:18.380 --> 00:07:20.950
gives it more like
a handwriting feel to it.

151
00:07:20.950 --> 00:07:24.518
So, feel free to look in through
all the OpenType fonts or

152
00:07:24.518 --> 00:07:27.740
OpenType features, and again,
if it's in brackets it means that,

153
00:07:27.740 --> 00:07:30.690
that is not built into
that particular font.

154
00:07:30.690 --> 00:07:33.280
They're very well crafted
fonts generally speaking.

155
00:07:33.280 --> 00:07:36.000
So, that's kind of all I wanna
say about OpenType really.

156
00:07:36.000 --> 00:07:37.730
Just so you know it's there, know that,

157
00:07:37.730 --> 00:07:40.460
that's the prefered format if
you have an option to do that.

158
00:07:40.460 --> 00:07:42.100
I know that there's
a lot more to dig into,

159
00:07:42.100 --> 00:07:46.622
and it's all in that character panel,
inside the OpenType panel that's there.

160
00:07:46.622 --> 00:07:49.890
All right, I'm gonna bring in
a whole new plain document,

161
00:07:49.890 --> 00:07:53.620
and we're gonna start bringing
in text from different places.

162
00:07:53.620 --> 00:07:54.620
So we're gonna import it.

163
00:07:54.620 --> 00:07:56.769
And then we're gonna do text flow.

164
00:07:56.769 --> 00:08:00.130
I've showed in a couple of episodes
about linked text or overset text,

165
00:08:00.130 --> 00:08:02.382
where we have text jumping
from frame to frame.

166
00:08:02.382 --> 00:08:04.053
Even jumping across pages.

167
00:08:04.053 --> 00:08:05.653
And that's called threaded text.

168
00:08:05.653 --> 00:08:06.816
So we're gonna do that as well.

169
00:08:06.816 --> 00:08:08.472
But where does that text come from?

170
00:08:08.472 --> 00:08:09.768
Do I have to type this all in?

171
00:08:09.768 --> 00:08:10.302
Nope.

172
00:08:10.302 --> 00:08:12.490
Do I have to use placeholder
text all the time?

173
00:08:12.490 --> 00:08:13.150
Nope.

174
00:08:13.150 --> 00:08:16.960
So I could bring that in from elsewhere,
whether that's rich text file, or

175
00:08:16.960 --> 00:08:19.280
it's a Word file, or
even a plain text file.

176
00:08:19.280 --> 00:08:24.030
Anywhere I can import a text file,
InDesign can handle that text.

177
00:08:24.030 --> 00:08:29.240
And unlike picture links when we bring in
a picture we saw in a previous episode,

178
00:08:29.240 --> 00:08:32.890
we bring in an image it creates
a link back to the original.

179
00:08:32.890 --> 00:08:35.630
That is not the standard case for text.

180
00:08:35.630 --> 00:08:39.370
When I bring in text from somewhere
else it is now just text and

181
00:08:39.370 --> 00:08:41.750
InDesign as if I typed it myself.

182
00:08:41.750 --> 00:08:45.930
Now I do have the option of setting that
preference and telling it that it is

183
00:08:45.930 --> 00:08:50.220
a link, that the text will be a link
instead of actual text when it comes in.

184
00:08:50.220 --> 00:08:53.950
But generally speaking I don't do
that because if I make changes and

185
00:08:53.950 --> 00:08:56.690
format the text in InDesign and

186
00:08:56.690 --> 00:09:01.190
I bring it back in from Word or wherever
it came from, I lose my formatting.

187
00:09:01.190 --> 00:09:05.670
So that's something I generally don't do,
there are plugins that handle that,

188
00:09:05.670 --> 00:09:08.080
the kind of two way back and
forth, make changes in InDesign,

189
00:09:08.080 --> 00:09:10.350
changes in the Word file and vice versa.

190
00:09:10.350 --> 00:09:12.580
So if that's something you need to do,
a lot of back and

191
00:09:12.580 --> 00:09:16.490
forth with text and edits not being ready
when they actually come to InDesign which

192
00:09:16.490 --> 00:09:18.880
is a problem we all
deal with as designers.

193
00:09:18.880 --> 00:09:22.390
If that's something you do all the time
a plugin might be something you need to

194
00:09:22.390 --> 00:09:23.780
look for with that.

195
00:09:23.780 --> 00:09:27.228
That being said let's bring in

text actually being there.

408
00:20:31.970 --> 00:20:33.970
So, I don't have to wait
til the text is ready.

409
00:20:33.970 --> 00:20:36.050
Sometimes, you're waiting for
that text from a client.

410
00:20:36.050 --> 00:20:39.260
So, I can actually take a text frame,

411
00:20:39.260 --> 00:20:43.740
draw out the text frame, go to my
selection tool, click on the out port,

412
00:20:43.740 --> 00:20:45.930
even though there's no red plus
because there's no text in there.

413
00:20:45.930 --> 00:20:48.460
Just click on that and
I have all the same options.

414
00:20:48.460 --> 00:20:51.640
Hold down the Option key or
the Alt key and I could thread those.

415
00:20:51.640 --> 00:20:55.210
And these things are still threaded,
there's just not any text yet.

416
00:20:55.210 --> 00:20:58.950
So if I turn on those text threads,
make sure we can see those.

417
00:20:58.950 --> 00:21:02.290
They're actually the select one, when I do
that, I can see how those are connected,

418
00:21:02.290 --> 00:21:04.350
even though there's no text in there.

419
00:21:04.350 --> 00:21:08.670
That means that if I bring text in,
it will flow across all the frames.

420
00:21:08.670 --> 00:21:11.290
Or, if I'm just sitting in
this text story here and

421
00:21:11.290 --> 00:21:16.320
I do my fill with placeholder text
keyboard shortcut, I can click that, and

422
00:21:16.320 --> 00:21:19.880
it fills in all of them because it
knows that that's one continuous story.

423
00:21:19.880 --> 00:21:21.580
So that's known as a story,

424
00:21:21.580 --> 00:21:25.040
you've got a frames but
the story can be several frames long.

425
00:21:25.040 --> 00:21:29.460
I'm gonna delete actually all
of these cuz this is separate.

426
00:21:29.460 --> 00:21:33.559
I'm wanna pick back up with this story
that we left off back on this page and

427
00:21:33.559 --> 00:21:36.960
I'm gonna click on the red plus and

428
00:21:36.960 --> 00:21:39.870
I'm gonna open the page pound, so
you can kind of see what's happening.

429
00:21:39.870 --> 00:21:42.720
So we have two pages right now,
we have two blank ones as well,

430
00:21:42.720 --> 00:21:44.550
I am going to come to
this blank page three.

431
00:21:44.550 --> 00:21:50.380
Actually I am going to start new, delete
page four or page three really quick.

432
00:21:50.380 --> 00:21:53.540
So I have this page ,I have picked
it up from here, then I am going to

433
00:21:53.540 --> 00:21:57.190
come over here and I am going to
hold down the shift key this time.

434
00:21:57.190 --> 00:22:01.100
What the shift key does is it gives us
that same serpentine but it's solid.

435
00:22:01.100 --> 00:22:04.050
It's not partially dashed like
the other one, and what that is,

436
00:22:04.050 --> 00:22:06.090
that's complete auto flow.

437
00:22:06.090 --> 00:22:09.400
So when I hold on to that,
it's gonna fill it to the margins, and

438
00:22:09.400 --> 00:22:13.790
then it's going to add pages as necessary
until that entire story is placed.

439
00:22:13.790 --> 00:22:17.120
So if you know you have your guide set
up and you always know exactly, or

440
00:22:17.120 --> 00:22:18.930
you know that the margins are set up and

441
00:22:18.930 --> 00:22:23.360
you just wanna flow the text across the
pages, you can just do this on page one.

442
00:22:23.360 --> 00:22:25.780
Just go ahead and place that and
it just flows through.

443
00:22:25.780 --> 00:22:28.530
But the reason I opened the pages
panel is so you can see what happens.

444
00:22:28.530 --> 00:22:31.870
We're actually gonna see pages
being added and filled in as well.

445
00:22:31.870 --> 00:22:34.990
Hold down the shift key and I'm gonna
click and it's gonna fill it to the right

446
00:22:34.990 --> 00:22:38.490
and to the bottom margin and
it's gonna add pages until it's all done.

447
00:22:38.490 --> 00:22:41.700
So it does that, I go scroll down
here to the very last page and

448
00:22:41.700 --> 00:22:43.380
there's the end of the story.

449
00:22:43.380 --> 00:22:45.580
So it went ahead and
filled that entire thing for me.

450
00:22:45.580 --> 00:22:49.410
So you can see how threading the text
frames is really quick and easy to do.

451
00:22:49.410 --> 00:22:53.400
I'm gonna undo do that, when I do that,
it's also gonna delete all those pages

452
00:22:53.400 --> 00:22:56.430
because I just stepped backwards and
got rid of all of those.

453
00:22:56.430 --> 00:22:59.870
So the text threads, let's come
back here to these text threads and

454
00:22:59.870 --> 00:23:02.280
it doesn't matter that I don't
have the whole story placed.

455
00:23:02.280 --> 00:23:07.720
But what that is, is always keeping track
of which text frame is next in the thread.

456
00:23:07.720 --> 00:23:12.000
So the cool things is I can do things
like take this frame and delete it.

457
00:23:12.000 --> 00:23:14.420
And when I do,
it doesn't sever the story there,

458
00:23:14.420 --> 00:23:18.060
I delete it and
it says you must wanna just go ahead and

459
00:23:18.060 --> 00:23:20.150
keep continuing with what was there,
so it doesn't break it.

460
00:23:20.150 --> 00:23:23.590
It's like a chain link fence and pull it
one link and it's self-repairs itself,

461
00:23:23.590 --> 00:23:25.030
it just comes in and fixes and

462
00:23:25.030 --> 00:23:28.510
says let's just keep this chain going,
it just gets rid of it.

463
00:23:28.510 --> 00:23:33.040
The cool thing is I can also
put a frame back in as well.

464
00:23:33.040 --> 00:23:36.190
If I decide, I really want
an extra text frame over here,

465
00:23:36.190 --> 00:23:40.130
I can draw this text frame,
draw it out and

466
00:23:40.130 --> 00:23:43.970
then use my selection tool to select
the frame I want it to start in.

467
00:23:43.970 --> 00:23:46.956
And click the out port button and
I am going to roll over this one and

468
00:23:46.956 --> 00:23:50.536
I am get this kind of this chain link icon
that is there, and roll over that, and

469
00:23:50.536 --> 00:23:53.952
I click into it, and when I do that it
doesnt end there, it picks it back up,

470
00:23:53.952 --> 00:23:57.593
it says, you were inserting that chain
link, that little link into there.

471
00:23:57.593 --> 00:24:00.503
Great, so you can add and
subtract from there, easily.

472
00:24:00.503 --> 00:24:03.976
If I want to break the frame though,
or a break it here.

473
00:24:03.976 --> 00:24:07.144
And on this first frame and everything
else will be kind of left behind.

474
00:24:07.144 --> 00:24:10.490
I can click on the import for
the second story here.

475
00:24:10.490 --> 00:24:13.620
I'm gonna click on that and
roll over it and let's zoom in so

476
00:24:13.620 --> 00:24:16.740
you can actually see that and
it changes to that broken link icon.

477
00:24:16.740 --> 00:24:18.480
So it says,
you wanna break the link there?

478
00:24:18.480 --> 00:24:19.340
Yes I do.

479
00:24:19.340 --> 00:24:20.730
We break that there.

480
00:24:20.730 --> 00:24:25.540
When I do that, all these now become empty
and that's because I severed the link.

481
00:24:25.540 --> 00:24:28.660
Link is there, the story is still there
it's just all hiding in the end of here,

482
00:24:28.660 --> 00:24:31.570
I gotta pick it up from here and
start linking it whether it's,

483
00:24:31.570 --> 00:24:36.030
am linking it up to existing frames,
or if I start drawing out new ones.

484
00:24:36.030 --> 00:24:37.170
Right?
So the same thing.

485
00:24:37.170 --> 00:24:40.720
So linking is easy to put together and
to pull apart as well.

486
00:24:42.360 --> 00:24:43.850
Now, last thing with the text and

487
00:24:43.850 --> 00:24:47.560
the text flow that I wanna show,
is, some of the other options.

488
00:24:47.560 --> 00:24:49.600
I'm sorry, I don't want to do the options.

489
00:24:49.600 --> 00:24:51.820
I want to show you smart text re-flow.

490
00:24:51.820 --> 00:24:53.770
That is something that
was just introduced,

491
00:24:53.770 --> 00:24:55.490
I don't even know how many versions ago.

492
00:24:55.490 --> 00:24:56.430
It is fairly new.

493
00:24:56.430 --> 00:24:59.780
I'm going to show you an option for
it first, in the preferences.

494
00:24:59.780 --> 00:25:02.630
Command or
Control + K brings up your preferences.

495
00:25:02.630 --> 00:25:07.300
Under "In Design" menu on the Mac and
under the "Edit" menu on PCs.

496
00:25:07.300 --> 00:25:12.230
And I want to come down to,
type, and I can't remember,

497
00:25:12.230 --> 00:25:13.200
it's type and advanced type.

498
00:25:13.200 --> 00:25:14.820
I can't remember if that's advanced or
not.

499
00:25:14.820 --> 00:25:18.810
It's not, it's under type, down at
the bottom, it's called Smart text reflow.

500
00:25:18.810 --> 00:25:22.840
And this basically will add and
subtract pages as you have text.

501
00:25:22.840 --> 00:25:25.500
And if you're coming from Word,
you think big deal.

502
00:25:25.500 --> 00:25:27.490
Word's always had this, and it's true.

503
00:25:27.490 --> 00:25:30.000
It's something that's fairly
new in InDesign because

504
00:25:30.000 --> 00:25:34.560
they're adding in more and more word
processing type of features into InDesign.

505
00:25:34.560 --> 00:25:37.320
So, in this case,
smart text reflow is that.

506
00:25:37.320 --> 00:25:41.180
I can limit it to primary text frames,
we'll talk about that in a future episode

507
00:25:41.180 --> 00:25:43.930
of text frames,
that has something to do with master pages

508
00:25:43.930 --> 00:25:46.440
I'm going to deselect that because
I don't have that in this document.

509
00:25:46.440 --> 00:25:49.390
I want it to be any frames,
not just primary text frames.

510
00:25:49.390 --> 00:25:51.490
I also tell it delete empty pages.

511
00:25:51.490 --> 00:25:54.770
What that is going to do,
as I ad text, as I get more and

512
00:25:54.770 --> 00:25:59.020
more text,
it's going to add pages to that document.

513
00:25:59.020 --> 00:26:01.360
So, if I come in here,
make sure I have nothing on this page,

514
00:26:01.360 --> 00:26:03.950
I am going to bring in, new text.

515
00:26:03.950 --> 00:26:07.670
And I'm gonna bring in that same text that
we just had, and I'm gonna tell it "okay".

516
00:26:07.670 --> 00:26:12.179
And all I'm gonna do is draw out
the frame, just like I did before.

517
00:26:13.250 --> 00:26:15.180
For this text frame and let go.

518
00:26:15.180 --> 00:26:18.990
And I'm gonna sit there and
then nothing happens.

519
00:26:18.990 --> 00:26:23.590
The thing with smart reflow is you
have to sort of kick start it I guess.

520
00:26:23.590 --> 00:26:28.100
You have to have at least two pages that
have one linked story for it to start.

521
00:26:28.100 --> 00:26:30.950
And that's maybe because if you put that
down there and it just added pages and

522
00:26:30.950 --> 00:26:32.620
linked it all together
it would frighten you.

523
00:26:32.620 --> 00:26:34.650
I don't know why it works that way,
but it does.

524
00:26:34.650 --> 00:26:37.790
So what I'm going to do is I'm going
to do the same thing we just did,

525
00:26:37.790 --> 00:26:40.100
add a page, and drag this out.

526
00:26:40.100 --> 00:26:45.290
Then when I let go, we will see
that the pages will add hopefully,

527
00:26:45.290 --> 00:26:46.540
somewhere along the way.

528
00:26:46.540 --> 00:26:48.300
There we go.
It takes a little while sometimes.

529
00:26:48.300 --> 00:26:49.260
But it went ahead and added it.

530
00:26:49.260 --> 00:26:52.730
I just added one, but because I had those
two pages with one linked textframe,

531
00:26:52.730 --> 00:26:59.190
it says you must want to add that, and
add the pages as necessary and fill it in.

532
00:26:59.190 --> 00:27:02.780
Here's the cool thing though, let's take
the end of this story and just delete it.

533
00:27:02.780 --> 00:27:05.700
That's on page 15, you can see down here,
I'm just gonna go ahead and

534
00:27:05.700 --> 00:27:08.440
delete everything up to that paragraph,
and

535
00:27:08.440 --> 00:27:12.840
I delete it And as soon as I do that,
page 15 went away.

536
00:27:12.840 --> 00:27:13.800
So it's not even there.

537
00:27:13.800 --> 00:27:15.390
So it says, it deletes empty pages.

538
00:27:15.390 --> 00:27:18.020
So it knows when you need a page,
it adds it, and

539
00:27:18.020 --> 00:27:19.500
if you don't need it, it deletes it.

540
00:27:19.500 --> 00:27:22.560
Now this is really cool if you're doing,
say a large catalogue layout,

541
00:27:22.560 --> 00:27:25.130
it's nice cuz it'll add pages
to the section for you.

542
00:27:25.130 --> 00:27:26.620
But it is something you
need to be aware of,

543
00:27:26.620 --> 00:27:29.210
that if you start deleting
things earlier in the section,

544
00:27:29.210 --> 00:27:31.630
you might not realize that it
actually deleted a page on you.

545
00:27:31.630 --> 00:27:35.630
So it's one of those things that is great,
but takes a lot of responsibility.

546
00:27:35.630 --> 00:27:37.060
What is it Spiderman says, you know?

547
00:27:37.060 --> 00:27:38.550
With great power comes
great responsibility.

548
00:27:38.550 --> 00:27:42.640
And that's one of those cases in
InDesign where that is absolutely true.

549
00:27:42.640 --> 00:27:45.370
So that's smart text reflow.

550
00:27:45.370 --> 00:27:45.900
>> All right.

551
00:27:45.900 --> 00:27:48.910
Well we appreciate you taking
the time to show us that, Erica.

552
00:27:48.910 --> 00:27:50.900
It does look like we're coming
to the end of another episode.

553
00:27:50.900 --> 00:27:52.460
However, before we sign off,

554
00:27:52.460 --> 00:27:54.600
do you have any additional words
you wanna throw in about text?

555
00:27:54.600 --> 00:27:57.740
>> Nope, just know where your text threads
are because sometimes it's hard to keep

556
00:27:57.740 --> 00:27:58.620
track of them.

557
00:27:58.620 --> 00:27:59.490
>> All right, very good.

558
00:27:59.490 --> 00:28:01.300
Well thank you for
joining us here in the studios and

559
00:28:01.300 --> 00:28:02.630
thank you to the viewer for watching.

560
00:28:02.630 --> 00:28:05.220
Signing off for ITPro TV,
I've been your host Wes Bryan.

561
00:28:05.220 --> 00:28:06.300
>> And I'm Erica Gamut.

562
00:28:06.300 --> 00:28:08.431
>> And we'll see you next time.

563
00:28:08.431 --> 00:28:14.894
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Erica demonstrate working with tables within Adobe InDesign. They discuss importing tables from external applications like Microsoft Excel and Microsoft Word as well as creating new table from the table menu inside of InDesign. They look at the some table basics like the type tool, rows, columns, cells, colors, cell options , headers and embedding images.
episodes.title: Working with Tables
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:11.973 --> 00:00:14.878
Welcome back to another exciting
episode here at at ITProTV.

3
00:00:14.878 --> 00:00:18.974
I'm your host, Wes Bryan, and in today's
episode we're continuing through our

4
00:00:18.974 --> 00:00:21.095
series in Adobe Creative Cloud 2015.

5
00:00:21.095 --> 00:00:24.125
That's right, more specifically,
we're looking at InDesign and

6
00:00:24.125 --> 00:00:27.140
joining me back in the studios today
is none other than Erica Gamet.

7
00:00:27.140 --> 00:00:28.220
Erica, how you doing today?

8
00:00:28.220 --> 00:00:29.130
>> I'm doing fantastic.

9
00:00:29.130 --> 00:00:31.850
>> Great, so we've been going
through our series here on InDesign.

10
00:00:31.850 --> 00:00:32.930
What are we looking at next?

11
00:00:32.930 --> 00:00:34.650
>> Now we're gonna work with tables.

12
00:00:34.650 --> 00:00:38.700
So I know that doesn't sound super, super
exciting, but we're gonna do that anyway.

13
00:00:38.700 --> 00:00:41.590
In fact, to get you a little bit more
excited about tables than you probably

14
00:00:41.590 --> 00:00:44.670
already are I'm gonna show
you some fun uses for tables.

15
00:00:44.670 --> 00:00:47.630
So tables, or graphs or charts or
whatever we wanna call them,

16
00:00:47.630 --> 00:00:51.810
or charts I guess, sometimes we always
think it's just tabular information, so

17
00:00:51.810 --> 00:00:57.360
just spreadsheets or
financial information in an annual report.

18
00:00:57.360 --> 00:00:58.710
But the great thing is in InDesign,

19
00:00:58.710 --> 00:01:02.250
if we are doing an annual report,
we do need that tabular information.

20
00:01:02.250 --> 00:01:04.290
But we can also make it look really cool.

21
00:01:04.290 --> 00:01:07.960
So I'm going to actually just jump in and
show you some samples of

22
00:01:07.960 --> 00:01:10.960
interesting tables anyway and
just different uses for tables.

23
00:01:10.960 --> 00:01:13.730
I've just got this file here with
just a bunch of samples in it.

24
00:01:13.730 --> 00:01:15.400
And these are actual tables.

25
00:01:15.400 --> 00:01:18.910
Now I know they don't actually
look like tables and we're gonna

26
00:01:18.910 --> 00:01:21.780
actually build some of these so that you
can see what you can do with a table.

27
00:01:21.780 --> 00:01:25.120
So in this case, I have this workshop,
that little logo,

28
00:01:25.120 --> 00:01:27.560
that graphic is actually a table.

29
00:01:27.560 --> 00:01:31.590
These two images, these two
pictures are actually in a table.

30
00:01:31.590 --> 00:01:35.640
But it just looks like they're two
picture frames with pictures in them.

31
00:01:35.640 --> 00:01:37.700
But again, that's done as a table.

32
00:01:37.700 --> 00:01:42.050
I jump to the next page, close this
panel out of my way, and jump to that.

33
00:01:42.050 --> 00:01:44.330
That grid is also a table.

34
00:01:44.330 --> 00:01:46.270
So I can make that into a table.

35
00:01:46.270 --> 00:01:50.830
Think how much time this would take if we
were just drawing out lines and boxes.

36
00:01:50.830 --> 00:01:54.900
But if we make this a table and it's blue
and it's maybe an eighth of an inch.

37
00:01:54.900 --> 00:01:55.730
And the client comes back and

38
00:01:55.730 --> 00:01:59.160
says, actually I need each of those
grid marks to be half an inch,

39
00:01:59.160 --> 00:02:02.950
I can just make one change in the table
settings and it changes for me.

40
00:02:04.460 --> 00:02:05.870
This is also a table.

41
00:02:05.870 --> 00:02:09.227
So this is something you may end up having
to to do a lot when you're working in

42
00:02:09.227 --> 00:02:09.760
InDesign.

43
00:02:09.760 --> 00:02:13.230
Not everything we do is really
exciting cool advertisements.

44
00:02:13.230 --> 00:02:16.150
A lot of it, a lot of what I do is
what I like to call grunt work.

45
00:02:16.150 --> 00:02:17.260
But I like the grunt work.

46
00:02:17.260 --> 00:02:21.440
I like making a really nice looking
form because forms are everywhere.

47
00:02:21.440 --> 00:02:22.300
You have to make forms.

48
00:02:22.300 --> 00:02:23.740
People have to fill out forms.

49
00:02:23.740 --> 00:02:25.150
There's no need for them to be boring.

50
00:02:25.150 --> 00:02:29.860
Now this one isn't exactly exciting but
at least it looks better than just name,

51
00:02:29.860 --> 00:02:33.270
line, address, line, so I gave it
a little bit of something different.

52
00:02:33.270 --> 00:02:34.580
We've got some nice headers.

53
00:02:34.580 --> 00:02:36.600
But again, this is done in a table.

54
00:02:36.600 --> 00:02:40.950
Now, why do it in a table instead of just
drawing out lines and boxes, is because

55
00:02:40.950 --> 00:02:44.880
when changes happen, and anybody
that has a client knows that change

56
00:02:44.880 --> 00:02:48.540
happens all the time, and not usually
at the most opportune time, either.

57
00:02:48.540 --> 00:02:51.380
So for me, if I set this up in a table and

58
00:02:51.380 --> 00:02:54.390
I suddenly realize that there isn't enough
room for people to write their names.

59
00:02:54.390 --> 00:02:55.610
I need to make it bigger.

60
00:02:55.610 --> 00:02:59.660
I can, again, across the board
in one little operation make

61
00:02:59.660 --> 00:03:04.310
all the lines bigger or all the spaces for
writing in bigger because it's in a table.

62
00:03:04.310 --> 00:03:09.990
Basically anything that has
to be laid out, I don't know,

63
00:03:09.990 --> 00:03:14.030

503
00:24:52.954 --> 00:25:00.050
So I can either go into here,
Table > Cell Options > Strokes and Fills.

504
00:25:00.050 --> 00:25:02.270
And fill in what the stroke is here.

505
00:25:02.270 --> 00:25:04.140
Or I can just use the control panel.

506
00:25:04.140 --> 00:25:08.290
Or if my color swatches are open,
I can just grab a swatch and

507
00:25:08.290 --> 00:25:11.270
drag it on top of a cell, so
I can just do that as well.

508
00:25:11.270 --> 00:25:12.630
So if I just want this to go here,

509
00:25:12.630 --> 00:25:16.460
boom, I can color each cell
individually easily that way as well.

510
00:25:17.590 --> 00:25:20.580
How did we do stuff like this,
the graphics in here?

511
00:25:20.580 --> 00:25:23.830
Well, putting a graphic in a cell,
it used to be really difficult.

512
00:25:23.830 --> 00:25:27.210
They've made it a lot easier,
they have a new tool for doing that.

513
00:25:27.210 --> 00:25:29.168
Let's come down here.

514
00:25:29.168 --> 00:25:33.660
Let's actually do right in here,
and we're gonna go ahead and

515
00:25:33.660 --> 00:25:35.910
put a graphic inside the cell.

516
00:25:35.910 --> 00:25:41.110
I'm just gonna do a simple table,
just a 2 by 2.

517
00:25:41.110 --> 00:25:43.150
Create the table, 2 by 2,
put that in there.

518
00:25:44.360 --> 00:25:47.966
Drag this out, and I'm gonna go ahead and
put an image in there.

519
00:25:47.966 --> 00:25:50.920
But what I wanna do first is I
wanna select all the cells, so

520
00:25:50.920 --> 00:25:53.030
I just come up here and select all those.

521
00:25:53.030 --> 00:25:55.160
And I wanna set a couple options first.

522
00:25:55.160 --> 00:25:59.050
Under the Table menu,
come into Cell Options > Text.

523
00:25:59.050 --> 00:26:02.570
And I wanna turn off this offset,
I wanna make sure the offset is 0.

524
00:26:02.570 --> 00:26:05.220
Otherwise, we're gonna have a gap
before the image, where the image is,

525
00:26:05.220 --> 00:26:07.880
there's gonna be a gap
between the stroke and that.

526
00:26:07.880 --> 00:26:10.890
So I'm gonna go ahead and
just tell it none,

527
00:26:10.890 --> 00:26:15.340
and then I also wanna tell it to
clip the contents to the cell.

528
00:26:15.340 --> 00:26:18.570
So like the table can run
outside the text frame,

529
00:26:18.570 --> 00:26:21.690
an image can run over to
the right side of a cell.

530
00:26:21.690 --> 00:26:23.890
So if it's too big, it's just
gonna run over into the next cell,

531
00:26:23.890 --> 00:26:25.370
which might not be what we're looking for.

532
00:26:25.370 --> 00:26:27.900
If I tell it Clip Contents,
it will clip it at the end.

533
00:26:27.900 --> 00:26:31.450
It will automatically clip it
at the bottom, though, and so

534
00:26:31.450 --> 00:26:32.800
I can go ahead and say OK.

535
00:26:32.800 --> 00:26:33.910
Now I know that's all set up, so

536
00:26:33.910 --> 00:26:38.890
that when I put an image in here, I just
have my cursor in here, do Cmd or Ctrl+D.

537
00:26:38.890 --> 00:26:41.930
And basically, what we're doing is
we're creating an inline graphic,

538
00:26:41.930 --> 00:26:43.870
which we did in an earlier episode.

539
00:26:43.870 --> 00:26:45.730
We're putting an image
inside a text frame.

540
00:26:45.730 --> 00:26:48.570
It's just this text frame
also lives inside a table,

541
00:26:48.570 --> 00:26:49.730
which is inside a text frame.

542
00:26:49.730 --> 00:26:51.380
I know it gets confusing,
it's like Inception.

543
00:26:51.380 --> 00:26:54.250
But I can come in here and
just drop that item in there.

544
00:26:54.250 --> 00:26:56.410
So I'm gonna go find one of
the pictures that we have.

545
00:26:56.410 --> 00:26:58.450
We'll just drop in a photo.

546
00:26:58.450 --> 00:27:00.100
Come in here.

547
00:27:00.100 --> 00:27:01.210
Let's grab a cactus.

548
00:27:01.210 --> 00:27:02.370
We haven't looked at a cactus lately.

549
00:27:02.370 --> 00:27:05.240
We'll do that, and
I'll turn off the import options,

550
00:27:05.240 --> 00:27:08.390
and I just want to drop right inside and
let go.

551
00:27:08.390 --> 00:27:11.060
And now that image fits
right inside there.

552
00:27:11.060 --> 00:27:13.500
Now I can select this,
just like any other image.

553
00:27:13.500 --> 00:27:15.000
I can move it around.

554
00:27:15.000 --> 00:27:16.830
Sometimes once you get it inside a frame,

555
00:27:16.830 --> 00:27:19.150
it's a little more difficult
to make changes to it.

556
00:27:19.150 --> 00:27:20.270
I saw they've made some changes.

557
00:27:20.270 --> 00:27:22.090
It's a bit easier than it used to be.

558
00:27:22.090 --> 00:27:26.650
But it used to be kind of difficult to
get it once you put it in there to make

559
00:27:26.650 --> 00:27:28.024
changes to the size.

560
00:27:28.024 --> 00:27:32.003
So what I have always done and find that
I don't need to as much anymore is I

561
00:27:32.003 --> 00:27:35.752
tend to place the image on top of
the table, just kind of on top of it.

562
00:27:35.752 --> 00:27:38.820
Get it to size, get it pretty good,
and then I copy that or

563
00:27:38.820 --> 00:27:42.780
cut that to the paste board, and
then paste it inside, so that I know.

564
00:27:42.780 --> 00:27:45.430
Instead of pasting it and
realizing your image is this big, and

565
00:27:45.430 --> 00:27:49.440
it's off the edge of the screen and trying
to size it down within a table cell,

566
00:27:49.440 --> 00:27:52.260
I just find that a little difficult.

567
00:27:52.260 --> 00:27:54.430
So yeah, so
we can jump these across the board.

568
00:27:54.430 --> 00:27:55.900
We can do some setup to this.

569
00:27:55.900 --> 00:27:57.715
Let's actually do that,
I wanna merge these.

570
00:27:57.715 --> 00:27:59.780
Cuz we didn't finish this guy here.

571
00:27:59.780 --> 00:28:03.453
I'm gonna reset my workspace really
quickly, so everything goes back nicely.

572
00:28:03.453 --> 00:28:05.550
And we need to merge these
items that are here.

573
00:28:05.550 --> 00:28:10.270
So I'm gonna go ahead and select all of
these and say, merge those cells, and

574
00:28:10.270 --> 00:28:11.030
do the same here.

575
00:28:11.030 --> 00:28:13.540
Unfortunately, you have to do each one,
because if I say merge,

576
00:28:13.540 --> 00:28:16.660
if I grab two rows and the merge,
it will make one large cell.

577
00:28:16.660 --> 00:28:17.730
And we don't wanna do that.

578
00:28:17.730 --> 00:28:20.440
There actually is a script for that
that lets you select multiple rows and

579
00:28:20.440 --> 00:28:21.990
just say merge all the columns.

580
00:28:21.990 --> 00:28:23.010
So I would merge all those.

581
00:28:23.010 --> 00:28:25.060
I'm not gonna take time
to merge all of them, but

582
00:28:25.060 --> 00:28:28.355
I can see that I can merge each one,
and now I have my individual lines.

583
00:28:28.355 --> 00:28:32.000
And now when it says I wanna make these
bigger, so I can come back here and

584
00:28:32.000 --> 00:28:34.110
make these bigger if I want.

585
00:28:34.110 --> 00:28:35.800
And then maybe I want these to be smaller.

586
00:28:35.800 --> 00:28:38.250
Well, the nice thing is,
I can always just pull that up, and

587
00:28:38.250 --> 00:28:41.090
it will stop, because it won't let me
get rid of that text that's there.

588
00:28:41.090 --> 00:28:44.035
It says, it's gonna stop when
I hit that particular text.

589
00:28:44.035 --> 00:28:47.585
So for me, what I do is I set the big one
sometimes, and then I come back here,

590
00:28:47.585 --> 00:28:49.665
just pull that up because I don't
really have to think about it.

591
00:28:49.665 --> 00:28:52.955
It stops it when it hits the text,
and I think that looks pretty nice,

592
00:28:52.955 --> 00:28:56.510
even if I have to come back and
rearrange the size of these frames again.

593
00:28:56.510 --> 00:28:58.612
So again, I'm gonna do it as tabs.

594
00:28:58.612 --> 00:29:00.510
I'm gonna create a table from that, and

595
00:29:00.510 --> 00:29:03.870
then I'm gonna start getting rid
of what I do and don't need.

596
00:29:03.870 --> 00:29:05.190
Now if I, at some point, decide,

597
00:29:05.190 --> 00:29:10.230
I actually needed something else here in
the state, I can select that entire cell,

598
00:29:10.230 --> 00:29:15.070
and then I can come up to the table menu
and split that horizontally or vertically.

599
00:29:15.070 --> 00:29:18.090
So I can split that, and
now I have an extra row to work with.

600
00:29:18.090 --> 00:29:20.893
Now I can grab this,
holding down the Shift key, and

601
00:29:20.893 --> 00:29:22.944
I can move that only to the next point.

602
00:29:22.944 --> 00:29:25.710
Notice I can move that through there,
I can't jump over.

603
00:29:25.710 --> 00:29:28.560
I can move it anywhere in that
original cell that I split, but

604
00:29:28.560 --> 00:29:30.740
I can't get it to go outside of that.

605
00:29:30.740 --> 00:29:36.460
So sometimes when you're setting up
your table using tab text to start with,

606
00:29:36.460 --> 00:29:38.860
think about how many times
you have to tab over and

607
00:29:38.860 --> 00:29:41.170
where all you're gonna
need your vertical lines.

608
00:29:41.170 --> 00:29:44.840
Although for me, I tend to do this, if I
knew I just needed one extra here, and

609
00:29:44.840 --> 00:29:48.790
it doesn't need, say, an extra line,
I just needed some more information here,

610
00:29:48.790 --> 00:29:52.190
I'm gonna cheat and
I'm just gonna set up a tab inside there.

611
00:29:52.190 --> 00:29:56.010
Now I can't just hit Tab because when
I do that, it tabs to the next frame.

612
00:29:56.010 --> 00:29:58.610
So what I need to do if I actually
wanna work with a tab, and

613
00:29:58.610 --> 00:30:02.400
I want some text over here, I have to
hold down the Option or the Alt key.

614
00:30:02.400 --> 00:30:06.440
And it tabs it and then I can put
whatever extra info needs to go in here.

615
00:30:06.440 --> 00:30:08.170
When I select this text and

616
00:30:08.170 --> 00:30:13.490
bring up the Tabs panel, you notice it
just works with that particular cell.

617
00:30:13.490 --> 00:30:16.840
So again, it's kinda like a paragraph
inside that text frame that's here.

618
00:30:16.840 --> 00:30:19.910
And I can set where
that tab actually sits.

619
00:30:19.910 --> 00:30:23.230
And if you're not working with strokes and
fills, you don't need to even worry about

620
00:30:23.230 --> 00:30:26.695
necessarily getting those
extra lines that are there.

621
00:30:26.695 --> 00:30:30.200
I, a lot of times, if I don't have the
extra lines that I need, I will cheat and

622
00:30:30.200 --> 00:30:33.360
just use the tabs that are inside there,
because again, it saves me so

623
00:30:33.360 --> 00:30:35.350
much more time down the line.

624
00:30:35.350 --> 00:30:40.140
One of the things I can do on the table
settings, I choose the entire table,

625
00:30:40.140 --> 00:30:43.460
the upper left, I click on that, I can
come in here to the table settings and

626
00:30:43.460 --> 00:30:44.770
do Table Options.

627
00:30:44.770 --> 00:30:48.610
And I can alternate either the strokes or
the fills, and I'm gonna alternate

628
00:30:48.610 --> 00:30:52.140
the fills really quickly, and
I'm gonna say alternate every other row.

629
00:30:52.140 --> 00:30:55.460
Let's turn on the preview, so we can see
that, and I can alternate every other row.

630
00:30:55.460 --> 00:30:59.480
The first row and the next rows, I can
tell it, let's say it's black 20%, and

631
00:30:59.480 --> 00:31:02.130
then let's make it yellow for the next.

632
00:31:02.130 --> 00:31:03.285
And I can go ahead and say OK.

633
00:31:03.285 --> 00:31:05.670
There's a lot of other options in there,
I won't go over all, but

634
00:31:05.670 --> 00:31:09.430
you can see that you can get
this nice alternating pattern.

635
00:31:09.430 --> 00:31:13.488
That's why when I do things like that
description, the tips and tricks here,

636
00:31:13.488 --> 00:31:17.298
I do the alternating pattern with that,
and then that way, if I add a whole

637
00:31:17.298 --> 00:31:21.378
new row, which I can do, I can select
a row here and say, Table > Insert a Row.

638
00:31:21.378 --> 00:31:23.380
Let's go ahead and insert one row.

639
00:31:23.380 --> 00:31:28.940
When I do that, I just do one below that,
it automatically puts in that new row.

640
00:31:28.940 --> 00:31:34.070
And it's gonna go ahead and
give me the alternating fills from that.

641
00:31:34.070 --> 00:31:35.480
Actually, did it do an alternating row?

642
00:31:35.480 --> 00:31:37.650
Let's see, let's go Alternating Fills.

643
00:31:37.650 --> 00:31:38.900
I do have alternate, it has two rows.

644
00:31:38.900 --> 00:31:41.110
That's why, we only want one of each.

645
00:31:41.110 --> 00:31:44.380
It had two, because I actually,
what I have in here is a little cheat.

646
00:31:44.380 --> 00:31:47.610
I wanted some extra room, so there was
actually an extra row between each

647
00:31:47.610 --> 00:31:48.970
to give me that little
bit of buffer space.

648
00:31:48.970 --> 00:31:51.280
So I would have had to
actually add two rows, so

649
00:31:51.280 --> 00:31:52.870
that they would actually
come into that new color.

650
00:31:52.870 --> 00:31:56.090
But you can see how easy it is
to add that in there afterwards.

651
00:31:56.090 --> 00:31:59.670
So while we're not always working with
tabular information with a table,

652
00:31:59.670 --> 00:32:02.750
you can see where having
them set up is super easy.

653
00:32:02.750 --> 00:32:06.380
So the very last thing I wanna
show you is this sample here.

654
00:32:06.380 --> 00:32:10.148
If I look at this particular table and I
select this and I decide I didn't want it

655
00:32:10.148 --> 00:32:13.914
to be in light blue, which doesn't show
up when you put it, say, on a copier,

656
00:32:13.914 --> 00:32:16.910
it's non re-probe blue,
I want it to be black, but 10%.

657
00:32:16.910 --> 00:32:18.900
I want it to show up, but very fine.

658
00:32:18.900 --> 00:32:20.886
I can change those strokes super,
super easy.

659
00:32:20.886 --> 00:32:25.102
I can go up into Table >
Cell Options > Strokes and Fills.

660
00:32:25.102 --> 00:32:29.158
And I tell it that I want the stroke
to be, instead of the blue,

661
00:32:29.158 --> 00:32:31.189
I want it to be black, 10%.

662
00:32:31.189 --> 00:32:35.008
And the other thing that I have here
is this is just sort of a proxy of

663
00:32:35.008 --> 00:32:38.211
the different rows and
columns that we've selected.

664
00:32:38.211 --> 00:32:42.978
So when I have multiple cells selected,
these lines are the inside lines, and

665
00:32:42.978 --> 00:32:46.820
these are the outside lines of
the actual table that's there.

666
00:32:46.820 --> 00:32:50.440
It's hard to see, I know, because
everything's selected, but if I just want

667
00:32:50.440 --> 00:32:54.000
the inside lines to be affected and not
the outside ones, I double click on that.

668
00:32:54.000 --> 00:32:55.620
And just those inside ones are selected,
and

669
00:32:55.620 --> 00:32:57.460
that's the only change
I'm making to those.

670
00:32:57.460 --> 00:33:00.500
If I select the outside ones
by double-clicking on them,

671
00:33:00.500 --> 00:33:02.630
I can say let's make the outside ones.

672
00:33:02.630 --> 00:33:05.210
Let's make those actually red,
and they'll actually be thicker.

673
00:33:05.210 --> 00:33:08.470
So all the outside ones that
I selected will be red.

674
00:33:08.470 --> 00:33:09.790
Hopefully, we can see that.

675
00:33:09.790 --> 00:33:11.450
Let's zoom in a little bit.

676
00:33:11.450 --> 00:33:14.165
And you can see that the outside
became that 10% red, and

677
00:33:14.165 --> 00:33:16.900
the inside became the 10%
black that's there.

678
00:33:16.900 --> 00:33:18.630
So that's how we change the cells on that.

679
00:33:18.630 --> 00:33:21.975
So you can see how quickly that works,
instead of having all these lines

680
00:33:21.975 --> 00:33:25.397
inside a box that we would have to move
every time we need to make a change.

681
00:33:25.397 --> 00:33:28.981
Especially when we change it, we decide
to change the size of the cell width or

682
00:33:28.981 --> 00:33:32.830
height, we can just go into that cell
options and make the change there as well.

683
00:33:32.830 --> 00:33:34.000
So use tables.

684
00:33:34.000 --> 00:33:36.670
Think about where you would use tables
that you wouldn't normally think about it.

685
00:33:36.670 --> 00:33:39.420
And just figure out how you
can organize it with a table.

686
00:33:39.420 --> 00:33:41.058
It makes changes so much easier.

687
00:33:41.058 --> 00:33:44.640
>> Erica, thank you for all that great
information on tables, and we hope you're

688
00:33:44.640 --> 00:33:48.240
a little bit more prepared if you do have
to enter in some tabular data yourself.

689
00:33:48.240 --> 00:33:51.130
Now looking at the clock, it does look
like we're coming to another episode, but

690
00:33:51.130 --> 00:33:53.640
before we do, do you have any additional
information you'd like to put in here?

691
00:33:53.640 --> 00:33:55.046
>> Nope, just use tables, I like them.

692
00:33:55.046 --> 00:33:56.510
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] All right, very good, well,

693
00:33:56.510 --> 00:33:59.400
we appreciate you being here in the
studios with us, and we appreciate you,

694
00:33:59.400 --> 00:34:00.280
the viewer, watching.

695
00:34:00.280 --> 00:34:03.450
Signing out for ITProTV,
I've been your host, Wes Bryan.

696
00:34:03.450 --> 00:34:04.380
>> And I'm Erica Gamet.

697
00:34:04.380 --> 00:34:06.564
>> And we'll see you next time.

698
00:34:06.564 --> 00:34:10.892
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Erica discuss using layers within Adobe InDesign. They talk about concepts like creating and deleting layers as well as the various options that are available with layers. They explain moving objects, the visibility, locking and re-arranging layers.
episodes.title: Working with Layers
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:11.784 --> 00:00:14.876
Welcome back to another exciting
episode here at ITPRO.TV,

3
00:00:14.876 --> 00:00:18.800
I'm your host Wes Bryan and in today's
episode we're continuing through our

4
00:00:18.800 --> 00:00:20.947
Series in Adobe Creative Cloud 2015.

5
00:00:20.947 --> 00:00:24.090
That's right we're coming back
at you with more in design.

6
00:00:24.090 --> 00:00:26.590
And joining me back in
the studios again is Erica Gamet.

7
00:00:26.590 --> 00:00:27.530
Erica how are you doing?

8
00:00:27.530 --> 00:00:28.330
>> Really good.

9
00:00:28.330 --> 00:00:30.310
>> All right, so
we're continuing along this journey.

10
00:00:30.310 --> 00:00:31.700
What is the next thing we're
going to be looking at?

11
00:00:31.700 --> 00:00:33.220
>> We're gonna start with layers.

12
00:00:33.220 --> 00:00:36.550
So we're gonna start putting
things on top of other things.

13
00:00:36.550 --> 00:00:37.560
So that's layers right?

14
00:00:37.560 --> 00:00:39.460
We're gonna start stacking it.

15
00:00:39.460 --> 00:00:40.680
In a previous episode we talked about.

16
00:00:40.680 --> 00:00:45.240
About stacking order where we had
actual objects on top of other objects.

17
00:00:45.240 --> 00:00:47.910
But now we're going to go back and
kind of pull out a little further and

18
00:00:47.910 --> 00:00:48.620
we're going to do layers.

19
00:00:48.620 --> 00:00:52.780
We're going to stack layers on top of
each other, and it's going to make sense.

20
00:00:52.780 --> 00:00:55.635
Don't think of it like Photoshop Layers
thought, that's where some people come

21
00:00:55.635 --> 00:00:59.055
in thinking it's like that, it's sort of
like that in that they're layered, but

22
00:00:59.055 --> 00:01:00.735
they don't work in exactly the same way.

23
00:01:00.735 --> 00:01:03.565
So what I'm gonna do is I'm actually
gonna show you a sample first.

24
00:01:03.565 --> 00:01:07.330

layers for and there's a lot of different

Think of it anytime you wanna separate
