Maybe you have an ad and you've got

Instead of maintaining three

00:02:19.950 --> 00:02:21.280

If we're ready to export them to a PDF,

00:02:25.200 --> 00:02:26.130

00:04:37.830 --> 00:04:40.220

00:04:40.220 --> 00:04:41.790

00:04:41.790 --> 00:04:43.890
So like I said you have

00:04:43.890 --> 00:04:47.120

00:04:47.120 --> 00:04:51.230
Now layers are not specific

00:04:51.230 --> 00:04:55.050

00:05:11.450 --> 00:05:14.480

Maybe it's just the cover that

00:05:23.820 --> 00:05:27.190
So again, keep in mind when you're

00:05:27.190 --> 00:05:29.540
the entire document, but

00:05:29.540 --> 00:05:32.500
you don't have to use every layer on

Whenever I use the new create new anything

00:05:59.590 --> 00:06:02.420

In this case I'm just gonna

00:06:11.480 --> 00:06:15.290
We don't really know what layers we're

00:06:15.290 --> 00:06:18.180
Some people do things like they
might put the text all in one and

00:06:18.180 --> 00:06:19.460
the images all on another.

00:06:19.460 --> 00:06:21.480
And as we'll see when we rearrange them,

00:06:21.480 --> 00:06:25.200
it's easy to say, I really wanted all

00:06:25.200 --> 00:06:29.000
Instead of going into each text frame

00:06:29.000 --> 00:06:32.460

00:06:32.460 --> 00:06:35.380

138
00:06:35.380 --> 00:06:38.650
So again, thinking back to how

00:06:38.650 --> 00:06:40.590
what's happening to this down the road.

140
00:06:40.590 --> 00:06:44.630
And that's a theme you'll see throughout

141
00:06:44.630 --> 00:06:47.570

what we're doing layers.

00:06:47.570 --> 00:06:49.830
We need to think,
what's the purpose of it?

00:06:49.830 --> 00:06:51.130
Where's this going?

00:06:51.130 --> 00:06:53.830
What happens to this file
once it leaves our hand?

00:06:53.830 --> 00:06:56.710
Or when it goes to the next
point in our own work flow?

146
00:06:56.710 --> 00:06:59.070
What happens to it, and
what will make more sense?

00:06:59.070 --> 00:07:01.610
So that's something I'm always
constantly thinking about.

00:07:02.690 --> 00:07:05.210
So in this layer I can say great,

00:07:22.270 --> 00:07:24.140

If you use the color that they choose,

they generally alternate [INAUDIBLE]
Between light and dark, which is nice.

So that as you start adding them, you can

That's that eyeball,

We can also lock that layer right here.

If I know this is the base layer,

Also whether or

Maybe it's just a layer full of notes.

I often have a layer that's

00:08:22.730 --> 00:08:27.100
And lock guides so anytime I create

00:08:27.100 --> 00:08:30.330

00:08:30.330 --> 00:08:32.710
Just again, options you may or

Suppress text wrap when layer is hidden,

00:08:47.130 --> 00:08:50.280
So, I leave that actually
off because you can actually

00:11:50.800 --> 00:11:53.700
I can actually just move them
if they're separate objects.

244
00:11:53.700 --> 00:11:56.470
In a layer, I can rearrange them there.

245
00:11:56.470 --> 00:11:59.410
And when we're working with
layers whatever is at the top

246
00:11:59.410 --> 00:12:04.630
is at the top of the order is actually at
the top of the stacking order for layers.

247
00:12:04.630 --> 00:12:07.830
So we've got a stacking order for
individual objects on a page.

248
00:12:07.830 --> 00:12:13.160
We also have stacking order for
objects for individual layers as well.

249
00:12:13.160 --> 00:12:15.270
So in this case the word safari is on top,

250
00:12:15.270 --> 00:12:20.070
well I can actually drag this item down
below and now it sits behind that logo.

251
00:12:20.070 --> 00:12:24.610
So its the same thing as if I did the
stacking order and moved it down as well.

252
00:12:24.610 --> 00:12:27.640
So this is an easier way to do that you
can actually see everything altogether you

253
00:12:27.640 --> 00:12:29.980
dont have to drill down
through the stacking order.

254
00:12:29.980 --> 00:12:31.780
I can also rearrange the layers.

255
00:12:31.780 --> 00:12:34.940
I have nothing on layer 2 so
lets actually put something on there.

256
00:12:34.940 --> 00:12:36.030
I m going to hide layer 1.

257
00:12:36.030 --> 00:12:37.790
And whenever you're working on a layer,

258
00:12:37.790 --> 00:12:40.950
you need to make sure that the layer
is selected in the layer panel.

259
00:12:40.950 --> 00:12:42.870
Otherwise you're working
on a different layer and

260
00:12:42.870 --> 00:12:44.060
you think, I looked at layer two,

261
00:12:44.060 --> 00:12:47.260
I thought that was the layer I was working
on, but it's actually on layer one.

262
00:12:47.260 --> 00:12:51.130
Whatever's selected here is where
your objects are going to end up.

263
00:12:51.130 --> 00:12:53.750
So I'm just gonna create
something super simple.

264
00:12:53.750 --> 00:12:58.290
Just come in here and
change the color, and

265
00:12:58.290 --> 00:13:01.210
just to that fill, and
that's on layer two.

266
00:13:01.210 --> 00:13:04.600
When I turn layer one back on you can
see that it's in front of that, but

267
00:13:04.600 --> 00:13:08.710
I can grab layer two, and
move that down below.

268
00:13:08.710 --> 00:13:12.770
It's like I move it back behind so I can
rearrange how those layers actually sit.

269
00:13:14.140 --> 00:13:18.580
Once I have something selected on a layer,
anything that I select, I'll get

270
00:13:18.580 --> 00:13:22.460
this little, let me actually move this so
we can see this, get this little proxy.

271
00:13:22.460 --> 00:13:25.750
So this little symbol, it just
indicates that something is selected.

272
00:13:25.750 --> 00:13:28.390
It doesn't matter if it's one thing or
ten things, whatever I have selected

273
00:13:28.390 --> 00:13:32.120
Selected it will automatically say hey,
you've got this item selected.

274
00:13:32.120 --> 00:13:35.360
So let's actually, I'm going to
drag across these two items here.

275
00:13:35.360 --> 00:13:38.510
Now if I had this item selected,
the logo, and

276
00:13:38.510 --> 00:13:41.460
the colored square back behind it,
I now have a proxy

277
00:13:41.460 --> 00:13:45.090
on both of those because I have an item
from each of those layers selected.

278
00:13:45.090 --> 00:13:46.680
What I want to do is grab this item.

279
00:13:46.680 --> 00:13:49.610
Let's actually grab this item here,
just the logo and

280
00:13:49.610 --> 00:13:53.070
it says hey, you've got an item selected,
what do you want to do with that?

281
00:13:53.070 --> 00:13:55.770
Well the reason that's handy
is that I could Copy and

282
00:13:55.770 --> 00:13:57.760
Paste to a new layer if I wanted to.

283
00:13:57.760 --> 00:13:58.950
That's not really what I wanna do.

284
00:13:58.950 --> 00:14:01.520
I wanna actually just
drag that little proxy.

285
00:14:01.520 --> 00:14:06.050
So if I want this item to go from Layer 1,
I want the logo to go from Layer 1 where

286
00:14:06.050 --> 00:14:11.210
it's sitting to layer two, I can just drag
that little proxy down to the other layer.

287
00:14:11.210 --> 00:14:15.110
Now the layer has to be unlocked and
it has to be visible for you to do that.

288
00:14:15.110 --> 00:14:16.460
But I can just drag it and

289
00:14:16.460 --> 00:14:19.420
now I did and now I can actually
see that it's out lined in the red.

290
00:14:19.420 --> 00:14:21.650
That means that it's on
that layer two logo or

291
00:14:21.650 --> 00:14:26.040
layer two layer, and
it went ahead and moved it down.

292
00:14:26.040 --> 00:14:29.370
Now, if I decided well actually,
what I wanted is I wanted it to be on

293
00:14:29.370 --> 00:14:34.330
both layers, cuz that's what I've done
over here, is I've got the logo, or

294
00:14:34.330 --> 00:14:36.940
sorry, the different words
appearing on each layer.

295
00:14:36.940 --> 00:14:39.540
So I say okay,
I'm ready to move that to a new layer.

296
00:14:39.540 --> 00:14:41.920
I can actually copy that
instead of move that.

297
00:14:41.920 --> 00:14:43.700
I'm actually gonna show you on here,

298
00:14:43.700 --> 00:14:47.430
cuz this is how I would do it if I was
ready to create a whole new layer.

299
00:14:47.430 --> 00:14:48.200
We've got another one.

300
00:14:48.200 --> 00:14:52.180
Maybe it's going to be called, I don't
know, we'll call it Travel Tours, or

301
00:14:52.180 --> 00:14:52.930
something like that.

302
00:14:52.930 --> 00:14:55.450
I don't know,
something interesting, Eco Tours.

303
00:14:55.450 --> 00:14:58.510
Let's decide we're going to go into
Eco Tours as well with this thing, and

304
00:14:58.510 --> 00:15:02.040
we need a whole new layer for
the Eco Tours.

305
00:15:02.040 --> 00:15:03.470
So I would come over to
something like this.

306
00:15:03.470 --> 00:15:07.320
I'd probably hide the top items and
probably the base layer too so

307
00:15:07.320 --> 00:15:09.460
I can kind of just see
what's on the safari layer.

308
00:15:09.460 --> 00:15:13.960
So, now I know I need this text frame and
these three image

309
00:15:13.960 --> 00:15:19.120
frames to go to my new layer that
I'm gonna create called, ecotourism.

310
00:15:19.120 --> 00:15:22.460
So what I'm gonna do is I'm
gonna copy all of those and

311
00:15:22.460 --> 00:15:24.650
again it shows me that
I have this proxy here.

312
00:15:24.650 --> 00:15:27.290
And I need to create a new layer,
so I'm going to go ahead and

313
00:15:27.290 --> 00:15:31.370
say new layer and either come up here or
use the button at bottom say new layer,

314
00:15:31.370 --> 00:15:37.990
and we'll call it Eco-Tourism and just
leave the preset set here and say okay.

315
00:15:37.990 --> 00:15:42.820
Now I have this safari stuff and
I'm going to drag this Proxy, I'm

316
00:15:42.820 --> 00:15:46.000
gonna hold down the Option key or the Alt
key, and that's going to copy that item.

317
00:15:46.000 --> 00:15:49.330
And I'm actually gonna zoom in so
we can take a look at that.

318
00:15:49.330 --> 00:15:51.410
Oops, let's make sure
we're high enough here.

319
00:15:51.410 --> 00:15:53.970
And, when I do that, I'm gonna hold
down the Option or the Alt key.

320
00:15:53.970 --> 00:15:56.810
Key and drag it and
I get a little plus when I do that.

321
00:15:56.810 --> 00:15:59.160
So I'm gonna drag it here and drop it.

322
00:15:59.160 --> 00:16:02.270
So now I have it in both places actually.

323
00:16:02.270 --> 00:16:05.440
So it's hard to see but it probably got
a little bit darker, cause I now have

324
00:16:05.440 --> 00:16:08.020
two versions sitting right on top
of each other, and that's fine,

325
00:16:08.020 --> 00:16:12.390
because I'm gonna go ahead and
hide safari, so I have that turned off.

326
00:16:12.390 --> 00:16:14.310
Now I just have that ecotourism one.

327
00:16:14.310 --> 00:16:19.140
I'm gonna come in here and make a change
to that, of course, and say ecotours,

328
00:16:19.140 --> 00:16:19.680
we'll call it that.

329
00:16:19.680 --> 00:16:23.020
And then of course I'm going to change
out the images to something else.

330
00:16:23.020 --> 00:16:24.940
So I'd just come in here and
make the changes to the images.

331
00:16:24.940 --> 00:16:26.770
I'm gonna leave them
as they are right now.

332
00:16:26.770 --> 00:16:29.300
I don't have any
ecotourism images on here.

333
00:16:29.300 --> 00:16:32.780
But I have that set and now I can
say okay turn on that base layer and

334
00:16:32.780 --> 00:16:36.010
turn on that top layer,
which just puts that line across there.

335
00:16:36.010 --> 00:16:39.340
And now I know that I have that ready,
so it's super easy to duplicate.

336
00:16:39.340 --> 00:16:43.090
Now, I could duplicate a whole layer if I
wanted to, instead of dragging those items

337
00:16:43.090 --> 00:16:48.030
individually, I could just select on
my layer and say duplicate layer.

338
00:16:48.030 --> 00:16:50.310
So I can do that as well if I
know everything has to move.

339
00:16:50.310 --> 00:16:52.310
I tend not to move things individually,
but

340
00:16:52.310 --> 00:16:54.460
I just want to show you that
you are able to do that easily.

341
00:16:54.460 --> 00:16:56.910
And again you can come down
to each of these items and

342
00:16:56.910 --> 00:16:59.130
I can see here's all the different images.

343
00:16:59.130 --> 00:17:01.880
I can say, okay I realize this
one is sitting on top of that,

344
00:17:01.880 --> 00:17:06.610
if they are overlapping it's a super easy
to just drag the order of those images and

345
00:17:06.610 --> 00:17:09.130
get again that stacking
order easily through there.

346
00:17:09.130 --> 00:17:13.570
And I think,
I wanna make sure that's all for layers,

347
00:17:13.570 --> 00:17:15.130
actually layers are pretty easy.

348
00:17:15.130 --> 00:17:18.430
It just for me it's thinking
about why you wanna use layers.

349
00:17:18.430 --> 00:17:21.990
Sometimes I'll get things that
are completely layered up, and

350
00:17:21.990 --> 00:17:23.320
I'm not really sure why.

351
00:17:23.320 --> 00:17:26.200
But for me, like I said,
when I'm ready to print, I can say, okay,

352
00:17:26.200 --> 00:17:28.520
I've got the ecotours ready to go.

353
00:17:28.520 --> 00:17:31.740
I could export that now to a PDF,
and I've got that ecotourism

354
00:17:31.740 --> 00:17:35.430
ready to go when it comes time to change
that, like I said the base layer.

355
00:17:35.430 --> 00:17:39.890
Come over here, we'll grab this,
grab the color, just change the color,

356
00:17:39.890 --> 00:17:42.050
I'm holding down the shift key
to switch to a different color.

357
00:17:42.050 --> 00:17:45.120
Gonna say great, let's change it,
woo that's nice and bright.

358
00:17:45.120 --> 00:17:49.040
We change that but now that's changed for
all four of those that we've made, and

359
00:17:49.040 --> 00:17:52.860
I can print out or export out PDFs,
super super easy to that.

360
00:17:52.860 --> 00:17:57.040
So layers are a huge way to manage
everything that's on your page.

361
00:17:57.040 --> 00:18:00.530
And individually on each of these as
well to be able to rearrange those

362
00:18:00.530 --> 00:18:01.540
as well
>> Erica,

363
00:18:01.540 --> 00:18:05.350
we appreciate you taking the time to
explain the ins and outs of layers.

364
00:18:05.350 --> 00:18:07.510
It does look like we're coming
to the end of another episode.

365
00:18:07.510 --> 00:18:08.240
But before we do,

366
00:18:08.240 --> 00:18:10.390
do you have any additional words
you would like to say on layers?

367
00:18:10.390 --> 00:18:11.410
>> No, I think I'm good.

368
00:18:11.410 --> 00:18:12.130
>> Alright, very good.

369
00:18:12.130 --> 00:18:15.000
Well thank you for joining us for this
topic and thank you for the viewer for

370
00:18:15.000 --> 00:18:16.600
watching and signing up for ITProTV.

371
00:18:16.600 --> 00:18:17.965
I've been your host Wes Brian.

372
00:18:17.965 --> 00:18:18.889
>> And I'm Erica Gamet.

373
00:18:18.889 --> 00:18:20.496
>> And we'll see you next time.

374
00:18:20.496 --> 00:18:27.815
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Erica discuss using pages and master pages inside of Adobe InDesign. They explain various options with using pages such as customization, adding pages, deleting pages, navigating pages, re-arranging pages and page labels. They also explore using master pages like creation, applying master pages to documents, primary text frames and smart text flow.
episodes.title: Pages and Master Pages
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:11.814 --> 00:00:14.644
Welcome back to another exciting
episode here at ITPro.TV.

3
00:00:14.644 --> 00:00:15.828
I'm your host, Wes Bryan.

4
00:00:15.828 --> 00:00:20.017
And in today's episode we're continuing
through our series in Adobe Creative Cloud

5
00:00:20.017 --> 00:00:20.608
2015.

6
00:00:20.608 --> 00:00:23.863
That's right, we're coming back
at you with more InDesign.

7
00:00:23.863 --> 00:00:26.072
And joining me back in
the studios today is Erica Gamet.

8
00:00:26.072 --> 00:00:27.251
Erica, how are you doing?

9
00:00:27.251 --> 00:00:27.961
>> Fantastic.

10
00:00:27.961 --> 00:00:31.505
>> All right, great, so we've been
continuing along the journey inside of

11
00:00:31.505 --> 00:00:33.232
InDesign, where are we going next?

12
00:00:33.232 --> 00:00:36.045
>> We're gonna start working
with pages and master pages.

13
00:00:36.045 --> 00:00:39.560
Now I know we've been working in pages but
only one page really.

14
00:00:39.560 --> 00:00:41.558
Couple times we've looked
at multiple pages, but

15
00:00:41.558 --> 00:00:43.891
now we're gonna look how to
navigate through those pages.

16
00:00:43.891 --> 00:00:46.161
And then we're going to
look at master pages, and

17
00:00:46.161 --> 00:00:49.900
master pages are way of putting items on
a page that appear on multiple pages.

18
00:00:49.900 --> 00:00:52.373
So you don't have to copy and
paste, and maintain, again,

19
00:00:52.373 --> 00:00:53.740
multiple pages of the same item.

20
00:00:53.740 --> 00:00:56.712
If it appears on the same page,
we put it on a master page and

21
00:00:56.712 --> 00:00:58.790
then it's just there magically for us.

22
00:00:58.790 --> 00:01:01.070
So we're gonna go ahead and
jump in and look at that.

23
00:01:01.070 --> 00:01:03.720
So the first thing I wanna do is, I'm
just gonna start with a blank document.

24
00:01:03.720 --> 00:01:06.926
Just a new document, Cmd or
Ctrl+N for that new document.

25
00:01:06.926 --> 00:01:10.224
I've got my Pages panel open so
we can look at that, but

26
00:01:10.224 --> 00:01:11.890
I have one page by default.

27
00:01:11.890 --> 00:01:17.210
So even if I never open the Pages panel,
there is one page in one section,

28
00:01:17.210 --> 00:01:19.300
and we'll go into sections
in just a little while.

29
00:01:19.300 --> 00:01:23.310
But I know that I have one page,
one section, and two master pages.

30
00:01:23.310 --> 00:01:25.500
A master page of none,
which sounds dumb, but

31
00:01:25.500 --> 00:01:27.758
we'll look at why we need
a master page of none.

32
00:01:27.758 --> 00:01:30.970
And also an a master page, again,
if we never go into the Pages panel,

33
00:01:30.970 --> 00:01:34.520
it's there, it's happy,
we don't have to touch it, no big deal.

34
00:01:34.520 --> 00:01:36.440
But when we wanna add more than one page,

35
00:01:36.440 --> 00:01:38.653
we need to start working
with the Pages panel.

36
00:01:38.653 --> 00:01:42.480
So a couple of things first, we're gonna
customize the panel to work for us.

37
00:01:42.480 --> 00:01:45.750
So we open up our Pages panel,
if it's not already open you need to go to

38
00:01:45.750 --> 00:01:50.180
the Window menu and come down to Pages and
open it from there.

39
00:01:50.180 --> 00:01:53.494
And then we can look at it and
we can say, okay, what do we wanna do,

40
00:01:53.494 --> 00:01:55.937
how do we want these pages
laid out in this panel?

41
00:01:55.937 --> 00:01:58.149
So I'm gonna go up to
the Pages panel menu, again,

42
00:01:58.149 --> 00:02:02.340
it's this little menu on the upper right
hand side, most of the panels have those.

43
00:02:02.340 --> 00:02:05.250
And go down to the bottom and
choose Panel Options.

44
00:02:05.250 --> 00:02:09.098
When I do that I get to choose what
size thumbnails I want each of

45
00:02:09.098 --> 00:02:10.282
these pages to be.

46
00:02:10.282 --> 00:02:14.554
And I've got my Pages, or what I call
document pages, just to kind of clarify

47
00:02:14.554 --> 00:02:18.920
which pages we're talking about,
and also Masters, or master pages.

48
00:02:18.920 --> 00:02:21.400
What size do we want each
of those icons to be?

49
00:02:21.400 --> 00:02:24.200
By default they set at medium,
I tend to leave it at that.

50
00:02:24.200 --> 00:02:28.530
And Show Thumbnails just means it's gonna
show us a little representation on there

51
00:02:28.530 --> 00:02:30.330
of what is on that page.

52
00:02:30.330 --> 00:02:33.085
And here's a little hint,
if your machine is being slowed down,

53
00:02:33.085 --> 00:02:37.030
there's several things you can do to kind
of, or not machine, but InDesign itself,

54
00:02:37.030 --> 00:02:38.460
it just feels a little sluggish.

55
00:02:38.460 --> 00:02:40.470
There's a couple things you
can do to speed that up, and

56
00:02:40.470 --> 00:02:42.260
one of them is turn off those thumbnails.

57
00:02:42.260 --> 00:02:44.780
Because that thumbnail,
every time we add something on the page,

58
00:02:44.780 --> 00:02:48.690
it has to redraw that thumbnail, and
that can kinda slow you down a little bit.

59
00:02:48.690 --> 00:02:51.550
So for the most part, I leave it on,
but if things are acting a little weird

60
00:02:51.550 --> 00:02:54.070
I try turning that off, so
that's a good place to check.

61
00:02:54.070 --> 00:02:58.570
Also on the master pages, do you want
to show the master pages vertically or

62
00:02:58.570 --> 00:02:59.200
horizontally?

63
00:02:59.200 --> 00:03:01.981
Meaning instead of coming down
in one long list over here,

64
00:03:01.981 --> 00:03:04.493
they'll actually go
vertically across the panel.

65
00:03:04.493 --> 00:03:07.182
Now that involves having to
scroll through the panel,

66
00:03:07.182 --> 00:03:10.160
I tend not to do that,
I tend to leave it set exactly as it is.

67
00:03:10.160 --> 00:03:13.220
Because this is kind of how
the Pages panel has looked

68
00:03:13.220 --> 00:03:16.490
through all the iterations of InDesign and
all the software that we used before it.

69
00:03:16.490 --> 00:03:20.710
So it kinda set a precedence and that's
just in my brain how Pages panels work.

70
00:03:20.710 --> 00:03:23.470
Also, again, thumbnails for
the masters as well.

71
00:03:23.470 --> 00:03:26.910
You can also have different icons that
sit next to each of the page icons that

72
00:03:26.910 --> 00:03:28.920
are here to tell you what's on that page.

73
00:03:28.920 --> 00:03:31.170
For instance,
there's one called Transparency.

74
00:03:31.170 --> 00:03:33.220
I can select that, and when I do that,

75
00:03:33.220 --> 00:03:37.400
if there's a transparent item, whether
it's a clipping path, or a drop shadow,

76
00:03:37.400 --> 00:03:41.960
or a photo that we brought in from
Photoshop that had transparency in it.

77
00:03:41.960 --> 00:03:45.416
It's gonna put that little checker box
that we're familiar with from Photoshop,

78
00:03:45.416 --> 00:03:46.900
that says it's transparent.

79
00:03:46.900 --> 00:03:50.920
It's gonna put a little box of
transparency, little old checkerboard next

80
00:03:50.920 --> 00:03:54.260
to the page to tell us hey, there's
some transparent items on this page.

81
00:03:54.260 --> 00:03:56.540
And when we get to output
in a future episode,

82
00:03:56.540 --> 00:04:00.410
we'll see that knowing which page
has transparency is super important.

83
00:04:00.410 --> 00:04:02.990
I keep talking about how
it can cause issues, so

84
00:04:02.990 --> 00:04:06.930
that's a great way to turn that on so
we can see that and find that easily.

85

00:15:22.710 --> 00:15:25.809
I can also move it to
an entirely new document.

300
00:15:25.809 --> 00:15:28.332
So if I have another document open,
let's actually open another one.

301
00:15:28.332 --> 00:15:32.275
I'll just open up another untitled one,
Untitled 9 is our other one.

302
00:15:32.275 --> 00:15:35.820
Came back to this original one that we
have our eight pages on and say move

303
00:15:35.820 --> 00:15:39.160
pages, and I can say, okay I would
like you to move it to untitled 9 and

304
00:15:39.160 --> 00:15:43.170
I would like to have you move
it obviously after page 1.

305
00:15:43.170 --> 00:15:45.460
There's only one page and
only has one choice, before or

306
00:15:45.460 --> 00:15:48.970
after that page which is the same as
the start and the end of the document but

307
00:15:48.970 --> 00:15:52.070
I can move that to page 3 and
I can even delete it from here if I want.

308
00:15:52.070 --> 00:15:54.740
So it'll pull it out of this document and
place it in the new and

309
00:15:54.740 --> 00:15:56.310
get rid of it in the old one if I want.

310
00:15:56.310 --> 00:15:58.320
That's off by default,
which is a good thing.

311
00:15:58.320 --> 00:16:02.450
When I say OK now I've got an extra page
over there, that page just moved over.

312
00:16:02.450 --> 00:16:04.685
And if I have section numbering and

313
00:16:04.685 --> 00:16:08.549
master page items applied to it
all of that would go as well.

314
00:16:08.549 --> 00:16:10.682
So that's kind of pages,
how we add them, how we move around.

315
00:16:10.682 --> 00:16:13.768
There's a lot of other ones,
there's keyboard shortcuts for page up and

316
00:16:13.768 --> 00:16:14.279
page down.

317
00:16:14.279 --> 00:16:15.897
There's some built in It's in shortcuts.

318
00:16:15.897 --> 00:16:19.197
I don't have the ten key pad ,so I
can't even use the page up and down.

319
00:16:19.197 --> 00:16:21.840
But that might be a key that
you have on your keyboard.

320
00:16:21.840 --> 00:16:24.350
Again, there's so
many ways to navigate around.

321
00:16:24.350 --> 00:16:25.730
Find which one works fastest for you.

322
00:16:25.730 --> 00:16:27.520
Maybe you know exactly what page it's on.

323
00:16:27.520 --> 00:16:29.230
Maybe you're looking at
the page thumbnails and

324
00:16:29.230 --> 00:16:30.670
that's how you're going to
figure out which one you need.

325
00:16:30.670 --> 00:16:32.240
And you're going to double
click on that page.

326
00:16:32.240 --> 00:16:34.665
But again, you want to make
sure that you're on the page.

327
00:16:34.665 --> 00:16:37.707
Double-click on the page to actually
be on the page you want to work on.

328
00:16:37.707 --> 00:16:40.030
Because you can't start working on
it until you've double-clicked and

329
00:16:40.030 --> 00:16:42.180
actually navigated to that page.

330
00:16:42.180 --> 00:16:44.550
So, those are pages or document pages.

331
00:16:44.550 --> 00:16:46.880
Now, we're gonna get into master pages.

332
00:16:46.880 --> 00:16:51.670
So, master pages are items that live on
a page that you want to appear elsewhere.

333
00:16:51.670 --> 00:16:54.460
And so, I'm actually going to show
you a sample of one and then,

334
00:16:54.460 --> 00:16:56.085
we're start with one that's
just really really simple.

335
00:16:56.085 --> 00:16:58.210
Without all the extraneous
information that's here, so

336
00:16:58.210 --> 00:17:00.230
I'm going to jump out to
this particular book.

337
00:17:01.650 --> 00:17:05.220
And I'm going to look at the master
pages and how I have those set up.

338
00:17:05.220 --> 00:17:06.590
So, these are my regular pages.

339
00:17:06.590 --> 00:17:07.280
I've got the cover.

340
00:17:07.280 --> 00:17:08.540
It doesn't have a master applied to it.

341
00:17:08.540 --> 00:17:11.870
I've got a blank page and then, I've
got a page here and if I look at this,

342
00:17:11.870 --> 00:17:16.400
I can see that C master is
applied to this particular page.

343
00:17:16.400 --> 00:17:20.940
And B master is applied to this page
that's here and D and B and so on.

344
00:17:20.940 --> 00:17:23.790
So, each of those master
pages has a little thumbnail.

345
00:17:23.790 --> 00:17:27.990
to tell me which master page
is applied to that particular

346
00:17:27.990 --> 00:17:29.370
document page that's there.

347
00:17:29.370 --> 00:17:31.890
Now, I'm going to go in and
look at the master pages and

348
00:17:31.890 --> 00:17:33.720
see what each of those are made of.

349
00:17:33.720 --> 00:17:36.290
And then, we're going to set
one up really, really quickly.

350
00:17:36.290 --> 00:17:38.220
Just a simple one.

351
00:17:38.220 --> 00:17:41.420
So, I have this one called king and
I'll explain what king means in a minute.

352
00:17:41.420 --> 00:17:44.320
So, I have one that is white page and
it's got a page number.

353
00:17:44.320 --> 00:17:46.410
I've got one left page
with the page number.

354
00:17:46.410 --> 00:17:50.920
Basically, I'm giving them descriptions of
what it is that's on each of those pages.

355
00:17:50.920 --> 00:17:55.050
This one says this is a grid right hand
page and a grid left hand page and

356
00:17:55.050 --> 00:17:55.560
a quote.

357
00:17:55.560 --> 00:17:58.232
I've got one with a pull-out quote and
whether it's a right-page or

358
00:17:58.232 --> 00:18:01.580
left-page, you notice the page
number is moving back and forth.

359
00:18:01.580 --> 00:18:03.420
So what I can do is,
I can come down here and say, okay,

360
00:18:03.420 --> 00:18:05.690
I've got this grid that's here.

361
00:18:05.690 --> 00:18:08.290
And I can come in here and I can change
it or maybe on this one is a blank one.

362
00:18:08.290 --> 00:18:11.440
I didn't assign a master page to it and
I'm ready to go, and

363
00:18:11.440 --> 00:18:13.270
I want to show you what
this master page is.

364
00:18:13.270 --> 00:18:15.710
So, I can go okay,
let's say it's a quote page.

365
00:18:15.710 --> 00:18:18.920
Page two is going to be a quote page and
it's page two, so it's a left-hand page.

366
00:18:18.920 --> 00:18:21.501
So I'm going to grab the quote left,

367
00:18:21.501 --> 00:18:26.020
going to drag the master page
right on top of the document page.

368
00:18:26.020 --> 00:18:29.220
And now everything that's
there is assigned to it.

369
00:18:29.220 --> 00:18:32.760
What you'll notice is, that I can't click
on any of the items I just put on there.

370
00:18:32.760 --> 00:18:35.160
That's because they belong
to the master page.

371
00:18:35.160 --> 00:18:37.510
That's the whole point of
putting on a master page, so

372
00:18:37.510 --> 00:18:40.200
they're always on the same
place when I need them.

373
00:18:40.200 --> 00:18:43.380
So what I'm going to do is, I'm going
to say, okay, maybe I like this but

374
00:18:43.380 --> 00:18:46.180
I really don't want this grid down here.

375
00:18:46.180 --> 00:18:47.970
Or maybe I don't want the top image,
right?

376
00:18:47.970 --> 00:18:51.540
I just wanted to say title and
the quote and two pictures at the bottom.

377
00:18:51.540 --> 00:18:54.310
I want to get rid of this
one line that's here.

378
00:18:54.310 --> 00:18:56.480
What I can do is called an override, so

379
00:18:56.480 --> 00:19:00.760
I can get to those master page items
on this particular document page.

380
00:19:00.760 --> 00:19:05.330
But I can't just accidentally move it,
I have to take an extra step.

381
00:19:05.330 --> 00:19:09.810
So I'm going to do command/control
shift and click on that item and

382
00:19:09.810 --> 00:19:12.900
when I do that, now I can actually
grab that frame that's there.

383
00:19:12.900 --> 00:19:16.210
So, I'm going to delete that and
let go of that.

384
00:19:16.210 --> 00:19:19.430
So I can actually, even if I didn't
delete it, lets say I don't delete, but

385
00:19:19.430 --> 00:19:20.960
I have it there.

386
00:19:20.960 --> 00:19:24.140
So if I do a select all, the only
thing I can select is that one item.

387
00:19:24.140 --> 00:19:26.970
Everything else is still
attached to that master page.

388
00:19:26.970 --> 00:19:30.380
This frame still has
an attachment to the master page.

389
00:19:30.380 --> 00:19:32.200
It's just that I overwrote it.

390
00:19:32.200 --> 00:19:36.210
So, I can do things like delete it or
I can move it or something like that, but

391
00:19:36.210 --> 00:19:38.850
it's still has that same connection to it.

392
00:19:38.850 --> 00:19:41.380
But I can come over here to the panel,
pages, panel, menu,

393
00:19:41.380 --> 00:19:43.320
and go to the master pages sub-menu.

394
00:19:43.320 --> 00:19:46.170
And I can say things like,
detach from the master.

395
00:19:46.170 --> 00:19:49.710
If I do that, I've totally severed
any connection to the master, and

396
00:19:49.710 --> 00:19:50.750
I tend not to do that.

397
00:19:50.750 --> 00:19:54.050
Because I may have just overridden
this to delete it and that's fine.

398
00:19:54.050 --> 00:19:56.920
I deleted it and it's gone, or maybe
I just wanted to make a change to it.

399
00:19:56.920 --> 00:19:59.230
Maybe I decided I just
don't like where it sits.

400
00:19:59.230 --> 00:20:02.940
Maybe on this page, I decided that
this needs to move up a whole lot, so

401
00:20:02.940 --> 00:20:04.400
we're just going to move it up here.

402
00:20:04.400 --> 00:20:07.910
I want it to suddenly maybe sit
behind the title that's back there.

403
00:20:07.910 --> 00:20:10.340
The page that's back there and
I just want to move that, but

404
00:20:10.340 --> 00:20:13.320
I don't want to totally
sever its connection.

405
00:20:13.320 --> 00:20:15.610
So, I can go back to the master
that I've created here and

406
00:20:15.610 --> 00:20:19.290
this is all the items that are on this
master, and I can select this item.

407
00:20:19.290 --> 00:20:21.630
Like I save, actually now,
what I would like is,

408
00:20:21.630 --> 00:20:25.020
I would like to change the stroke
of this on the master page.

409
00:20:25.020 --> 00:20:26.658
And I'm going to make it bigger.

410
00:20:26.658 --> 00:20:30.500
I'm going to go to Strokes Panel, I would
just make it bigger and then maybe,

411
00:20:30.500 --> 00:20:31.810
we're actually going to
fill it with a color.

412
00:20:31.810 --> 00:20:33.320
For whatever reason,
we're going to do that.

413
00:20:33.320 --> 00:20:36.160
Just so that,
that's something easy to see and, whoops.

414
00:20:36.160 --> 00:20:38.720
We're going to actually change
the fill and not the stroke.

415
00:20:38.720 --> 00:20:42.250
Let's change the fill here to something
dark and blue and we'll say, okay.

416
00:20:42.250 --> 00:20:45.100
And then, I'm going to go back to that
page that I assigned that master.

417
00:20:45.100 --> 00:20:49.940
And you'll notice, that the color and
the stroke all got changed.

418
00:20:49.940 --> 00:20:54.230
Even though I moved that
master page item away.

419
00:20:54.230 --> 00:20:58.450
So what I did when I did that override,
when I Shift+Cmd+Clicked on that.

420
00:20:58.450 --> 00:20:59.270
I overwrote it and

421
00:20:59.270 --> 00:21:03.030
said okay, I want to do some stuff to
this item that's on the master page.

422
00:21:03.030 --> 00:21:07.050
I want to change the fill color and I want
to change the stroke thickness of it.

423
00:21:08.240 --> 00:21:10.880
Everything else is still
attached where it sits.

424
00:21:10.880 --> 00:21:13.910
Anything else that is
dictated by that master page

425
00:21:13.910 --> 00:21:16.970
is still going to come through
to this item on that page.

426
00:21:16.970 --> 00:21:21.930
Except the stroke color and stroke width
and the fill color, so anything I change.

427
00:21:21.930 --> 00:21:24.780
So anything I overrode,
remains whatever I did here, but

428
00:21:24.780 --> 00:21:27.530
everything else is still common and
is still coming through.

429
00:21:27.530 --> 00:21:28.450
So, hopefully that makes sense.

430
00:21:28.450 --> 00:21:33.080
You can move around where things sit but
you say hey, maybe just on this page,

431
00:21:33.080 --> 00:21:33.740
I need to move it.

432
00:21:33.740 --> 00:21:36.860
Or maybe in this case,
we just didn't want it all together and

433
00:21:36.860 --> 00:21:37.730
we delete and that's fine.

434
00:21:37.730 --> 00:21:39.720
I can always bring that back.

435
00:21:39.720 --> 00:21:43.750
I can come in here and I can reapply
that master page, so I'll go ahead and

436
00:21:43.750 --> 00:21:45.340
reapply that master page.

437
00:21:45.340 --> 00:21:50.320
Come here and apply this master
page back to that page two.

438
00:21:50.320 --> 00:21:53.720
So I can say, apply that to page 2,
and it comes back and

439
00:21:53.720 --> 00:21:56.390
it's back there exactly as it was.

440
00:21:56.390 --> 00:21:58.300
So I come in here, it's applied and

441
00:21:58.300 --> 00:22:03.980
again, now I can't select that item,
because it's connected to the master page.

442
00:22:03.980 --> 00:22:06.588
So, let's start from the beginning here,
how I normally do this.

443
00:22:06.588 --> 00:22:09.620
I'm going to go back to that
eight page section that we have.

444
00:22:09.620 --> 00:22:10.743
Pull this up slightly.

445
00:22:10.743 --> 00:22:13.820
I'm going to create a couple of
things on this master page and

446
00:22:13.820 --> 00:22:17.182
I'm going to show you something
called cascading master pages.

447
00:22:17.182 --> 00:22:19.670
And that just means that
what I put on one page,

448
00:22:19.670 --> 00:22:22.145
if I duplicate or
base a master on that master.

449
00:22:22.145 --> 00:22:25.600
Everything that's on the original map
master rr what's called the parent,

450
00:22:26.850 --> 00:22:30.140
filters down into all the child
pages that I create from it.

451
00:22:30.140 --> 00:22:31.280
Now why is that important?

452
00:22:31.280 --> 00:22:34.580
Well, I might have page numbers
throughout my document.

453
00:22:34.580 --> 00:22:35.410
Maybe I'm making a book.

454
00:22:35.410 --> 00:22:36.640
I've got page numbers.

455
00:22:36.640 --> 00:22:38.740
I'm going to have section headers on each.

456
00:22:38.740 --> 00:22:40.010
Maybe I want sections along the top and

457
00:22:40.010 --> 00:22:43.480
I also want the name of my book across
the top that's going to be on every page.

458
00:22:43.480 --> 00:22:47.600
Now, it might move where it sits and on
pages, we might have a righthand page and

459
00:22:47.600 --> 00:22:48.990
a left-hand page.

460
00:22:48.990 --> 00:22:51.680
And so for me, I'm going to put
everything that I think is going to be

461
00:22:51.680 --> 00:22:53.540
common throughout my document.

462
00:22:53.540 --> 00:22:55.240
I'm going to put that on Master Page A.

463
00:22:55.240 --> 00:22:58.180
I have that one called
King in my other sample.

464
00:22:58.180 --> 00:22:59.780
The King is like he's in charge.

465
00:22:59.780 --> 00:23:02.290
Sometimes I just call it a Master and
leave it at that.

466
00:23:02.290 --> 00:23:03.830
I can change the name if I want to.

467
00:23:03.830 --> 00:23:06.730
However, but right now I'm just
going to leave it as a Master.

468
00:23:06.730 --> 00:23:10.635
And I'm going to say everything that I
think is going to end up in the book will

469
00:23:10.635 --> 00:23:12.500
end up on Master Page A.

470
00:23:12.500 --> 00:23:15.950
And I base other Masters on that and I
can base Masters that are based on those.

471
00:23:15.950 --> 00:23:18.720
we can keep coming down
the the family tree and base that.

472
00:23:18.720 --> 00:23:22.250
But the cool thing is, if I say,
I hate the way the page numbers look.

473
00:23:22.250 --> 00:23:23.800
I want to change the font.

474
00:23:23.800 --> 00:23:25.920
I change it on the master Page A and

475
00:23:25.920 --> 00:23:29.840
it changes on all of the child pages and
all of the ones that are based on it.

476
00:23:29.840 --> 00:23:30.890
And then,

477
00:23:30.890 --> 00:23:34.200
all of the document pages that have
that master applied to it also change.

478
00:23:34.200 --> 00:23:37.620
Change it in one place and it ripples
throughout the entire document, so

479
00:23:37.620 --> 00:23:38.700
let's do that really quickly.

480
00:23:38.700 --> 00:23:40.140
I'm just going to show
you what I would do.

481
00:23:40.140 --> 00:23:42.040
This is not going to be
the best designed book.

482
00:23:42.040 --> 00:23:44.860
We're just going to come in here,
and we're going to center it.

483
00:23:44.860 --> 00:23:46.440
We're going to call it My Great Book.

484
00:23:46.440 --> 00:23:48.520
That's what I'm going to call it.

485
00:23:48.520 --> 00:23:52.630
Oops, Great Book here, and
make that a little bit bigger.

486
00:23:52.630 --> 00:23:54.330
So again, I'm just going to
work with a couple things here.

487
00:23:54.330 --> 00:23:56.872
I'm going to make that bold and
I'm going to do something.

488
00:23:56.872 --> 00:23:59.550
I'm going to set section
up really quick as well.

489
00:23:59.550 --> 00:24:01.829
I'm just going to type section,
or that might be the chapter or

490
00:24:01.829 --> 00:24:03.160
something like that.

491
00:24:03.160 --> 00:24:04.120
And again, I'm going to make it.

492
00:24:04.120 --> 00:24:06.888
I'm going to design it how I want it and
some of this stuff,

493
00:24:06.888 --> 00:24:08.931
we're going to automate in just a minute.

494
00:24:08.931 --> 00:24:13.068
But I like to have something in there, so
I know what my text is going to look like.

495
00:24:13.068 --> 00:24:15.397
I'm also going to do page numbers and
in this case, I'm going to put them up.

496
00:24:15.397 --> 00:24:17.539
High so that we can see them up here.

497
00:24:17.539 --> 00:24:20.824
And I'm gonna go ahead and just put in,
for me when I do page numbers,

498
00:24:20.824 --> 00:24:24.619
I put in the biggest, like fattest number
I can think of cuz I wanna make sure that

499
00:24:24.619 --> 00:24:28.980
my text frame is big enough to accommodate
that text without getting overset text.

500
00:24:28.980 --> 00:24:33.230
So in this case I'm gonna do a keyboard
short cut for right justified text.

501
00:24:33.230 --> 00:24:37.240
I may copy this item, so I'm just going
to option or Alt Click on that, and

502
00:24:37.240 --> 00:24:40.556
hold down the Shift key so
it moves straight across the page.

503
00:24:40.556 --> 00:24:44.650
And I'm gonna left justify that,
Cmd or Ctrl+Shift+L to justify that.

504
00:24:44.650 --> 00:24:46.350
I'm gonna look at that and
say, okay, great.

505
00:24:46.350 --> 00:24:48.700
This is where my chapter's gonna go,
so the title.

506
00:24:48.700 --> 00:24:51.530
These are the page numbers, and then
maybe I have some text in there as well.

507
00:24:51.530 --> 00:24:54.340
I can set up a text frame if I want for
easy flowing.

508
00:24:54.340 --> 00:24:56.200
Or, if I"m bringing a text
from somewhere else.

509
00:24:56.200 --> 00:24:58.010
I don't need to setup
the text frame ahead of time,

510
00:24:58.010 --> 00:25:01.260
I can do that auto flow where
it automatically flows for me.

511
00:25:01.260 --> 00:25:04.960
So I'll set that up and then I realize
all the pages now look like that, but

512
00:25:04.960 --> 00:25:08.470
I never apply master page
A to my document pages.

513
00:25:08.470 --> 00:25:11.080
It's sort of the repository
where everything sits.

514
00:25:11.080 --> 00:25:13.870
I'm gonna base other masters on it.

515
00:25:13.870 --> 00:25:15.850
So let's go back to master page A.

516
00:25:15.850 --> 00:25:17.880
Gonna double click on that master page.

517
00:25:17.880 --> 00:25:19.834
And I'm gonna create a new master page,
right?

518
00:25:19.834 --> 00:25:24.920
So I'm gonna say New Master, and
I'm gonna give it a name and a prefix.

519
00:25:24.920 --> 00:25:27.650
And that prefix appears on document pages,

00:36:26.520 --> 00:36:29.710
Erica, I appreciate you and we appreciate
you and I know the viewers out

737
00:36:29.710 --> 00:36:32.860
there appreciate you taking the time
to show us Pages and Master Pages.

738
00:36:32.860 --> 00:36:35.840
Does look like we're coming to end
of another episode but before we do,

739
00:36:35.840 --> 00:36:38.100
do you have any additional words you'd
like to throw into this episode?

740
00:36:38.100 --> 00:36:39.485
>> No,
I think we've covered everything on that.

741
00:36:39.485 --> 00:36:41.970
[LAUGH]
>> All right, very good, and thank you for

742
00:36:41.970 --> 00:36:44.319
joining us in the studios and
thank you to the viewer watching,

743
00:36:44.319 --> 00:36:45.224
signing up fo ITPro TV.

744
00:36:45.224 --> 00:36:46.358
I've been your host, Wes Bryan.

745
00:36:46.358 --> 00:36:47.181
>> And I'm Erica Gamet.

746
00:36:47.181 --> 00:36:49.317
>> And we'll see you next time.

747
00:36:49.317 --> 00:36:58.360
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Erica discuss InDesign libraries and Adobe Creative Cloud Libraries. They explain creating and opening libraries as well as adding items, adding groups of items and using items within an InDesign libraries.
episodes.title: Libraries
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:11.959 --> 00:00:15.229
Welcome back to another exciting episode
here at ITPro.TV, I'm your host,

3
00:00:15.229 --> 00:00:15.800
Wes Bryan.

4
00:00:15.800 --> 00:00:16.630
And in today's episode,

5
00:00:16.630 --> 00:00:19.380
we're coming back at you with more
about Adobe Creative Cloud 2015.

6
00:00:19.380 --> 00:00:23.480
More specifically,
we're diving back into InDesign, and

7
00:00:23.480 --> 00:00:25.590
joining me back in the studios
today is Erica Gamet.

8
00:00:25.590 --> 00:00:26.480
Erica, how you doing?

9
00:00:26.480 --> 00:00:27.450
>> Fantastic, thanks.

10
00:00:27.450 --> 00:00:28.030
>> Great.
So we've

11
00:00:28.030 --> 00:00:30.020
been going through this
journey in InDesign.

12
00:00:30.020 --> 00:00:31.290
What's the next destination?

13
00:00:31.290 --> 00:00:32.750
>> We're gonna stop at the library.

14
00:00:32.750 --> 00:00:33.691
>> All right, very good!

15
00:00:33.691 --> 00:00:36.276
>> [LAUGH] All right, so
we're gonna talk about libraries.

16
00:00:36.276 --> 00:00:39.280
And there are now actually two
flavors of libraries in InDesign, so

17
00:00:39.280 --> 00:00:40.860
we're going to talk about them separately.

18
00:00:40.860 --> 00:00:45.330
So for clarity's sake we're going to call
them InDesign Libraries and CC Libraries,

19
00:00:45.330 --> 00:00:46.940
or Creative Cloud libraries.

20
00:00:46.940 --> 00:00:50.180
We're going to start first with
the InDesign Libraries, and

21
00:00:50.180 --> 00:00:53.300
I may just call them libraries, because
that's how they're tagged in the menus.

22
00:00:53.300 --> 00:00:54.450
So I'm going to jump in and

23
00:00:54.450 --> 00:00:58.270
we are going to look at what a library is,
why we want to use it.

24
00:00:58.270 --> 00:01:01.860
And the reason there are two, is because
there have been libraries in InDesign for

25
00:01:01.860 --> 00:01:02.670
a very, very long time.

26
00:01:02.670 --> 00:01:05.490
I don't even remember how long, but
they've been there for a long time.

27
00:01:05.490 --> 00:01:08.380
And with the advent of the Creative Cloud
and being able to sync all your

28
00:01:08.380 --> 00:01:11.450
assets together they've
introduced libraries there.

29
00:01:11.450 --> 00:01:13.430
So, there's just sort of this separation.

30
00:01:13.430 --> 00:01:16.790
At some point I think they will merge and
become only one, but for

31
00:01:16.790 --> 00:01:17.690
now we've got both.

32
00:01:17.690 --> 00:01:20.480
So, a library is just a place,

33
00:01:20.480 --> 00:01:24.000
a repository to keep items that
you use over and over again.

34
00:01:24.000 --> 00:01:26.150
So again, we're gonna start
with the InDesign library, so

35
00:01:26.150 --> 00:01:30.140
that's their native just to InDesign they
work within the InDesign environment only.

36
00:01:30.140 --> 00:01:33.660
And then we'll branch out to the CC
libraries, but both of them work in

37
00:01:33.660 --> 00:01:37.810
the same way as that you put something in
there, so that you can easily access it.

38
00:01:37.810 --> 00:01:40.920
So we're always trying to find things that
we use over and over again, like logos,

39
00:01:40.920 --> 00:01:41.840
and things like that.

40
00:01:41.840 --> 00:01:45.460
So a library file,
an InDesign library file,

41
00:01:45.460 --> 00:01:49.250
is a standalone file, and
it's not document specific.

42
00:01:49.250 --> 00:01:53.700
So I can have a library open that
I just have open all the time, and

43
00:01:53.700 --> 00:01:58.100
I can pull the elements from that library
into whatever document I'm working on.

44
00:01:58.100 --> 00:02:01.750
So for me,
I might have one that is all of my logos.

45
00:02:01.750 --> 00:02:03.630
So why would I need a lot
of different logos.

46
00:02:03.630 --> 00:02:05.919
Well I might have one that
has a graphic with it,

47
00:02:05.919 --> 00:02:09.696
one that's just maybe my type logo,
I've got one that's in black and white,

48
00:02:09.696 --> 00:02:12.846
I've got one that's in RGB for
all my web and digital output, and

49
00:02:12.846 --> 00:02:15.600
one that's in CMYK for
any printing that I need to do.

50
00:02:15.600 --> 00:02:19.100
So I'm going to have different
versions of that logo, and

51
00:02:19.100 --> 00:02:22.470
I want to know that they're always sitting
there where I can access them easily.

52
00:02:22.470 --> 00:02:24.800
And I would put those in a library file.

53
00:02:24.800 --> 00:02:28.020
So the first thing I'm gonna do is,
I'm gonna open up an existing library and

54
00:02:28.020 --> 00:02:30.800
show you how to grab
items from that library.

55
00:02:30.800 --> 00:02:35.300
Then we'll put some items into a library
and save that library as something new.

56
00:02:35.300 --> 00:02:36.900
So to get to a library,

57
00:02:36.900 --> 00:02:41.050
we just go to the File menu just as
if we were opening an InDesign file.

58
00:02:41.050 --> 00:02:46.560
If we did file open, we might open
up an InDesign file, an Indd file,

59
00:02:46.560 --> 00:02:52.260
or we can come into whoever is
sitting in our computer and

60
00:02:52.260 --> 00:02:58.030
I can see that I have something called an
Indl file, that is InDesign library file.

61
00:02:58.030 --> 00:03:00.980
And if we click on this,
you might see that it says, CS4.

62
00:03:00.980 --> 00:03:02.800
That's what it was created.

63
00:03:02.800 --> 00:03:06.470
So the libraries themselves don't get
updated so if you were to just click

64
00:03:06.470 --> 00:03:10.400
on this library item out on the desktop or
on the explorer, it's going to

65
00:03:10.400 --> 00:03:14.080
launch whatever version or try to launch
whatever version it was created in.

66
00:03:14.080 --> 00:03:17.770
In fact, if I double click on this
will launch CS4, which is really old.

67
00:03:17.770 --> 00:03:20.010
And my computer might explode, who knows.

68
00:03:20.010 --> 00:03:23.910
So for me, I always wanna go from within
the application, from within InDesign, and

69
00:03:23.910 --> 00:03:26.380
say file open, and open that library.

70
00:03:26.380 --> 00:03:28.570
So I'm gonna open up this one, and
this is just called wild items.

71
00:03:28.570 --> 00:03:31.270
This just means that these
are items that I would use for

72
00:03:31.270 --> 00:03:35.740
this wild photography company
that I'm working on stuff here.

73
00:03:35.740 --> 00:03:41.010
So, in this library, and it's hard to see,
the thumbnails are not all that great.

74
00:03:41.010 --> 00:03:44.110
I can actually make them bigger,
unless they are as big as they can.

75
00:03:44.110 --> 00:03:47.020
Up under the library panel menu,
I can come in here and

76
00:03:47.020 --> 00:03:49.820
I can say, large thumbnail, but
it doesn't help a whole lot.

77
00:03:49.820 --> 00:03:52.140
Made my logos a little bit bigger and
easier to see.

78
00:03:52.140 --> 00:03:55.950
But all this text is still greeked
out meaning that it's just grey.

79
00:03:55.950 --> 00:03:58.550
I can't really see what it says,
but I can roll over it and

80
00:03:58.550 --> 00:04:00.570
I do have a little bit of a description.

81
00:04:00.570 --> 00:04:04.090
So what I'm gonna do is just scroll
through and see what I have inside here.

82
00:04:04.090 --> 00:04:07.980
I can see that I have my color logo and
a black and white logo and

83
00:04:07.980 --> 00:04:12.240
I can double-click on each and
see what keywords I've put in there.

84
00:04:12.240 --> 00:04:13.220
So if I double click,

85
00:04:13.220 --> 00:04:17.520
I can see that it has a name to it, that's
the name of the file that I put in there.

86
00:04:17.520 --> 00:04:20.120
And it's an image that
automatically tags that for me.

87
00:04:20.120 --> 00:04:20.820
I never change that.

88
00:04:20.820 --> 00:04:24.890
There's no reason to, I just
whatever it deems it as, I leave as.

89
00:04:24.890 --> 00:04:26.700
And then I put a description here.

90
00:04:26.700 --> 00:04:28.290
These are just sets of key words.

91
00:04:28.290 --> 00:04:31.040
This is helpful if you have lots and
lots of logos.

92
00:04:31.040 --> 00:04:34.590
So if I had lots of levels here,
I might put just black, I might put CMYK,

93
00:04:34.590 --> 00:04:38.500
I might put that it's Pantone color,
I might put that it's RGB.

94
00:04:38.500 --> 00:04:42.510
Just something so that when I'm looking
for all my logos, maybe I have one that's

95
00:04:42.510 --> 00:04:47.100
the graphic, one that's the text, and
I've got three different types of logos.

96
00:04:47.100 --> 00:04:50.470
And then I've got each of those in
black and white, in CMYK, and RGB,

97
00:04:50.470 --> 00:04:53.760
I might wanna Just look for my RGB Images.

98
00:04:53.760 --> 00:04:56.570
So I can tag those, but we're going
to put things in a library in just

99
00:04:56.570 --> 00:05:00.190
a second I just wanted to kind of get you
familiar with what a library looks like.

100
00:05:00.190 --> 00:05:03.480
Now this library is just sort of,
think of it like a bookshelf.

101
00:05:03.480 --> 00:05:06.930
Just where I put my logos on the shelf and
I grab them from.

102
00:05:06.930 --> 00:05:09.510
There's no two way communication

103
00:05:09.510 --> 00:05:13.070
with libraries with in design
libraries back to the libraries.

104
00:05:13.070 --> 00:05:18.010
So for instance, if I put something from
this library into my InDesign document and

105
00:05:18.010 --> 00:05:20.570
make changes to it in
the InDesign document.

106
00:05:20.570 --> 00:05:23.790
It doesn't notify the library
that changes have been made.

107
00:05:23.790 --> 00:05:27.500
So that's one of the limitations to
the InDesign libraries that are there.

108
00:05:27.500 --> 00:05:30.640
But like I said, it's just a place
where we keep it on the shelf so

109
00:05:30.640 --> 00:05:31.400
it's there when we need it.

110
00:05:31.400 --> 00:05:34.320
We can pull it down and
put it into our document, but

111
00:05:34.320 --> 00:05:37.780
it doesn't ever tell the shelf
have made changes to this item.

112
00:05:37.780 --> 00:05:40.000
So how do we get things under the page?

113
00:05:40.000 --> 00:05:41.410
Well, when I open up a library,

114
00:05:41.410 --> 00:05:46.630
and again this library is there as long
it's open even if I create a new document.

115
00:05:46.630 --> 00:05:50.150
I'm just gonna do command Ctrl+N
to create a new document.

116
00:05:50.150 --> 00:05:52.700
When I open that up,
that library is still there.

117
00:05:52.700 --> 00:05:56.200
It wasn't specific to
that particular document.

118
00:05:56.200 --> 00:05:58.240
So, again, it's not document specific.

119
00:05:58.240 --> 00:05:59.020
So I can have that open.

120
00:05:59.020 --> 00:06:03.000
If I know I'm working on a bunch of stuff
for wild, I'll open up my wild library and

121
00:06:03.000 --> 00:06:04.820
leave it there just all day long.

122
00:06:04.820 --> 00:06:06.800
All right, so let's grab something.

123
00:06:06.800 --> 00:06:09.490
I think, okay,
we're going to go digital with this.

124
00:06:09.490 --> 00:06:12.640
So my nice color version of my AI file,

125
00:06:12.640 --> 00:06:15.810
my illustrator file is
the logo that I want to use.

126
00:06:15.810 --> 00:06:19.210
So, I have a couple of different options,
I can either use the panel menu and

127
00:06:19.210 --> 00:06:24.210
place that item, or
I can just simply drag that onto the page.

128
00:06:24.210 --> 00:06:27.540
And when I do, I drag and drop it.

129
00:06:27.540 --> 00:06:31.356
And it puts it to the size it
was when I put in the library.

130
00:06:31.356 --> 00:06:34.690
Now one thing you might notice,
is that it's just a big gray square.

131
00:06:34.690 --> 00:06:39.180
Well what happened is that when I put
that in the library the logo was in

132
00:06:39.180 --> 00:06:40.600
a specific place.

133
00:06:40.600 --> 00:06:43.380
So a specific directory on hard drive.

134
00:06:43.380 --> 00:06:46.080
That's where it expects to find it.

135
00:06:46.080 --> 00:06:49.510
In a previous episode we talked about
links, and making sure our links were

136
00:06:49.510 --> 00:06:52.420
always updated, and make sure that
we don't have something missing.

137
00:06:52.420 --> 00:06:54.660
I'm gonna look in my links panel, and

138
00:06:54.660 --> 00:06:59.510
I can see that this particular
item is actually missing.

139
00:06:59.510 --> 00:07:02.290
I've got big question mark right there.

140
00:07:02.290 --> 00:07:04.110
So it says, okay, it's missing.

141
00:07:04.110 --> 00:07:08.180
So when I put it into that library,
it was sitting in a specific spot.

142
00:07:08.180 --> 00:07:10.680
Since then,
I have moved where that sits, and

143
00:07:10.680 --> 00:07:13.010
now what I've done is
placed a broken link.

144
00:07:13.010 --> 00:07:15.010
So, I need to actually fix the link.

145
00:07:15.010 --> 00:07:19.420
So again, it moved, but nobody told
the library that it's been moved.

146
00:07:19.420 --> 00:07:21.280
I have to actually update that.

147
00:07:21.280 --> 00:07:22.940
So I'll go into my Links Panel.

148
00:07:22.940 --> 00:07:25.590
And I'm just going to relink,
and then we'll go out and

149
00:07:25.590 --> 00:07:26.880
find where that's sitting.

150
00:07:26.880 --> 00:07:28.140
That is the photo logo two.

151
00:07:28.140 --> 00:07:31.070
We'll actually update it with this one,
it's not two, but it's one,

152
00:07:31.070 --> 00:07:31.810
we'll update it with that.

153
00:07:31.810 --> 00:07:33.600
And I have that.

154
00:07:33.600 --> 00:07:38.100
Now I can actually tell it this item
needs to be updated, because otherwise

155
00:07:38.100 --> 00:07:42.080
if I keep placing this logo everywhere,
and I have obviously renamed it.

156
00:07:42.080 --> 00:07:45.460
I took the two off there or
I moved it or whatever happened to it.

157
00:07:45.460 --> 00:07:49.166
Each time I place it in a new document,
I'm gonna keep getting that same error.

158
00:07:49.166 --> 00:07:52.252
So if I know that,
the one that I just relinked it to,

159
00:07:52.252 --> 00:07:57.246
it's where it's going to be sitting, then
may be I should go ahead and update that.

160
00:07:57.246 --> 00:07:59.538
So that I don't have to keep doing this.

161
00:07:59.538 --> 00:08:03.473
So I'm gonna select the The item on
the page, and the item in the library,

162
00:08:03.473 --> 00:08:04.881
they're both selected.

163
00:08:04.881 --> 00:08:07.908
And I'm going to go up to the panel menu,
and I'm going to go ahead and

164
00:08:07.908 --> 00:08:09.850
update that library item.

165
00:08:09.850 --> 00:08:13.080
So, now when I do that, the next time I
place this anywhere whether it's in this

166
00:08:13.080 --> 00:08:16.500
document, or in a new document,
when I drag it out there it is.

167
00:08:16.500 --> 00:08:17.770
It's there, it's not missing.

168
00:08:17.770 --> 00:08:21.150
We don't have a missing link in
the links panel any more, it's perfect.

169
00:08:21.150 --> 00:08:22.960
So that's something we need to.

170
00:08:22.960 --> 00:08:24.920
We need to maintain that library.

171
00:08:24.920 --> 00:08:28.480
And that library file, I'm gonna actually
just jump out to the desktop and

172
00:08:28.480 --> 00:08:31.780
we can actually see where that library,
it's just a library item,

173
00:08:31.780 --> 00:08:33.740
like I said it's a .indl file.

174
00:08:33.740 --> 00:08:38.220
I can give this library item,
this library file to anybody else so

175
00:08:38.220 --> 00:08:40.380
that they have the information as well.

176
00:08:40.380 --> 00:08:41.920
It can be kept on a server.

177
00:08:41.920 --> 00:08:44.080
There are some issues
with certain servers,

178
00:08:44.080 --> 00:08:47.770
especially Windows servers don't
play nicely with libraries.

179
00:08:47.770 --> 00:08:51.000
If you're working in group
environment whether it's at school or

180
00:08:51.000 --> 00:08:55.100
if it's for a Job and
you've got all these libraries.

181
00:08:55.100 --> 00:08:58.870
Generally you want to have someone who
their job is to maintain the libraries and

182
00:08:58.870 --> 00:09:02.090
make sure that they are the most current
ones as well, because otherwise,

183
00:09:02.090 --> 00:09:03.870
you will keep getting those missing links.

184
00:09:03.870 --> 00:09:07.770
But it is a file that you can just hand
off because as far as like the links go,

185
00:09:07.770 --> 00:09:12.660
all it really does is it's just told
in design where to find that file.

186
00:09:12.660 --> 00:09:14.980
Now if the item was something
that was created and

187
00:09:14.980 --> 00:09:19.140
in design, whether it's text, this one is
text, let's actually just drag this out.

188
00:09:19.140 --> 00:09:23.220
So I've just got this travel quote,
I'm gonna pull it out and drop it here.

189
00:09:23.220 --> 00:09:27.120
And it came out as actually formatted
exactly like my poll quotes, and

190
00:09:27.120 --> 00:09:29.550
that's because I have that font loaded.

191
00:09:29.550 --> 00:09:33.120
If I didn't have that font loaded,
and I dragged that quote out,

192
00:09:33.120 --> 00:09:36.430
it's gonna come up and
show me that the font needs to be updated.

193
00:09:36.430 --> 00:09:40.560
So again all it did is it said,
you've formatted it like this, and

194
00:09:40.560 --> 00:09:44.670
it looks like this, and it uses this
font and these colors and these styles.

195
00:09:44.670 --> 00:09:47.740
And I'm gonna recreate it for
you when I drag it under the page.

196
00:09:47.740 --> 00:09:50.375
If it doesn't have the elements
it needs Needs to recreate it.

197
00:09:50.375 --> 00:09:51.855
You'll have to update it manually,

198
00:09:51.855 --> 00:09:55.035
and then again you can recreate
it back to the library.

199
00:09:55.035 --> 00:09:59.595
So how do things get into
a library to begin with?

200
00:09:59.595 --> 00:10:03.267
Well, they have to be put
onto an InDesign page.

201
00:10:03.267 --> 00:10:07.217
So whether it's an image that we place,
just like we place normally and we decide,

202
00:10:07.217 --> 00:10:08.987
hm I'm gonna use that picture again.

203
00:10:08.987 --> 00:10:12.467
Let's drag that into a library,
we just drag it right back in.

204
00:10:12.467 --> 00:10:15.790
So for instance, I can come over here and
I'll create something.

205
00:10:15.790 --> 00:10:16.770
So whether it's text or

206
00:10:16.770 --> 00:10:19.890
it's just a shape I'm just gonna
create a really simple shape.

207
00:10:19.890 --> 00:10:22.170
And then I can say,
okay I want to go ahead.

208
00:10:22.170 --> 00:10:26.340
And let's actually scroll down in here and
get this color.

209
00:10:26.340 --> 00:10:31.620
And I wanna put this shape into my
library, into my wild items library.

210

So now, when I'm ready to create this four

00:21:07.820 --> 00:21:09.980
