426
00:21:26.890 --> 00:21:30.870
If you're on your machine, or if you're on
someone elses machine, you can actually

427
00:21:30.870 --> 00:21:36.500
still log into your Adobe account and
get those assets from the cloud.

428
00:21:36.500 --> 00:21:40.210
And with the Creative Cloud library,
I can put anything into this library and

429
00:21:40.210 --> 00:21:42.440
I can also share that library with others.

430
00:21:42.440 --> 00:21:45.400
Again it's a whole concept
that I can probably

431
00:21:45.400 --> 00:21:48.020
talk all day on about Creative Cloud and
all that, but

432
00:21:48.020 --> 00:21:51.380
just know that there are the two
different types of libraries.

433
00:21:51.380 --> 00:21:54.610
And at any time I can take
these InDesign libraries and

434
00:21:54.610 --> 00:21:56.500
I can convert those to a Creative Cloud.

435
00:21:56.500 --> 00:21:59.870
In fact, that's down here at
the bottom of the Libraries panel,

436
00:21:59.870 --> 00:22:02.540
it says Convert to a Creative Cloud,
or Migrate Library Items.

437
00:22:02.540 --> 00:22:05.920
So I can actually send that to a library.

438
00:22:05.920 --> 00:22:08.390
So let's actually open
up our CC libraries now.

439
00:22:08.390 --> 00:22:12.630
So I'm going to double click just
to collapse those panels back up.

440
00:22:12.630 --> 00:22:15.770
Go up under the window menu,
and choose CC libraries.

441
00:22:15.770 --> 00:22:17.980
When I do that,
I get the CC library panel.

442
00:22:17.980 --> 00:22:18.890
It's kind of huge.

443
00:22:18.890 --> 00:22:21.860
I can shrink that down, and
there's a lot of stuff in the libraries.

444
00:22:21.860 --> 00:22:24.550
So the libraries are things like colors.

445
00:22:24.550 --> 00:22:28.410
Are color themes, if you're creating color
themes using the Capture app or anything.

446
00:22:28.410 --> 00:22:31.590
And again, this is all Creative Cloud
stuff, different course all together,

447
00:22:31.590 --> 00:22:35.320
but feel free to go out and
explore and see what is out there.

448
00:22:35.320 --> 00:22:37.890
Especially if you have the cloud,
you're paying for it,

449
00:22:37.890 --> 00:22:40.530
you might as well explore it and
see what you can do with it.

450
00:22:40.530 --> 00:22:43.360
So at the top here I have all
the different libraries that I have,

451
00:22:43.360 --> 00:22:46.840
these are CC Libraries, and
I can just place this in here.

452
00:22:46.840 --> 00:22:48.790
I have one called wild photo logos.

453
00:22:48.790 --> 00:22:51.240
So in here,
I have things like color themes.

454
00:22:51.240 --> 00:22:53.540
These are themes that I
just dragged in there.

455
00:22:53.540 --> 00:22:56.920
I probably would not use all
these different themes in my wild

456
00:22:56.920 --> 00:22:58.630
photography stuff obviously.

457
00:22:58.630 --> 00:23:02.310
It's just I have a lot in there for
demo purposes, but

458
00:23:02.310 --> 00:23:05.800
I also have down here graphics
move this up a little bit.

459
00:23:05.800 --> 00:23:09.260
And I can look and see that I have
these three graphics here, and

460
00:23:09.260 --> 00:23:12.460
these are the two, basically the same two
that I have in the other library that

461
00:23:12.460 --> 00:23:15.270
are here, but
I just dragged them into that library.

462
00:23:15.270 --> 00:23:21.235
Same as if it was a InDesign library,
that can take InDesign library,

463
00:23:21.235 --> 00:23:25.025
drag it onto the page and
then drag it into the library as well.

464
00:23:25.025 --> 00:23:27.785
I am going to go ahead and
add that and it puts it into a nice

465
00:23:27.785 --> 00:23:31.595
little category it says okay that's
artwork, it kinda separates everything.

466
00:23:31.595 --> 00:23:33.349
If I go back to that text that I have,

467
00:23:33.349 --> 00:23:36.055
let's say that we want
[INAUDIBLE] quote that's here.

468
00:23:36.055 --> 00:23:41.063
Now when I drag this into the CC library,
it doesn't actually, I mean it adds

469
00:23:41.063 --> 00:23:46.014
it as a graphic, but I can also tell it
that I want to add it as a style instead.

470
00:23:46.014 --> 00:23:49.896
So I can come in here and
go to the panel menu, and go ahead,

471
00:23:49.896 --> 00:23:54.596
I want to Whoops, I can actually just
select the text and drag that in.

472
00:23:54.596 --> 00:23:56.650
It should actually bring it in as style.

473
00:23:56.650 --> 00:23:58.120
There we go, sorry.

474
00:23:58.120 --> 00:24:02.540
Down here at the bottom add a character
style or a paragraph style.

475
00:24:02.540 --> 00:24:06.435
So instead of dragging it in as a graphic,
I've got the text selected and

476
00:24:06.435 --> 00:24:09.297
I'd like to save that as a character or
paragraph style.

477
00:24:09.297 --> 00:24:10.813
Now it's set up as a paragraph style.

478
00:24:10.813 --> 00:24:13.310
We're gonna do styles
in an upcoming episode.

479
00:24:13.310 --> 00:24:15.780
But I have styles applied to this text so

480
00:24:15.780 --> 00:24:19.160
it's says would you like to put
it in here as a paragraph style?

481
00:24:19.160 --> 00:24:23.305
So I say sure, and I do that and now I've
got this paragraph style which actually

482
00:24:23.305 --> 00:24:25.335
tells me what font it was,
what size and all that.

483
00:24:25.335 --> 00:24:27.925
And all the information
that's in a paragraph style

484
00:24:27.925 --> 00:24:31.135
is now in here which means I can
use that in other documents.

485
00:24:31.135 --> 00:24:33.730
So, I know I always have
the same text set up.

486
00:24:33.730 --> 00:24:38.470
Keep in mind that InDesign lets you grab
paragraph styles and character styles and

487
00:24:38.470 --> 00:24:40.620
put them into a CC library.

488
00:24:40.620 --> 00:24:44.340
The other programs that actually
can access CC libraries,

489
00:24:44.340 --> 00:24:47.840
like Illustrator and Photoshop,
can't handle paragraph styles.

490
00:24:47.840 --> 00:24:49.500
They can only handle character styles.

491
00:24:49.500 --> 00:24:52.650
So just keep that in mind,
that if you put a paragraph style in here,

492
00:24:52.650 --> 00:24:55.820
you might not be able to access it in
other programs that you wanna use.

493
00:24:55.820 --> 00:24:59.390
So for me, if I just want the text and
I wanna remember that I used,

494
00:24:59.390 --> 00:25:02.190
whatever it was,
23 point Rockwell in here.

495
00:25:02.190 --> 00:25:04.950
I'll add it as a character style, so
at least I can see that when I get

496
00:25:04.950 --> 00:25:07.510
into Photoshop and I wanna start
laying something out in Photoshop, and

497
00:25:07.510 --> 00:25:11.360
I wanna use the same text,
I will have that available to me.

498
00:25:11.360 --> 00:25:13.350
But again it's just a nice repository.

499
00:25:13.350 --> 00:25:15.194
It keeps it synced so
as soon as I make changes,

500
00:25:15.194 --> 00:25:21.190
iIf I make changes to something from a CC
library, if I were to pull this out and

501
00:25:21.190 --> 00:25:24.540
make changes here, I can't actually
make changes cuz that's a placed item.

502
00:25:24.540 --> 00:25:27.740
But if I grab something,
let's say, the paragraph style and

503
00:25:27.740 --> 00:25:31.740
I made changes to that,
if I go into Photoshop and

504
00:25:31.740 --> 00:25:35.180
I have that same library open,
those changes are instant.

505
00:25:35.180 --> 00:25:39.040
So that it does have the two way
communication that you don't have

506
00:25:39.040 --> 00:25:40.620
in the InDesign library.

507
00:25:40.620 --> 00:25:44.500
So like I said, I think they're
obviously migrating to that.

508
00:25:44.500 --> 00:25:48.530
It seems kind of almost cumbersome
now to have two sets of libraries

509
00:25:48.530 --> 00:25:50.680
although I do use them very differently.

510
00:25:50.680 --> 00:25:54.930
I don't find that the organization
of the libraries, the CC libraries,

511
00:25:54.930 --> 00:25:56.240
are quite there yet.

512
00:25:56.240 --> 00:25:58.550
They're just sort of in
this really long list.

513
00:25:58.550 --> 00:26:00.360
And also,
they all live somewhere else, and

514
00:26:00.360 --> 00:26:05.380
they don't work into the file hierarchy
that I'm used to using in my work flow.

515
00:26:05.380 --> 00:26:06.750
If you're just getting started,

516
00:26:06.750 --> 00:26:11.190
though, you might just be wise to start
using just the Creative Cloud library,

517
00:26:11.190 --> 00:26:14.920
because those InDesign libraries
may go away at some point.

518
00:26:14.920 --> 00:26:18.900
And also, this is kind of where things
are going for workflow, I think.

519
00:26:18.900 --> 00:26:21.920
It's just they're not quite there yet
for me, for my organizational,

520
00:26:21.920 --> 00:26:23.850
the way I like to organize things.

521
00:26:23.850 --> 00:26:25.690
But I love that it's instant.

522
00:26:25.690 --> 00:26:28.790
If I open up Illustrator, I go to
a friend's house and I'm like, hey,

523
00:26:28.790 --> 00:26:31.230
let me show you this thing
I made in Illustrator,

524
00:26:31.230 --> 00:26:34.160
I can log into my Adobe account and
there's everything that I created.

525
00:26:34.160 --> 00:26:37.320
I don't have to worry about, it's on
my other machine or anything like that.

526
00:26:37.320 --> 00:26:40.960
If you work at home and
you've got your school computer or

527
00:26:40.960 --> 00:26:43.640
your work computer,
you can have it on both as well.

528
00:26:43.640 --> 00:26:47.320
And so you always have access to
the items that you've created.

529
00:26:47.320 --> 00:26:50.300
So I think the Creative Cloud libraries
are actually pretty cool as well.

530
00:26:51.790 --> 00:26:54.520
So that is libraries in a nutshell.

531
00:26:54.520 --> 00:26:55.460
>> All right, very good.

532
00:26:55.460 --> 00:26:58.510
You know it's interesting,
the debate today,

533
00:26:58.510 --> 00:27:01.950
local storage versus the cloud storage,
and as we've seen, and

534
00:27:01.950 --> 00:27:05.110
as you've seen Erica mention, everything
does seem to be going to the cloud.

535
00:27:05.110 --> 00:27:07.000
So who knows what we'll
see in a couple years.

536
00:27:07.000 --> 00:27:09.260
Now Erica, it does look like we're
running to the end of another episode,

537
00:27:09.260 --> 00:27:11.880
but before you sign off,
do you have additional words on libraries?

538
00:27:11.880 --> 00:27:13.777
>> No.
Just keep in mind where it is,

539
00:27:13.777 --> 00:27:17.420
how you wanna work and
which library would work best for you.

540
00:27:17.420 --> 00:27:18.240
>> All right, very good.

541
00:27:18.240 --> 00:27:19.960
Well, thank you for
being here in the studio and

542
00:27:19.960 --> 00:27:21.130
thank you to the viewer watching.

543
00:27:21.130 --> 00:27:23.731
Signing off for ITProTV,
I've been your host Wes Bryan.

544
00:27:23.731 --> 00:27:24.424
>> And I'm Erica Gamet.

545
00:27:24.424 --> 00:27:26.673
>> And we'll see you next time.

546
00:27:26.673 --> 00:27:34.930
>> [SOUND]

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Erica talk about working with styles within Adobe InDesign. They explain paragraph styles including creating a style from scratch or an existing type. They also look at character styles, nested styles and object styles.
episodes.title: Styles
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:11.674 --> 00:00:12.801
Welcome back to another exciting
episode here at ITProTV.

3
00:00:14.940 --> 00:00:15.904
I'm your host, Wes Bryan.

4
00:00:15.904 --> 00:00:17.107
And in today's episode,

5
00:00:17.107 --> 00:00:20.880
we're continuing along through our
Adobe Create a Cloud 2015 series.

6
00:00:20.880 --> 00:00:24.240
More specifically, we're coming
back at you with more InDesign.

7
00:00:24.240 --> 00:00:26.250
Joining me back in the studios
today is Erica Gamet.

8
00:00:26.250 --> 00:00:27.140
Erica, how are you doing?

9
00:00:27.140 --> 00:00:28.050
>> I'm doing great, thanks.

10
00:00:28.050 --> 00:00:28.830
>> All right, very good.

11
00:00:28.830 --> 00:00:31.270
So we've been taking this
journey through InDesign.

12
00:00:31.270 --> 00:00:32.440
What's our next destination?

13
00:00:32.440 --> 00:00:34.080
>> We're going to talk about styles.

14
00:00:34.080 --> 00:00:34.991
>> All right, very good.

15
00:00:34.991 --> 00:00:37.851
>> All right, so styles is a great
way to do the same thing over and

16
00:00:37.851 --> 00:00:41.390
over again without having to actually
do the same thing over and over again.

17
00:00:41.390 --> 00:00:42.560
What do I mean by that?

18
00:00:42.560 --> 00:00:45.620
It means that all the stuff that we've
done in all these prior episodes.

19
00:00:45.620 --> 00:00:50.075
We're styling text, we're styling
text frames, we're styling objects,

20
00:00:50.075 --> 00:00:53.115
we're putting drop shadows and
different effects on there.

21
00:00:53.115 --> 00:00:55.135
We've done that over and over again, but

22
00:00:55.135 --> 00:01:01.025
I don't want to have to do that every time
I want the same looking item on my page.

23
00:01:01.025 --> 00:01:02.480
I want to save those as a style.

24
00:01:02.480 --> 00:01:04.920
You might also hear the term style sheets.

25
00:01:05.940 --> 00:01:07.540
They'll be just called some styles.

26
00:01:07.540 --> 00:01:12.280
And so basically we can format
something and then create a style so

27
00:01:12.280 --> 00:01:14.890
that next time we wanna format it,
we just click on it and

28
00:01:14.890 --> 00:01:16.970
it formats it beautifully we
don't have to think about it.

29
00:01:16.970 --> 00:01:18.550
Now why do we use that?

30
00:01:18.550 --> 00:01:22.530
For consistency for one thing and
also to make it easier and faster.

31
00:01:22.530 --> 00:01:26.210
But for me,
consistency is the huge benefit of that,

32
00:01:26.210 --> 00:01:30.050
because I don't wanna be trying to
keep track of what size type I used,

33
00:01:30.050 --> 00:01:32.680
or what size frame, or
what the frame looked like,

34
00:01:32.680 --> 00:01:37.020
any of the qualities that it had, and then
be worried that when I do another job for

35
00:01:37.020 --> 00:01:39.670
that same client, or whatever,
that it looks slightly different.

36
00:01:39.670 --> 00:01:41.830
So, consistency is huge,
and also time saving.

37
00:01:41.830 --> 00:01:44.790
So, let's go ahead and
look at how I build styles, and

38
00:01:44.790 --> 00:01:49.680
we're gonna start with text styles,
not textiles, but text styles.

39
00:01:49.680 --> 00:01:52.900
And so there are two different types,
there are character styles and

40
00:01:52.900 --> 00:01:54.020
paragraph styles.

41
00:01:54.020 --> 00:01:56.700
And I'm just gonna start with a big
old blank page, cuz this is kind of

42
00:01:56.700 --> 00:02:01.410
how I start when I'm creating styles,
those paragraph and character styles.

43
00:02:01.410 --> 00:02:05.040
So I'm gonna open up each panel,
character styles and paragraph styles.

44
00:02:06.640 --> 00:02:09.960
And these kind of look, or the information
that's in the paragraph, and

45
00:02:09.960 --> 00:02:14.030
the character styles, are the same thing
that you find in the paragraph and

46
00:02:14.030 --> 00:02:17.080
character panels, and
I am gonna start with paragraph styles.

47
00:02:17.080 --> 00:02:18.010
So start with that on top.

48
00:02:18.010 --> 00:02:21.710
In fact, I'm gonna use character styles,
just move him out of the way for now.

49
00:02:21.710 --> 00:02:26.220
And paragraph styles, and
it's a little confusing only that

50
00:02:26.220 --> 00:02:30.320
some of the information that goes in
a paragraph, is actually stuff that you

51
00:02:30.320 --> 00:02:34.990
enter in the character panel to
start with, and here's why that is.

52
00:02:34.990 --> 00:02:38.810
A paragraph style, and
I kind of liken this to building a house,

53
00:02:38.810 --> 00:02:41.590
not that I know anything about building
a house, but I've seen them built.

54
00:02:41.590 --> 00:02:44.010
When you look at when
a house is being built,

55
00:02:44.010 --> 00:02:45.440
you've got a lot of common elements.

56
00:02:45.440 --> 00:02:46.730
You've got the foundation.

57
00:02:46.730 --> 00:02:48.200
And you've got the framing.

58
00:02:48.200 --> 00:02:48.880
Right?
No matter what

59
00:02:48.880 --> 00:02:52.520
the house is gonna look like, you've got
some kind of foundation and framing.

60
00:02:52.520 --> 00:02:55.160
And that is what your paragraph style is.

61
00:02:55.160 --> 00:02:58.410
So it's sort of the base of what your
paragraph is going to look like.

62
00:02:58.410 --> 00:03:01.950
So things that actually go into
that are things like the alignment,

63
00:03:01.950 --> 00:03:05.940
the hyphenation, things we put in
the paragraph panel when we started.

64
00:03:05.940 --> 00:03:08.910
However, the other thing that you
have is part of that base and

65
00:03:08.910 --> 00:03:14.880
that paragraph is the font, and the size,
the type size, and the letting.

66
00:03:14.880 --> 00:03:19.260
Even though that's a character based
setting, it's sort of like, but

67
00:03:19.260 --> 00:03:24.080
the whole paragraph is going to have that
font in that size, for the most part.

68
00:03:24.080 --> 00:03:28.040
Now going back to the house analogy,
each room has different,

69
00:03:28.040 --> 00:03:32.170
let's say, texture on the walls,
different paint, different decor.

70
00:03:32.170 --> 00:03:35.420
Everything that gives that
room its character, and

71
00:03:35.420 --> 00:03:36.900
that's what a character style is like.

72
00:03:36.900 --> 00:03:39.280
It's sort of the exception to the rule.

73
00:03:39.280 --> 00:03:42.450
So your paragraph style might have
something where it might have 10 point

74
00:03:42.450 --> 00:03:45.060
type with 12 point letting, Palatino.

75
00:03:45.060 --> 00:03:49.270
But certain words we might want
to be bold italic or in green or

76
00:03:49.270 --> 00:03:52.670
something like that, and so
that would be a character style.

77
00:03:52.670 --> 00:03:55.200
So we have paragraph styles
as the foundation and

78
00:03:55.200 --> 00:03:59.240
on top of that, character styles
always go on top of paragraph styles.

79
00:03:59.240 --> 00:04:01.910
So we have a paragraph style that says
this is what the paragraph basically looks

80
00:04:01.910 --> 00:04:05.520
like, except for these things, and
that's where we apply a character style.

81
00:04:05.520 --> 00:04:06.770
So that's all going to come into play.

82
00:04:06.770 --> 00:04:09.250
Hopefully, it will make a lot
more sense than my analogy,

83
00:04:09.250 --> 00:04:11.240
when we actually start
putting stuff on the page.

84
00:04:11.240 --> 00:04:12.800
So let's go ahead and do that.

85
00:04:12.800 --> 00:04:13.370
So, for me,

86
00:04:13.370 --> 00:04:17.080
I'm not the type of person that will say,
okay, I'm ready to lay this out.

87
00:04:17.080 --> 00:04:18.840
Let me think about what
this will look like.

88
00:04:18.840 --> 00:04:20.350
It will be 10 point or 12 point".

89
00:04:20.350 --> 00:04:21.910
I'm not going to map all that out.

90
00:04:21.910 --> 00:04:23.500
That's not how I work.

91
00:04:23.500 --> 00:04:25.100
I throw some text on a page.

92
00:04:25.100 --> 00:04:27.650
So I'm going to use my type tool,
create a text frame,

93
00:04:27.650 --> 00:04:31.510
use my keyboard shortcut that I set
up F2 to fill placeholder text.

94
00:04:31.510 --> 00:04:35.090
If you don't have a keyboard
shortcut it's under the type menu,

95
00:04:35.090 --> 00:04:36.550
fill with placeholder text.

96
00:04:36.550 --> 00:04:39.240
And I'm just gonna throw
some text on the page.

97
00:04:39.240 --> 00:04:42.250
I'm also going to zoom in a little bit so
we can see a little better.

98
00:04:42.250 --> 00:04:47.440
And I said in a prior episode when we were
talking about just styling paragraphs,

99
00:04:47.440 --> 00:04:51.290
not paragraph styles, but we were just
putting some style into our paragraphs,

100
00:04:51.290 --> 00:04:54.310
that you only have to have
your cursor in the paragraph.

101
00:04:54.310 --> 00:04:57.540
Well because I'm actually going to be
adding things like font information,

102
00:04:57.540 --> 00:05:00.030
I need to have at least
one character selected.

103
00:05:00.030 --> 00:05:03.240
So generally, I'll put stuff

We'll call that first paragraph.

547
00:27:00.250 --> 00:27:01.723
So the first paragraph has a drop cap.

548
00:27:01.723 --> 00:27:04.460
And I'm gonna come down to Drop Caps and
Nested Styles.

549
00:27:04.460 --> 00:27:07.090
And I'm just gonna come in here and
say, I would like a drop cap.

550
00:27:07.090 --> 00:27:10.220
And this looks just like we did when
we were working in the Character panel

551
00:27:10.220 --> 00:27:11.220
to create a drop cap.

552
00:27:11.220 --> 00:27:15.230
I'm gonna tell it I want it to be three
lines, just the first character, but

553
00:27:15.230 --> 00:27:17.680
I can also choose a character style for
that.

554
00:27:17.680 --> 00:27:20.390
So maybe it's the italic green.

555
00:27:20.390 --> 00:27:22.620
So it's gonna be in the same font,
but it'll be italic green.

556
00:27:22.620 --> 00:27:26.000
If I had a character style,
I normally have one called drop caps, and

557
00:27:26.000 --> 00:27:30.070
it's usually one of my scripty fonts, and
it's bigger, and it's bold, or whatever.

558
00:27:30.070 --> 00:27:31.900
So I would put in whatever I need here.

559
00:27:31.900 --> 00:27:33.850
You can also create one on the fly,
right here.

560
00:27:33.850 --> 00:27:36.490
If you say, I didn't make one for
drop caps, I can create one here.

561
00:27:36.490 --> 00:27:38.420
So I'm gonna go ahead and say that.

562
00:27:38.420 --> 00:27:42.510
I can actually preview it and see that
that's what that's going to look like, and

563
00:27:42.510 --> 00:27:44.610
I can make changes as I need from there,
but

564
00:27:44.610 --> 00:27:46.280
that's what my first paragraph looks like.

565
00:27:46.280 --> 00:27:48.080
I can also do things like line styles.

566
00:27:48.080 --> 00:27:52.450
There's a lot to styles that we could
take hours and hours to talk about.

567
00:27:52.450 --> 00:27:55.960
So just be sure to explore and see what
else you can build into your style.

568
00:27:55.960 --> 00:27:58.480
Anything that you're doing
to your paragraphs or

569
00:27:58.480 --> 00:28:02.200
your characters, make sure that you build
those into a style because you wanna

570
00:28:02.200 --> 00:28:05.110
be able to do those and
recreate that again and again.

571
00:28:05.110 --> 00:28:09.117
The last thing I will do with the styles,
though, is I wanna make sure that this

572
00:28:09.117 --> 00:28:13.000
first paragraph gets wedged into that
next style rotation that we have.

573
00:28:13.000 --> 00:28:16.810
So I wanna make sure that after author,
we actually go,

574
00:28:16.810 --> 00:28:19.976
instead of to body text,
we go to first paragraph.

575
00:28:19.976 --> 00:28:21.310
And then in the first paragraph,

576
00:28:21.310 --> 00:28:24.810
I wanna make sure that
the next style is body text.

577
00:28:24.810 --> 00:28:26.430
So we say, OK, we'll come back over here,

578
00:28:26.430 --> 00:28:30.240
and I'm gonna zap this back
out to basic paragraph.

579
00:28:30.240 --> 00:28:32.841
Now I have to make sure that I
have some more text down here.

580
00:28:34.965 --> 00:28:37.660
So now I have that, do the same thing.

581
00:28:37.660 --> 00:28:42.140
I will say to apply Headline,
and then Next Style.

582
00:28:42.140 --> 00:28:44.384
When I do that now I have that drop cap.

583
00:28:44.384 --> 00:28:47.270
Now the drop cap doesn't look great
because I have a three line drop cap and

584
00:28:47.270 --> 00:28:49.940
I had very little text, but
that is the first paragraph and

585
00:28:49.940 --> 00:28:52.250
that's what the rest of
the paragraphs look like from there.

586
00:28:52.250 --> 00:28:54.060
So it's easy to rerun that.

587
00:28:54.060 --> 00:28:56.670
Usually, I just zap it out with basic
paragraph cuz that gets rid of all

588
00:28:56.670 --> 00:28:59.558
the styling, and
then apply the new styling on top of it.

589
00:28:59.558 --> 00:29:03.890
That's text styles in a nutshell,
a very small nutshell, there's so

590
00:29:03.890 --> 00:29:04.500
much you can do.

591
00:29:04.500 --> 00:29:08.390
Like I said, any time you add any styling,
go ahead and put it into a paragraph style

592
00:29:08.390 --> 00:29:11.430
or a character style so
you can use it over and over again.

593
00:29:11.430 --> 00:29:15.330
And the other thing that we can do is
that we can do the same thing to objects,

594
00:29:15.330 --> 00:29:16.400
we have object styles.

595
00:29:16.400 --> 00:29:19.440
So let me show object styles
really super quickly.

596
00:29:19.440 --> 00:29:24.080
So same concept, create something,
and then create a style for it.

597
00:29:24.080 --> 00:29:26.300
Let me close up these items.

598
00:29:26.300 --> 00:29:27.884
I'm gonna reset my workspace.

599
00:29:27.884 --> 00:29:32.530
I'm gonna go back to Styles,
it's under Window, down under Styles and

600
00:29:32.530 --> 00:29:33.690
choose Object Styles.

601
00:29:35.070 --> 00:29:39.480
And it's a lot of the same concept, create
something, create a style based on that.

602
00:29:39.480 --> 00:29:43.170
But there are two different styles
that we can look at in object styles,

603
00:29:43.170 --> 00:29:45.660
we have a Graphics Frame and a Text Frame.

604
00:29:45.660 --> 00:29:48.855
So think about if you wanted,
let's say, a graphics frame,

605
00:29:48.855 --> 00:29:51.695
it was like that rectangular
we did with a drop shadow.

606
00:29:51.695 --> 00:29:55.080
We wanna use that a lot, or maybe it's
a picture frame with a drop shadow.

607
00:29:55.080 --> 00:29:56.380
So let's set that up.

608
00:29:56.380 --> 00:29:59.220
We can draw this out, we think,
okay, this is a picture frame.

609
00:29:59.220 --> 00:30:01.100
Now it's not keeping
track of what size it is.

610
00:30:01.100 --> 00:30:03.650
It's not like a library item where
it's gonna draw the same thing.

611
00:30:03.650 --> 00:30:05.950
It's just saying what are the attributes.

612
00:30:05.950 --> 00:30:10.310
Well, we have a stroke of,
let's actually make this stroke.

613
00:30:10.310 --> 00:30:13.660
I want to make this stroke a color and
we'll just choose one from our swatches.

614
00:30:13.660 --> 00:30:17.590
And we'll come in here and
we'll grab this dark green, and

615
00:30:17.590 --> 00:30:18.670
I'm gonna make it a thick stroke.

616
00:30:21.090 --> 00:30:24.510
And let's go ahead and
add a drop shadow to it.

617
00:30:24.510 --> 00:30:26.490
I'm just gonna use
whatever's basic in here.

618
00:30:26.490 --> 00:30:29.870
We're gonna say, okay, and I actually
want the fill to be white just for now so

619
00:30:29.870 --> 00:30:32.830
I don't see that drop shadow coming
through the frame that's there.

620
00:30:32.830 --> 00:30:36.010
So let's make the fill just paper or
white.

621
00:30:37.200 --> 00:30:38.940
But maybe we're gonna
put images in it anyway,

622
00:30:38.940 --> 00:30:40.060
we wouldn't have seen the drop shadow.

623
00:30:40.060 --> 00:30:43.690
But I will say, okay, that's what I want
on my picture frames or my boxes for

624
00:30:43.690 --> 00:30:45.720
anything, whether or
not I'm putting an image in it or

625
00:30:45.720 --> 00:30:48.250
it's just sitting there
with some text in it.

626
00:30:48.250 --> 00:30:49.670
I want my frame to look like that.

627
00:30:49.670 --> 00:30:52.950
Now you notice the graphics frame
over here suddenly has a plus

628
00:30:52.950 --> 00:30:57.330
because it went from the basic and
I added this overriding stuff.

629
00:30:57.330 --> 00:31:02.030
So I'm gonna Option or Alt-click on New,
and we'll call it Shadow Frame.

630
00:31:02.030 --> 00:31:04.280
Maybe I'll call it Shadow Frame Green.

631
00:31:04.280 --> 00:31:07.940
I always try to put in there
what it is that goes in there.

632
00:31:07.940 --> 00:31:12.780
Now the basic attributes, by default,
everything is set to be on except for

633
00:31:12.780 --> 00:31:13.920
Paragraph Styles.

634
00:31:13.920 --> 00:31:16.950
And this isn't a text frame, so
it won't actually apply to this at all.

635
00:31:16.950 --> 00:31:19.674
So we'll do that in the next example.

636
00:31:19.674 --> 00:31:24.294
So right now, it says everything
that's in that item that I just

637
00:31:24.294 --> 00:31:28.936
have selected is being force fed
into this particular setting.

638
00:31:28.936 --> 00:31:29.910
In fact, there are so

639
00:31:29.910 --> 00:31:32.590
many settings we have to drill
down on each of those to see.

640
00:31:32.590 --> 00:31:36.290
But basically, I create one and say, make
a new one and everything that's there,

641
00:31:36.290 --> 00:31:40.900
anything that I've styled is there and
is part of that option.

642
00:31:40.900 --> 00:31:44.030
Now, with the Paragraph Styles,
if you notice there's a little slash.

643
00:31:44.030 --> 00:31:47.780
You can either have them on or
not important.

644
00:31:47.780 --> 00:31:51.700
So that just basically says,
if I put a paragraph style in there and

645
00:31:51.700 --> 00:31:55.360
it's different from what you're expecting,
don't flag that as an override,

646
00:31:55.360 --> 00:31:57.380
that's what that slash means.

647
00:31:57.380 --> 00:32:00.045
But we don't have Paragraph Style
cuz this is not a text frame,

648
00:32:00.045 --> 00:32:01.112
it's a graphics frame.

649
00:32:01.112 --> 00:32:02.043
So, I'll just say OK to that.

650
00:32:02.043 --> 00:32:04.653
That's a shadow frame, and then I
wanna make sure I actually apply that.

651
00:32:04.653 --> 00:32:07.176
So I'll select it and apply that and
say, great, that's a shadow frame.

652
00:32:07.176 --> 00:32:09.147
Whoops, why did it do that?

653
00:32:09.147 --> 00:32:12.472
Let me select this and
make the new shadow frame.

654
00:32:12.472 --> 00:32:17.390
Let's do that, and say that's what the
shadow frame needed to look like, or not.

655
00:32:17.390 --> 00:32:18.470
It's not going to let me do that.

656
00:32:18.470 --> 00:32:22.190
I'm going to copy that and then paste
that, and say okay here's what I want.

657
00:32:22.190 --> 00:32:24.970
I want a new one,
we are just going to do the same thing.

658
00:32:24.970 --> 00:32:29.876
Option, alt click, and
say let's do green shadow frame,

659
00:32:29.876 --> 00:32:33.530
and apply that to the selection.

660
00:32:33.530 --> 00:32:36.220
So now I have that frame set up and

661
00:32:36.220 --> 00:32:41.270
I want to grab this little item that's
here, this little proxy and drag it down.

662
00:32:41.270 --> 00:32:45.510
And say for all new shadow frames,
or I'm sorry, for all new graphic

663
00:32:45.510 --> 00:32:49.800
frames that is the default for
that, if that makes sense.

664
00:32:49.800 --> 00:32:52.425
So otherwise,
it's always going to draw this other one.

665
00:32:52.425 --> 00:32:55.027
So now every time I draw
out a new frame like that,

666
00:32:55.027 --> 00:32:57.263
it automatically has that applied to it.

667
00:32:57.263 --> 00:32:59.664
And now I have an override on it,
sometimes this happens,

668
00:32:59.664 --> 00:33:02.907
it's like it should grab what was there
but it's grabbing some information.

669
00:33:02.907 --> 00:33:04.936
Automatically did an override,
I didn't do that,

670
00:33:04.936 --> 00:33:07.180
it's just grabbing
information from somewhere.

671
00:33:07.180 --> 00:33:10.320
Remember to option or
alt click on that name and

672
00:33:10.320 --> 00:33:15.160
it gets rid of that override and makes
it adhere to that standard that we have.

673
00:33:15.160 --> 00:33:16.330
So that's a graphics frame.

674
00:33:16.330 --> 00:33:18.530
We can do the same thing for a text frame.

675
00:33:18.530 --> 00:33:21.930
So if you know you constantly
want a three-column text frame,

676
00:33:21.930 --> 00:33:23.100
we can do the same thing.

677
00:33:23.100 --> 00:33:25.970
So I can draw the text frame,
open to the object menu,

678
00:33:25.970 --> 00:33:28.540
and come down to text frame options.

679
00:33:28.540 --> 00:33:30.260
And tell it,
let's say it's three columns, and

680
00:33:30.260 --> 00:33:33.150
we put a gutter in there, and
we say okay, because every

681
00:33:33.150 --> 00:33:36.810
time I draw a new text frame I don't want
to have to go into text frame options.

682
00:33:36.810 --> 00:33:41.290
I can select this, do the option or alt,
we'll call this a three column frame,

683
00:33:43.050 --> 00:33:47.700
and here's where I can say yes, and
the paragraph style is also important.

684
00:33:47.700 --> 00:33:51.732
So like you are doing say a side bar you
can set it up not only the way the border

685
00:33:51.732 --> 00:33:54.730
looks and the fields looks,
you can also and always

686
00:33:54.730 --> 00:33:58.340
fill it with your paragraph style called
sidebar text or whatever you've call it.

687
00:33:58.340 --> 00:34:00.970
So you need to select on this,
actually click on this, and

688
00:34:00.970 --> 00:34:02.920
say what text need to go in there.

689
00:34:02.920 --> 00:34:06.960
So in this case let's in this
we always put body text, and

690
00:34:06.960 --> 00:34:08.630
do we include the next style as well?

691
00:34:08.630 --> 00:34:11.630
If that's part of that rotation,
you might wanna include that as well.

692
00:34:11.630 --> 00:34:12.320
So now I say OK.

693
00:34:12.320 --> 00:34:16.660
And that's this three column frame,
and I want that to be the default, so

694
00:34:16.660 --> 00:34:17.880
I drag that down.

695
00:34:17.880 --> 00:34:23.340
Now every time I draw out a new text frame
in this document, it's automatically

696
00:34:23.340 --> 00:34:27.000
three columns, and when I fill a
placeholder text, it's also automatically

697
00:34:27.000 --> 00:34:32.770
filled with our body text that's in
that particular document that's there.

698
00:34:32.770 --> 00:34:34.390
So anytime we do the same thing over and

699
00:34:34.390 --> 00:34:36.120
over again,
we want to make a styles for it.

700
00:34:36.120 --> 00:34:39.090
There are also sale styles and
table styles as well.

701
00:34:39.090 --> 00:34:41.730
So basically anything you do over and
over and over again or

702
00:34:41.730 --> 00:34:45.280
you want consistency, make a style for it
so that you don't have to think about it.

703
00:34:45.280 --> 00:34:50.340
We just draw it, it works,for this, I've
suddenly got a three-column text frame.

704
00:34:50.340 --> 00:34:52.350
And I've got that paragraph
style already assigned.

705
00:34:52.350 --> 00:34:54.800
I don't even have to think anything
about it, I'm just ready to get up and

706
00:34:54.800 --> 00:34:56.380
start putting the text in there.

707
00:34:56.380 --> 00:34:57.410
>> Erica, that's nice.

708
00:34:57.410 --> 00:35:00.430
The styles just definitely seems like
it can save you a lot of time and

709
00:35:00.430 --> 00:35:03.990
a lot of headache and
really help that project just go smoothly.

710
00:35:03.990 --> 00:35:06.240
Does look like we're coming to
the end of another episode,

711
00:35:06.240 --> 00:35:09.460
but before we sign out this episode,
do you have any additional words or

712
00:35:09.460 --> 00:35:11.270
advice you'd like to give on styles?

713
00:35:11.270 --> 00:35:12.125
>> Yes, use them.

714
00:35:12.125 --> 00:35:13.270
[LAUGH] That's it.

715
00:35:13.270 --> 00:35:14.610
>> Very good, that's great.

716
00:35:14.610 --> 00:35:17.220
Well, thank you for joining us here in
the studios and the wealth of knowledge on

717
00:35:17.220 --> 00:35:19.790
styles, and thank you to you,
the viewer, for watching.

718
00:35:19.790 --> 00:35:22.290
Signing out for ITProTV,
I've been your host Wes Brian.

719
00:35:22.290 --> 00:35:23.400
>> And I'm Erica Gamet.

720
00:35:23.400 --> 00:35:24.520
>> And we'll see you next time.

721
00:35:24.520 --> 00:35:32.408
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Erica demonstrate prepping the output of a project within Adobe InDesign. They explain transparencies and using native files from Illustrator, Photoshop, Acrobat and PDFs. They will also discuss non-transparencies, flatteners and separations.
episodes.title: Prepping the Output
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:11.756 --> 00:00:14.352
Welcome back to another exciting
episode here at ITProTV.

3
00:00:14.352 --> 00:00:15.637
I'm your host, Wes Bryan.

4
00:00:15.637 --> 00:00:16.703
In today's episode,

5
00:00:16.703 --> 00:00:20.130
we are coming back at you with more
of the Adobe Creative Cloud 2015.

6
00:00:20.130 --> 00:00:22.810
That's right,
back again with more InDesign.

7
00:00:22.810 --> 00:00:24.630
Joining me in the studio is Erica Gammet.

8
00:00:24.630 --> 00:00:25.425
Erica how ya doing?

9
00:00:25.425 --> 00:00:26.111
>> Fantastic.

10
00:00:26.111 --> 00:00:26.670
>> All right, so

11
00:00:26.670 --> 00:00:29.430
we've been travelling along this
journey that is known as InDesign.

12
00:00:29.430 --> 00:00:30.800
Where are we going next?

13
00:00:30.800 --> 00:00:32.580
>> We're gonna start prepping for output.

14
00:00:32.580 --> 00:00:33.420
>> All right, very good.

15
00:00:33.420 --> 00:00:34.250
>> So, we're gonna jump in and

16
00:00:34.250 --> 00:00:36.870
we're gonna start talking about
some issues we might have.

17
00:00:36.870 --> 00:00:39.890
And start thinking about how
we're going to output this

18
00:00:39.890 --> 00:00:43.080
piece that we've been creating,
whether that's to print or digital.

19
00:00:43.080 --> 00:00:45.560
So we need to start making
some more considerations and

20
00:00:45.560 --> 00:00:49.150
start making sure that the work we've
put into it actually is going give us

21
00:00:49.150 --> 00:00:51.260
the results that we're
expecting in the end.

22
00:00:51.260 --> 00:00:54.200
So, the first thing I'm going
to talk about is transparency.

23
00:00:54.200 --> 00:00:56.780
So I'm going to look at a couple
items that I have on my page

24
00:00:56.780 --> 00:00:58.330
that are transparent.

25
00:00:58.330 --> 00:01:00.610
So I've just got some simple
shapes here right now.

26
00:01:00.610 --> 00:01:04.000
And transparency is something
we've been adding as we go along.

27
00:01:04.000 --> 00:01:07.990
Through all the episodes, we've added
things like drop shadows and effects,

28
00:01:07.990 --> 00:01:08.700
feathers.

29
00:01:08.700 --> 00:01:11.540
In this case,
I have two objects overlapped.

30
00:01:11.540 --> 00:01:15.460
I have done things like clipping paths,
so that we can add a drop shadow.

31
00:01:15.460 --> 00:01:16.560
And while point of that is so

32
00:01:16.560 --> 00:01:21.350
that we can do things like put this on
top of this text, and it looks like

33
00:01:21.350 --> 00:01:25.970
a drop shadow hanging on top of some
text and over this shape here, as well.

34
00:01:25.970 --> 00:01:30.920
And all of that is well and
good if we're going to digital.

35
00:01:30.920 --> 00:01:33.156
Because, and
even then we can run into some issues.

36
00:01:33.156 --> 00:01:36.640
But for printing,
let's take that into consideration first.

37
00:01:36.640 --> 00:01:40.260
Because what happens is, when we're
working with these transparent objects or

38
00:01:40.260 --> 00:01:42.960
effects, is we're working with light.

39
00:01:42.960 --> 00:01:47.070
So we've got objects that are shining
through other objects, right?

40
00:01:47.070 --> 00:01:51.870
So in this case, I've got this bluish
square on this yellow square and

41
00:01:51.870 --> 00:01:56.550
where they overlap is some form of green
or brown, or depending your monitor.

42
00:01:56.550 --> 00:01:58.970
So, but it's a different color,
we can see that.

43
00:01:58.970 --> 00:02:03.020
Well what happens is, if we were going
to print this, whether it's digitally,

44
00:02:03.020 --> 00:02:04.180
we're going to print to toner,

45
00:02:04.180 --> 00:02:07.670
we're going to print it on the printing
press with ink, it doesn't matter.

46
00:02:07.670 --> 00:02:13.760
What happens though when we go to print,
we have to fake that transparency.

47
00:02:13.760 --> 00:02:16.090
So basically,
you can't print in transparent ink.

48
00:02:16.090 --> 00:02:18.530
Now there is transparent ink and
transparent,

49
00:02:18.530 --> 00:02:19.792
you know if you've ever
worked on model planes,

50
00:02:19.792 --> 00:02:23.230
you know there's transparent paint,
right, and it shows through.

51
00:02:23.230 --> 00:02:27.310
But when we're trying to do something
like this, I can't use transparent ink.

52
00:02:27.310 --> 00:02:30.860
Because here I need to be solid blue,
and here a solid yellow, but

53
00:02:30.860 --> 00:02:32.780
here I need it to be transparent.

54
00:02:32.780 --> 00:02:35.380
So what happens when we go to print,
we have to fake it.

55
00:02:35.380 --> 00:02:39.570
We have to make it look transparent,
and that's where issues can come in.

56
00:02:39.570 --> 00:02:42.850
Now, year by year as we go along,
there are fewer and fewer issues, but

57
00:02:42.850 --> 00:02:44.870
we still be to be aware of them.

58
00:02:44.870 --> 00:02:48.990
And one thing that I can do, is I can,
in my pages panel, and we looked at this

59
00:02:48.990 --> 00:02:53.410
in a prior episode, when we went ahead and
worked with the pages panel, is one of

60
00:02:53.410 --> 00:02:58.170
the things I can tell it in the panel
options, is to show me my transparency.

61
00:02:58.170 --> 00:03:00.230
So, I'm gonna say OK, and when I do that,

62
00:03:00.230 --> 00:03:04.320
I get these little checker boards next to
it, telling me that there's transparency.

63
00:03:04.320 --> 00:03:08.980
And it says, okay, I need to be aware that
there are transparent issues on this page.

64
00:03:08.980 --> 00:03:12.270
They may or may not be a problem,
but I need to keep an eye on it.

65
00:03:12.270 --> 00:03:14.730
So in this case,
I have transparency on both pages.

66
00:03:14.730 --> 00:03:17.520
I've got a drop shadow and
I've got these items over lapped.

67
00:03:17.520 --> 00:03:19.780
So what happens when, or
why is that a problem?

68
00:03:19.780 --> 00:03:24.190
Well, we have to trick our eyes
into making it look transparent.

69
00:03:24.190 --> 00:03:26.650
So when I go to output whether
I'm going to press and

70
00:03:26.650 --> 00:03:29.000
I'm going to print it to a digital plate,
or

71
00:03:29.000 --> 00:03:34.240
I'm going to maybe just output it on
a laser printer, color laser printer.

72
00:03:34.240 --> 00:03:37.130
I have to have a way for
the machine to know

73
00:03:37.130 --> 00:03:40.320
that this is not actually transparency,
but let's make it look transparent.

74
00:03:40.320 --> 00:03:43.870
So what happens, in a nutshell,
is something called flattening.

75
00:03:43.870 --> 00:03:48.820
So right now we have all these layers, and
they work together well in this lighted

76
00:03:48.820 --> 00:03:51.730
environment that we're working in
to give you that transparency.

77
00:03:51.730 --> 00:03:56.150
But, I need to flatten it all down when it
goes to print because it's going to be one

78
00:03:56.150 --> 00:03:57.370
solid output.

79
00:03:57.370 --> 00:03:58.030
So I have to flatten it.

80
00:03:58.030 --> 00:04:02.370
So what happens in what's called a RIP,
a raster image processor, when we go to

81
00:04:02.370 --> 00:04:06.780
output it is that it says, okay, you've
got this blue square that's in here.

82
00:04:06.780 --> 00:04:08.770
If we can jump back to the screen.

83
00:04:08.770 --> 00:04:11.390
We've got this blue square and
we've got this yellow square, but

84
00:04:11.390 --> 00:04:13.290
we also have this third region.

85
00:04:13.290 --> 00:04:15.800
This green square,
whatever we want to call it.

86
00:04:15.800 --> 00:04:20.550
The machine, when it exports, whether
it's us exporting it from InDesign and

87
00:04:20.550 --> 00:04:25.100
that engine is working on it or we send
it to a RIP machine and that RIP machine,

88
00:04:25.100 --> 00:04:30.310
that software has to go, okay, how do I
make that look like a transparent square?

89
00:04:30.310 --> 00:04:33.770
It says, I'm gonna create these
things called atomic regions.

90
00:04:33.770 --> 00:04:36.900
And so, there's the blue one, and the
yellow one, and the one in the middle, so

91
00:04:36.900 --> 00:04:38.450
it breaks it down.

92
00:04:38.450 --> 00:04:41.700
That's some place where a lot
of the processors give up, and

93
00:04:41.700 --> 00:04:43.630
they say I can't figure
out how to do that.

94
00:04:43.630 --> 00:04:44.690
Same thing with the drop shadow.

95
00:04:44.690 --> 00:04:45.370
Shadow.

96
00:04:45.370 --> 00:04:48.990
The drop shadow says, you've got all these
different images, all these different

97
00:04:48.990 --> 00:04:54.750
shades of black basically, to give it
the illusion of this transparency.

98
00:04:54.750 --> 00:04:57.480
And then also,
if you have information back behind it,

99
00:04:57.480 --> 00:04:59.690
now I have that added as well.

100
00:04:59.690 --> 00:05:03.480
So I've got all these different shades of
yellow, all the different shades of gray

101
00:05:03.480 --> 00:05:05.950
and I have to make each one it's
own little separate region.

102
00:05:05.950 --> 00:05:07.310
Now, why do I tell you that?

103
00:05:07.310 --> 00:05:11.830
Because sometimes what happens is like say
the machinary or the software gives up and

104
00:05:11.830 --> 00:05:14.600
says that is a beautiful
drop shadow that you have,

105
00:05:14.600 --> 00:05:16.300
here is a big black square instead.

106
00:05:16.300 --> 00:05:18.400
Because that's all it can
do at it that sometimes.

107
00:05:18.400 --> 00:05:22.030
So I'm just saying keep an eye on that and
know that that might be an issue.

108
00:05:22.030 --> 00:05:25.300
Going back to the very beginning where
I said always know what happens to your

109
00:05:25.300 --> 00:05:27.819
piece when it leaves,
what happens when to it, do a test.

110
00:05:27.819 --> 00:05:32.556
If you think you're gonna run a bunch of
stuff with drop-shadows and transparency,

111
00:05:32.556 --> 00:05:33.310
run a test.

112
00:05:33.310 --> 00:05:35.590
Export it how the printer
wants you to export it,

113
00:05:35.590 --> 00:05:37.820
whether that's a PDF with their settings.

114
00:05:37.820 --> 00:05:39.210
You send it to them and say okay, great.

115
00:05:39.210 --> 00:05:40.520
Can you put it on a press and test it?

116
00:05:40.520 --> 00:05:41.300
It out.

117
00:05:41.300 --> 00:05:44.420
It sounds expensive, but the great thing
is if you're running it on a four color

118
00:05:44.420 --> 00:05:48.630
press, they're usually on big sheets,
there's usually a section off to the side

119
00:05:48.630 --> 00:05:51.330
that they're just gonna cut away and
throw away anyway.

120
00:05:51.330 --> 00:05:53.370
You can often throw that
on there as a separate job.

121
00:05:53.370 --> 00:05:55.580
And just put it on there and
make sure, hey, does that look right?

122
00:05:55.580 --> 00:05:59.200
And make sure that it gives you
the results you're going to give.

123
00:05:59.200 --> 00:06:01.330
So a lot of thing I know is technical.

124
00:06:01.330 --> 00:06:04.510
And if you're not printing you might
think, I don't need to worry about this.

125
00:06:04.510 --> 00:06:07.330
But when we export to PDF
in an upcoming episode,

126
00:06:07.330 --> 00:06:11.865
we're gonna see that transparency is
still a thing, just not as big a deal.

127
00:06:11.865 --> 00:06:15.240
[LAUGH] So there's some ways to
test where you might have problems.

128
00:06:15.240 --> 00:06:17.770
Instead of trying to remember
where your transparency is or

129
00:06:17.770 --> 00:06:20.960
just relying on the little icon
that's here next to the pages,

130
00:06:20.960 --> 00:06:25.370
is that we can go ahead and
look at that in an output preview mode.

131
00:06:25.370 --> 00:06:28.850
So right now, what we're working in
is just sort of the normal art mode.

132
00:06:28.850 --> 00:06:30.570
And I can choose Overprint Preview.

133
00:06:30.570 --> 00:06:34.420
I'm actually go down and look at
those squares of color that we have.

134
00:06:34.420 --> 00:06:36.210
I'm gonna turn on Overprint Preview.

135
00:06:36.210 --> 00:06:39.150
Let's move this out of the way so
we can actually see the change happen.

136
00:06:39.150 --> 00:06:41.810
So watch the squares that are there,
and so Overprint Preview.

137
00:06:42.970 --> 00:06:44.000
Now it changed a little bit.

138
00:06:44.000 --> 00:06:45.900
You notice the blue got
a little bit darker.

139
00:06:45.900 --> 00:06:48.680
Not a whole lot, sometimes you'll
see a huge shift of colors.

140
00:06:48.680 --> 00:06:52.695
And it just depends on your monitor and
the shapes that I have set up, but

141
00:06:52.695 --> 00:06:55.025
I can see that it might
look a little different.

142
00:06:55.025 --> 00:06:58.075
If I had a different color background for
instance, that paper.

143
00:06:59.335 --> 00:07:00.955
In an earlier episode,

144
00:07:00.955 --> 00:07:04.870
we changed the swatches,
the paper swatches to something else.

145
00:07:04.870 --> 00:07:08.900
I said, okay let's put paper and
let's give it just a slight blue tint.

146
00:07:08.900 --> 00:07:09.630
Just a slight,

147
00:07:09.630 --> 00:07:12.760
slight blue tint because that's
the paper that we're gonna print on.

148
00:07:12.760 --> 00:07:14.070
You think okay, that looks good.

149
00:07:14.070 --> 00:07:17.230
Well let's actually turn
on Overprint Preview.

150
00:07:17.230 --> 00:07:18.260
It got really dark.

151
00:07:18.260 --> 00:07:20.220
That yellow got super muddy.

152
00:07:20.220 --> 00:07:22.630
Because that yellow of the shape and

153
00:07:22.630 --> 00:07:26.190
the blue of the paper combine to
make this sort of muddy green color.

154
00:07:26.190 --> 00:07:29.700
And that's exactly what will happen
when you print that in the real world.

155
00:07:29.700 --> 00:07:33.930
So again, turning on the Overprint
Preview, while not super, super accurate,

156
00:07:33.930 --> 00:07:37.388
it will show you, hm, that's not quite
the look that I wanted to go for.

157
00:07:37.388 --> 00:07:41.290
So that's Overprint Preview,
you can turn that on and check that out.

158
00:07:41.290 --> 00:07:41.890
So what happens?

159
00:07:41.890 --> 00:07:45.140
How do we fix some of these things?

160
00:07:45.140 --> 00:07:47.170
Like this cactus bloom words.

161
00:07:47.170 --> 00:07:50.900
Well, if text is back behind
a transparent object,

162
00:07:50.900 --> 00:07:55.800
one of the things that might happen is how
it breaks it into those atomic regions.

163
00:07:55.800 --> 00:08:01.510
So for instance, when it comes to text,
it might say, okay, this U over here or

164
00:08:01.510 --> 00:08:05.790
maybe even the L from
the L onward is text.

165
00:08:05.790 --> 00:08:10.030
So I'm gonna render that as actual text,
actual font.

166
00:08:10.030 --> 00:08:13.680
But this part of the B, this top part
of the B where it has transparency,

167
00:08:13.680 --> 00:08:17.170
I'm gonna render that as raster image.

168
00:08:17.170 --> 00:08:20.350
And I'm gonna render the bottom
part as vector image.

169
00:08:20.350 --> 00:08:21.205
And it's able to do that.

170
00:08:21.205 --> 00:08:26.532
So it will chop up your word into these
little pieces which sounds terrible,

171
00:08:26.532 --> 00:08:27.540
and it can be.

172
00:08:27.540 --> 00:08:30.334
Because what'll happen is
where it's rasterized,

173
00:08:30.334 --> 00:08:33.430
it might get just slightly fatter,
slightly fuzzier.

174
00:08:33.430 --> 00:08:37.150
Not a whole lot, but when you're
looking at letters especially, you're

175
00:08:37.150 --> 00:08:39.790
gonna say that doesn't look right, what's
wrong with the top of the B, it's weird.

176
00:08:39.790 --> 00:08:42.170
So it breaks it down into
these little regions.

177
00:08:42.170 --> 00:08:44.380
So keep in mind that that
might happen as well.

178
00:08:44.380 --> 00:08:48.120
In a second, we're gonna look how to
visualize where issues might come up.

179
00:08:48.120 --> 00:08:49.290
But how can we fix that?

180
00:08:49.290 --> 00:08:54.210
Well, one thing is we can move this in
the layers panel or in the stacking order.

181
00:08:54.210 --> 00:08:58.380
We can move this word,
cactus bloom up above that photo.

182
00:08:58.380 --> 00:09:00.301
That will fix our transparency problem.

183
00:09:00.301 --> 00:09:02.250
But now it doesn't look like
we wanted it to, right.

184
00:09:02.250 --> 00:09:06.220
The whole point was to have this
nice shadow overlaying the text.

185
00:09:06.220 --> 00:09:10.700
So just keep in mind if that's a problem,
that might be your only option to do that.

186
00:09:10.700 --> 00:09:13.600
The other thing you can do is
you can take this text and

187
00:09:13.600 --> 00:09:15.190
you can convert it to outlines.

188
00:09:15.190 --> 00:09:17.750
So if you go up under type and

189
00:09:17.750 --> 00:09:22.920
come down to create outlines,
now that text is no longer text.

190
00:09:22.920 --> 00:09:24.960
It is actually vector image.

191
00:09:24.960 --> 00:09:26.990
You still might have a problem
cuz it's still vector, and

192
00:09:26.990 --> 00:09:28.550
it might rasterize part of it.

193
00:09:28.550 --> 00:09:30.910
But you're gonna cut out a lot
of issues that way as well.

194
00:09:32.580 --> 00:09:34.610
So just a lot of different
things to keep in mind.

195
00:09:34.610 --> 00:09:36.720
Again, this is mostly for printing.

196
00:09:36.720 --> 00:09:40.510
Although you will see sometimes
just weird, chunky drop shadows or

197
00:09:40.510 --> 00:09:45.175
chunky boxes where drop shadows should
be when you go to a PDF as well.

198
00:09:45.175 --> 00:09:46.415
So, another place to look at that as well,

199
00:09:46.415 --> 00:09:48.245
I'm gonna actually make
sure I'm backed up here.

200
00:09:48.245 --> 00:09:50.145
I actually want this to be text,

201
00:09:50.145 --> 00:09:53.225
because I want to see where
I might be having problems.

202
00:09:53.225 --> 00:09:55.915
So, there's a couple output
panels that you can look at

203
00:09:55.915 --> 00:09:59.260
to kinda get an idea of
where you might have issues.

204
00:09:59.260 --> 00:10:01.740
So one of them is called the flattener.

205
00:10:01.740 --> 00:10:06.700
So going way back to the very beginning
when we first set up a new document,

206
00:10:06.700 --> 00:10:09.350
we told it what our intent was, right?

207
00:10:09.350 --> 00:10:13.290
We said, Cmd or Ctrl+N,
new document our intent is print and

208
00:10:13.290 --> 00:10:15.920
it say's you are going to CMYK.

209
00:10:15.920 --> 00:10:19.710
So as we chose colors,
it kept trying to steer us toward CMYK.

210
00:10:19.710 --> 00:10:26.430
So, if I go up under the Edit menu and
come down to the Transparency Blend Space,

211
00:10:26.430 --> 00:10:29.940
it says that it is set for Document CMYK.

212
00:10:29.940 --> 00:10:32.700
So it automatically knows
that's where it's going.

213
00:10:32.700 --> 00:10:36.675
So it's going to give you clues
as to where you might have

214
00:10:36.675 --> 00:10:38.881
trouble outputting the CMYK.

215
00:10:38.881 --> 00:10:42.020
So let's go ahead and
open up our flattener panel.

216
00:10:42.020 --> 00:10:43.890
So the flattener, again,
is just saying okay,

217
00:10:43.890 --> 00:10:47.220
when I go to output this,
at some point I have to flatten it.

218
00:10:47.220 --> 00:10:50.390
And when we export the PDF in
a future episode, we'll see that

219
00:10:50.390 --> 00:10:54.760
we can choose to do it when we make
the PDF or it might be that the PDF,

220
00:10:54.760 --> 00:10:59.320
whoever's outputting the PDF for print
might actually be flattening it as well.

221
00:10:59.320 --> 00:11:01.010
Let's open up one of our panels.

222
00:11:01.010 --> 00:11:01.830
Under the window menu,

223
00:11:01.830 --> 00:11:05.560
we have a whole bunch here under output
and the flattener preview is one of them.

224
00:11:07.020 --> 00:11:08.990
And by default, nothing is highlighted.

225
00:11:08.990 --> 00:11:11.230
Now this doesn't mean,
when we look at this,

226
00:11:11.230 --> 00:11:16.220
it doesn't say this will be a problem
It says this could be a problem.

227
00:11:16.220 --> 00:11:17.130
So let's open that.

228
00:11:17.130 --> 00:11:20.730
I'm gonna go ahead and
just choose them from the pull-down menu.

229
00:11:20.730 --> 00:11:23.480
And I can go ahead and look at each
individual item that we might have

230
00:11:23.480 --> 00:11:26.650
problems with,
like where might I see outlined text?

231
00:11:26.650 --> 00:11:29.490
Let's choose that and
it automatically highlights that.

232
00:11:29.490 --> 00:11:33.010
Now, it doesn't mean that it would
happen necessarily, or even if it did,

233
00:11:33.010 --> 00:11:34.930
that it would happen in this nice square.

234
00:11:34.930 --> 00:11:38.660
It's basically where the flower hits and
overlaps.

235
00:11:38.660 --> 00:11:44.320
Cuz remember, everything lives in
rectangular bounding boxes, including

236
00:11:44.320 --> 00:11:48.690
those atomic regions where it picks and
chooses what needs to be rasterized.

237
00:11:48.690 --> 00:11:53.000
So it's just saying that this bit of
the text might end up rasterized.

238
00:11:53.000 --> 00:11:57.680
Well, if it does that, that little bit
might be fuzzy, or just slightly bolder.

239
00:11:57.680 --> 00:11:59.820
And we don't want that,
because that could be an issue.

240
00:11:59.820 --> 00:12:00.650
So how do we fix that?

241
00:12:00.650 --> 00:12:02.670
We say, okay,
maybe we bring this to the front.

242
00:12:02.670 --> 00:12:05.930
Going to right-click or
Ctrl-click on it, and say, Arrange, and

243
00:12:05.930 --> 00:12:07.400
bring that to the front.

244
00:12:07.400 --> 00:12:10.780
When I do that, you notice,
the red regions went away.

245
00:12:10.780 --> 00:12:12.440
Because it says, now, not an issue.

246
00:12:12.440 --> 00:12:15.970
Again, it's not exactly what we want
though, we wanted it back behind.

247
00:12:15.970 --> 00:12:18.700
So let's go ahead and refresh that and
see where we might have trouble.

248
00:12:19.810 --> 00:12:21.950
We can also turn on all
rasterized regions, and

249
00:12:21.950 --> 00:12:24.750
it will show you everything that's
going to be rasterized in that image.

250
00:12:24.750 --> 00:12:27.340
So, you can see, obviously,
the image is going to rasterized, and

251
00:12:27.340 --> 00:12:30.750
the drop shadow is going to rasterized,
and those are raster effects.

252
00:12:30.750 --> 00:12:34.720
But also where it overlaps
could be a problem as well.

253
00:12:34.720 --> 00:12:37.910
And again, we don't know that
this is actually going to happen.

254
00:12:37.910 --> 00:12:40.250
This is just what we think might happen.

255
00:12:40.250 --> 00:12:41.570
And you've got some presets here.

256
00:12:41.570 --> 00:12:43.280
These are your flattener presets.

257
00:12:43.280 --> 00:12:46.750
So, by default, you've got three of them,
low medium, and high.

258
00:12:46.750 --> 00:12:52.043
So when you go to Export or when you go to
Print from a document, and we're saying

259
00:12:52.043 --> 00:12:56.943
printing to our laser jet in the office,
we might use medium resolution.

260
00:12:56.943 --> 00:13:00.546
Because we're just telling it, it needs to
flatten it and give us sorta the effect,

261
00:13:00.546 --> 00:13:03.050
and I need to kinda see
where my drop shadows are.

262
00:13:03.050 --> 00:13:04.690
But I'm not gonna tell it high resolution,

263
00:13:04.690 --> 00:13:07.560
it's not going to send all that
information to the printer because

264
00:13:07.560 --> 00:13:10.980
the laser jet can't actually
handle high resolution anyway.

265
00:13:10.980 --> 00:13:11.480
So, but

266
00:13:11.480 --> 00:13:16.240
when I go to print, if I'm doing my final
piece, I need to say high resolution.

267
00:13:16.240 --> 00:13:20.080
Now, if we're sending
out this file as a PDF,

268
00:13:20.080 --> 00:13:23.380
this will also be an option
when we go to export to PDF.

269
00:13:23.380 --> 00:13:27.435
I have a couple other here that are called
high with outlines, and high with text and

270
00:13:27.435 --> 00:13:28.625
strokes outlined.

271
00:13:28.625 --> 00:13:33.985
Meaning that I set this up to say
that anytime there's high resolution,

272
00:13:33.985 --> 00:13:38.605
I also would like you to change
all of the text to outlines.

273
00:13:38.605 --> 00:13:42.635
So instead of me selecting the text
like I did and say convert to outlines,

274
00:13:42.635 --> 00:13:45.950
sort of kind of minimize some
of those transparency issues,

275
00:13:45.950 --> 00:13:49.205
I can tell it to do that on the fly
when I send this out to a PDF.

276
00:13:49.205 --> 00:13:53.821
And the great thing about that is that
my text is still editable text here in

277
00:13:53.821 --> 00:13:57.990
InDesign, but the stuff that went
into the PDF is no longer text and

278
00:13:57.990 --> 00:14:01.330
may get rid of some of
those transparency issues.

279
00:14:01.330 --> 00:14:04.030
So I know it's a lot to
take in transparency, but

280
00:14:04.030 --> 00:14:08.300
for me, generally I look at it and then if
I am running a test, I know where to look.

281
00:14:08.300 --> 00:14:10.080
I don't have to look
through my whole document.

282
00:14:10.080 --> 00:14:14.210
If I only have transparency on two pages,
you know theres 20 other pages in

283
00:14:14.210 --> 00:14:18.370
there that don't have transparency I know
I only need to concentrate on those two.

284
00:14:18.370 --> 00:14:20.230
So it just saves a lot of
time to be able to do that.

285
00:14:20.230 --> 00:14:21.530
And you're going to learn.

286
00:14:21.530 --> 00:14:23.624
If it's the first time you've
sent something to a printer,

287
00:14:23.624 --> 00:14:24.781
you're gonna have to test a lot.

288
00:14:24.781 --> 00:14:25.815
But once you've done it,

289
00:14:25.815 --> 00:14:29.130
you're probably fine knowing,
the drop shadows worked last time.

290
00:14:29.130 --> 00:14:33.455
My PDF could handle it, their software
could handle it, we're all good on that.

291
00:14:33.455 --> 00:14:37.130
And the last thing in
the previews is separation.

292
00:14:37.130 --> 00:14:42.141
So if you are going to print and you're
going to actually print it on an offset

293
00:14:42.141 --> 00:14:46.761
press where you need to separate your
item out on two separate plates,

294
00:14:46.761 --> 00:14:49.689
we wanna check how those separations look.

295
00:14:49.689 --> 00:14:53.520
We wanna make sure that each color that
I need is actually on its own plate.

296
00:14:53.520 --> 00:14:56.800
Now in this case, I'm gonna zoom out
a little bit, this is a four color image.

297
00:14:56.800 --> 00:15:02.240
So that should separate in the CMYK, and I
said way back earlier that in my swatches,

298
00:15:02.240 --> 00:15:05.010
I don't have CMYK listed in my swatches.

299
00:15:05.010 --> 00:15:07.360
Because I never assigned Cyan, Magenta, or

300
00:15:07.360 --> 00:15:12.260
Yellow, individually to an object,
but I do have images that are CMYK.

301
00:15:12.260 --> 00:15:13.260
And that's fine.

302
00:15:13.260 --> 00:15:14.080
It knows it.

303
00:15:14.080 --> 00:15:16.160
It's here and it says,
these are the colors that you have.

304
00:15:16.160 --> 00:15:19.570
So when I have a four color image,
or a CMYK image, or

305
00:15:19.570 --> 00:15:24.030
even in this case, it's an RGB image and
it can actually change on the fly for us.

306
00:15:24.030 --> 00:15:26.830
But I'm gonna see how that
separates out when I print that.

307
00:15:26.830 --> 00:15:29.250
And again, it knows we're going to print,

308
00:15:29.250 --> 00:15:32.410
cuz we told that way back in
the beginning that our intent was print.

309
00:15:33.740 --> 00:15:36.710
So I can choose to view my separations.

310
00:15:36.710 --> 00:15:38.330
I'm gonna choose separations.

311
00:15:38.330 --> 00:15:40.030
And it shows all of them together.

312
00:15:40.030 --> 00:15:43.490
I can turn of the CMYK right here
just by clicking the little eyeball.

313
00:15:43.490 --> 00:15:44.663
And it shows me the Pantone 266.

314
00:15:44.663 --> 00:15:47.900
Now, you notice it showed me it in black.

315
00:15:47.900 --> 00:15:51.000
Then I see as when I view individual
plates, it shows it in black so

316
00:15:51.000 --> 00:15:54.500
we can actually see what
is printing on that.

317
00:15:54.500 --> 00:15:55.810
So, in this case,

318
00:15:55.810 --> 00:15:59.830
the job that I'm printing would
end up being a five color job.

319
00:15:59.830 --> 00:16:03.860
We've got cyan, magenta, yellow,
black, plus a Pantone on top of that.

320
00:16:03.860 --> 00:16:07.290
It's not a cheap job but, if those are our
colors, that's what we have to use.

321
00:16:07.290 --> 00:16:08.440
Right, so I can go ahead and to that.

322
00:16:08.440 --> 00:16:10.130
So I can say okay, great,
that's what I wanted.

323
00:16:10.130 --> 00:16:12.860
I wanted that to be a solid Pantone color.

324
00:16:12.860 --> 00:16:16.640
I can then select another color and
deselect another eyeball.

325
00:16:16.640 --> 00:16:17.810
So I just turn on each one.

326
00:16:17.810 --> 00:16:20.920
So I can see okay,
that's printing in black, that's great.

327
00:16:20.920 --> 00:16:22.348
That's printing in yellow.

328
00:16:22.348 --> 00:16:25.010
And notice when you add another one,
it suddenly shows that in the colors,

329
00:16:25.010 --> 00:16:25.820
which is kind of cool.

330
00:16:25.820 --> 00:16:29.060
You can actually build your file and
see how that's going to build together.

331
00:16:29.060 --> 00:16:32.870
But for me I want to make sure
that everything separated well.

332
00:16:32.870 --> 00:16:36.280
I tend not to look at my
CMYK separations so much.

333
00:16:36.280 --> 00:16:40.834
But what I usually wanna make sure is that
my Pantone color is exactly, everything

334
00:16:40.834 --> 00:16:45.524
that I want to be that Pantone color shows
on that Pantone color plate that's there.

335
00:16:45.524 --> 00:16:49.680
The other thing I could do
is I can check my inclement.

336
00:16:49.680 --> 00:16:54.260
And the inclement is just something that
if you are setting it to an offset press,

337
00:16:54.260 --> 00:16:57.310
you need to discuss with your printer,
how much ink is too much ink?

338
00:16:57.310 --> 00:17:00.930
So think about if you had
something that was 90% of cyan,

339
00:17:00.930 --> 00:17:03.840
magenta, yellow and 80% black,
that is a lot of ink.

340
00:17:03.840 --> 00:17:06.300
That's nearly 400% ink.

341
00:17:06.300 --> 00:17:09.090
Ink is actual stuff that
gets put on the paper and

342
00:17:09.090 --> 00:17:13.140
the more you have the heavier and
the soggier that paper can become.

343
00:17:13.140 --> 00:17:14.799
And that's a bad thing, right?

344
00:17:14.799 --> 00:17:16.910
That's gonna end up,
everything is gonna look muddy.

345
00:17:16.910 --> 00:17:19.050
So most printers have a limit.

346
00:17:19.050 --> 00:17:21.590
And 300 is just kind of one of
those magic numbers that may or

347
00:17:21.590 --> 00:17:23.370
may not actually be a real number.

348
00:17:23.370 --> 00:17:25.500
But 300 is just a good
thing to think about.

349
00:17:25.500 --> 00:17:28.770
So I can say okay, my inclement is 300,
so I want to go ahead and view that and

350
00:17:28.770 --> 00:17:32.360
make sure that I don't have too
much of anything in this inclement.

351
00:17:32.360 --> 00:17:35.890
So I can come and here say,
let's say our inclement is only 280.

352
00:17:35.890 --> 00:17:38.120
If I do that actually, that's still good.

353
00:17:38.120 --> 00:17:40.800
Let's say our increment is
200 which is really low.

354
00:17:40.800 --> 00:17:43.280
But when I do that,
you get these red points and

355
00:17:43.280 --> 00:17:44.670
it just says that's too much ink.

356
00:17:44.670 --> 00:17:48.240
Now the solution to that is
to go back into Photoshop and

357
00:17:48.240 --> 00:17:49.800
actually make changes to that graphic.

358
00:17:49.800 --> 00:17:52.143
So unfortunately, that's your choice.

359
00:17:52.143 --> 00:17:56.437
200's really low, but the great thing is
if I say 300, nothing is tagged in red so

360
00:17:56.437 --> 00:17:57.900
I'm pretty much ready to go.

361
00:17:57.900 --> 00:17:59.690
I know that what I have is going to work.

362
00:17:59.690 --> 00:18:02.430
If I've worked with this printer
before and I know they can handle that

363
00:18:02.430 --> 00:18:05.680
transparency, I can see where
the transparency issues were.

364
00:18:05.680 --> 00:18:08.180
But I'm gonna keep an eye on
that when we do a test run.

365
00:18:08.180 --> 00:18:11.940
So for me, I look at this before
I send it out to a press.

366
00:18:11.940 --> 00:18:13.510
I check the separations.

367
00:18:13.510 --> 00:18:18.180
And I check the transparency
flattener to make sure that I'm

368
00:18:18.180 --> 00:18:21.060
not going to have any issues
with my transparency.

369
00:18:21.060 --> 00:18:24.740
So again, think about this,
this is printing thing only pretty much.

370
00:18:24.740 --> 00:18:28.340
Like I said were gonna look at it a little
bit when we start talking about PDFs.

371
00:18:28.340 --> 00:18:31.960
And other than that, just know that
you need to keep an eye on things and

372
00:18:31.960 --> 00:18:34.698
hopefully everything will work out
when we get it out to the press.

373
00:18:34.698 --> 00:18:38.960
>> All right Erica, I know we're getting
one step closer to the final product here

374
00:18:38.960 --> 00:18:41.130
but it does look like we're coming
to the end of another episode.

375
00:18:41.130 --> 00:18:41.790
But before we do,

376
00:18:41.790 --> 00:18:45.330
do you have any additional words
of wisdom on prepping the output?

377
00:18:45.330 --> 00:18:46.090
>> Not yet.

378
00:18:46.090 --> 00:18:47.378
[LAUGH]
>> All right, very good.

379
00:18:47.378 --> 00:18:49.856
We appreciate you being here and
we appreciate you the viewer watching.

380
00:18:49.856 --> 00:18:52.462
Signing out for ITProTV,
I've been your host Wes Brian.

381
00:18:52.462 --> 00:18:53.491
>> And I'm Erica Gammit.

382
00:18:53.491 --> 00:18:54.590
>> And we'll see you next time.

383
00:18:54.590 --> 00:19:04.419
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Erica talk about getting a project ready to print within Adobe InDesign. They explain the print window, common areas as well as saving,loading, and archiving styles. They explore the panel list and the various options such as general, setup, marks, bleeds, output, color management and more.
episodes.title: Printing
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:11.496 --> 00:00:14.680
Welcome back to another exciting
episode here at ITPro.TV.

3
00:00:14.680 --> 00:00:15.995
I'm your host Wes Bryan and

4
00:00:15.995 --> 00:00:20.239
in today's episode we're coming back at
you with more Adobe Creative Cloud 2015.

5
00:00:20.239 --> 00:00:23.050
That's right, back again for
more in design.

6
00:00:23.050 --> 00:00:24.870
Joining me in the studios
today is Erica Gamet.

7
00:00:24.870 --> 00:00:25.678
Erica how are you doing?

8
00:00:25.678 --> 00:00:26.455
>> I'm doing great thanks.

9
00:00:26.455 --> 00:00:27.023
>> Great, so

10
00:00:27.023 --> 00:00:31.170
we've been going through the journey I
should say that is known as InDesign.

11
00:00:31.170 --> 00:00:32.117
What is our next stop?

12
00:00:32.117 --> 00:00:32.930
>> We're gonna do some printing.

13
00:00:32.930 --> 00:00:34.188
>> All right, very good.

14
00:00:34.188 --> 00:00:38.528
>> All right, so whether you're printing
to your desktop printer or you're working

15
00:00:38.528 --> 00:00:42.125
in a print press environment and
you need to print actually out to your

16
00:00:42.125 --> 00:00:46.670
rip devise you're going to encounter the
same dialogue box, the print dialogue box.

17
00:00:47.890 --> 00:00:50.256
Pretty much everybody's familiar how
to get to their print dialogue box.

18
00:00:50.256 --> 00:00:54.920
It's Cmd or Ctrl+P, unless you've changed
it in your keyboard shortcuts of course,

19
00:00:54.920 --> 00:00:57.960
or it's up under the File menu,
File > Print.

20
00:00:57.960 --> 00:01:03.080
Now remember, it's automatically assuming
that we're going to CMYK when we created

21
00:01:03.080 --> 00:01:06.420
all of our documents we kept telling
it that the intent was print.

22
00:01:06.420 --> 00:01:08.330
And actually, I should probably step
backwards on that a little bit.

23
00:01:08.330 --> 00:01:13.360
We said print, if we're going to print and
something digital whether it's the web or

24
00:01:13.360 --> 00:01:15.400
we're going to a PDF or
something like that.

25
00:01:15.400 --> 00:01:19.730
And for all our examples we're basically
going to print out to a device,

26
00:01:19.730 --> 00:01:23.040
whether it's an inkjet printer or
laser printer or whatever.

27
00:01:23.040 --> 00:01:26.850
We're gonna choose that the print dialogue
box, and also we're gonna print and

28
00:01:26.850 --> 00:01:29.190
export out to a PDF as well.

29
00:01:29.190 --> 00:01:33.219
So we started with the more
constrained print environment,

30
00:01:33.219 --> 00:01:37.727
which means that we have a CMYK
color model which has fewer options.

31
00:01:37.727 --> 00:01:40.332
It's a more restrictive color model, and

32
00:01:40.332 --> 00:01:43.720
we can always grow out from
there when we go to RGB.

33
00:01:43.720 --> 00:01:47.030
So again, I'm gonna assume we're
going to print right out here.

34
00:01:47.030 --> 00:01:48.610
We're going to do File, and choose Print.

35
00:01:50.220 --> 00:01:53.020
And in here is where we choose
everything that's specific to

36
00:01:53.020 --> 00:01:54.470
whatever we're printing to.

37
00:01:54.470 --> 00:01:58.030
So the first thing we need to do is
come up to the printer at the top and

38
00:01:58.030 --> 00:01:59.800
choose what printer we need.

39
00:01:59.800 --> 00:02:02.250
Now, we might have
a Print Preset already set up.

40
00:02:02.250 --> 00:02:05.475
I have one called Friendly Alien,
don't you?

41
00:02:05.475 --> 00:02:08.969
And so but here we would have all
the Print Presets that we have for

42
00:02:08.969 --> 00:02:12.284
whatever it is we're printing to,
our different devices.

43
00:02:12.284 --> 00:02:14.670
But first we have to set up
all that information, and

44
00:02:14.670 --> 00:02:17.500
put in those parameters before
we can save that Print Preset.

45
00:02:18.650 --> 00:02:21.960
So we need to choose a printer, and I'm
actually not going to print to anything

46
00:02:21.960 --> 00:02:23.850
specific, I'm not actually
hooked to a printer.

47
00:02:23.850 --> 00:02:25.640
But here's where you'd
put all your devices,

48
00:02:25.640 --> 00:02:29.260
whether it's your to your office
printer or whatever it would be here.

49
00:02:29.260 --> 00:02:30.166
When you choose that,

50
00:02:30.166 --> 00:02:32.939
you need to make sure you choose
the one you are actually printing to.

51
00:02:32.939 --> 00:02:36.243
Because that's going to change many
of the other options that we see in

52
00:02:36.243 --> 00:02:37.700
our print dialogue box.

53
00:02:37.700 --> 00:02:39.756
So I'm just gonna choose one and
actually I wanna see, if I have one.

54
00:02:39.756 --> 00:02:42.270
I don't have one that does
separations necessarily.

55
00:02:42.270 --> 00:02:46.506
We can do separations, but you're probably
not going to be doing that anyway.

56
00:02:46.506 --> 00:02:50.048
And again most of what I do,
I don't print for

57
00:02:50.048 --> 00:02:54.470
my final output anymore,
most of what I do goes to PDF.

58
00:02:54.470 --> 00:02:58.600
However, I like to print a proof
obviously for myself, for

59
00:02:58.600 --> 00:03:01.410
my client, on my own internal devices.

60
00:03:01.410 --> 00:03:03.514
So I'm just gonna choose the kind
of printer that I have here, and

61
00:03:03.514 --> 00:03:05.450
we're gonna look at the different options.

62
00:03:05.450 --> 00:03:07.840
Obviously, we can choose
how many copies we want.

63
00:03:07.840 --> 00:03:11.350
I'm just going to do one of course, and
I can't do it from the first order.

64
00:03:11.350 --> 00:03:14.700
So these are options that we'll see
also a lot of these are repeated

65
00:03:14.700 --> 00:03:16.990
in the PDF export as well.

66
00:03:16.990 --> 00:03:18.910
Page Range, so if we wanna go ahead and

67
00:03:18.910 --> 00:03:24.260
put all the pages that are in the document
or I can choose an individual range.

68
00:03:24.260 --> 00:03:25.860
And I have a few options with that.

69
00:03:25.860 --> 00:03:29.205
I can choose to do all the pages in
the document which is the same as all or

70
00:03:29.205 --> 00:03:30.812
I can choose this pull down menu.

71
00:03:30.812 --> 00:03:33.571
And I can choose from what's
called alternate layouts and

72
00:03:33.571 --> 00:03:37.640
that's something I wont be covering in
this could it's a little more advanced.

73
00:03:37.640 --> 00:03:40.550
But just know that you can have
different layouts in the same document.

74
00:03:40.550 --> 00:03:44.555
I could have my postcards and my business
cards, and I could have my PDF versions of

75
00:03:44.555 --> 00:03:47.631
them and my print versions of them
all in the same document, and

76
00:03:47.631 --> 00:03:49.625
here's where I can choose that as well.

77
00:03:49.625 --> 00:03:52.330
I can also choose to print
All pages from here.

78
00:03:52.330 --> 00:03:56.440
I could also print just the Current page,
whatever page I'm sitting on.

79
00:03:56.440 --> 00:03:59.605
And in this case, it's v.;1.

80
00:03:59.605 --> 00:04:03.560
So just know that that's the vertical
layout and it's the first page.

81
00:04:03.560 --> 00:04:06.381
So if I'm sitting on one page and
I just want that page to print,

82
00:04:06.381 --> 00:04:07.939
I can also print the current page.

83
00:04:07.939 --> 00:04:09.110
I'm gonna go ahead and say all.

84
00:04:10.160 --> 00:04:13.660
I can choose if I want to print all
the pages or just the even pages or

85
00:04:13.660 --> 00:04:14.550
the odd pages.

86
00:04:15.900 --> 00:04:19.880
And I can also choose whether I
want individual pages or spreads.

87
00:04:19.880 --> 00:04:21.450
So when we looked to the pages panel,

88
00:04:21.450 --> 00:04:26.610
we saw that we could set two pages side by
side, that's known as a two page spread.

89
00:04:26.610 --> 00:04:28.930
So I could print it out as a spread.

90
00:04:28.930 --> 00:04:32.481
So if I had an 8.5 by 11 sheet, and
I'm actually gonna cancel out of this and

91
00:04:32.481 --> 00:04:34.554
just jump out to the Pages
panel really quick.

92
00:04:34.554 --> 00:04:37.748
These are 8.5 by 11 pages,
if I wanted to print

93
00:04:37.748 --> 00:04:41.776
the spread side by side maybe
it's just this two page document.

94
00:04:41.776 --> 00:04:45.716
But I know they're actually gonna sit
side by side, either for printing or for

95
00:04:45.716 --> 00:04:46.980
the actual final piece.

96
00:04:46.980 --> 00:04:49.920
I can go ahead and put those side by side.

97
00:04:49.920 --> 00:04:53.100
To do those, we have to go back
to the Page Panel menu and

98
00:04:53.100 --> 00:04:55.390
deselect Allow Selected Spreads
to Shuffle.

99
00:04:55.390 --> 00:04:58.740
Basically, it says don't constrain
me to these single pages,

100
00:04:58.740 --> 00:05:03.145
