bring this upside side by side and
I can look at it in this spread.

101
00:05:03.145 --> 00:05:07.519
I might wanna print it in a spread like
that on an 11 by 17 sheet of paper.

102
00:05:07.519 --> 00:05:10.045
So I've just doubled it and
put on the same sheet.

103
00:05:10.045 --> 00:05:14.048
So going back to the print
dialog box Cmd or Ctrl+P.

104
00:05:14.048 --> 00:05:17.050
I can come down here and
choose to print that in spreads.

105
00:05:17.050 --> 00:05:18.451
Now right now if I look down here,

106
00:05:18.451 --> 00:05:20.766
everything I'm making a change
to shows up over here.

107
00:05:20.766 --> 00:05:23.724
And it kind of gives you an idea of what
it's gonna look like when I print it.

108
00:05:23.724 --> 00:05:27.650
Well I can kinda see that even this first
page doesn't fit on the page itself, and

109
00:05:27.650 --> 00:05:28.995
we'll see why in a second.

110
00:05:28.995 --> 00:05:32.745
But the second one is completely
thrown off the page, and

111
00:05:32.745 --> 00:05:37.687
that's because my Cannon printer
only does 8.5 by 11 sheet of paper.

112
00:05:37.687 --> 00:05:42.340
But I'm told that to spreads at 100%
it means it's not all going to fit.

113
00:05:42.340 --> 00:05:45.340
So always keep in mind
what that looks like.

114
00:05:45.340 --> 00:05:47.970
So again, I can kind of see it's
offset and we're gonna see why.

115
00:05:47.970 --> 00:05:50.130
That's because I have crop
marks probably set up and so

116
00:05:50.130 --> 00:05:55.076
it needs to accommodate the crop marks
which also won't fit, not at 100% anyway.

117
00:05:55.076 --> 00:05:57.620
So those are some options
to look at there.

118
00:05:57.620 --> 00:06:00.130
Down here we have what
layers we wanna print, and

119
00:06:00.130 --> 00:06:03.120
by default Visible &
Printable Layers are turned on.

120
00:06:03.120 --> 00:06:07.560
When we worked with layers in a previous
movie, we said is this printable?

121
00:06:07.560 --> 00:06:11.290
Does everything show up, and
also is everything on it visible or

122
00:06:11.290 --> 00:06:12.800
is the layer itself visible?

123
00:06:12.800 --> 00:06:16.157
You can choose to print only
the visible and printable layers,

124
00:06:16.157 --> 00:06:18.512
which is probably what
you want by default.

125
00:06:18.512 --> 00:06:20.192
I like that that's on by default, so

126
00:06:20.192 --> 00:06:22.973
you don't have to think about
it when you go ahead and print.

127
00:06:22.973 --> 00:06:26.963
So if I set it up as viewable and
printable when I created that layer,

128
00:06:26.963 --> 00:06:29.880
it will now automatically show up here.

129
00:06:29.880 --> 00:06:32.910
I could tell it to do all layers, that
means if I have a layer that was a hidden

130
00:06:32.910 --> 00:06:36.340
layer, maybe my layer full of notes for
a client, I could go ahead and

131
00:06:36.340 --> 00:06:39.750
have that print right away even
though it's set to not print.

132
00:06:39.750 --> 00:06:42.402
So that's often what I do,
is if I have my annotations.

133
00:06:42.402 --> 00:06:46.430
Whether it's to myself or to my client,
I have a separate layer for that.

134
00:06:46.430 --> 00:06:50.541
I might tell it, don't print that layer,
so I have it set to not print.

135
00:06:50.541 --> 00:06:54.483
But I can still override that in the print
dialog box and say yes, let's go ahead and

136
00:06:54.483 --> 00:06:55.830
print that.

137
00:06:55.830 --> 00:06:59.280
Might turn that back to
the Visible & Printable Layers.

138
00:06:59.280 --> 00:07:01.690
I can also tell it to print
non-printing objects.

139
00:07:01.690 --> 00:07:04.192
That sounds like a conundrum or
I don't know an oxymoron, something.

140
00:07:04.192 --> 00:07:05.540
It just sounds wrong.

141
00:07:05.540 --> 00:07:06.966
Print non printable objects.

142
00:07:06.966 --> 00:07:09.640
Well I can tell objects that
they're not printable, but

143
00:07:09.640 --> 00:07:11.480
I might want them to show up here.

144
00:07:11.480 --> 00:07:15.240
And a good example of that,
is if I am printing business cards,

145
00:07:15.240 --> 00:07:20.305
often you'll have a company logos that
are four color, ie expensive to print.

146
00:07:20.305 --> 00:07:21.819
And you've printed those ahead of time.

147
00:07:21.819 --> 00:07:23.796
So we've got four business cards and

148
00:07:23.796 --> 00:07:27.765
they just have the logos where they
need to be in the business card.

149
00:07:27.765 --> 00:07:30.212
And then later, we're gonna do
what's called an over print.

150
00:07:30.212 --> 00:07:33.725
We're gonna come back and
just print the people's business card.

151
00:07:33.725 --> 00:07:36.668
We've got four new employees,
we want to print their business card and

152
00:07:36.668 --> 00:07:38.004
we put in all that information.

153
00:07:38.004 --> 00:07:42.718
And we take shells we already have the
logo, the expensive four color logo on.

154
00:07:42.718 --> 00:07:46.363
And we just overprint the black part
where we have the name and address and

155
00:07:46.363 --> 00:07:49.070
phone number and
all that stuff on top of that.

156
00:07:49.070 --> 00:07:53.020
Well in my InDesign file,
that logo needs to be there so

157
00:07:53.020 --> 00:07:56.970
I can see where the logo is, so
I don't run any text into it.

158
00:07:56.970 --> 00:07:58.349
But it doesn't need to print,

159
00:07:58.349 --> 00:08:01.225
when I print that out I just want
the black overprint to come out.

160
00:08:01.225 --> 00:08:05.142
Well when I come back into the dialogue
box here in the print dialogue box,

161
00:08:05.142 --> 00:08:07.109
this is print non printing objects.

162
00:08:07.109 --> 00:08:08.896
I want those logos to show up.

163
00:08:08.896 --> 00:08:13.490
Not in the final piece, but
when I'm doing a proof for a client.

164
00:08:13.490 --> 00:08:16.270
Because I can't tell you how many times
I've just printed out the black, and

165
00:08:16.270 --> 00:08:17.840
the client says where's my logo.

166
00:08:17.840 --> 00:08:20.920
There's supposed to be a logo, and
you have to explain to them again.

167
00:08:20.920 --> 00:08:21.520
It's there.

168
00:08:21.520 --> 00:08:22.580
It's already printed.

169
00:08:22.580 --> 00:08:26.800
So I'll turn that on and say here's what
we look at, or if my notes to myself or

170
00:08:26.800 --> 00:08:28.910
to my client, are set to non-print.

171
00:08:28.910 --> 00:08:31.180
I can turn that on for
this instance, for a proof.

172
00:08:31.180 --> 00:08:34.960
I'm gonna turn it back off when I do
the final print, or when I export to PDF.

173
00:08:34.960 --> 00:08:38.520
I can also choose to print blank pages.

174
00:08:38.520 --> 00:08:41.110
This is something that should
be on by default, probably cuz

175
00:08:41.110 --> 00:08:44.140
there are a lot of times, you'll have
a blank page and it needs to be there.

176
00:08:44.140 --> 00:08:47.370
So that your page three, or your
chapter starts on the right hand side.

177
00:08:47.370 --> 00:08:49.590
You might have a blank
page sitting next to it.

178
00:08:49.590 --> 00:08:53.490
So I'll generally leave that turned on,
and I can go ahead and

179
00:08:53.490 --> 00:08:55.730
print visible guides, and baseline grids.

180
00:08:55.730 --> 00:08:57.660
This is if we've set up
guides in the background, or

181
00:08:57.660 --> 00:08:59.610
we just want to see where that's set up.

182
00:08:59.610 --> 00:09:03.350
I rarely use that, but you might,
if you're setting up say a new newsletter.

183
00:09:03.350 --> 00:09:06.990
And you want to make sure that they
guides are set up, and the whole kind of

184
00:09:06.990 --> 00:09:10.910
overlay and the kind of structure
to your document looks good to you.

185
00:09:10.910 --> 00:09:14.780
So by printing it, I can actually see
what the underlying structure is.

186
00:09:14.780 --> 00:09:17.890
Again, this would not be for the final
output, but something that you work on.

187
00:09:19.400 --> 00:09:23.170
I can also go back into the next pane,
which is setup.

188
00:09:23.170 --> 00:09:25.360
And setup,
this is where we choose what size paper.

189
00:09:25.360 --> 00:09:29.940
Now again, you only have options based
on the printer that you chose up above.

190
00:09:29.940 --> 00:09:34.377
So down here I cannot choose 1117 because
this printer does not allow for it.

191
00:09:34.377 --> 00:09:35.287
So I'm gonna go ahead and say, nope.

192
00:09:35.287 --> 00:09:36.950
I want it to be only 8.5 by 11.

193
00:09:36.950 --> 00:09:40.510
We still have some issues down here where
it's not lined up on that paper yet, but

194
00:09:40.510 --> 00:09:42.170
we'll keep an eye on that.

195
00:09:42.170 --> 00:09:45.400
I can choose to scale it,
the width and the height.

196
00:09:45.400 --> 00:09:46.980
I can constrain the proportions.

197
00:09:46.980 --> 00:09:50.900
So I could make that fit with whatever's
causing that to be pushed off the page.

198
00:09:50.900 --> 00:09:55.230
Maybe we print it at 80%, or
maybe I just tell it scale to fit.

199
00:09:55.230 --> 00:09:57.660
And when I do that,
I can now see that there's enough.

200
00:09:57.660 --> 00:09:58.700
Well, I have a bleed.

201
00:09:58.700 --> 00:10:01.710
I can tell by that little red
mark that's around there.

202
00:10:01.710 --> 00:10:04.020
We set this document up with a bleed, and

203
00:10:04.020 --> 00:10:07.720
a bleed remember is where
the image comes off the page.

204
00:10:07.720 --> 00:10:11.887
You print it on a larger sheet of paper,
and you come back and trim it.

205
00:10:11.887 --> 00:10:14.893
So in this case,
with the bleed it's 8.5 X 11.

206
00:10:14.893 --> 00:10:17.770
Plus I have an eighth of an inch
bleed all the way around.

207
00:10:17.770 --> 00:10:23.510
So that's going to be 8.75 X 11.25
I think, if I did my math properly.

208
00:10:23.510 --> 00:10:26.030
So I have that, and so
I need that amount of space.

209
00:10:26.030 --> 00:10:27.360
Plus I need a little extra room,

210
00:10:27.360 --> 00:10:30.720
because remember whatever you're printing
through has to grab that paper as well.

211
00:10:30.720 --> 00:10:34.040
So I probably print that
on a 9 X 12 sheet of paper.

212
00:10:34.040 --> 00:10:36.060
I can't do that on this printer.

213
00:10:36.060 --> 00:10:37.565
It only does 8.5 X 11.

214
00:10:37.565 --> 00:10:41.330
So I either have to scale it down to fit,
and since we're just doing a proof.

215
00:10:41.330 --> 00:10:44.081
That seems like a perfect
solution to that problem.

216
00:10:44.081 --> 00:10:48.473
I can also tell where it sits on the page
if I don't have it scaled to fit.

217
00:10:48.473 --> 00:10:51.166
I can come in here and
just choose where it sits, move it around.

218
00:10:51.166 --> 00:10:53.192
Generally, I leave it at centered.

219
00:10:53.192 --> 00:10:54.947
I can also do thumbnails.

220
00:10:54.947 --> 00:10:58.930
So maybe I'm doing a book that is 8.5
X 11, and I wanna print out a proof.

221
00:10:58.930 --> 00:11:02.560
And I've got a lot of pages,
but I don't wanna waste paper.

222
00:11:02.560 --> 00:11:04.700
So I wanna go ahead and
put thumbnails on there.

223
00:11:04.700 --> 00:11:06.440
I can do this basically two up.

224
00:11:06.440 --> 00:11:09.690
I would not use this for printing,
because it's not really accurate.

225
00:11:09.690 --> 00:11:13.023
Where it throws those two thumbnails,
or those four thumbnails, or

226
00:11:13.023 --> 00:11:14.757
whatever we end up with on the page.

227
00:11:14.757 --> 00:11:18.720
It's just a great way to get the pages
kinda squashed down onto the page.

228
00:11:18.720 --> 00:11:19.631
So we can look at that.

229
00:11:19.631 --> 00:11:23.083
Plus, it puts a little line
around where the page edge is.

230
00:11:23.083 --> 00:11:25.170
So that wouldn't help us in printing.

231
00:11:25.170 --> 00:11:27.830
It's again, more for proofing the thing.

232
00:11:27.830 --> 00:11:29.670
Also, if you do have
something that's really huge.

233
00:11:29.670 --> 00:11:30.720
Let's come back up here.

234
00:11:30.720 --> 00:11:32.650
I'm gonna go back to General really quick.

235
00:11:32.650 --> 00:11:36.566
Choose spreads, and
then go back to set up and say tile.

236
00:11:36.566 --> 00:11:38.460
Well I can tile it if
I want it in spreads.

237
00:11:38.460 --> 00:11:42.230
I can also tile it so that prints out
what it can on the sheet of paper and

238
00:11:42.230 --> 00:11:44.650
continues it on the next sheet of paper.

239
00:11:44.650 --> 00:11:46.988
And it basically gives you
an amount of overlap, and

240
00:11:46.988 --> 00:11:49.127
that's what this overlap
amount is down here.

241
00:11:49.127 --> 00:11:53.253
So basically, it's if you have something
really big you want to print at 100%, but

242
00:11:53.253 --> 00:11:55.504
your printer can't print
on a page that large.

243
00:11:55.504 --> 00:11:58.834
You can tile it, and then youd have
to do the old fashion paste it up,

244
00:11:58.834 --> 00:12:01.833
a little tape, a little glue or
whatever, put that together.

245
00:12:01.833 --> 00:12:04.417
But it gives you an overlap, and
it gives you a little crop marks as well.

246
00:12:04.417 --> 00:12:06.497
So you can line it up easily.

247
00:12:06.497 --> 00:12:08.084
Again, this is stuff for proofing.

248
00:12:08.084 --> 00:12:10.316
This is not gonna be for the final sheet.

249
00:12:10.316 --> 00:12:12.676
Let me go back into General and
just put pages back on.

250
00:12:12.676 --> 00:12:14.480
So it looks a little bit
more like were expecting.

251
00:12:15.810 --> 00:12:17.285
Marks and bleeds.

252
00:12:17.285 --> 00:12:21.214
Marks and bleeds are something that youll
use in if you are sending this out for

253
00:12:21.214 --> 00:12:23.180
print, or even if you're doing it.

254
00:12:23.180 --> 00:12:27.205
Let's say you're doing it yourself, and
you're making postcards on your inkjet

255
00:12:27.205 --> 00:12:29.660
printer, or it's just something
that you're doing either in-house,

256
00:12:29.660 --> 00:12:32.940
or you're a design student and
you're just getting started.

257
00:12:32.940 --> 00:12:35.090
And you are going to do this
whole job start to finish.

258
00:12:35.090 --> 00:12:36.740
You're not gonna send it out to a printer.

259
00:12:36.740 --> 00:12:39.680
It's something decent, you got
a decent printer you can do and you're

260
00:12:39.680 --> 00:12:42.636
gonna do post cards and maybe you're
going to do two of them up on a page.

261
00:12:42.636 --> 00:12:43.980
They're 4 X 6 postcards.

262
00:12:43.980 --> 00:12:46.970
You're gonna put them on
an 8.5 X 11 sheet of paper.

263
00:12:46.970 --> 00:12:49.550
You've used your libraries
with the crops and the guides,

264
00:12:49.550 --> 00:12:50.570
and you've laid it out beautifully.

265
00:12:50.570 --> 00:12:53.780
And you're gonna print it out on some
nice card stock on your inkjet or

266
00:12:53.780 --> 00:12:54.350
laser printer.

267
00:12:54.350 --> 00:12:55.652
Your jet printer.

268
00:12:55.652 --> 00:13:00.642
You're gonna want some guides,
where to trim that particular item.

269
00:13:00.642 --> 00:13:05.100
So I've seen people that will print it
out with a key line around each one.

270
00:13:05.100 --> 00:13:06.089
Print one out that way.

271
00:13:06.089 --> 00:13:07.910
Then print the rest out without,
and lay it on top.

272
00:13:07.910 --> 00:13:12.060
But things move,
I like to have crop marks on the page.

273
00:13:12.060 --> 00:13:15.130
And maybe that's just cuz I'm old school,
I started in printing and I like that.

274
00:13:15.130 --> 00:13:17.090
But the marks and bleeds are important.

275
00:13:17.090 --> 00:13:20.470
The ones that I use only pretty much,
Crop Box.

276
00:13:20.470 --> 00:13:23.033
There's a lot of other stuff,
registration marks, color bars.

277
00:13:23.033 --> 00:13:25.641
These are things that are geared
towards the print industry,

278
00:13:25.641 --> 00:13:27.959
that we've been using forever
in the print industry.

279
00:13:27.959 --> 00:13:30.538
But, even when I was
working a lot in print.

280
00:13:30.538 --> 00:13:32.963
I don't do as much anymore
in the print industry,

281
00:13:32.963 --> 00:13:35.174
because I've gone to
a lot of digital stuff.

282
00:13:35.174 --> 00:13:37.699
But even when I'm doing that,
I would never put color bars for

283
00:13:37.699 --> 00:13:38.920
registration marks.

284
00:13:38.920 --> 00:13:42.750
That's something the person who
runs the press really wants to do.

285
00:13:42.750 --> 00:13:45.260
They each have their own individual
thing that they need to do.

286
00:13:45.260 --> 00:13:48.980
And that's just stuff that goes off on
the side, that will get trimmed off later.

287
00:13:48.980 --> 00:13:51.367
Color bars just to make sure
all the colors are the same and

288
00:13:51.367 --> 00:13:52.326
accurate and mixing.

289
00:13:52.326 --> 00:13:56.171
A good example of color bars is, if you
ever looked at packaging on cereal or

290
00:13:56.171 --> 00:13:59.725
anything like that, any of
the cardboard packaging under the flap.

291
00:13:59.725 --> 00:14:00.587
It'll have those squares.

292
00:14:00.587 --> 00:14:03.420
You'll see cyan, magenta,
yellow, and black squares.

293
00:14:03.420 --> 00:14:05.380
And they're all lined up and
there's little targets,

294
00:14:05.380 --> 00:14:06.598
little circles with x's in them.

295
00:14:06.598 --> 00:14:09.234
Those are targets and that's where
the printer, as it came through.

296
00:14:09.234 --> 00:14:12.268
They made sure that they lined up and
they didn't get offset at all.

297
00:14:12.268 --> 00:14:13.901
Where you've got the yellow and

298
00:14:13.901 --> 00:14:16.510
the magenta not sitting
right on top of each other.

299
00:14:16.510 --> 00:14:17.070
That's what those are.

300
00:14:17.070 --> 00:14:18.540
Those are color bars.

301
00:14:18.540 --> 00:14:20.350
I don't use those very often.

302
00:14:20.350 --> 00:14:22.278
Crop marks, super important though.

303
00:14:22.278 --> 00:14:25.365
I even do crop marks a lot of
times when I'm exporting to pdf.

304
00:14:25.365 --> 00:14:29.465
And one thing you do need to keep in mind,
whether you're printing or

305
00:14:29.465 --> 00:14:33.790
exporting the pdf, is the weight and
the offset of the crop marks.

306
00:14:33.790 --> 00:14:35.530
So here's a weird little thing.

307
00:14:35.530 --> 00:14:37.850
So I've told it that I wanna bleed, right?

308
00:14:37.850 --> 00:14:41.270
So it says Use Document Bleed Settings
down here, right?

309
00:14:41.270 --> 00:14:44.830
So it says, Use Document Bleed Settings
which automatically gives me that

310
00:14:44.830 --> 00:14:47.340
eighth of an inch that we created
when we created this document.

311
00:14:47.340 --> 00:14:50.290
We said give it a bleed
amount of eighth of an inch.

312
00:14:50.290 --> 00:14:54.990
So by default, in some versions,
this is turned off.

313
00:14:54.990 --> 00:14:57.090
And it says, we created with a bleed.

314
00:14:57.090 --> 00:14:59.990
We made sure images came out to a bleed.

315
00:14:59.990 --> 00:15:03.700
And then we didn't select use document
bleed settings when we exported or

316
00:15:03.700 --> 00:15:04.980
when we printed.

317
00:15:04.980 --> 00:15:06.540
And so there's no bleed amount.

318
00:15:06.540 --> 00:15:09.090
So it's just gonna trim it
right at the edge of the page.

319
00:15:09.090 --> 00:15:10.920
We need that bleed setting to go past.

320
00:15:10.920 --> 00:15:14.370
We need the entire image to bleed
the amount that we told it to bleed.

321
00:15:14.370 --> 00:15:18.070
So we need to make sure that is
checked if we used to bleed.

322
00:15:18.070 --> 00:15:20.160
But, what happens is with a crop mark.

323
00:15:20.160 --> 00:15:22.421
You notice we have
an eighth of an inch bleed.

324
00:15:22.421 --> 00:15:26.066
Well back up here we have the weight,
how thick the stroke is.

325
00:15:26.066 --> 00:15:28.577
A quarter point is plenty.

326
00:15:28.577 --> 00:15:33.175
But the offset I don't know 0.0833
works out into in fraction, but

327
00:15:33.175 --> 00:15:36.304
I can tell you it's less
than an eighth of an inch.

328
00:15:36.304 --> 00:15:38.300
So what happened is we have this bleed.

329
00:15:38.300 --> 00:15:40.936
We have a sheet of paper,
and we have a bleed.

330
00:15:40.936 --> 00:15:45.427
And we've said make sure the image goes
an eighth of an inch past where it's

331
00:15:45.427 --> 00:15:46.230
gonna trim.

332
00:15:46.230 --> 00:15:48.740
And we made sure the images

to give you the output and

557
00:26:27.750 --> 00:26:30.800
the results that you're expecting
from the piece that you've created.

558
00:26:30.800 --> 00:26:31.380
>> All right Erica,

559
00:26:31.380 --> 00:26:34.610
it looks like we're getting one step
closer to a final project here.

560
00:26:34.610 --> 00:26:37.310
Now, it does look like we're coming to the
end of another episode, but before we do,

561
00:26:37.310 --> 00:26:39.730
do you have any additional
words about printing?

562
00:26:39.730 --> 00:26:42.050
>> Just know where it's going and
know what the options are for

563
00:26:42.050 --> 00:26:43.460
the device you're printing to.

564
00:26:43.460 --> 00:26:44.300
>> All right, good advice.

565
00:26:44.300 --> 00:26:46.950
Thank you for being here in the studios
and thank you to the viewer for watching.

566
00:26:46.950 --> 00:26:49.430
Signing out for ITProTV,
I've been your host Wes Bryan.

567
00:26:49.430 --> 00:26:50.460
>> And I'm Erica Gammet.

568
00:26:50.460 --> 00:26:52.599
>> And we'll see you next time.

569
00:26:52.599 --> 00:26:58.616
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Erica explore Live Preflight and packaging within Adobe InDesign. They explain various digital output considerations, the Live Preflight, basic preflight summary and creating a package folder.
episodes.title: Preflight and Packaging
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.002 --> 00:00:10.002
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:11.614 --> 00:00:14.286
Welcome back to another exciting
episode here at ITProTV.

3
00:00:14.286 --> 00:00:14.786
I'm your host Wes Bryan.

4
00:00:16.020 --> 00:00:16.900
And in today's episode,

5
00:00:16.900 --> 00:00:19.880
we're coming back at you with
more Adobe Creative Cloud 2015.

6
00:00:19.880 --> 00:00:22.890
That's right, focusing in on InDesign.

7
00:00:22.890 --> 00:00:25.060
And joining me back in
the studios today is Erica Gamet.

8
00:00:25.060 --> 00:00:25.950
Erica, how you doing?

9
00:00:25.950 --> 00:00:26.650
>> I'm doing great.

10
00:00:26.650 --> 00:00:27.650
>> Great.
Thank you for

11
00:00:27.650 --> 00:00:31.400
taking us along this journey that
is InDesign, where we going next?

12
00:00:31.400 --> 00:00:34.140
>> We are going to start doing
some pre flighting and packaging.

13
00:00:34.140 --> 00:00:34.680
>> All right.

14
00:00:34.680 --> 00:00:37.650
>> All right.
So pre flighting is just the thing

15
00:00:37.650 --> 00:00:40.690
that we have to do before
we send it somewhere else,

16
00:00:40.690 --> 00:00:44.050
whether it's going digital or
print, we need to pre flight it.

17
00:00:44.050 --> 00:00:47.000
And InDesign actually has something called
Live Pre Flighting which means it can do

18
00:00:47.000 --> 00:00:48.560
it as we're working.

19
00:00:48.560 --> 00:00:50.020
So it's always doing it in the background.

20
00:00:50.020 --> 00:00:53.600
Sometimes I shut it off because it does
take a little bit extra process or time.

21
00:00:53.600 --> 00:00:56.170
But it's something that's
always constantly checking for

22
00:00:56.170 --> 00:01:00.080
us to make sure that the stuff we're
putting in here will give us that

23
00:01:00.080 --> 00:01:01.670
end piece that we're looking for.

24
00:01:01.670 --> 00:01:03.960
And it's a theme that I've been
hitting in all the episodes.

25
00:01:03.960 --> 00:01:07.700
Make sure you know what's happening to
your files from the very beginning.

26
00:01:07.700 --> 00:01:12.580
Well, if you don't tell InDesign in your
Preflight what it's suppose to be doing.

27
00:01:12.580 --> 00:01:13.810
Where it's suppose to end up.

28
00:01:13.810 --> 00:01:16.140
There's no way it can check it and
make sure that it's doing it right.

29
00:01:16.140 --> 00:01:19.200
It will use whatever's built in and
it might say this is a problem.

30
00:01:19.200 --> 00:01:22.270
But it's not really a problem because you
haven't told it where your actually going

31
00:01:22.270 --> 00:01:24.990
to end up with this particular piece.

32
00:01:24.990 --> 00:01:27.500
So that's what Preflighting is.

33
00:01:27.500 --> 00:01:29.850
We're going to first look at
the live Preflighting for that.

34
00:01:29.850 --> 00:01:32.940
And then we are going go into packaging,

35
00:01:32.940 --> 00:01:36.950
which is basically when we need to
send this file to somebody else.

36
00:01:36.950 --> 00:01:39.460
We're actually sending
the InDesign file to someone else.

37
00:01:39.460 --> 00:01:43.230
So we'll look into the reasons why we
may or may not want to do that as well.

38
00:01:43.230 --> 00:01:46.040
So let's start with the Preflighting to
make sure that the file that we have,

39
00:01:46.040 --> 00:01:49.240
no matter what we're doing with it,
printing, or exporting, or

40
00:01:49.240 --> 00:01:53.660
sending it to somebody else, is set with
the parameters that we needed to VM.

41
00:01:53.660 --> 00:01:55.700
So we're gonna open up live Preflighting.

42
00:01:55.700 --> 00:01:57.360
And it's way down here at the bottom.

43
00:01:57.360 --> 00:02:02.020
Let's scroll down here, make sure we
don't hit my Mac doc that's down here.

44
00:02:02.020 --> 00:02:04.640
But I have a couple different options down
here, I'm actually gonna pull this up but

45
00:02:04.640 --> 00:02:06.060
this is how we get to it.

46
00:02:06.060 --> 00:02:09.650
We need to come down here and choose one
of these little arrows that are here.

47
00:02:09.650 --> 00:02:11.960
And actually,
I'm gonna do this one over here.

48
00:02:11.960 --> 00:02:15.530
Gotta be very good with the zoom on,
and I wanna choose the Preflight Panel.

49
00:02:15.530 --> 00:02:18.200
That's all I'm trying to do is
get that to pop up so it's there.

50
00:02:18.200 --> 00:02:21.140
I just wanted to show you where it
normally lives, and one of the things down

51
00:02:21.140 --> 00:02:24.800
at the bottom, you notice there's a big
green button, and it says no errors.

52
00:02:24.800 --> 00:02:25.880
Well, it says no errors, but

53
00:02:25.880 --> 00:02:27.700
I haven't even told it what it's
supposed to be looking for.

54
00:02:27.700 --> 00:02:29.460
So of course I have no errors.

55
00:02:29.460 --> 00:02:33.010
But for me, I tend to have a lot of errors
there all the time, and that's okay.

56
00:02:33.010 --> 00:02:37.000
Because as we're putting things together,
they might not be the exact piece we need.

57
00:02:37.000 --> 00:02:40.315
Or again, we might have
a wrong parameter set in here.

58
00:02:40.315 --> 00:02:42.010
Anyway it might be telling
you it's an error, and

59
00:02:42.010 --> 00:02:44.240
it's not actually an error at all.

60
00:02:44.240 --> 00:02:46.470
So let's look what Preflighting does for
us.

61
00:02:46.470 --> 00:02:47.770
So I can turn it on.

62
00:02:47.770 --> 00:02:48.650
It's on by default.

63
00:02:48.650 --> 00:02:52.200
You can turn that off though if it does
seem to be slowing down you processor

64
00:02:52.200 --> 00:02:53.190
speed at all.

65
00:02:53.190 --> 00:02:54.510
But on by default, and

66
00:02:54.510 --> 00:02:57.230
it's going to keep checking
everything you're putting in there.

67
00:02:57.230 --> 00:03:00.620
And it's going to do that by
the profile that you tell it to use.

68
00:03:00.620 --> 00:03:03.050
And basic working is
the one that's built in,

69
00:03:03.050 --> 00:03:05.630
so it's whatever perimeters Adobe has set.

70
00:03:05.630 --> 00:03:08.770
So you're probably going to wanna
change those depending on what it is

71
00:03:08.770 --> 00:03:11.080
your document is that you're working on.

72
00:03:11.080 --> 00:03:14.400
So I have a couple that are here by
default, or that I've created and

73
00:03:14.400 --> 00:03:16.322
put in here in addition
to the default one.

74
00:03:16.322 --> 00:03:18.870
I'm on that's called high
resolution print, one that's called

75
00:03:18.870 --> 00:03:23.150
digital publishing, one that I didn't give
a very good name, new Preflight profile.

76
00:03:23.150 --> 00:03:26.320
So we're gonna go ahead and
say high-res print, and

77
00:03:26.320 --> 00:03:28.500
I'm just going to turn on to see
if we get any other results.

78
00:03:28.500 --> 00:03:32.150
Lets assume that this thing that we
have setup, this cover that we have

79
00:03:32.150 --> 00:03:37.150
is going to be printed on an offset press
and we need it to be high resolution.

80
00:03:37.150 --> 00:03:40.250
So when we look at what makes up that
high resolution profile in a minute.

81
00:03:40.250 --> 00:03:42.380
But right now let's just
turn it on see what happens.

82
00:03:42.380 --> 00:03:45.200
It's checking and it says,
there's an error.

83
00:03:45.200 --> 00:03:47.030
So, this is what the live Preflight does.

84
00:03:47.030 --> 00:03:50.300
As I put things in and
I make changes and I put it in there and

85
00:03:50.300 --> 00:03:54.330
it falls outside the parameters that
I've set, it tells me I have a problem.

86
00:03:54.330 --> 00:03:56.300
So let's look at what that problem is and

87
00:03:56.300 --> 00:03:59.160
then we'll look at why it
might not be a problem at all.

88
00:03:59.160 --> 00:04:00.980
So when it tells you you have an issue,

89
00:04:00.980 --> 00:04:04.710
all your errors will be listed
here in the center field.

90
00:04:04.710 --> 00:04:08.580
If I click on the disclosure triangle, it
tells me that there is a style override.

91
00:04:08.580 --> 00:04:12.240
When we looked at styles,
we said we don't want any overrides.

92
00:04:12.240 --> 00:04:16.150
Well I set into this profile,
to make sure it looked for that.

93
00:04:16.150 --> 00:04:17.480
You can tell it to ignore that,

94
00:04:17.480 --> 00:04:20.020
I wanted to make sure I didn't
have any style overrides.

95
00:04:20.020 --> 00:04:23.990
I can drill down one more time, and
see what that style override is and

96
00:04:23.990 --> 00:04:25.130
where it lives.

97
00:04:25.130 --> 00:04:27.810
So right now, I can click and
see that it says safari.

98
00:04:27.810 --> 00:04:29.510
I have six characters for whatever reason.

99
00:04:29.510 --> 00:04:31.410
That text has an override.

100
00:04:31.410 --> 00:04:33.970
But it has this blue one,
and that's a hyperlink.

101
00:04:33.970 --> 00:04:36.650
And that means when I click on it,
it will actually jump to and

102
00:04:36.650 --> 00:04:40.710
select the object that is outside
of the parameters I've set.

103
00:04:40.710 --> 00:04:43.190
So now it's up to me to fix it.

104
00:04:43.190 --> 00:04:48.770
Now we might have a fix for it,
down in this info box at the bottom.

105
00:04:48.770 --> 00:04:52.590
It tells me that text has local formatting
that conflicts with the style definition.

106
00:04:52.590 --> 00:04:56.680
It does tell me which paragraph
style is the issue and

107
00:04:56.680 --> 00:04:59.720
it just says click the clear overrides
button in the paragraph styles panel

108
00:04:59.720 --> 00:05:02.460
that might not be the actual
solution I wanna do.

109
00:05:02.460 --> 00:05:04.730
So again, it's up to me to say,
okay what's wrong with that?

110
00:05:04.730 --> 00:05:05.670
Well, let's go look.

111
00:05:05.670 --> 00:05:08.980
And the we go to the paragraph
styles panel and

112
00:05:08.980 --> 00:05:15.070
it tells me that there is a override to
that quotes, a paradox style that's there.

113
00:05:15.070 --> 00:05:17.440
That probably wasn't even
the one I wanted quotes.

114
00:05:17.440 --> 00:05:19.990
It probably was something
that I copied and pasted and

115
00:05:19.990 --> 00:05:21.300
that style came along with it.

116
00:05:21.300 --> 00:05:22.150
So I have options.

117
00:05:22.150 --> 00:05:26.370
I can either do what it said, which was
to option or I'll click on the quotes.

118
00:05:26.370 --> 00:05:27.900
When I do that, it went away.

119
00:05:27.900 --> 00:05:31.080
And that's because the quotes
is really teeny-tiny text.

120
00:05:31.080 --> 00:05:31.730
I'm gonna undo that.

121
00:05:31.730 --> 00:05:34.930
What I probably want to do, I notice I
have no other styles in this document,

122
00:05:34.930 --> 00:05:38.840
just the quotes, I probably need to
create a whole new style from there.

123
00:05:38.840 --> 00:05:41.330
So, if you've seen the styles episode,

124
00:05:41.330 --> 00:05:44.410
you'll see that you can create one
based on text that I have selected.

125
00:05:44.410 --> 00:05:45.830
That's what I would do at this point.

126
00:05:45.830 --> 00:05:47.930
So I'm gonna fix it in
whatever way I need to.

127
00:05:47.930 --> 00:05:52.800
Some of the things we might run into are
images that are way too low resolution.

128
00:05:52.800 --> 00:05:53.610
So lets actually do that.

129
00:05:53.610 --> 00:05:55.520
I'm gonna throw another one into it,

130
00:05:55.520 --> 00:05:58.960
because I know this is a high
resolution print profile that I setup.

131
00:05:58.960 --> 00:06:01.570
So one of the things I've
probably told it to look for

132
00:06:01.570 --> 00:06:03.390
is high resolution images, right?

133
00:06:03.390 --> 00:06:05.460
So let's actually take one of
these images that we have,

134
00:06:05.460 --> 00:06:07.490
and I'm gonna go into the links panel.

135
00:06:07.490 --> 00:06:09.770
And you can see if you've gone
through the other episodes,

136
00:06:09.770 --> 00:06:12.760
you can see that everything here,
we're taking all the knowledge that we've

137
00:06:12.760 --> 00:06:15.210
learned along the way, and
figuring out how to fix it.

138
00:06:15.210 --> 00:06:19.060
And hopefully we don't wait till we're at
the point where we're ready to export or

139
00:06:19.060 --> 00:06:22.560
package it, or we're on deadline
before we start seeing these images.

140
00:06:22.560 --> 00:06:27.010
So, even if we didn't place an image in
before we go to the links panel to check

141
00:06:27.010 --> 00:06:31.950
it, if live Preflight is running,
we can always keep an eye on it that way.

142
00:06:31.950 --> 00:06:34.200
I don't necessarily keep
it running all day long.

143
00:06:34.200 --> 00:06:37.950
I might, if I'm working on a big job,
I might run it once or twice a day.

144
00:06:37.950 --> 00:06:39.030
Just turn it on.

145
00:06:39.030 --> 00:06:43.150
So that it isn't right as I'm ready to go
to export it and the client is waiting for

146
00:06:43.150 --> 00:06:44.430
it that I find my issue.

147
00:06:44.430 --> 00:06:46.550
I can find it at least
by the end of the day.

148
00:06:46.550 --> 00:06:47.930
Even if it's not a constant thing,

149
00:06:47.930 --> 00:06:50.420
I'm not always looking down
there to see what errors I have.

150
00:06:50.420 --> 00:06:51.300
But at the end of the day or

151
00:06:51.300 --> 00:06:54.980
twice a day like I said, I might look at
it and make sure what where my issues.

152
00:06:54.980 --> 00:06:57.040
So in this case,
let's take this item here and

153
00:06:57.040 --> 00:07:02.190
it says that it is actually
261 effective resolution.

154
00:07:02.190 --> 00:07:04.470
Well 261 is kind of low so,

155
00:07:04.470 --> 00:07:07.160
I must have given myself a little
bit of leeway in this profile.

156
00:07:07.160 --> 00:07:08.550
Maybe I said it had to be at least 250.

157
00:07:08.550 --> 00:07:11.120
And we'll look at that
like I say in a second.

158
00:07:11.120 --> 00:07:15.320
But let's make that, I'm gonna
increase the size of this photo so

159
00:07:15.320 --> 00:07:19.040
that as I do that my effective
resolution goes down.

160
00:07:19.040 --> 00:07:20.440
Goes down to 140.

161
00:07:20.440 --> 00:07:21.320
When I did that,

162
00:07:21.320 --> 00:07:24.490
now I go back over the Preflight and
I can see I've got another error.

163
00:07:24.490 --> 00:07:26.000
And that is this image.

164
00:07:26.000 --> 00:07:28.530
So, scroll down or drill down to that.

165
00:07:28.530 --> 00:07:30.320
It says there's a problem
with image resolution.

166
00:07:30.320 --> 00:07:35.940
I drill down again and it says the
Elephants.jpg file on page 1 is a problem.

167
00:07:35.940 --> 00:07:38.870
So again when I click on it, it's gonna
tell you what you can do with that.

168
00:07:38.870 --> 00:07:41.720
Well, usually what you can do
with it is change the size and

169
00:07:41.720 --> 00:07:44.480
if you can't do that, you might have
to put a whole new photo in there.

170
00:07:44.480 --> 00:07:47.937
Or go back to Photoshop and see if you
can crop it a little differently or

171
00:07:47.937 --> 00:07:51.056
whatever it is you need to do, but
you need to fix that some way.

172
00:07:51.056 --> 00:07:53.470
It does tell me it's only 140 ppi and

173
00:07:53.470 --> 00:07:56.555
that is outside of
the parameters that I've set.

174
00:07:56.555 --> 00:07:59.595
So let's actually look at
the parameters that we have set for

175
00:07:59.595 --> 00:08:01.095
this high resolution print.

176
00:08:01.095 --> 00:08:04.498
To do that we're gonna go
over to the Panel menu, so

177
00:08:04.498 --> 00:08:09.380
the preflight Panel menu and
come down to Define Profiles.

178
00:08:09.380 --> 00:08:12.430
So we do that we have the different
profiles set up that we have here.

179
00:08:12.430 --> 00:08:13.807
So these are ones we have set up,

180
00:08:13.807 --> 00:08:16.006
we can also create a new one
down here at the bottom.

181
00:08:16.006 --> 00:08:19.150
Just do + and we'll add in a whole
new profile for ourselves here.

182
00:08:20.170 --> 00:08:23.570
So I'm going to look at this high
resolution print and see what we have.

183
00:08:23.570 --> 00:08:28.040
Now some of the items have little lines
through them, little dashes in them.

184
00:08:28.040 --> 00:08:30.600
That means that there're some
things that it's looking for

185
00:08:30.600 --> 00:08:33.420
inside this particular category.

186
00:08:33.420 --> 00:08:36.113
I generally just scroll down
everything and just look and

187
00:08:36.113 --> 00:08:39.600
say okay in links there are a few
things that is looking for.

188
00:08:39.600 --> 00:08:43.050
I want it to flag if there is a missing or
modified link.

189
00:08:43.050 --> 00:08:45.780
So again, this is something we
can see in the links panel.

190
00:08:45.780 --> 00:08:48.690
But if we don't look it
over as we're working and

191
00:08:48.690 --> 00:08:51.980
we realize oops there was one
that was missing or modified.

192
00:08:51.980 --> 00:08:54.710
And actually they added something
a couple of versions back.

193
00:08:54.710 --> 00:08:59.070
So that on the frame itself,
there's a little question mark or a little

194
00:08:59.070 --> 00:09:02.250
exclamation point that actually appears
on the frame if it's missing or modified.

195
00:09:02.250 --> 00:09:04.480
We don't even need to go
in the links panel anymore.

196
00:09:04.480 --> 00:09:08.610
But here it tells us, links missing or
modified, please let me know.

197
00:09:08.610 --> 00:09:13.190
If there are inaccessible URL links, so
you can have hyperlinks in your document.

198
00:09:13.190 --> 00:09:15.610
If you're going to export it to PDF for

199
00:09:15.610 --> 00:09:18.550
instance you can have a document
that has navigation in it.

200
00:09:18.550 --> 00:09:21.440
You click on an arrow and it jumps
to the next page and the next page.

201
00:09:21.440 --> 00:09:24.540
Or it clicks on a URL and
it goes out to that website.

202
00:09:24.540 --> 00:09:28.760
Well it constantly checks that to make
sure that that URL is also working.

203
00:09:28.760 --> 00:09:29.790
So if it's not,

204
00:09:29.790 --> 00:09:33.470
if it hits one of those instead of having
to see it in the hyperlinks panel.

205
00:09:33.470 --> 00:09:37.260
This is basically keeping you from having
to open all the individual panels and

206
00:09:37.260 --> 00:09:38.280
keep an eye on all of those.

207
00:09:38.280 --> 00:09:40.100
So this tells you as you go along,

208
00:09:40.100 --> 00:09:42.980
you've done something that
is outside the parameters.

209
00:09:42.980 --> 00:09:45.000
So again,
if that's not something you need,

210
00:09:45.000 --> 00:09:48.310
if I'm going to high resolution print,
I probably don't care about URLs.

211
00:09:48.310 --> 00:09:50.440
