00:21:22.430 --> 00:21:25.730
Now I've got them all over and
I need to just sort of organize myself and

431
00:21:25.730 --> 00:21:30.220
know that I have it in a nice folder
called ABC Client, whatever, or

432
00:21:30.220 --> 00:21:33.060
we'll do Wild Travel Cover, right?

433
00:21:33.060 --> 00:21:36.420
So we got the photography cover here and
we want to put that in a folder and

434
00:21:36.420 --> 00:21:39.510
I want to know that I have all the images
and everything that I need for that.

435
00:21:39.510 --> 00:21:41.010
I need to package that.

436
00:21:41.010 --> 00:21:42.310
So I'll do that, I'll package it up and

437
00:21:42.310 --> 00:21:45.140
then I have that nice folder
where everything lives together.

438
00:21:45.140 --> 00:21:47.600
So I'm actually gonna show you,
actually let's jump out and show you,

439
00:21:47.600 --> 00:21:52.760
I have an actual folder that's in here,
for the wild one.

440
00:21:54.020 --> 00:21:58.250
So in this wild photo book that's here,
I have, oops,

441
00:21:58.250 --> 00:22:02.680
I guess I don't have the,
I will actually package it up,

442
00:22:02.680 --> 00:22:05.620
cuz I thought I had it actually
separated out from a package.

443
00:22:05.620 --> 00:22:08.090
I may have pulled the bits
of the package all apart but

444
00:22:08.090 --> 00:22:09.090
we're gonna create one anyway.

445
00:22:09.090 --> 00:22:12.430
So we'll do it from this one that we have,
we're gonna fix this elephant.

446
00:22:12.430 --> 00:22:13.920
Don't like that he's hanging out there,

447
00:22:13.920 --> 00:22:16.970
we're gonna put him back where he belongs,
looks pretty good.

448
00:22:16.970 --> 00:22:20.400
We'll shorten him up and
we say okay, we're ready with this,

449
00:22:20.400 --> 00:22:24.170
we're ready to send it off to a printer
who wants our InDesign files or

450
00:22:24.170 --> 00:22:26.950
to someone else on our team who needs
all the InDesign files as well.

451
00:22:26.950 --> 00:22:29.640
So let's package everything up,
under the FIle Menu,

452
00:22:29.640 --> 00:22:33.550
we'll come out to Package and
it's gonna ask you,

453
00:22:33.550 --> 00:22:37.920
it's gonna give you some warnings, it will
always tell you that you have RGB images.

454
00:22:37.920 --> 00:22:41.610
So it's just gonna tell you that, again
that's not an issue, don't worry about it.

455
00:22:41.610 --> 00:22:44.680
So I'm gonna look under fonts, I also
have chosen down here at the bottom,

456
00:22:44.680 --> 00:22:45.890
Show Problems Only.

457
00:22:45.890 --> 00:22:48.560
So if it's not a problem,
don't show it to me, I don't care.

458
00:22:48.560 --> 00:22:52.110
So obviously there's nothing here, I have
no problems with my fonts and I'm gonna

459
00:22:52.110 --> 00:22:56.190
talk a little bit about fonts in just
a second in this whole packaging of fonts.

460
00:22:56.190 --> 00:22:57.120
Right now, I'm gonna assume,

461
00:22:57.120 --> 00:23:00.380
I'm sending it, just moving it,
somewhere else on my desktop.

462
00:23:00.380 --> 00:23:02.070
So it says there's no problem with that.

463
00:23:02.070 --> 00:23:05.800
Links and images, I can come in here and
see what the names of each one are.

464
00:23:05.800 --> 00:23:08.040
The type of color space,
that's where it's flagging it and

465
00:23:08.040 --> 00:23:09.930
telling me these are RGB images.

466
00:23:09.930 --> 00:23:13.960
What pages they're on, they're linked,
which is good, they're not embedded, and

467
00:23:13.960 --> 00:23:17.260
I have no color profile assigned, and
we didn't talk about color profiles.

468
00:23:17.260 --> 00:23:19.820
But I can just go ahead and see,
and it only shows me the problems,

469
00:23:19.820 --> 00:23:24.050
like it says It's RGB, it thinks that's
a problem, I'm going to ignore that.

470
00:23:24.050 --> 00:23:26.340
Colors and inks,
not gonna worry about these at all.

471
00:23:26.340 --> 00:23:30.270
The print setting, this just shows
what the last print settings we used

472
00:23:30.270 --> 00:23:32.270
on this document, I never use that either.

473
00:23:32.270 --> 00:23:35.510
And external plugins, usually not
a problem at all, t his just shows plugins

474
00:23:35.510 --> 00:23:39.320
that I have that may or
may not have been used in this document.

475
00:23:39.320 --> 00:23:42.968
I call this the iffy box, because I never
know why it shows me that I have a recipe

476
00:23:42.968 --> 00:23:46.085
wizard plug-in, I certainly
didn't use that in this document.

477
00:23:46.085 --> 00:23:48.080
But what we need to
worry about is package.

478
00:23:48.080 --> 00:23:51.229
So we just make sure everything's good,
package needs to be saved.

479
00:23:51.229 --> 00:23:54.599
Great lets save it, it's gonna save it to
the desktop and it's gonna ask you for

480
00:23:54.599 --> 00:23:55.716
printing instructions.

481
00:23:55.716 --> 00:23:57.871
This is where you can put
in all your information,

482
00:23:57.871 --> 00:24:00.452
once you put it in there it's
there every time you package.

483
00:24:00.452 --> 00:24:04.053
And you can also put individual
instructions for this particular document.

484
00:24:04.053 --> 00:24:06.940
Theoretically, this is so
people at print shops will read this.

485
00:24:06.940 --> 00:24:10.040
I know from working in a lot of print
shops, a lot of people don't read them.

486
00:24:10.040 --> 00:24:13.760
But I like to have it so that I have
notes to myself, if nothing else.

487
00:24:13.760 --> 00:24:16.288
It keeps track of what fonts you used,
what images you used,

488
00:24:16.288 --> 00:24:19.758
what colors are used, things like that,
things that might be handy down the road,

489
00:24:19.758 --> 00:24:22.800
and it puts it in the folder that
we're creating, this package folder.

490
00:24:24.270 --> 00:24:25.840
So now we need to choose where this goes.

491
00:24:25.840 --> 00:24:27.560
I'm just gonna put this
out on the desktop.

492
00:24:27.560 --> 00:24:31.020
It takes the name of the document and
adds Folder to it.

493
00:24:31.020 --> 00:24:34.660
And we've got a couple different options
we need to worry about here, Copy Fonts,

494
00:24:34.660 --> 00:24:39.660
except for CJK, that's Cyrillic, Japanese
and Korean, and also Typekit fonts.

495
00:24:39.660 --> 00:24:43.180
So it won't take any of your Typekit
fonts that you used and package them up.

496
00:24:43.180 --> 00:24:45.970
But if we're sending it to someone
else who has Creative Cloud

497
00:24:45.970 --> 00:24:47.060
they have access to the Typekit and

498
00:24:47.060 --> 00:24:49.860
they're gonna sync it through their
own Creative Cloud subscription.

499
00:24:49.860 --> 00:24:52.120
So we don't need to worry about
putting it in the package.

500
00:24:52.120 --> 00:24:55.280
So let me talk a little bit about putting
fonts in the package while we're copying

501
00:24:55.280 --> 00:24:56.550
the fonts.

502
00:24:56.550 --> 00:24:59.430
Legally most font licenses
that you have do not

503
00:24:59.430 --> 00:25:01.700
allow you to actually
distribute the fonts.

504
00:25:01.700 --> 00:25:05.181
So that means, even if I'm sending
this to my printer at a print shop,

505
00:25:05.181 --> 00:25:06.370
I am packaging that up.

506
00:25:06.370 --> 00:25:09.120
If I send the fonts with them,
I am violating the terms,

507
00:25:09.120 --> 00:25:12.380
most likely, of my font licensing.

508
00:25:12.380 --> 00:25:16.100
That being said, every printer would
have to have every font known to man,

509
00:25:16.100 --> 00:25:18.400
and this is something people
have been doing for a long time.

510
00:25:18.400 --> 00:25:22.350
Generally speaking, most printers will
take those fonts, and they have systems in

511
00:25:22.350 --> 00:25:26.270
place so that they only turn on the font
that you gave them for your job,

512
00:25:26.270 --> 00:25:29.350
still probably outside the licensing
boundary, but that's kind of how it works.

513
00:25:29.350 --> 00:25:32.450
So I always joke about the font police,
but it really is no joke,

514
00:25:32.450 --> 00:25:33.615
it is a licensing.

515
00:25:33.615 --> 00:25:35.930
I'm gonna let you do with that
what you need to do with that, but

516
00:25:35.930 --> 00:25:38.820
just know that you can't be
distributing those, most likely.

517
00:25:38.820 --> 00:25:40.730
But it does let you put it in there.

518
00:25:40.730 --> 00:25:42.830
If I'm doing this for
my own use, which I said I was,

519
00:25:42.830 --> 00:25:46.270
I'm going to move this all to
the desktop and just reorganize it.

520
00:25:46.270 --> 00:25:49.580
I like that all the fonts
come with it as well.

521
00:25:49.580 --> 00:25:51.830
I can also copy the link to graphics.

522
00:25:51.830 --> 00:25:52.850
That's super important.

523
00:25:52.850 --> 00:25:54.600
That's one of the reasons
that we're packaging this up,

524
00:25:54.600 --> 00:25:57.310
is that I have all these linked
graphics I placed in there.

525
00:25:57.310 --> 00:26:00.950
I would like a copy of them put in a
folder that is right next to the InDesign

526
00:26:00.950 --> 00:26:03.490
file so that I know it's all together
in this neat little package.

527
00:26:03.490 --> 00:26:04.620
That's the whole point.

528
00:26:04.620 --> 00:26:08.260
If I'm sending this out to print
then I definitely need that copy of

529
00:26:08.260 --> 00:26:13.210
the link graphics, and also update
the graphic links in the package.

530
00:26:13.210 --> 00:26:17.310
If you don't do that, let's say I did it
and didn't select that update and I send

531
00:26:17.310 --> 00:26:21.210
it to a printer, he has the links and
that's great, but when he opens the Links

532
00:26:21.210 --> 00:26:25.710
panel it's gonna say that they're either
missing or modified, probably missing, and

533
00:26:25.710 --> 00:26:30.550
then he's gonna have to to go and relink
each of those graphics individually.

534
00:26:30.550 --> 00:26:32.220
So he's gonna have to do
a little bit extra work.

535
00:26:32.220 --> 00:26:35.640
If you say update it, it automatically
says, it's in this new folder,

536
00:26:35.640 --> 00:26:37.890
in this folder that we're sending.

537
00:26:37.890 --> 00:26:41.060
That's where the links go and
it re-does all the path names for that.

538
00:26:41.060 --> 00:26:42.110
So that's something we wanna do.

539
00:26:42.110 --> 00:26:44.000
And the last one is to include fonts and

540
00:26:44.000 --> 00:26:45.990
links from hidden and
non-printing content.

541
00:26:45.990 --> 00:26:48.420
It may be that you're sending a little
bit of extra information, but for

542
00:26:48.420 --> 00:26:50.760
me I might have a hidden layer.

543
00:26:50.760 --> 00:26:52.818
I forgot I hid it, I actually needed it.

544
00:26:52.818 --> 00:26:55.570
Especially like when the one where
we turned on the layers on and

545
00:26:55.570 --> 00:26:56.840
off in a previous episode.

546
00:26:56.840 --> 00:26:59.440
We had three different layers,
turned each one on and off.

547
00:26:59.440 --> 00:27:03.800
Well, I probably left the last one turned
on, but I need all those images from those

548
00:27:03.800 --> 00:27:06.640
hidden layers to also go with the package,
so I tend to leave that on.

549
00:27:07.700 --> 00:27:10.730
The last two options in
the packaging document, or

550
00:27:10.730 --> 00:27:14.870
dial up box, is include IDML, and
thats an InDesign Markup Language.

551
00:27:14.870 --> 00:27:19.160
So you might see an .idml file as
well,and basically what that is is

552
00:27:19.160 --> 00:27:21.070
a backwards compatibility feature.

553
00:27:21.070 --> 00:27:23.140
So if I have that and
I send it to them and

554
00:27:23.140 --> 00:27:28.210
they only have InDesign CC 2014
they can open that IDML file.

555
00:27:28.210 --> 00:27:32.080
So it's not just the InDesign file, but
this IDML file that can be opened in

556
00:27:32.080 --> 00:27:35.400
earlier versions, only a few
versions back, but they can do that.

557
00:27:35.400 --> 00:27:40.070
Now there might be special things I used
in InDesign that might cause some issues,

558
00:27:40.070 --> 00:27:41.080
so keep that in mind.

559
00:27:41.080 --> 00:27:44.290
But I have that there, and
also it's just a nice, kind of,

560
00:27:44.290 --> 00:27:46.300
backup of the same file in there.

561
00:27:46.300 --> 00:27:50.880
And I can also include a PDF print
including whatever preset I decide for

562
00:27:50.880 --> 00:27:51.870
my PDF to do there.

563
00:27:51.870 --> 00:27:52.983
So I might just have one.

564
00:27:52.983 --> 00:27:54.720
I have one usually that's for proofing.

565
00:27:54.720 --> 00:27:57.990
So I might say here's one for
proofs so that they have a nice PDF of

566
00:27:57.990 --> 00:28:00.710
what it should look like when
they open the InDesign file.

567
00:28:00.710 --> 00:28:03.040
Make sure that all the fonts loaded,
all the images are there, and

568
00:28:03.040 --> 00:28:05.110
it looks exactly like it did in that PDF.

569
00:28:05.110 --> 00:28:08.790
When we're done with that
we just say Package and

570
00:28:08.790 --> 00:28:11.020
it's going to give you a little
warning from the font police.

571
00:28:11.020 --> 00:28:12.230
You may read it if you want.

572
00:28:12.230 --> 00:28:12.810
It's really long,

573
00:28:12.810 --> 00:28:15.230
it basically says, you probably don't
have permission to send that font.

574
00:28:15.230 --> 00:28:18.320
Just say, OK, do with it what you will.

575
00:28:18.320 --> 00:28:21.350
I'm gonna jump out and
jump out to the desktop.

576
00:28:21.350 --> 00:28:24.290
Let's see how long that actually takes,
we may just jump out.

577
00:28:24.290 --> 00:28:26.460
I'm gonna have a folder that's here,
it's still working so

578
00:28:26.460 --> 00:28:29.240
I'm not gonna click on anything inside
cuz it's still doing its thing.

579
00:28:29.240 --> 00:28:31.510
But I can see that
there's my InDesign file.

580
00:28:31.510 --> 00:28:34.310
I did not click the IDML file,
you would see that in there as well.

581
00:28:34.310 --> 00:28:37.710
There's the PDF I said to send,
here's the Instructions text.

582
00:28:37.710 --> 00:28:40.170
Let me jump back to InDesign and
make sure we're actually actually done.

583
00:28:40.170 --> 00:28:42.040
I don't wanna click on anything.

584
00:28:42.040 --> 00:28:46.380
All right, so I come over here and I also
have my Links, there's all the Images that

585
00:28:46.380 --> 00:28:49.980
were inside that Document
nicely linked to this folder.

586
00:28:49.980 --> 00:28:51.500
Here's the Instruction file.

587
00:28:51.500 --> 00:28:56.400
So I look at that I can see all the files
that we used when we printed it and

588
00:28:56.400 --> 00:28:59.800
also the document fonts that
I used inside that document.

589
00:28:59.800 --> 00:29:04.300
So when I send this I can go ahead and zip
that up and put it into a nice compressed

590
00:29:04.300 --> 00:29:09.250
little package and send that off to the
printer to use and they can open it up and

591
00:29:09.250 --> 00:29:12.690
they've got everything they need
to output that file from InDesign.

592
00:29:12.690 --> 00:29:15.640
>> Erica, lot of great information
on pre-flighted packaging.

593
00:29:15.640 --> 00:29:16.930
We thank you for the wealth of knowledge.

594
00:29:16.930 --> 00:29:18.710
It just look like we're coming to
the end of another episode but

595
00:29:18.710 --> 00:29:22.580
before before we do, do you have any
additional advice you would like to say?

596
00:29:22.580 --> 00:29:25.630
>> Just make sure you have everything
you need when you send it off to print.

597
00:29:25.630 --> 00:29:28.310
>> Alright, we appreciate you being
here with us, and we appreciate you,

598
00:29:28.310 --> 00:29:29.050
the viewer, watching.

599
00:29:29.050 --> 00:29:30.110
Signing out for ITPro.TV.

600
00:29:30.110 --> 00:29:31.820
I've been your host, Wes Bryan.

601
00:29:31.820 --> 00:29:33.210
>> And I'm Erica Gamut.

602
00:29:33.210 --> 00:29:34.058
>> And we'll see you next time.

603
00:29:34.058 --> 00:29:39.450
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Erica explain the last step on a project called exporting within Adobe InDesign. They discuss exporting to PDF and JPEG, as well as compression topics such as bicubic downsampling, automatic exporting and compression of text and line art.
episodes.title: Exporting
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:11.609 --> 00:00:14.383
Welcome back to another exciting
episode here at ITPro.TV.

3
00:00:14.383 --> 00:00:15.940
I'm your host, Wes Bryan, and

4
00:00:15.940 --> 00:00:20.235
in today's episode we're coming back at
you with more Adobe Creative Cloud 2015.

5
00:00:20.235 --> 00:00:22.971
That's right, diving back into InDesign.

6
00:00:22.971 --> 00:00:25.496
And joining me in the studios today
is Erica Gamet, Erica how you doing?

7
00:00:25.496 --> 00:00:26.294
>> Fantastic.

8
00:00:26.294 --> 00:00:30.510
>> All right, so we have been going
through a long journey within InDesign,

9
00:00:30.510 --> 00:00:31.811
what is our next stop?

10
00:00:31.811 --> 00:00:32.856
>> We're going to export.

11
00:00:32.856 --> 00:00:33.882
>> All right, very good.

12
00:00:33.882 --> 00:00:37.205
>> So we're gonna export to
a couple different file formats,

13
00:00:37.205 --> 00:00:40.071
the biggest most major one
being exporting to PDF.

14
00:00:40.071 --> 00:00:43.433
And we've actually got two flavors
of PDF that we're gonna export to,

15
00:00:43.433 --> 00:00:46.810
then we're gonna export to a couple
other file format options as well.

16
00:00:46.810 --> 00:00:49.890
But they all start in the same place,
back in our InDesign file.

17
00:00:49.890 --> 00:00:52.250
And we actually have this page laid out,
this cover.

18
00:00:52.250 --> 00:00:54.600
And we're gonna go ahead and export it.

19
00:00:54.600 --> 00:00:58.270
So the first thing we wanna do
is get to the Export dialog box.

20
00:00:58.270 --> 00:01:01.290
So we can either do a Cmd or
Ctrl+E for export.

21
00:01:01.290 --> 00:01:03.750
And we can go up to the File menu,
and choose Export.

22
00:01:05.250 --> 00:01:08.017
And then we decide where we
wanna export that to first,

23
00:01:08.017 --> 00:01:11.701
before we tell what we're exporting as or
putting in any of our options.

24
00:01:11.701 --> 00:01:15.441
So I'm just gonna go ahead and
hit Cmd or Ctrl+D to jump to my desktop.

25
00:01:15.441 --> 00:01:17.532
And I'm gonna choose the format down here,
and

26
00:01:17.532 --> 00:01:19.580
we've got several
different to choose from.

27
00:01:19.580 --> 00:01:22.327
We're only gonna talk about a few,
and like I said,

28
00:01:22.327 --> 00:01:24.581
the first one being Adobe PDF, and Print.

29
00:01:24.581 --> 00:01:25.850
It's just Print in there.

30
00:01:25.850 --> 00:01:27.450
We've got two different flavors of PDF.

31
00:01:27.450 --> 00:01:29.710
We've got Print and Interactive, so

32
00:01:29.710 --> 00:01:32.570
we're gonna start with the print one
because we're gonna lead off from

33
00:01:32.570 --> 00:01:35.300
a previous episode, where were
talking about printing and exporting.

34
00:01:35.300 --> 00:01:39.100
So we're gonna do the same sort of
thing where we were printing it to our

35
00:01:39.100 --> 00:01:40.160
inkjet printer or

36
00:01:40.160 --> 00:01:43.775
we were packaging it up to send to
a printer to print from our InDesign file.

37
00:01:43.775 --> 00:01:48.676
But where you're probably going to
send files to a print shop to be

38
00:01:48.676 --> 00:01:50.350
output is to a PDF.

39
00:01:50.350 --> 00:01:52.860
Now you may also do a PDF
as your final piece.

40
00:01:52.860 --> 00:01:56.340
It might be something that's
going to be read on a tablet or

41
00:01:56.340 --> 00:01:59.120
even on a desktop, in a browser.

42
00:01:59.120 --> 00:02:03.290
It might be something that you put up
on your website, a PDF is ubiquitous.

43
00:02:03.290 --> 00:02:07.080
It's everywhere and
it's a portable document format.

44
00:02:07.080 --> 00:02:08.210
That's what it stands for

45
00:02:08.210 --> 00:02:12.080
and the whole thing is that we have
everything that we need inside this PDF.

46
00:02:12.080 --> 00:02:14.990
We don't need external links,
we don't need external text,

47
00:02:14.990 --> 00:02:16.400
we don't need anything else.

48
00:02:16.400 --> 00:02:19.960
It's all in this little
portable job file format.

49
00:02:19.960 --> 00:02:22.580
And it has like I said,
everything we need, and

50
00:02:22.580 --> 00:02:26.915
it looks like we expect it to look,
if we do our magic correctly.

51
00:02:26.915 --> 00:02:31.025
So we're gonna go ahead and
say Adobe PDF Print as our file format.

52
00:02:31.025 --> 00:02:33.334
It gives us the PDF extension of course.

53
00:02:33.334 --> 00:02:36.270
Even if you're doing an interactive PDF,
it still gives you that PDF.

54
00:02:36.270 --> 00:02:39.800
It's just we have different options
to put in in this dialog box.

55
00:02:39.800 --> 00:02:43.914
So I'm gonna click Save, and I get a lot
of options that look very familiar to

56
00:02:43.914 --> 00:02:45.730
the print dialogue box options.

57
00:02:45.730 --> 00:02:49.115
So some of those we're gonna skip over,
because they're pretty much the same, and

58
00:02:49.115 --> 00:02:51.390
I'll indicate which ones those are.

59
00:02:51.390 --> 00:02:54.149
Like a lot of the other
dialog boxes in InDesign,

60
00:02:54.149 --> 00:02:56.244
one of our first choices is a Preset.

61
00:02:56.244 --> 00:02:59.976
So this is something we've seen through
all the episodes that after we put in

62
00:02:59.976 --> 00:03:02.030
a lot of this information in a dialog box.

63
00:03:02.030 --> 00:03:05.796
Whether it's a new document or
printing or PDF, we can save that so

64
00:03:05.796 --> 00:03:09.810
we don't have to put in all this
information over and over again.

65
00:03:09.810 --> 00:03:13.690
We have consistency and
we have a streamlined workflow as well.

66
00:03:13.690 --> 00:03:15.480
So we'll come back to
that at the very end,

67
00:03:15.480 --> 00:03:18.720
when we actually put in the information,
and save the present.

68
00:03:18.720 --> 00:03:23.490
Next time we come, we can just choose from
our long list of presets that are here.

69
00:03:23.490 --> 00:03:27.996
So the first thing when we're exporting to
a PDF, it ask us if we have a standard.

70
00:03:27.996 --> 00:03:31.147
Now there are a couple of PDF standards,
and the reason for

71
00:03:31.147 --> 00:03:35.197
this is that if you have a workflow that
everything has to fit the standard or

72
00:03:35.197 --> 00:03:39.721
the printer has one you need to make sure
that you're fitting one of this standard.

73
00:03:39.721 --> 00:03:43.082
The other thing is by having a standard
you don't have to chose a lot

74
00:03:43.082 --> 00:03:45.555
of the options they're all ready there for
you.

75
00:03:45.555 --> 00:03:50.940
And if you're sending let's say to a
printer nad use say the PDF/X-1a standard.

76
00:03:50.940 --> 00:03:53.660
And that's just a printing standard
that's been around for a long time.

77
00:03:53.660 --> 00:03:56.061
You can use one of the newer
ones which is the 2003.

78
00:03:56.061 --> 00:03:58.469
I still pretty much use the 2001,

79
00:03:58.469 --> 00:04:02.090
it basically lets them know
they can just check that PDF.

80
00:04:02.090 --> 00:04:04.580
They don't have to open it and
look at all the images, and

81
00:04:04.580 --> 00:04:06.030
all the text and everything.

82
00:04:06.030 --> 00:04:08.840
They know that if you've told
them it's a PDF/X-1a, and

83
00:04:08.840 --> 00:04:12.280
we've done everything here in the standard
still gets tagged as a standard.

84
00:04:12.280 --> 00:04:16.475
They can just use a piece of software to
look at the PDF that you've given them,

85
00:04:16.475 --> 00:04:18.586
and it says yes, it's a PDF/X-1a.

86
00:04:18.586 --> 00:04:19.926
They know that's print ready.

87
00:04:19.926 --> 00:04:22.332
That's ready to be printed
on an offset printer.

88
00:04:22.332 --> 00:04:24.407
And they can just take that and
send it back to the press.

89
00:04:24.407 --> 00:04:29.060
You might chop two days off your
production time by doing that as well.

90
00:04:29.060 --> 00:04:32.430
Now for me, I don't generally choose
the standard from the pull down menu.

91
00:04:32.430 --> 00:04:36.480
I choose one of the PDF presets that's
here by default when you get InDesign.

92
00:04:36.480 --> 00:04:40.490
So the ones that are in brackets are the
ones that came with the application.

93
00:04:40.490 --> 00:04:44.810
So I'm gonna choose PDF/X-1a
as my standard to start with.

94
00:04:44.810 --> 00:04:47.800
When I do that,
the standard item changes here.

95
00:04:47.800 --> 00:04:48.950
What I want to make sure is,

96
00:04:48.950 --> 00:04:53.600
if I know that my PDF/X-1a is the standard
I want, there are a few things I

97
00:04:53.600 --> 00:04:57.890
can change without making it fall
outside that standard perimeter.

98
00:04:57.890 --> 00:05:00.770
I wanna make sure that this
never ends up saying None.

99
00:05:00.770 --> 00:05:03.730
If it says None, it means I changed
something I wasn't supposed to, and

100
00:05:03.730 --> 00:05:05.590
it now no longer fits that standard.

101
00:05:05.590 --> 00:05:08.090
So we'll start with that, we may
actually change that as we go along with

102
00:05:08.090 --> 00:05:11.400
the different options we
have in this dialog box.

103
00:05:11.400 --> 00:05:16.050
Also Compatibility, so the Compatibility
changed when I choose the PDF/X-1a.

104
00:05:16.050 --> 00:05:21.320
And it changed to Acrobat 4 which is
really old, because they had version 11,

105
00:05:21.320 --> 00:05:25.280
and now they're on Acrobat DC,
so document cloud.

106
00:05:25.280 --> 00:05:27.090
So that actually changed,
the numbering changed.

107
00:05:27.090 --> 00:05:29.670
But so they're basically
theoretically on version 12,

108
00:05:29.670 --> 00:05:31.840
so version 4 sounds really old.

109
00:05:31.840 --> 00:05:35.270
So what does version 4,
why do we have that as that standard?

110
00:05:35.270 --> 00:05:37.976
Well you can see the standard
is kinda of old it's 2001.

111
00:05:37.976 --> 00:05:41.610
And so that been a while but
what that does is it basically,

112
00:05:41.610 --> 00:05:44.511
the first thing it does
is it flattens it down.

113
00:05:44.511 --> 00:05:48.764
So that all that transparency that we
looked when working in drop shadow and

114
00:05:48.764 --> 00:05:50.732
effects and other transparency.

115
00:05:50.732 --> 00:05:54.160
And we looked at transparency
issues in a previous episode.

116
00:05:54.160 --> 00:05:58.000
This says,
I want to flatten that right now.

117
00:05:58.000 --> 00:06:02.076
So one of the issues that we might
have with transparency is if we send

118
00:06:02.076 --> 00:06:04.951
the transparency still
as live transparency.

119
00:06:04.951 --> 00:06:08.861
So that would be above acrobat version 4,
anything higher than that still has

120
00:06:08.861 --> 00:06:12.250
transparency in it and
at some point that has to be flattened.

121
00:06:12.250 --> 00:06:15.167
While I'm letting them flatten it maybe
they're gonna flatten it on their

122
00:06:15.167 --> 00:06:15.731
rip machine.

123
00:06:15.731 --> 00:06:19.506
The Raster image processor
machine that they use to send,

124
00:06:19.506 --> 00:06:23.370
to play to negatives,
whatever they need to to print that.

125
00:06:23.370 --> 00:06:25.040
And then I don't know
what their software is.

126
00:06:25.040 --> 00:06:28.260
Their software might be old then it might
say that's a beautiful drop shadow,

127
00:06:28.260 --> 00:06:31.250
here's your solid box cuz
that's what happens a lot.

128
00:06:31.250 --> 00:06:35.639
But if I do it here, I know that when I
see the resulting PDF, if it looks like

129
00:06:35.639 --> 00:06:40.268
a nice soft drop shadow, that's exactly
what I'm gonna get on the other end.

130
00:06:40.268 --> 00:06:44.386
Because the transparency has been
flattened by the engine built in to

131
00:06:44.386 --> 00:06:45.240
InDesign.

132
00:06:45.240 --> 00:06:48.068
So for me, that's almost always what I do.

133
00:06:48.068 --> 00:06:51.900
There may be a reason that I wanna send it
with transparency in tact to someone else.

134
00:06:51.900 --> 00:06:53.919
It might be that I've
worked with them before,

135
00:06:53.919 --> 00:06:56.856
I know their equipment can handle it,
but for the most part I do this.

136
00:06:56.856 --> 00:06:59.850
I also do this if I don't
know who's printing it.

137
00:06:59.850 --> 00:07:02.230
I do a lot of ads for
a ski resort company and

138
00:07:02.230 --> 00:07:04.681
it goes to magazines all over the country.

139
00:07:04.681 --> 00:07:07.220
And I don't know who's
actually printing it,

140
00:07:07.220 --> 00:07:10.760
so this is a great,
I call it the lowest common denominator.

141
00:07:10.760 --> 00:07:13.450
I can send it out there and
I know that it's going to be flattened and

142
00:07:13.450 --> 00:07:16.900
it's also going to be in CMYK already.

143
00:07:16.900 --> 00:07:20.814
So even if I have those RGB images that
have been in my document that I like.

144
00:07:20.814 --> 00:07:23.736
I know that when I save it as a PDF/X-1a,

145
00:07:23.736 --> 00:07:27.396
it's going to convert those
images from RGB to CMYK.

146
00:07:27.396 --> 00:07:30.496
And I know that that's already
built into that standard so

147
00:07:30.496 --> 00:07:31.959
it is a printing standard.

148
00:07:31.959 --> 00:07:33.369
If you are going to export this, and

149
00:07:33.369 --> 00:07:35.630
it's going to be something we
are gonna read on tablets.

150
00:07:35.630 --> 00:07:36.930
We are probably not going to use that.

151
00:07:36.930 --> 00:07:41.540
We can absolutely keep it unflattened
because it is gonna be right on a device.

152
00:07:41.540 --> 00:07:42.767
We don't need to worry about it.

153
00:07:42.767 --> 00:07:46.992
If I think that people might download
it or print it to their inkjet printer,

154
00:07:46.992 --> 00:07:48.719
their $29 inkjet printer.

155
00:07:48.719 --> 00:07:53.096
I might wanna flatten it because I don't
wannna assume that they can take that PDF.

156
00:07:53.096 --> 00:07:55.204
And either their computer's
flattening it or

157
00:07:55.204 --> 00:07:58.420
the software in their printer is
actually trying to flatten it.

158
00:07:58.420 --> 00:08:01.480
So I might think, that looked beautiful,
and then everybody distributes it and

159
00:08:01.480 --> 00:08:03.733
thinks, that was the ugliest
newsletter I've ever seen.

160
00:08:03.733 --> 00:08:05.774
Because it doesn't have
those great drop-shadows or

161
00:08:05.774 --> 00:08:07.335
whatever transparency that I've used.

162
00:08:07.335 --> 00:08:11.008
So, it's just the way to control it, and
know that when I get the PDF out of this,

163
00:08:11.008 --> 00:08:14.170
I can already look and see if I
have any issues with transparency.

164
00:08:14.170 --> 00:08:16.030
That's the big one for that.

165
00:08:16.030 --> 00:08:19.545
Also, If you tell a printer,
you say, can you take a PDFX1A?

166
00:08:19.545 --> 00:08:22.300
They're gonna be mighty impressed
that you know what a PDF X1A is,

167
00:08:22.300 --> 00:08:25.140
and they're gonna say yes, because,
like I said, that's a printing standard.

168
00:08:25.140 --> 00:08:29.630
And it gives you a description
here of the preset that you use.

169
00:08:29.630 --> 00:08:31.160
I rarely ever read that.

170
00:08:31.160 --> 00:08:33.770
It's a lot of information that
doesn't really pertain to me,

171
00:08:33.770 --> 00:08:35.480
just learn the ones that we need for
the preset.

172
00:08:35.480 --> 00:08:36.630
Down here,

173
00:08:36.630 --> 00:08:39.860
we've got a lot of things that look
exactly the same as the print dialog box.

174
00:08:39.860 --> 00:08:41.360
So we've got what pages do we want.

175
00:08:41.360 --> 00:08:45.260
What range do we want to print, and
spreads, and also the layout view.

176
00:08:45.260 --> 00:08:50.970
So we can actually choose how we want
the PDF to be viewed when they open it.

177
00:08:50.970 --> 00:08:51.970
So I can do single page.

178
00:08:51.970 --> 00:08:55.910
Now I'm doing single page PDF, so
if I've done an eight page document,

179
00:08:55.910 --> 00:08:57.560
it's gonna be eight single pages.

180
00:08:57.560 --> 00:09:01.040
But I can tell it to do Single Page
Continuous, which means as you scroll,

181
00:09:01.040 --> 00:09:04.860
it can scroll through the half page, or
I can tell a single page which means that

182
00:09:04.860 --> 00:09:08.310
as they hit the up and down arrow key,
a whole page comes into focus.

183
00:09:08.310 --> 00:09:12.420
Now the thing is a lot of this stuff,
I leave it on default, because the people

184
00:09:12.420 --> 00:09:15.610
on the other, end your reader, they
actually have their preferences set up,

185
00:09:15.610 --> 00:09:17.740
which override a lot of
what you put in here.

186
00:09:17.740 --> 00:09:19.270
I generally don't worry about that.

187
00:09:19.270 --> 00:09:21.450
I can force them to open
in full screen mode,

188
00:09:21.450 --> 00:09:23.510
that will actually
override what they've set.

189
00:09:23.510 --> 00:09:24.848
That can be scary to some people.

190
00:09:24.848 --> 00:09:27.662
If they double click on a PDF, and
suddenly it takes over their whole screen,

191
00:09:27.662 --> 00:09:30.041
and they don't know how to escape
out of that full screen mode, so

192
00:09:30.041 --> 00:09:31.530
I tend to not do that either.

193
00:09:31.530 --> 00:09:32.980
Now, depends who's reading this,

194
00:09:32.980 --> 00:09:36.210
if you know your sending this
internally to all your sales reps.

195
00:09:36.210 --> 00:09:39.240
You can set it up because you wanted
them to have the same experience

196
00:09:39.240 --> 00:09:40.430
across the board.

197
00:09:40.430 --> 00:09:42.680
And when we're working with digital files,
if they're for

198
00:09:42.680 --> 00:09:46.140
digital consumption,
you have to realize that there's so

199
00:09:46.140 --> 00:09:49.750
many different flavors of PDF readers out
there, and that everybody's experience

200
00:09:49.750 --> 00:09:52.790
will be different based on
the preferences they have set.

201
00:09:52.790 --> 00:09:56.010
If you're going to print,
this is for print, then I'm

202
00:09:56.010 --> 00:09:59.220
not gonna worry about any of this because
they're just gonna open it, print it.

203
00:09:59.220 --> 00:10:01.140
They're not even gonna worry
about viewing it on the screen.

204
00:10:02.160 --> 00:10:05.490
I can embed page thumbnails if
I want just as so that when

205
00:10:05.490 --> 00:10:09.030
the person is looking at it in their PDF
reader, we have thumbnails down the side,

206
00:10:09.030 --> 00:10:12.060
so they can visually see what
each of the pagees look like.

207
00:10:12.060 --> 00:10:12.650
Optimized for

208
00:10:12.650 --> 00:10:16.780
fast web view, this is something I
rarely ever use if I'm doing this for

209
00:10:16.780 --> 00:10:20.478
output, because obviously I don't care
if it's fast web view, it's a print PDF.

210
00:10:21.490 --> 00:10:24.930
I can also choose to
View PDF After Exporting, so

211
00:10:24.930 --> 00:10:27.560
once I make it here in InDesign it
automatically will launch whatever

212
00:10:27.560 --> 00:10:30.655
I use as my PDF viewer so
I can see it automatically.

213
00:10:30.655 --> 00:10:31.960
You can turn that on or
off, that's just for

214
00:10:31.960 --> 00:10:36.090
yourself, it has nothing to do with
the PDF, the PDF content itself.

215
00:10:36.090 --> 00:10:39.650
And you can create a tagged PDF if
you've done shortcuts or rollovers for

216
00:10:39.650 --> 00:10:40.950
the visually impaired.

217
00:10:40.950 --> 00:10:42.890
You can go ahead and
say create tagged PDF so

218
00:10:42.890 --> 00:10:46.185
that those actually show up in the PDF
when they have the reader turned on.

219
00:10:46.185 --> 00:10:47.475
If they roll over something it will

220
00:10:47.475 --> 00:10:49.245
give the description of
the image that you have.

221
00:10:49.245 --> 00:10:52.395
If you've built that image into your
document, you need to go ahead and

222
00:10:52.395 --> 00:10:55.005
tell it to save that
tagged information there.

223
00:10:55.005 --> 00:10:58.140
Layers, same as the print Print dialogue
box, do we want visible printable?

224
00:10:58.140 --> 00:11:00.410
Do we want all of them or
just the visible layers?

225
00:11:01.700 --> 00:11:04.030
We have a couple options
that are not available here.

226
00:11:04.030 --> 00:11:07.540
These are not available in a PDF X1A,
cuz we're going to Acrobat 4,

227
00:11:07.540 --> 00:11:10.700
certain things that we don't have,
create Acrobat layers.

228
00:11:10.700 --> 00:11:14.230
If we go to version five and
up, sorry six and up,

229
00:11:14.230 --> 00:11:18.480
let go to six once I get six
I can create acrobat layers.

230
00:11:18.480 --> 00:11:21.710
So as I changed it to five or
six though my standards went away.

231
00:11:21.710 --> 00:11:22.990
So that not gonna be good for

232
00:11:22.990 --> 00:11:26.370
PDF X1A does seem modified now
cuz I made some changes this.

233
00:11:26.370 --> 00:11:30.126
Let's put this back to Acrobat 4, and,
actually, now it got rid of everything.

234
00:11:30.126 --> 00:11:33.740
I have to actually go back and tell it
PDFX1A, let's put it back where we had it,

235
00:11:33.740 --> 00:11:37.280
and I can choose to print
the non-printing objects if I want.

236
00:11:37.280 --> 00:11:40.960
And this is gonna keep popping up for
you if you have not tried Publish online.

237
00:11:40.960 --> 00:11:43.680
The first time that you try it,
it will go away.

238
00:11:43.680 --> 00:11:46.440
It just wants you to try their
new service and publish online.

239
00:11:46.440 --> 00:11:48.310
So you feel free to
check that if you want.

240
00:11:48.310 --> 00:11:50.310
Just ignore it if not.

241
00:11:50.310 --> 00:11:53.060
This is where the real
magic happens with a PDF.

242
00:11:53.060 --> 00:11:57.230
The whole point of a PDF, like I said,
is to get it as portable as possible,

243
00:11:57.230 --> 00:12:01.600
as small as possible, and as optimized as
possible with as much information that you

244
00:12:01.600 --> 00:12:05.450
need to deliver the experience you
hoped to with your finished piece.

245
00:12:05.450 --> 00:12:07.810
And compression is where that happens.

246
00:12:07.810 --> 00:12:10.476
There is no resolution for a PDF.

247
00:12:10.476 --> 00:12:14.508
If someone asks you what resolution your
PDF is, they don't know what they're

248
00:12:14.508 --> 00:12:18.310
talking about, cuz there is no actual
overall resolution of the PDF.

249
00:12:18.310 --> 00:12:22.200
There is resolution for each of
the individual elements in your PDF,

250
00:12:22.200 --> 00:12:24.160
and this is where you control it.

251
00:12:24.160 --> 00:12:27.160
So, for instance, we placed a lot of
images, we made sure they released 300,

252
00:12:27.160 --> 00:12:30.850
we had live preflight on or
we checked the links panel, and

253
00:12:30.850 --> 00:12:32.260
make sure there were at least 300 PPI.

254
00:12:32.260 --> 00:12:37.515
But here we can tell it, actually, only
send them as 200 ppi, if we wanted to.

255
00:12:37.515 --> 00:12:39.284
Right, so we have it set maybe for print.

256
00:12:39.284 --> 00:12:41.050
We do a print one at 300.

257
00:12:41.050 --> 00:12:44.284
Then we're gonna do another one at 150,
just a low resolution for

258
00:12:44.284 --> 00:12:46.320
viewing on a phone or something like that.

259
00:12:46.320 --> 00:12:47.940
So I can choose that here.

260
00:12:47.940 --> 00:12:52.500
So, there's a lot of things to choose,
but here's the good thing.

261
00:12:52.500 --> 00:12:55.332
Whatever the defaults are, make sure you
remember what those are and keep those,

262
00:12:55.332 --> 00:12:57.398
and I'll show you what they are,
they're the ones I have.

263
00:12:57.398 --> 00:12:59.100
Bicubic downsampling.

264
00:12:59.100 --> 00:13:01.300
So there's a lot of choices
to choose from here.

265
00:13:01.300 --> 00:13:05.430
This basically says, Do Not Downsample,
